HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

Opera

"ADRIANA LECOUVREUR." After "Tosca," it's the most famous opera about a diva. A century after the premiere of this enduring work by Francesco Cilea, Eve Queler and the Opera Orchestra of New York move from bel canto to verismo with the second in their season of three concert operas. Ms. Queler has a strong cast this time around: the role of Maurizio, first sung by Caruso, is taken by Marcello Giordani; the indomitable Dolora Zajick is the Princess, while Aprile Millo is the "humble handmaid" of art, Adriana herself, a role traditionally taken by the grandes dames of opera. Sunday night at 8, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $23 to $100 (Anne Midgette).

"DOCTOR FAUSTUS LIGHTS THE LIGHTS." Many of Gertrude Stein's writings are better known by their titles than by their contents, but her 1938 "Faustus" play has actually had a number of productions, both here and in Europe. Now Stanley Walden, a composer, has turned the piece into a new jazz opera, which will be given a workshop production this weekend by the Center for Contemporary Opera. Like Stein, Mr. Walden has a foot in both the United States and Europe; he has spent a number of years in Berlin, introducing American musical theater to German conservatory students, although in New York he may be better known for his work on "Oh! Calcutta!" Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, the Neighborhood Playhouse, 340 East 54th Street, Manhattan, (212) 758-2757. Tickets: $25 (Midgette).

"L'ELISIR D'AMORE." Still basking in the afterglow of PBS's warm and fuzzy documentary about its octogenarian founders, the Amato Opera has mounted a new production of Donizetti's radiant comedy about requited love brought to fruition thanks to -- or in spite of -- a lovable traveling quack. The indefatigable Anthony Amato conducts, and Richard Cerullo, the company's resident designer, has produced period sets and costumes, including a paddle-wheel steamer to bring in Dulcamara (which, in Amato's tiny theater, should be quite a sight). Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30; Sunday afternoon at 2:30 p.m. Amato Opera, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 228-8200. Tickets: $28; $23 for students, 65+ and children under 12 (Midgette).

"PORGY AND BESS." George Gershwin's great tribute to black American music returns to the New York City Opera this weekend, with previews tonight and tomorrow and a formal opening on Sunday afternoon. The performances begin the company's spring season. Tazewell Thompson directs. The sets by Douglas W. Schmidt are taken from a production originating at Radio City Music Hall in 1983. John DeMain conducts tonight, with Marquite Lister as Bess, Alvy Powell as Porgy, Angela Renee Simpson as Serena, Timothy Robert Blevins as Crown and Dwayne Clark as Sportin' Life. The matinee tomorrow is conducted by Richard Bado, with Alison Buchanan as Bess, James Edward Pierce as Porgy, Rochelle Ellis as Serena, Cedric Cannon as Crown and Robert Mack as Sportin' Life. Tomorrow night Mr. DeMain conducts again, with Marsha Thompson as Bess, Leonard Rowe as Porgy, Monique McDonald as Serena, Mr. Blevins as Crown and Mr. Clark as Sportin' Life. The opening on Sunday afternoon will have the same cast as tonight. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 1:30 p.m. New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 307-4100. Tickets: $25 to $98 tonight; $30 to $105 tomorrow and Sunday; very few tickets remain on Sunday (Bernard Holland).

"RIGOLETTO." The soprano Ruth Ann Swenson's vocally lustrous portrayal of Gilda is the reason to see the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Verdi's "Rigoletto" in Otto Schenk's grimly effective 1989 production. In the title role, the baritone Juan Pons sings with intensity but with too much huffing and forcing of his voice. Though the tenor Marcelo Alvarez, as the Duke, has an essentially attractive voice and some zinging high notes, his singing is uneven and his legato sometimes rough. Denyce Graves provides some glamour in the small role of Maddalena. Marco Guidarini, in his company debut, gets a passably good but uninspired performance from the Met orchestra. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $30 to $190 (Anthony Tommasini).

"TOSCA." "Vissi d'arte," "I lived for art," sings Floria Tosca in this Puccini opera. Franco Zeffirelli's production at the Metropolitan Opera has been living for art since; its true-to-life replicas of the opera's venerable Roman settings evoke the originals more with every year. Now yet another cast has come in to occupy this familiar territory: Georgina Lukacs as the diva, Richard Leech as Cavaradossi, Carlo Guelfi as Scarpia, and the eminent Julius Rudel in the pit. Taken together, these four should make for a lot of loud if blunt music-making, which, depending on your tastes, could either bring across a resounding reading of the opera or provide a fitting rendering of what Joseph Kerman, the musicologist, famously dubbed a "shabby little shocker." Tomorrow night at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: sold out, but returns may be available before the performance (Midgette).

"WAR AND PEACE," Prokofiev's epic four-hour operatic adaptation of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" has finally come to the Metropolitan Opera in a co-production with the Kirov Opera in St. Petersburg. The project was spearheaded by the conductor Valery Gergiev, whose belief in this work comes through at every moment in this engrossing performance. The production by Andrei Konchalovsky offers some alluring silhouetted images and striking stage effects, like the burning-of-Moscow scene. But the set is dominated by a clunky rotating dome that slopes straight down into the orchestra pit, and it's unsettling to watch the singers negotiate the stage. The huge cast is splendid, especially Dmitri Hvorostovsky as Prince Andrei, Anna Netrebko as Natasha, Gegam Grigorian as Count Bezukhov and Samuel Ramey as Field Marshal Kutuzov. Saturday at 12:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: Sold out, but returns may be available before the performance (Tommasini).

Classical Music

ACADEMY OF ANCIENT MUSIC. Bearing one of the oldest names in the early-music field, and one of the most reliable, the Academy is conducted by its founder, Christopher Hogwood, in two Mozart piano concertos -- the C minor and the C major (K. 467) -- together with the D major Rondo (K. 382), all with Robert Levin playing the solos and extemporizing cadenzas. As if that were not enough, Mr. Levin also promises to improvise "in Mozart's style" on themes submitted by the audience. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Tickets: $14 to $54 (Paul Griffiths).

BARGEMUSIC. This excellent series has had a rough season with, first, the terrorist attacks just across the way in Lower Manhattan and now a period of administrative upheaval, centering on a raise in musicians' pay. (And note the rise in ticket prices.) Still, with its view of the Manhattan skyline and its live, intimate acoustics, this remains one of the finest places in the city to hear chamber music. The concerts here were planned by the cellist Ronald Thomas, who is to be joined tonight by Randall Hodgkinson, a pianist, and Ida Levin, a violinist, in works by Beethoven, Dvorak and Roger Sessions. Tomorrow and on Sunday those performers are to be joined by Marcus Thompson, a violist, in works by Mozart, Faure and Ravel. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday at 4 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing, under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083. Tickets: $35; $20 for students (James R. Oestreich).

BOSTON PHILHARMONIC. Benjamin Zander and this student orchestra have developed a cult following in Boston (with "60 Minutes" in tow) through performances of Beethoven and Mahler that some find revelatory. In a recent wave of recordings, most with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London, which is professional and then some, Mr. Zander's interpretations have tended to sound perverse in their zeal to make often dubious points. Tomorrow, at any rate, is an opportunity for cooler heads to judge the matter in Mahler's Ninth Symphony. The students, typically rehearsed to the teeth, will undoubtedly play beautifully. (Mr. Zander and the orchestra are to follow with a free concert and pep rally on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall, with audience participation.) Tomorrow night at 8, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $21 to $82 (Oestreich).

COLLEGIATE CHORALE. This venerable choir, directed by Robert Bass, is celebrating its 60th anniversary this season. With the Orchestra of St. Luke's on hand for support, Mr. Bass is leading his singers tonight in a hefty if oddly balanced program: Haydn's celebratory "Te Deum" and Mozart's sublime "Ave Verum Corpus" are to open the concert, and then the focus will shift to the world of opera. The soprano Kathleen Battle is to sing arias by Bellini and Rossini, and the choir will sing excerpts from Boito's "Mefistofele" and the "Va, pensiero" chorus from Verdi's "Nabucco." Ms. Battle then returns to sing a hefty selection of spirituals. Tonight at 8, Carnegie Hall, (917) 322-2140. Tickets: $15 to $75 (Allan Kozinn).

MANHATTAN SCHOOL OF MUSIC SYMPHONY. Gunther Schuller, who published a provocative book on conducting a few years ago, has the chance to demonstrate his ideas tonight when he conducts the Manhattan School students in Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony. The program also includes Lutoslawski's poetic Piano Concerto, with Jessica Bruser as the soloist, and Mr. Schuller's own classic "Seven Klee Studies." Tonight at 8, Borden Auditorium, Manhattan School of Music, 122nd Street and Broadway, Morningside Heights, (212) 749-2802. Free. (Griffiths).

NEW AMSTERDAM SINGERS. Clara Longstreth, the music director of the impressive New Amsterdam Singers, has won well-earned praise for her imaginative programming, which she continues with the chorus's all-20th-century offering this weekend, called "Spiritual Journey," which will be performed tonight and Sunday afternoon. There will be works by, among others, Poulenc, Messiaen, Rautavaara, Farkas and the New York premieres of Adolphus Hailstork's "God of Glory" and Judith Shatin's "Songs of War and Peace," the latter a commemoration of Israel's 50th anniversary. Tonight at 8 and Sunday at 4 p.m., Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West, at 65th Street, (212) 568-5948. Tickets: $18 (Tommasini).

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Prokofiev's Second Piano Concerto is a work of beastly difficulties, and the young Russian firebrand Arcadi Volodos seems just the man to grapple with it. Leonard Slatkin conducts an attractive program, also including Bartok's Romanian Folk Dances and Witold Lutoslawski's Third Symphony, a two-movement work from 1983 that draws inspiration from Classical symphonies, notably those of Haydn. Today at 2 p.m., tomorrow and Monday at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: today, $19 to $68; tomorrow and Monday, $21 to $82 (Oestreich).

PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI. The centerpiece of this program is likely to be a performance of the Schumann Cello Concerto, with Carter Brey, the principal cellist of the New York Philharmonic. The program, to be conducted by Richard Kapp, the orchestra's founder and director, also includes Haydn's Symphony No. 100, Stravinsky's "Pulcinella" and Jose Bragato's "Graciela y Buenos Aires." Tomorrow night at 7, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 570-3949. Tickets: $30 (Kozinn).

POLYHYMNIA. Even those who know choral music by the 15th-century Dutch master Jacob Obrecht are unlikely to know everything here -- selections from several Masses, the ceremonial motet "Quis Numerare Queat" and a "Salve Regina" -- and will need no further encouragement to seek it out. Those who don't know Obrecht's music are in for a rare and delightful immersion. The program, "Of Flanders Fair," is the work of a small and presumably elite group, performing in its eighth season. Tomorrow night at 8, St. John's in the Village, 11th Street and Waverly Place, Greenwich Village, (917) 838-4636. Tickets: $15; $10 for students, 60+ and members of Early Music America (Oestreich).

"PUEBLO JOVEN." This oratorio by the tango master Astor Piazzolla and the poet Horacio Ferrer looks at the history of Argentina, with an eye to its economic and social landscapes. The work is to be performed by the Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra, with Katie Viquiera, a folk singer; Juan Villarreal narrating; and Pablo Zinger conducting. Filling out the program is a group of Piazzolla's instrumental works, including several New York premieres. They are to be performed by Triangulo, an ensemble in which Mr. Zinger is the pianist, with Marco Granados, flutist, and Gustavo Tavares, cellist. Sunday at 3 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824 or (212) 307-4100. Tickets: $30 to $35 (Kozinn).

BRYN TERFEL. The renowned bass-baritone Bryn Terfel, who has come to town to rehearse the Metropolitan Opera's much anticipated production of Verdi's "Falstaff," which opens later this month, will give his only New York recital of the season on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. There will be songs by Schubert, Duparc, Copland, Vaughan Williams and Roger Quilter and the premiere of a work by Jake Heggie, the composer of the opera "Dead Man Walking." Mr. Terfel's accompanist is the elegant pianist Malcolm Martineau. Sunday at 2 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $24 to $102 (Tommasini).

Dance

DONALD BYRD/THE GROUP. Mr. Byrd's gritty and energetic choreography is on display in a panorama of jazz dancing through the decades, a romp based on social dancing and a serious meditation on the state of art in America. Tonight at 7; Saturday at 2 and 7 p.m.; Sunday at 12 and 5 p.m. New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. Tickets: $10 to $30 (Jack Anderson).

CHAMECKI AND LERNER. Performing in the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Project's 92 and 42 Festival, the Brazilian modern-dance choreographers and dancers Rosane Chamecki and Andrea Lerner will present "Hidden Form," which chronicles a woman's attempts to confront her fears, and their 1997 "Antonio Caldo," a film and dance piece about the unpredictability of fate. Tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m. the Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 415-5552. Tickets: $20 (Jennifer Dunning).

COMPAGNIA ESPANOLA DE ANTONIO MARQUEZ. Mr. Marquez, who is from Seville, trained at and performed with the Ballet National de Espana and danced as a lead performer with Ballet Espanol de Madrid and Ballet Region de Murcia. He has received the Most Esteemed Professional Dancer award from the Spanish government. Tomorrow night at 8, the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, N.Y., (914) 251-6222. Tickets: $25 to $35 (Dunning).

CONSTRUCTION COMPANY: DANCE/MUSIC COLLABORATIONS. Three choreographers (Rajika Puri, Christopher Caines and Linda Seifert) will collaborate with three composers (Nora York, Anton Webern and Lois Dilivio). Tomorrow through Monday at 8 p.m., Construction Company, 10 East 18th Street, Flatiron District, (212) 924-7882. Tickets: $12; $10 for students and 65+. Sold out, but returns may be available at the box office (Dunning).

DANCE AT THE 92ND STREET Y. The Y offers two informal programs this weekend. Skip Costa, Regina Nejman and Netta Terushalmy will perform today at noon in a free showcase of new dances and works-in-progress. Molly Rabinowitz will preview a dance with gymnastics equipment on Sunday at 3 p.m. The 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5552. Tickets: $10 (Dunning).

PAULA HUNTER. Sounds as if Ms. Hunter is doing her usual madcap thing in "The Unexpected," seven linked episodes that pop up in a woman's mind after a car runs into her house. Tonight through Sunday night at 8, Dixon Place, 309 East 26th Street, Manhattan, (212) 532-1546. Tickets: $15 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted); $10 for students and 65+ (Dunning).

PAUL KAISER AND SHEELEY ESHKAR: "PEDESTRIAN." Miniature computer-generated pedestrians will interact with the real thing in three locations in New York City, through March 23. The outdoor sites are the Studio Museum in Harlem (144 West 125th Street) and 45 Rockefeller Plaza (51st Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas), where the free show goes on for 24 hours, seven days a week. The virtual street dodgers will also be seen at the Eyebeam Atelier in Chelsea (540 West 21st Street) in a free show that can be seen Wednesdays through Saturdays from noon to 6 p.m. (Dunning)

NANCY KARP AND DANCERS. Ms. Karp and her San Francisco-based modern-dance troupe, relatively unknown to New Yorkers, will perform excerpts from "Kalasam," inspired by a fascination with Indian dance and music that the choreographer shares with her composer and longtime collaborator Paul Dresher. Two other pieces will also be performed, set to music by Charles Amirkhanian and Bill Fontana. Tonight through Sunday night at 8, Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and 65+ (Dunning).

KENNEDY CENTER: JOFFREY BALLET OF CHICAGO. Washington is about as close as New Yorkers are likely to get to this former resident troupe, and the program is a nicely varied one. All three dances are classics: the company director Gerald Arpino's pretty, speedy "Kettantanz"; Agnes de Mille's "Rodeo"; and Antony Tudor's brooding "Lilac Garden." Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 p.m. Kennedy Center, Washington, (202) 467-4600; outside Washington, (800) 444-1324. Tickets: $26 to $65 (Dunning).

MOISEYEV DANCE COMPANY. The mighty Moiseyev of Moscow will present its usual bill of gliding, galloping folk dances and exuberant folk music from Russia, with a newer repertory from nine other nations, including Spain, Japan, China, Mexico and the United States. Tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 2 p.m. Lehman Concert Hall, Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, at Goulden Avenue, Bedford Park, the Bronx, (718) 960-8833. Tickets: $25 to $40 (Dunning).

NATIONAL DANCE THEATER COMPANY OF JAMAICA. Still going strong after 40 years, the troupe will perform classics and a New York premiere. Tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 2 p.m. Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Flatbush, (718) 951-4500. Tickets: $35 to $40 (Dunning).

NEW YORK BAROQUE DANCE COMPANY. The audience, which is invited but not required to wear costumes, will join the dancers in an 18th-century ball. The evening will also include excerpts from Gluck's "Orfeo," Rameau's "Zephyre" and a version by Carlos Fittante of Corelli's "Follia." Tonight through Sunday night (and March 7 through 10) at 8:30, Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. Tickets: $15 (Dunning).

PEYARI DANCE PROJECT. Jen MacQueen has choreographed musical theater, industrial shows and children's touring shows in addition to concert dance. In "Be," which is set to music by composers and performers including Scott Joplin, Janis Joplin, Metallica and Corky and the Juice Pigs, Ms. MacQueen and her modern-dance company tackle the need to achieve spiritual and emotional fulfillment and to help others achieve it. Tomorrow and Thursday at 7 p.m.; Sunday at 1 p.m.; Monday at 8:30 p.m.; Wednesday at 6 p.m. Raw Space, 529 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. Tickets: $15 (Dunning).

HENNING RUBSAM'S SENSEDANCE. The company's engagement as a whole is called "X," and because it features premieres as well as older works, that X can stand for the unknown. But it also stands for the troupe's celebration of its 10th anniversary, and guest dancers will add to the festivities. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 3 p.m. The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-1515. Tickets: $20, except for tonight, a benefit for Dancers Responding to AIDS, when tickets are $40 (Anderson).

PAUL TAYLOR DANCE COMPANY. One of modern dance's great choreographic eclectics gazes on human foibles, sometimes lovingly, sometimes with amusement and sometimes with alarm. His repertory, taken from five decades of choreographic creativity, includes serious dances about the Great Depression and religious fervor, a spoof of psychoanalysis and tributes to the joy of movement and the tinkling sounds of old player pianos and music boxes. Tonight at 8; Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 and 7:30 p.m. City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212. Tickets: $30 to $60 (Anderson).

TRINITY IRISH DANCE COMPANY. The troupe's home is Chicago, and its technique derives from that of traditional Irish step dancing. But its outlook is global, and its choreographers are not afraid to use old traditions in new ways. Its offerings range from a work inspired by a dream to pieces combining Irish dances with steps deriving from soft shoe and the swing era of the 1950's. Tonight at 8; Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $38 (Anderson).

WORKS AND PROCESS AT THE GUGGENHEIM: ANDREW ASNES AND JOHN SELYA. Who else but these two goofy modern-dance and ballet choreographers would do a soft shoe in flippers? That is part of their new "Synch or Swim," which will be performed in a program that also includes a discussion of their collaborative process. Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m., the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3587. Tickets: $18; $12 for students and 65+ (Dunning).

GRAPHIC: Photo: The bass-baritone Bryn Terfel will sing on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. (Henry Grossman/Metropolitan Opera)

HEADLINE: New Chief Says It's Go on Lincoln Center 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
Reynold Levy, the new president of Lincoln Center, said yesterday that he planned to proceed on schedule with the organization's contentious $1.2 billion redevelopment plan and that he hoped the project would help make the center more inviting to audiences it doesn't usually attract.
 One of the goals of the plan is to redesign the central plaza and surrounding buildings to make them less imposing. In an interview, Mr. Levy said, "To the degree that the redevelopment plan will have people lingering a bit, I think that's a big plus for audience diversity." 
 Mr. Levy was unanimously selected yesterday by the center's board and will officially begin work on May 1, although he said he planned to begin meeting with Lincoln Center executives and board members immediately.
Given the fractiousness over the 10-year redevelopment plan and indications from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that the city might not be able to keep to its commitment to provide $240 million over 10 years, it is clear that he has his work cut out for him. In the interview, also attended by the center's chairwoman, Beverly Sills, he presented himself as a patient conciliator who thought he could fashion consensus on issues like whether to build a new home for the New York City Opera, a subject that has already led to recriminations and staff turmoil.
Mr. Levy is president of the International Rescue Committee, one of the world's largest refugee relief organizations. Before that he was president of the AT&T Foundation, which specializes in giving to the arts, and he was also a senior officer in charge of government relations. He has also been executive director of the 92nd Street Y.
Some arts professionals have said the job of Lincoln Center president is a no-win position because of the complicated relationship between the center and the 12 often powerful independent arts groups that function on its campus. While Lincoln Center Inc. is the complex's landlord, it is also just one constituent among many that shape broad policy.
Nevertheless, Mr. Levy, a scholarly-looking, soft-spoken man of 57, said he didn't need more authority than the president's office already has. "It's very important that the constituent companies see Lincoln Center Inc. as serving them," he said.
"These companies have to live together in close proximity and work together in the interests of artists and audiences," he added. "I don't think it would serve anyone's interests to have a change of authority overriding the will of the others."
Rather, Mr. Levy said, he is excited about the job and undaunted by the prospect of trying to unite Lincoln Center's constituents. "Redeveloping this campus is a complicated, long-term task, so a lot of the reports of differences don't surprise me," he said. While he added that he thought those differences were natural, Mr. Levy also said that they had been exaggerated.
"On 90 percent of these issues there is total agreement," he said. "I wouldn't rule out the possibility of coming to an agreement."
In the past Ms. Sills has said she would step down when a new president was in place. Yesterday she declined to be specific about when that might happen. "I will stay for a smooth transition," she said. "I've not made it a secret that I'm leaving."
Mr. Levy said he was in no hurry to see Ms. Sills go. "I intend to learn as much and do as much with Beverly as I can while she's here," he said. "The judgment of how long she's here is entirely hers."
So far, the 11 groups participating in the redevelopment have been unable to agree on whether City Opera should stay at the New York State Theater, which it shares with the New York City Ballet, or move to its own new home, and whether Avery Fisher Hall, home of the New York Philharmonic, should be renovated or razed and replaced.
The City Opera is considering a move downtown to the site of the World Trade Center as part of a larger cultural complex. Ms. Sills, a former City Opera star, said she still hoped the City Opera would find a way to stay put. "I worry about the company," she said. "I think they will be able to raise the money to build a new house. What has to be asked is, can you get endowment money to maintain the house? There are a lot of practicalities that trouble me."
Mr. Levy said it was too soon for him to take a position on City Opera and other unresolved aspects of the redevelopment. His first task, he said, would be "an enormous amount of active, empathic listening."
"There are a lot of committed trustees and arts managers and administrators who put their lives into their companies and serving their audiences," Mr. Levy said. "I need to know what they're thinking and what motivates them. Also to develop warm and trusting relations."
Some arts professionals involved with the center have suggested changing the bylaws, which require board unanimity on every major aspect of the plan. Mr. Levy said he hoped that would be unnecessary. He also said he believed the redevelopment could move forward despite the large outstanding issues. "I think a great deal can be done without every i being dotted and every t being crossed," he said.
Although the events of Sept. 11 and a difficult economic climate will make raising money for the redevelopment a challenge, Mr. Levy said, he is optimistic about coming up with the money. He said he would begin fund-raising immediately after formally taking over in May.
"We have had the largest aggregation of wealth the country has ever seen," he said. "We have an enormous number of people who have taken care of themselves, of their families, who are looking to do something consequential and enduring. Lincoln Center offers the opportunity to participate in projects that will have meaning for decades."
While some arts professionals outside Lincoln Center question whether the institution can pull off its redevelopment, Mr. Levy suggested that everyone would get on board. "There does come a time when it is necessary to recognize that everyone is part of a continuous physical space," he said. "That is what should give rise to collaboration."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Reynold Levy, elected president of Lincoln Center yesterday. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. More Wary on Bailouts Abroad 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
In the vast lecture hall where he taught introductory economics to hundreds of students at Stanford University, John B. Taylor would sing, dance and even dress up as a California raisin to show how government intervention can distort markets.
 Now, wearing a staid suit in a lavish Treasury office once occupied by Andrew Johnson, Mr. Taylor, the under secretary for international affairs, intends to bring the Bush administration's hands-off market-based philosophy to troubled countries around the world. 
 In the biggest crisis on his watch so far -- Argentina's default on much of its debt -- Mr. Taylor has essentially left American creditors to fend for themselves. "We don't want to be bailing out the private bondholders," he said in an interview. "Official resources are limited." 
Because research into the creditworthiness of emerging economies has improved, Mr. Taylor said, financial crises these days are less likely than before to spread beyond their country of origin. That means the rationale for the United States and other wealthy nations to step in and bail out countries like Argentina has dwindled. "You can't continue to have large, elephant-style packages," he said.
Instead of intervening after a crisis, Mr. Taylor argued, the United States and other governments should work to improve the flow of information between international borrowers and lenders. "What we have been trying to do is to find a way to add clarity to how these markets work," he said. Private-sector lenders would then feel more comfortable lending to them, and more money would flow at lower interest rates, he said.
The notion that financial contagion is a thing of the past gets mixed reviews from other experts in international economics. "It's probably premature to reach that judgment," said Edwin M. Truman, who served in senior international finance policy posts at the Federal Reserve and the Treasury during the Clinton administration and is now a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics. "It so happens in the Argentine case that it hasn't caused a lot of contagion," Mr. Truman said. "There will be other mistakes; there will be more contagion."
Mr. Taylor may have another reason for being reticent in Argentina's case. Strategic importance to the United States can make obtaining international aid easier, said Barry J. Eichengreen, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley. Turkey, which is a member of NATO, has received a steady stream of financial support. "If the country is Argentina, which is less critical from a political point of view, that becomes less of a motivation."
Mr. Taylor said his very first meeting as under secretary dealt with Turkey. He met with Horst Kohler and Anne O. Krueger, the director and first deputy director of the International Monetary Fund, and they decided that Turkey would not have to face many conditions or checkpoints while receiving aid from the fund. Instead, Turkey would mainly be held to targets for fiscal health before a new aid package began. The fund would become less of a back-seat driver for troubled countries pursuing economic reforms.
Not for the first time, academic pedigree may forge a close relationship between the Treasury and the I.M.F. In the 1990's, Professor Eichengreen said, it was common knowledge in economic circles that Lawrence H. Summers, who held Mr. Taylor's job and eventually became Treasury secretary in the Clinton cabinet, had taken courses from Stanley Fischer, who held Ms. Krueger's current job from 1994 to 2001. Now, Mr. Taylor works alongside his Stanford University colleague of eight years, Ms. Krueger.
In testimony before Congress two weeks ago, Mr. Taylor backed some of Ms. Krueger's ideas for limiting the chaos inherent in debt crises like Argentina's. He praised clauses written into bond contracts that, in the event of a default, would oblige creditors to accept majority voting on repayment deals rather than require unanimous consent. But he stopped short of endorsing "a larger role for the I.M.F. than the more decentralized market-oriented approach," in which the fund might serve as an arbiter or debtor-in-possession during a country's bankruptcy.
Mr. Taylor has also made revamping of the World Bank and its partner institutions a top priority. "The World Bank and the multilateral development banks have had too many roles," he said.
In his view, Mr. Taylor said, the only way to end poverty is to concentrate exclusively on programs that enhance the productivity of labor. He said he was pleased that President Bush had called for the World Bank to change its aid from loans to grants and to provide aid based on the potential for measurable improvements in productivity -- essentially, through a market.
The World Bank declined to comment on the administration's proposals.

HEADLINE: EchoStar Announces Smaller 4th-Quarter Loss 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: LITTLETON, Colo. Feb. 28 

 BODY:
A satellite television company, EchoStar Communications, posted a narrower fourth-quarter loss today, with net subscriber additions on the high side of analysts' expectations.
 The company, which operates the Dish Network and plans to take over its larger rival, Hughes Electronics, posted a loss of $42.9 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with a loss of $184.2 million, or 39 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. EchoStar is based in Littleton. 
 Revenue rose 43 percent, to $1.15 billion from $805.4 million a year ago. The results exceeded analysts' estimates, which ranged from $1.06 billion to $1.10 billion.
Shares in EchoStar rallied sharply in response, rising $2.52, or 11 percent, to $26.12 a share on Nasdaq. 
Revenue for the full year was $4 billion, compared with $2.7 billion in 2000. EchoStar repeated that it expected revenue this year to rise by 20 percent to 25 percent, even though the economy is still slow.
EchoStar added 400,000 net subscribers during the quarter, a gain that was within analysts' forecasts of 350,000 to 410,000 additions. It ended 2001 with 6.83 million subscribers.
Net subscriber additions rose 11 percent from 360,000 in the third quarter, but fell 19 percent from 495,000 a year earlier.
Average monthly revenue per subscriber, a key measurement for satellite and cable companies, was $49.32 for 2001, up 8.8 percent from $45.33 in 2000. The company said it expected a modest increase in monthly revenue per subscriber.
Subscriber acquisition costs totaled $395 per subscriber, up 17 percent from $338 in 2000. EchoStar said it expected subscriber acquisition costs in 2002 to be consistent with those in 2001.
EchoStar's chief executive, Charles W. Ergen, said the regulatory review of the Hughes merger was proceeding as expected.
The $25 billion deal would combine the top two satellite broadcasters. The prospect of that step has raised concerns that it would eliminate competition in the satellite market and slow the two companies' efforts to offer local channels and other services in smaller and rural markets.

HEADLINE: A Swiss Vote on Joining U.N. Has a Good Chance This Time 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: SION, Switzerland 

 BODY:
Encompassing the majestic Matterhorn, the Great St. Bernard Pass and the upscale Zermatt ski resort, this ancient valley, known by the Romans as Vallis Poenina and now as Valais, is expected to vote on March 3 in favor of joining the United Nations -- but just barely.
 The decisive vote on whether to open Switzerland to the outside world will be close here in the heartland, which backed the overwhelming vote against a similar bid 16 years ago. 
 But an unusual government, banking, labor and industry coalition is trying to push this aloof Alpine enclave, which has long prided itself on independence, neutrality and armed preparedness, to ease away from its splendid isolation. Nationalists are pushing back, urging the country not to abandon neutrality.
In 1986, even as the Soviet Union was crumbling, the Communist threat still gripped Switzerland, which required every home to have a nuclear bomb shelter. Valaisans surpassed their countrymen in rebuffing United Nations membership, piling up an 83 percent "no." 
Now the Valais economy has shifted from its self-sufficiently agrarian base and, like Switzerland's as a whole, thrives on the three pillars of banking, insurance and services, bringing people into closer contact with the outside world, said Francois Dayer, chief editor of the daily Le Nouvelliste. "It's been a complete transformation," he said in his Sion office. "In 50 years, we've gone from washing our laundry at the fountain to the washing machine."
Yet, he concedes, the argument for neutrality still has a powerful attraction for the country's older, rural, often German-speaking population. 
The isolationist Swiss People's Party maintains that United Nations membership would cancel "direct democracy, neutrality and federalism," and that Switzerland would be dragged into military engagements and economic boycotts at the bidding of powerful nations. The arguments are rewarmed from 1986, but instead of Russia and China, the party leader, Christoph Blocher, points to the United States. 
"It's the large countries that have the say, and now it's the Americans," he said, invoking fears here that Switzerland will be forced to take part in an American-led response to terrorism. Opinion polls last fall found that more than 70 percent of Swiss saw the Sept. 11 attacks resulting from flawed American policies, especially in the Middle East.
"The anti-United States sentiment is very strong now," noted Chantal Balet Emery, of western Switzerland's Economie Suisse business federation, who agreed with some experts that such sentiments could tip the balance against joining. "People are afraid of U.S. overreaction," she said. "At the same time, they are afraid of terrorism, and realize we can't defend ourselves alone."
The federal government has countered that Sweden, Austria and Finland, United Nations members, have not abandoned their neutrality or independence. They argue that Swiss troops are already in the Balkans, even if only for logistical backup, and that Switzerland has observed most recent economic sanctions.
Promoting United Nations membership may also take some heat off Switzerland for banking practices that have enriched it. Europeans and Americans are pressing the Swiss to shed their banking secrecy and improve rules against money laundering, customs fraud and tax evasion. 
"Symbolically," Rudolf Stahm, a Swiss lawmaker, told the magazine L'Hebdo, "a 'yes' would soften our reputation as a 'bad guy.' "

HEADLINE: Budget for Port Agency Projects Stays High, With More Security 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved a $4.5 billion expense and capital budget for 2002 today that was about $100 million less than last year's spending plan, and reflected the loss of the agency's World Trade Center complex in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.
 But that loss was largely offset by $1.1 billion that the agency has already received from their insurance policy on the towers. The agency is also negotiating for a remaining $270 million that it claims it is due because of a variety of emergency expenses and losses from the attacks. 
 The budget also reflected some $120 million in additional security costs at the airports, bridges, tunnels and terminals that the agency operates, a 50 percent increase over the previous year's figure.
There was only minor trimming of the agency's ambitious, $14 billion, five-year capital construction program. And the port agency also decided to increase its reserves as a sign to the financial community that the authority is still strong financially and well able to cover the costs associated with its accumulated $7.2 billion in outstanding bonds.
"The world changed on Sept. 11," said Jack G. Sinagra, the chairman of the 12-member board. "This budget reflects new realities and new priorities. The region will be stronger, more secure and more prosperous as a result of the spending program approved today."
Agency officials said that in spite of the difficulties they faced in the last year, they would be spending $544 million over the next 18 months to restore PATH service to Lower Manhattan. In addition, work will continue to complete the Air Train system to connect Kennedy International Airport to subway and Long Island Rail Road lines. The agency will also continue a host of other airport improvements and begin planning for a permanent ferry terminal at Battery Park City and one at La Guardia Airport.
Gross operating revenues were $2.7 billion, up 2 percent over the previous year's gross but below pre-Sept. 11 projections of $2.9 billion. The 7,000-employee agency's net income from operations, or the accounting equivalent of profit, was $109 million last year, a steep decline from the $372 million net from 2000.
Expenses were $2.1 billion compared with $1.8 billion the year before and well over the budgeted 2001 amount of $1.9 billion.
Charles F. McClafferty, the chief financial officer of the Port Authority, said that activity levels at the facilities it operated reflected economic declines generally in the region as well as specific effects of Sept. 11. The 82 million air travelers last year at the three airports were down 11 percent from the 2000 levels, and the 2002 budget envisions that figure's declining to 72 million, Mr. McClafferty said.

HEADLINE: Europe Opens Convention To Set Future of Its Union 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
A European Union that has become increasingly distant from its citizens began an extraordinary effort today to create a more representative government as the 15-nation bloc expands across the Continent and absorbs as many as nine new members.
 A group of 105 parliamentarians, experts and governmental nominees opened a yearlong constitutional convention of sorts in Brussels that was designed to chart a more efficient and more democratic structure for the growing union. 
 "If we succeed, in 50 years' time, Europe will have changed its role in the world," said the convention's chairman, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the former French president. "It will be respected and listened to, not only as the economic power it already is, but as a political power that will speak as an equal with the largest existing and future powers on the planet." 
Symbolic of European aspirations for a more perfect association, the convention began on the day that national currencies like the French franc and the German mark officially stopped circulating, replaced by a single European currency, the euro, in 12 of the member states.
Already creaking at its current size, the European Union is expected to expand to as many as 24 nations by the middle of 2004, as it takes in the poorer countries of formerly socialist eastern Europe, with the Balkan states and Turkey still to come.
But how such a vastly bigger European Union should be shaped and governed -- as a federation or as a confederation of different states, and in a way that small countries have a say and large countries have a stake and ordinary citizens feel some real connection to the bureaucrats in Brussels -- has bedeviled busy leaders for years.
So last December, at their summit meeting in Laeken, Belgium, European nations agreed to set up this convention, which has been likened to the American constitutional convention of 1787.
"If we fail," Mr. Giscard d'Estaing warned the delegates today, "each country will go back to the logic of a free trade area. None of us, not even the biggest, would have sufficient weight to deal with the big powers of this world."
In his opening address today, he switched from French to English to German, and, rather like the Pope at Christmas, greeted the assembled "ladies and gentlemen" in all 11 official languages of the European Union, and then in Polish as a gesture to the candidate states.
How to better share sovereignty between Brussels and the member states, whether to directly elect a "president" of Europe, whether to give more executive powers to the government-appointed European Commission in Brussels and more legislative powers to the European Parliament are knotty questions that go to the heart of Europe's future.
But the delegates will also grapple with how to make decision-making more efficient in a Europe where some nations want to move faster than others and France, for example, does not want to lose the old principle, enshrined in the early days of the union, of equality with a Germany that is now reunited and much larger.
Nor do smaller states, like Denmark, Finland or Ireland, want to be bulldozed by the larger states, so the smaller ones are likely to favor continued strong powers for the commission.
The convention could even try to draft a European constitution, which would try to put the last 50 years of stop-gap treaties into one, coherent document.
It will be the leaders of the member nations who will receive the recommendations of this convention and decide what to do. But it will be harder for the leaders to ignore the recommendations that emerge from this open process, and harder for them to maintain the European Union as a top-down affair, with little power given to the European Parliament.
For all the talk of Philadelphia in 1787, the dream of a "United States of Europe," which animated one of the European Union's founders, Jean Monnet, the French economist, has been dead for years.
The president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, said that the real aim of this convention "is not to build a superstate." European integration is unique, he said, and "the E.U. is unique in that it is a union of peoples and states."
But he supported the idea of a constitution for Europe, saying that such a document would mark "the birth of Europe as a political entity."

HEADLINE: Mr. Mugabe's Destructive Course 

 BODY:
An honest election in Zimbabwe next week could well end President Robert Mugabe's 22-year grip on power there. To prevent that, Mr. Mugabe has been doing all he can to deny a fair chance to the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. Voters have been arbitrarily disqualified, European and African election observers harassed and the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, implausibly charged with treason. Should the opposition win anyway, army officers have pledged to keep Mr. Mugabe in power. Repressive new laws permit the banning of public rallies and silencing of critical reporting. A fraudulent election could seriously harm not only Zimbabwe, but also many of its neighbors. These countries, especially South Africa, need to take a stronger stand against Mr. Mugabe's attempts to suffocate democracy. 
 Zimbabwe was once one of southern Africa's most democratic and prosperous countries. Today it is a wreck that threatens the region's stability and prospects. The economy has been contracting sharply for three years. Average incomes have fallen dramatically and famine threatens. 
 The European Union imposed sanctions on Mr. Mugabe and his close cronies after the head of its team of election observers was expelled. Washington has rightly banned American visas for Mr. Mugabe's inner circle. But the impact of these measures has been blunted by the failure of South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, and the 14-country Southern African Development Community to take strong action too. Mr. Mugabe is still shielded by misplaced deference from Mr. Mbeki and other African leaders who view him as a former icon of the African liberation struggle. 
The liberation Africa needs today is from deepening poverty, corrupt governments, shameful neglect by Western aid givers and the skittishness of foreign investors. Last month, Mr. Mbeki was in New York soliciting support for a farsighted international partnership designed to attack these problems head on, linking an African commitment to better governance with a call for greater international investment. By failing to take strong action against Mr. Mugabe's manipulations, Mr. Mbeki betrays the spirit of this promising initiative.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
S.& P. and Nasdaq Dropped for Month, but Dow Gained

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to its biggest monthly drop since September, on concern corporate profits would rebound more slowly than expected.
 Intel and Walt Disney led the loss. 
 "It's hard to see where earnings increases are going to come from to sustain any kind of rally," said Wendell Perkins of Johnson Asset Management in Racine, Wis. 
The S.& P. 500 fell 3.16 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,106.73. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 21.45 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,106.13. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 20.39 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,731.49.
For the month, the S.& P. 500 dropped 2.1 percent, and the Nasdaq shed 10 percent. Both also fell in January. The Dow rose 1.9 percent, its fourth monthly gain in five months.
Stocks initially gained after a government report showed that the economy grew at the fastest pace in a year in the fourth quarter and an industry report showed that manufacturing in the Chicago area expanded in February for the first time since July 2000. For a second day, the rally faded on concern about how much profits would rebound and when.
Cigna, Kinder Morgan and PeopleSoft tumbled amid concern their accounting practices did not accurately reflect earnings.
"People are gravitating to companies in businesses they can get their arms around," said Jack Ablin, chief investment officer at Harris Trust and Savings in Chicago.
Disney slid $1.25, to $23. A Goldman, Sachs analyst, Richard Greenfield, said Disney might miss estimates for its second quarter.
Intel fell $1.34, to $28.55. Its shares trade at 54 times earnings, and some analysts said that makes them too expensive.
Kinder Morgan slumped $5.20, to $41, after a Prudential Securities analyst, Carol Coale, questioned the use of partnerships at Kinder Morgan Energy Partners "to enhance bottom-line earnings of the parent company," which is Kinder Morgan. She lowered her rating of the company. Kinder Morgan Energy fell $3.30, to $28.60.
Cigna declined $4.18, to $89.70. The company, a health insurer, said the Justice Department was investigating whether a New Mexico unit had accurately reported costs to collect Medicare reimbursements.
PeopleSoft dropped $2.77, to $29.07. The information service SEC Insight said the Securities and Exchange Commission might be investigating the company, which makes business software, or a competitor.
A company spokesman said it had not been told of an inquiry, and an S.E.C. spokesman declined to comment. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday after three reports showed better economic growth, fewer jobless claims than expected and a surge in regional manufacturing activity.
The losses wiped out some of the hefty gains of Wednesday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said an expected recovery would probably be moderate, suggesting interest rates would remain steady for months to come.
The reports yesterday prompted market players to raise the odds that the Fed might increase its benchmark overnight bank lending rate, currently at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent, as soon as the June policy meeting.
By late in the day, the price of a 10-year note fell 13/32, to 100 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.87 percent from 4.83 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond dropped 25/32, to a price of 99 13/32. Its yield rose to 5.42 percent from 5.36 percent.

HEADLINE: Cubans Set On Asylum Crash a Bus Into Embassy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
A bus carrying Cubans seeking to leave the island nation crashed through the gates of the Mexican Embassy in Havana late Wednesday. At least 21 Cubans remained inside the embassy today, Mexican officials said, adding that they did not qualify for political asylum. 
 After the blue and white bus rammed through the embassy's gate in the upscale Miramar neighborhood, the police battled with youths who tried to push their way into the compound behind the bus. An unknown number were arrested. 
 Hundreds of police officers with nightsticks and dogs were deployed to control the crowds around the embassy Wednesday night. Today the streets leading to the mission were blocked with government vehicles and patrolled by police officers and plainclothes agents.
The bus episode came after a day when small groups of people gathered outside the embassy on hearing rumors that the Mexican government was offering asylum. The rumors, Cuban and Mexican officials said, were based on a report from Radio Marti, a station financed by the United States government. It quoted Foreign Minister Jorge G. Castaneda of Mexico as saying, "The doors of the Mexican Embassy in Havana are open to all Cuban citizens, as is Mexico."
Mr. Castaneda made the comments on Tuesday night in Miami, where he was presiding over the opening of the Mexican Cultural Institute. He said today that Radio Marti had taken his words out of context and that he had been speaking in general terms about how the institute would welcome all visitors.
Mr. Castaneda said that 'radical elements in Miami" were angered that President Vicente Fox of Mexico had visited Cuba this month to reaffirm ties with President Fidel Castro. Those Cubans, he said, had sought to "use and twist these declarations about the Mexican Cultural Institute and, in effect, Mexico's traditional policy, to launch what we could call a small provocation."
The Cuban government blamed Radio Marti for the episode, accusing it of "cynically" twisting Mr. Castaneda's words. Mr. Castro drove past the embassy compound in a military vehicle about two hours after the bus incident, but he made no comment at that time. 
Salvador Lew, the director of the Office of Cuban Broadcasting, which oversees Radio and TV Marti, denied that there was any distortion. 
"We have on tape what he said and that was what we transmitted, not one word more or less," Mr. Lew said. "We made no comment. We transmitted his voice. If he now has repented, it is his right. But if he has bad memory I can give him a copy so he can hear it."
Mexican officials, hoping to avert a diplomatic crisis or a wave of refugees, said today that they were trying to persuade the asylum seekers to leave the embassy compound.
"They are, it appears to be the case, without employment and want to go to Mexico for economic reasons, so it will be very difficult that they will be given a visa," Mr. Castaneda said on the radio in Mexico City this morning. "We are not going to press charges, but we want to speak with them to see if they can leave the embassy in a quick and friendly manner, because in reality they have nothing to do there." 
A similar standoff at the Peruvian Embassy in 1980 set off the Marielboatlift, when 125,000 Cubans left the island.
President Fox now faces a delicate situation. As part of his goal of nudging Cuba toward reform, he also met with Cuban dissidents who have been advocating for human rights and democracy.
Mr. Castaneda sent his deputy foreign minister to Havana this morning to negotiate with the group and to obtain assurances from Mr. Castro that no reprisals would be taken. 
While Cuban officials continue to blame Radio Marti for the incident a State Department official said it was beside the point.
"The reason that 20 people are in the Mexican Embassy in Havana is not because of what the foreign minister said or what was reported," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It is because those people, like 11 million others, live in a country in which there are essentially no human rights. In countries where human rights are respected, you do not have incidents where buses crash into embassy gates as a way of people trying to get out of the country."

HEADLINE: 2 Clothing Retailers Post Gains 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
Limited Inc., the second-largest United States clothing retailer, and its majority-owned Intimate Brands Inc. said their fiscal fourth-quarter profits rose as the companies controlled inventories and expenses.
 A 35 percent profit gain at Intimate Brands, the parent of the Victoria's Secret lingerie stores, bolstered Limited's net income by 37 percent to $326.5 million, or 75 cents a share, in the quarter, which ended Feb. 2. 
Limited's sales fell 11 percent to $3.14 billion. The company plans to buy the 16 percent stake it does not already own in Intimate Brands. 
 The companies kept their inventories down heading into the holiday season and controlled costs, which bolstered profit margins. They also benefited as shoppers paid full price for Limited's denim jeans and stretch fabric clothing, and Victoria's Secret bras and panties, analysts said. First-quarter sales will be hurt as consumers remain wary of spending in the recession, the retailers said.
The shares of Limited, which owns Express and Limited stores, fell 28 cents, to $18.01. Intimate Brands, which also owns Bath & Body Works stores, fell 37 cents, to $19.33. 
The companies, which are based in Columbus, said per-share earnings in the first quarter will be little changed from a year earlier, as sales at stores open at least a year decline at Limited and remain unchanged at Intimate Brands. Profit this year will rise at a "low- to mid-single-digit" percentage rate, the companies said. 
Limited has 1,997 stores and Intimate Brands has 2,617 stores. Gap Inc. is the largest United States clothing retailer. Net income rose to $299.9 million, or 61 cents, at Intimate Brands. Its sales were little changed at $1.94 billion.

HEADLINE: U.N. Report Shows Rapid Aging Of Populations Around Globe 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
While many countries worry about a bulge in the number of restless young people with no jobs and too much time on their hands, the United Nations said today that the world's population is in fact steadily getting older everywhere.
 "The changes that are going on are not paralleled in any century before the 20th century," said Joseph Chamie, an American demographer who directs the United Nations population division. "We will see this trend accelerating in the 21st century." 
 Mr. Chamie introduced figures show aging as pervasive -- not just confined to rich countries -- and likely to have profound implications on economies in all regions.
If there were fears of instability generated by the idea of large numbers of unemployed young people becoming ready recruits for militancy or criminal activities, an older population raises other concerns.
As the United States has already discovered, pressures mount on health care systems, health insurance plans and social security as well as private pensions. In poorer countries, some of these safety nets do not now exist. Sri Lanka, for example, has a rapidly aging population and free health care -- but no social security and few pension plans outside government service.
The United Nations found that in richer countries, people over 60 now account for one-fifth of the population. Predictions indicate that the proportion will reach one-third by 2050. In poorer countries, only 8 percent of the population is over 60 now, but that is expected to rise to 20 percent by 2050.
With more people living longer and families getting smaller in most countries, the fastest-growing age group in the world are people over 80, the United Nations found. That group is growing at 3.8 percent annually.
United Nations demographers are riveted on a statistic they call the "potential support ratio": the number of people 15 to 64 who are available as workers to sustain the retirees. In 1950, the ratio was 12 to 1; in 2000, it was 9 to 1. By 2050, there may be only four working-age people for every person over 65 worldwide.
On Tuesday, Secretary General Kofi Annan released a report on the abuse of the elderly, in advance of a conference in Madrid in April on issues facing the aging. It mentioned practices like ostracism, which occurs in some societies when elderly women are used as scapegoats for natural disasters, epidemics or other catastrophes. "Women have been ostracized, tortured, maimed or even killed if they failed to flee the community," the report read. 
It also asserted that while physical, financial, emotional and sexual abuse of older people is "grossly underreported" generally, studies done in the United States, Argentina, Australia, Britain and Canada show that the problem is found in richer as well as poorer nations.

HEADLINE: Amex Coming Back to Lower Manhattan 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
American Express is abandoning Jersey City and moving its employees back to its building in Lower Manhattan to consolidate operations that were scattered across the New York region after the World Trade Center attack.
 The decision, described by American Express executives in a memorandum to employees yesterday, reverses an early decision to significantly reduce the number of workers in Lower Manhattan by shifting some of them to Jersey City. 
 But American Express officials said that after making a round of layoffs late last year, there would be enough space in Lower Manhattan to accommodate all of its local employees. American Express owns the building it will be reoccupying, 3 World Financial Center, in a partnership with Lehman Brothers, which has not committed to returning. 
"American Express today is so far the biggest win for the city and the state," said M. Myers Mermel, the president of Tenantwise.com, a commercial real estate broker on Wall Street.
The decision to return 3,500 employees to the World Financial Center is considered a much-needed boost for New York as it struggles to recover from the Sept. 11 attack. Those workers returning to the city include about 560 technology and finance workers who had been in Jersey City since 1999.
"They made the pledge to come back to Lower Manhattan, but they went beyond that by taking 500 additional jobs from Jersey City and into Lower Manhattan," said Charles E. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. "I am hoping that this could be a reversal of the trend of these jobs moving out of the city."
The move was a blow to economic development officials in Jersey City who had still hoped to retain some companies that had relocated after the attacks. "We are sorry to see them go, but we are glad to see New York is rebounding," said Stan H. Eason, a spokesman for Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham. 
The Sept. 11 attack displaced 4,500 American Express workers based in 3 World Financial Center, 40 Wall Street and 7 World Trade Center. The workers were sent to the Jersey City office and other space that the company quickly leased in Stamford, Conn., and Short Hills and Parsippany, N.J.
Molly Faust, an American Express spokeswoman, said the decision to close the Jersey City office and move everything back to Lower Manhattan was made primarily for financial reasons.
Ms. Faust said the total number of employees back in Manhattan -- about 4,000 -- will be lower than the company's pre-Sept. 11 head count because of a round of layoffs at the company.
"Work force reductions mean that we have more space in the World Financial Center and now we have the space to bring the people back to the city," she said, adding that American Express plans to sublease its office space in Jersey City and three other locations. 
Jersey City became the home to several companies displaced in the attack, including Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. 
Mr. Gargano said American Express received no tax breaks or other financial incentives to return to New York.
In November, American Express executives said they planned to return some workers to the World Financial Center but would keep a significant contingent in Jersey City. But officials involved in the process said that with the layoffs, officials realized they could save more money by consolidating operations.
In the months after the attacks, many companies said they were going to spread their operations over the region for security reasons. But many analysts said the costs of making such moves in tough economic times might be too high.

HEADLINE: U.S. Growth Rate, at 1.4%, Is Far Better Than Expected 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With consumer spending holding up much better than anyone had expected, the American economy grew at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday in a sharp upward revision of its original estimate. The new growth rate was surprisingly vigorous for a nation in recession.
 A few forecasters even went so far as to declare an end to the recession that started last March. Most were more cautious, however, noting that apart from consumption, other basic indicators of the economy's health were still going in the wrong direction -- particularly unemployment, profits and business spending. 
 "What drove up consumer spending in the fourth quarter, and is still driving it up, was zero-percent financing, price discounts, tax rebates and huge promotional pricing for big- ticket items," said James W. Paulsen, a senior economist at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "If nothing else, there soon won't be anyone left who needs anything."
Although the recession officially started last March, when the economy began to weaken, there has been only one quarter of negative growth. That was the third quarter, which included the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the instant, but short-lived damage to airline travel, tourism and retail sales.
Reflecting the rapid bounce-back, the Commerce Department said in January that the gross domestic product, after declining at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the third quarter, had risen in the fourth at a meager 0.2 percent, adjusted for inflation. The revision increased that first estimate sevenfold.
Trying to explain the strength in consumer spending through so many months of recession, economists and pollsters increasingly argue that bargain prices have been too tempting for consumers to resist -- despite rising debt loads and widespread layoffs. Some economists particularly cite the sharp drop in borrowing costs as the Federal Reserve cut rates in rapid response to the weakening economy.
Whatever the reasons, spending on durable goods -- that is, big-ticket items like vehicles, appliances, furniture and the like -- rose to a very strong annual rate of $1.021 trillion, up $81.1 billion from the third quarter, more than enough to account for the positive economic growth.
The current recession, the 10th since World War II, is an anomaly. Virtually all of the others have resulted from a decline in consumer spending, followed by a drop in business investment in machinery, computers, office buildings, factories and all the other tools used to produce goods and services.
This time, however, business investment brought on the recession as it fell sharply from its surging levels in the late 1990's, while personal consumption remained strong, even rising at a very robust 6 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, up from the 5.4 percent originally estimated.
And business investment must revive to end the recession decisively. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, made that point in Congressional testimony on Wednesday. The hope, of course, is that consumer spending will sustain the economy, even at a low rate of growth, until business investment kicks back in.
Some economists, including Mr. Paulsen, contend that consumption will falter because the bargain pricing that has sustained consumer spending will give out soon. Most forecasters, however, anticipate that consumption can remain robust until capital spending begins to revive, perhaps in late summer.
The optimists note that while spending on buildings fell sharply in the fourth quarter, the decline in spending on machinery and equipment slowed, suggesting that the excess production capacity that has inhibited investment is abating.
"What you are betting is that the kick from consumption and inventories that we are getting will incite the passion of investors; I don't mean stock market investors, I mean the business executives who invest in real capital," said Alan S. Blinder, a Princeton economist who expects a revival in business investment by July.
Consumption and inventories of unsold merchandise are intertwined. The strong consumer spending, particularly for new vehicles during weeks of zero-interest financing, reduced inventories at an annual rate of $120 billion in the fourth quarter, or nearly double the rate in the third quarter. With inventories falling to levels characteristic of the late 1990's boom, inventory restocking resumed late last year.
The Commerce Department, in its first estimate of fourth-quarter growth, had given imports too big a role in this restocking. The revision yesterday showed that imports, which add nothing to America's economic growth, were less than expected and that domestic production, particularly of durable goods, played a bigger role. Half of the upward revision in the fourth-quarter G.D.P. number came from this change.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
FOUNDER IS STEPPING DOWN AS CHIEF AT LILLIAN VERNON

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The Lillian Vernon Corporation, which sells household items and toys, said yesterday that its chief executive, Lillian Vernon, was stepping down. HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: France: Jobless Rate Rises 

BYLINE:  By John Tagliabue (NYT) 

 BODY:
 As French business reacted with layoffs to an economy that contracted in the fourth quarter of last year, the number of French unemployed rose by 5,000 in January, to 2.41 million people, or 9 percent of the work force, its highest level in more than a year. The French economy contracted 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter, its first decline in five years, slowed by the economic sluggishness of France's two biggest trade partners, Germany and the United States. 
Jobs are a major issue in the French presidential race, which ends with a first round of voting in April. The government expects the economy to grow only 1.5 percent this year, after a 2 percent rise in 2001. John Tagliabue (NYT)

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
WALINSKY, LOUIS J.

 BODY:
 WALINSKY-Louis J. Economist and playwright, died peacefully in Washington, DC, on December 24, 2001, at the age of 93. Walinsky was born in London, the son of the labor leader Ossip J. Walinsky and the sculptress and author Rosa Newman Walinsky. Coming to America in 1915, he attended Cornell University where he received honors in economics. After graduate study at the University of Berlin, he wrote the play "Heil Hitler!" His dramatization of Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World" was banned in London, but performed in Paris by the English Players. He taught economics in New York City high schools from 1930 until 1943, when he joined the War Production Board in Washington, remaining there with the Civilian Production Administration until 1947. He then led the efforts of the World ORT Union to rehabilitate and train Displaced Persons in the refugee camps of Europe. In 1950 he joined Robert R. Nathan Associates in Washington, DC, working mostly on the problems of developing nations. He served from 1953 to 1958 as Chief Economic Adviser to the Government of Burma (now Myanmar). After 1963 he worked as a consultant for the World Bank, undertaking missions to Korea, Afghanistan, El Salvador, Brazil, East Africa, Israel, Iran, India, Bolivia, Venezuela, Newfoundland, Papua New Guinea and Puerto Rico. He authored several books on economic development. He was an original member of the national board of Americans for Democratic Action, and the Executive Director of the International Commission of the World Jewish Congress in 1979-80. 
From 1991 to 1995 he was vice chairman of the American Friends of Democracy in Burma, which opposed the military dictatorship there. His wife Dorothy died in 1987. An earlier marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by his daughters, Marian Harrison of Bethesda, MD, and Louisa Parker of Vancouver, BC, by his son, Adam of Scarsdale, NY, and sister, Emily Rubin of New York City, and by three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will take place at Joseph Gawler and Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue NW, in Washington, D.C. on April 26 at 11 AM.

HEADLINE: W.T.O. Pact Would Set Global Accounting Rules 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
As Congress and regulatory officials consider ways to tighten auditing and accounting rules to prevent a repeat of the Enron debacle, a little-known global agreement that places untested new requirements on the domestic regulation of professional services like accounting is quietly advancing -- with the help of firms like Arthur Andersen, Enron's much-criticized auditor. 
 The new rules would give the World Trade Organization oversight of the domestic regulation of accounting. Any new national regulation could be challenged by other countries as unfair if it was "more trade restrictive than necessary." 
 Critics of the new rules say such a standard could hobble a government's ability to regulate scores of services. But American officials say the requirement will simply prevent governments from setting up discriminatory rules, limitations and quotas that would interfere with the right of foreign service companies to enter their markets. 
So far, the new rules, which are being drafted by the World Trade Organization with the help of Arthur Andersen and other companies, have attracted little outside attention. They fall under the General Agreement on Trade in Services, or GATS, a 1994 pact that seeks to liberalize trade in many areas, like architecture and real estate brokerage services, the way the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, has done for many goods.
The services agreement has generated none of the public controversy that has swirled around the organization's attempts to promote merchandise trade. Even after street protests disrupted the group's Seattle conference in 1999, talks on services moved forward.
But since the Enron bankruptcy proceedings drew public attention to accounting practices, public interest groups and critics of free trade have begun to worry that the services pact may hamper efforts to curb abuses. 
"The Enron-Andersen crisis just shows that governments need to retain the ability to experiment with deregulation and then, if they realize they've gone too far, to re-regulate," said Ellen D. Gould, an independent consultant and researcher working on contract with Georgetown University. "What the W.T.O. and these agreements seek to do is make deregulation a one-way street." 
Even critics agree that in the current atmosphere, unfair-trade complaints would be unlikely against the measures now being discussed. But they ask how the new rules will be interpreted when future issues arise, and a government proposes measures disliked by a trading partner. 
"What we really need to ask is to what degree are global agreements like this going to limit our ability to regulate services domestically," said Patricia J. Arnold, an associate professor of business at the University of Wisconsin's Milwaukee campus. "The long-term goal of GATS is to eliminate barriers in the cross-border trade in services." 
American trade officials said such fears were overblown. They point to recent changes in banking regulations, also covered by the services agreement, that were not challenged by any nation on trade grounds. 
"We think that these things are written sufficiently broadly enough not to cause any problems," a senior trade official said. 
Joshua Ronen, a professor of accounting at New York University, said the detailed agreement on accounting now being drawn up did not specify licensing requirements or exam standards for individual nations; it merely insists that any such regulations be legitimate and transparent. "I don't think they will have any impact on any reform the United States has in mind," he said.
GATS was adopted in 1994 by the 140 nations of the trade organization in response to brisk growth in services, which accounted for one-fifth of all cross-border trade in 1999, or more than $1.35 trillion in all. Trade in services has grown faster than merchandise trade for 20 years. 
The agreement covers nearly all services, except those provided solely by governments and those involved in air transportation. Developing nations are given leeway to offer some protection for local companies.
Accounting was one of the first services for which detailed rules were written. Charles Leonard, an Arthur Andersen spokesman, said the firm was part of an international accounting group that helped draft them. "We were striving for openness and transparency in national standards," he said. 
The rules do not take formal effect until 2005, but member nations have already agreed not to impose any new regulations that do not meet the proposed standard for openness. 
It is not clear how that commitment applies to the measures now being debated in Washington. During the process of drafting the agreement several years ago, American officials raised questions about whether prohibiting an accounting company from doing both auditing and consulting work for the same client would be viewed as restricting trade. Such a measure is being considered in Washington now.
