HEADLINE: Head of Miss America Pageant Resigns, Citing Board Disagreements 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
The head of the Miss America Pageant resigned yesterday after a two-year tenure in which he threatened to move the money-losing event out of Atlantic City and cut budgets. He also solicited new sponsors and licensed Miss America slot machines and other merchandise to resurrect the 81-year-old dowager's finances.
 It was unclear last night if the departure of Robert M. Renneisen Jr., 55, as the pageant's $250,000-a-year president and chief executive was a dismissal or a voluntary withdrawal. He declined to comment when reached by telephone, but issued a brief written statement referring to disagreements with his board. 
 The move was "negotiated on amicable terms and both regretted the necessity for the decision," it said. "Both the board and I want only success for the Miss America organization. However, it has become clear that we differ in our definition of success and on the means necessary to achieve it. Perhaps a change in leadership will bring new perspectives to the many challenges facing this organization."
While the disagreements were not spelled out, the resignation comes only weeks after an attempted coup by directors of some state pageants and after angry complaints from mentors and relatives of the current Miss America, Katie Harmon, who accused Mr. Renneisen of depriving her of press opportunities and even short-changing her on bills for clothing alterations.
The pageant said that Mr. Renneisen would be succeeded temporarily by George Bauer, 58, the second-ranking official. Mr. Renneisen is the pageant's third top official in four years, and the second to go before his contract expired. His predecessor, Robert L. Beck, was ousted after he proposed to end a long-standing ban on contestants who were divorced or had had an abortion.
A former casino and marketing executive, Mr. Renneisen had a host of ideas for modernizing a pageant that had evolved over the years from a bathing beauty contest into a competition that combined talent and personality and promoted images of young women with ideas about culture, politics and their communities.
The trouble was that the pageant was losing money, and traditional sources of revenue had begun to wither, along with the national television audience. The 2000 pageant had the lowest ratings in the event's 43 years on television: only 8.8 million homes tuned in, compared with 22 million in 1970.
Last year, 13.5 million viewers were watching, but revenue was not nearly enough to cover the organization's expenses. ABC paid $5.8 million for the broadcast rights to the September pageant, a sum Mr. Renneisen recently said had been shrinking in recent years.
"When the company hired me two years ago, given this economic paradigm, we knew we must begin to increase and expand our sources of revenue from other areas," Mr. Renneisen said in an interview a few weeks ago. "Clothing, jewelry, T-shirts, dolls, whatever."
Mr. Renneisen's proposal to license Miss America slot machines for casinos drew immediate fire from a number of state pageant officials, who characterized the idea as demeaning to the wholesome image the organization has tried to promote. Nevertheless, he said he had reached an agreement with a slot-machine maker.
The dispute exposed something of a culture clash in the pageant, setting state directors in California, Oregon, Illinois, Texas and other states -- some of whom had long shunned two-piece bathing suits for contestants -- against Mr. Renneisen.
Last December, Mr. Renneisen threatened to move the pageant out of Atlantic City, where it had been founded in 1921, unless the city, which has been paying about $500,000 annually, came up with $1 million more. He said that the location of the pageant was a license he could sell, and that the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn., had offered $1.5 million.
Atlantic City's Convention and Visitor's Bureau, perhaps sensing a bluff, said it would not pay the additional money, and the pageant's board voted unanimously to remain in Atlantic City for at least one more year.
More tensions arose in January at a Las Vegas workshop sponsored by the national organization. Timothy Crammer, a New Jersey lawyer who represents the National Association of Miss America State Pageants, said that several state officials complained that Mr. Renneisen did not promptly return the calls of potential sponsors solicited by the state groups.
The state directors appealed to the Miss America Organization board, and at a meeting on Feb. 4 presented what one state official called a "book of grievances" against Mr. Renneisen. Two state officials asked for his resignation.
In response, Mr. Renneisen said the volunteers who run state pageants did not grasp the size of the economic problems of the national organization.

HEADLINE: They Give, but They Also Take: Voters Muddle States' Finances 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: PHOENIX, March 1 

 BODY:
The voters of Arizona have spoken. They want lower taxes. They also want higher taxes -- but only if they go to the state's beleaguered public schools, consistently ranked among the worst in the nation.
 The people of Colorado have spoken as well. They passed a constitutional amendment that limits how much state government can spend or take in, even in flush times. But then a few years later they passed another amendment, calling for guaranteed annual increases in education spending. Pay for it however possible, the voters seemed to be saying, but do not raise our taxes. 
 In Washington State, the voters have sent a similar mixed message. By a sizable majority, people voted in 1999 to cut taxes. But the next year an even bigger majority voted to spend $800 million to give teachers annual raises and reduce class size, without also offering any new money to pay for the initiatives. 
Call them unfinanced mandates from the people. Now all three states are facing crushing deficits and may have to close parks, delay road construction, close hospitals and reduce police officers in rural areas. Standard & Poor's has warned Colorado that its credit rating may be downgraded.
Still, the voter message seems to be, Deal with it.
As state legislators struggle to find ways to adhere to the popular will, some are now wondering whether it was a good idea to let people shape big chunks of the budget by voter initiatives, leaving the messy details to lawmakers.
Some state politicians have even coined a term for their new diminished role. They call themselves the Bypass Legislature. In the last 10 years, the number of states where voters have put budgetary strictures on their elected officials has practically doubled, to 13.
At the same time, in the 24 states where lawmaking by ballot is permitted, voters went on a spending spree of their own, mandating money for drug treatment, schools, parks and roads.
Voter initiatives have never been particularly popular with state lawmakers, who see their job as taxing and spending. But most of what voters did was largely inconsequential in the prosperous 1990's. Now, in the midst of a lingering recession and increased cost for domestic security, the bill is coming due, and in a growing number of states, expenses and revenues do not add up.
More than 40 states have a budget shortage. And unlike the federal government, these budgets are required by law to be balanced.
"This makes my job very difficult," said Nancy McCallin, the budget director for Colorado. "But the voters pay the taxes, and if they are telling us this is how they want us to run things, we have to do it."
Voter moods can vary. Colorado is now trying find a way to make up a two-year budget shortage of about $700 million, in part because of new voter-mandated spending programs. But the state is also scrounging for a way to give about $1 billion back to taxpayers in voter-mandated refunds, which was deferred.
In the West, where taxing and spending by initiative has a strong tradition, the balancing act is particularly difficult.
"I wouldn't say voters are stupid," said Phil Talmadge, a former Washington Supreme Court judge and legislator. "But the same voter who wants unlimited services also does not want to pay for it. There's a disconnect."
Voter initiatives, Mr. Talmadge said, were created nearly a hundred years ago because people did not trust their legislators to act for the public good. But in recent years, such initiatives have grown in popularity and importance.
"What happened in the 1990's is that special interests decided it was a lot cheaper to buy initiatives than buy legislators," Mr. Talmadge said.
The result, he said, is that Democrats used the initiative process for new spending programs on education, health care and the environment, and Republicans used it to cut taxes or limit states' ability to raise taxes. Many voters punched yes for both sides.
"This puts us in somewhat of a civic death spiral," said Richard Davis, president of the Washington Research Council, a nonpartisan public policy research group in Seattle. "You give the voters an up or down without any nuance. They are reacting to a line item, and they never have to deliberate, as legislators do."
The message in the states where voters can basically do the job that elected officials were once primarily charged with doing, Mr. Davis said, "is not liberal or conservative -- it's reactive."
Others who have studied the initiative patterns agree.
"Where direct democracy becomes a more dominant force than representative government the result is a whipsaw, without any long-term coherence," said Brian Weberg, an official with the National Conference of State Legislatures.
People on both sides of the political spectrum say the system has gotten out of control. Lawmakers in some states have called for hearings on the initiative process. Still, these states with strong initiative powers have populist traditions, and lawmakers are loath to mess with the majority sentiment, however contradictory that can seem.
"Legislators don't want to do anything because it may be viewed as tinkering with the will of the people," said Daniel A. Smith, a professor of political science at the University of Denver.
Washington State legislators, for instance, now seem cowed by the initiative, Mr. Davis said. When people voted to cut the annual car- registration fee to a flat fee of $30 from $500 or more, depending on the year and model of the car, officials argued that the measure would increase the state's deficit. But when the State Supreme Court threw out the measure, legislators, with the aid of Gov. Gary Locke, a Democrat, resurrected the issue, made the $30 car-registration fee the law and said it was the will of the people.
Now Washington is struggling to finance road construction to ease Seattle's chronic traffic congestion. But legislative leaders from both parties say they are afraid to raise gasoline taxes to pay for new roads without first putting it to a vote of the people.
Here in Arizona, voters passed a 1992 constitutional amendment making it almost impossible for the Legislature to raise taxes. But in the late 1990's, during boom times, voters started mandating by initiative more money for health care and education.
To make sure state politicians got the message, voters passed another measure that said the lawmakers could not undo what the voters had just decided to do.
In the 2000 election, Arizona voters decided to raise the amount of money spent on schools every year. They also said lawmakers could not use school money for other purposes. But, several legislators say, the fund created for the schools does not have enough money to satisfy the law that says schools must be given a certain amount every year.
In part because of the dual mandates from voters, Arizona is now facing a deficit of up to $2 billion over this year and next. Washington's shortage is about $1.6 billion, and Colorado has a $700 million hill to climb.
"It's a mess," said Panfilo Contreras, executive director of the Arizona School Boards Association. "What's happening now is we're getting our comeuppance for what we've been doing over the last 10 years."
Mr. Contreras says voters realized that voting to restrict taxes and revenue 10 years ago was a mistake, because schools and health facilities in the state fell apart. Now the voters are more educated, he said, and are trying to undo piecemeal what they did earlier.
Others have a different interpretation, saying voters are inconsistent.
So Arizona legislators continue meeting here, now in their third special session over the last year, trying to figure out exactly what the voters intended while having to make large, unpopular cuts. Nearly 60 percent of the budget cannot be touched, under orders from the people.
"We have become somewhat of a Bypass Legislature state," said Francie Noyes, a spokeswoman for Gov. Jane Dee Hull, a Republican. "We have very little flexibility, particularly in hard times, to make budget decisions because of all the demands from voter initiatives."

HEADLINE: Chevrolet Sales Surpass Ford's For First Time In 10 Years 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 1 

 BODY:
Chevrolet outsold the Ford brand in February for the first month in more than a decade, industry figures showed today, further highlighting the resurgence of the General Motors Corporation and the struggles of the Ford Motor Company. 
 George Pipas, Ford's manager of industry sales analysis, said of G.M. during a conference call about February sales that "I would say congratulations if they've managed to pull that off." 
 He quickly added that Ford was not so concerned about its signature brand's trailing Chevrolet after the first two months of the year. 
"This is not Nascar," he said. "You don't get points for lap leadership. What counts is the end of the year." 
But in a city where every tenth of a percent of market share is agonized over every month, Ford's latest stumble was a significant milestone in the shifting competitive terrain.
"Does it drive Dearborn crazy? Absolutely," said Gerald Meyers, a professor at the University of Michigan and the former chief executive of American Motors, referring to Ford, which is based in Dearborn, Mich.
"They live that," he added. "The whole company lives the who's-on-top game."
Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director for global market and industry analysis, announced on his company's conference call that "Chevrolet won the gold medal."
G.M. appears determined to hold the line on its market share by driving up incentive costs while Ford and Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, are in weakened positions and are struggling to regain profitability.
G.M. said today that it would extend its aggressive $2,002 rebate offers through March and would bring back some of the interest-free financing deals that it offered at the end of last year.
Executives at both Ford and Chrysler have complained about the incentive battle, but the two companies have largely been forced to match the G.M. offers to stay competitive.
Today, Ford officials said that the company would extend its interest-free financing and its rebate offers and add bonuses of as much as $1,500 for customers who renew leases.
The incentives have been great news for consumers but have not helped the automakers' bottom lines. Last year, Ford lost $5.5 billion and Chrysler $1.9 billion; G.M. managed a net profit of $601 million. 
Even with the incentives, Ford and Chrysler have been pressed to stem eroding market shares. Last month, sales at G.M. rose by less than half a percent, but sales at Ford and Chrysler fell about 11 percent. G.M.'s market share rose to 31.2 percent from 29.9 percent in the month a year ago, while Ford's fell to 20.4 percent from 22.3 percent and Chrysler's fell to 14.8 percent from 16 percent. 
Over all, United States auto sales fell 3.4 percent but were better than expected, given the weak economy and the strong sales at this time last year. Some took the performance as an indication that the economy was improving.
"I guess the recession is milder and the hangover from zero percent financing is milder than expected," said David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities.
"Affordability has got to be a factor in there," he added. "Cars are cheaper relative to incomes than they ever have been, despite the recession."
Sales of foreign brands continue to keep the pressure on the Big Three. Sales at Toyota, the fourth-largest automaker in the American market, rose 1.7 percent in February from the month a year ago, though Honda sales fell 4.6 percent. Nissan sales rose 10.4 percent from last February, and sales of BMW rose 14 percent. 
Even so, the most significant news was symbolic. The Ford brand had not been surpassed in monthly sales since Chevrolet last beat it in July 1991, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank. Chevrolet's sales were up 4.4 percent, driven entirely by surging sales of big trucks like the Silverado and the Avalanche. For Chevrolet and G.M. in general, sales of passenger cars fell substantially but were offset by the company's pickups and sport utility vehicles. Sales of Ford's F-Series pickup were flat and sales of its sport utilities slowed. 
The looming question is how long Chevrolet can stay on top. 
"Ordinarily, I would say it's not sustainable, but these are not ordinary times," Mr. Meyers said. "G.M. is piling on now. I was really shocked to see them restore the zero percent financing. That's a real loser to the auto companies." 
"It's a battle best fought by people with deep pockets," he added. "Who's got deep pockets these days? Not Chrysler, not Ford, it's only G.M. now" among the Big Three.
G.M. also took a competitive poke at Ford in the bond market today when it raised $3.3 billion from the sale of 30-year bonds that can be converted into stock. The sale was smaller than the $5 billion Ford raised in a bond sale in January, but G.M. received a better price.
The offering was popular with investors, who bought more bonds than G.M. had originally intended to sell, said Fred Fiddle, a managing director at Merrill Lynch & Company, which co-managed the bond sale with Morgan Stanley. The success of the offering came as little surprise to Merrill's brokers. Word among them this week was that failure was not an option because Merrill's president, E. Stanley O'Neal, has a seat on G.M.'s board.

HEADLINE: If Not One Problem, It's Another, For the Struggling Giant Qwest 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Qwest Communications International continues to market itself to Wall Street as the model phone company of the future, but all that investors seem interested in is how the voice and data communications giant plans to survive the present. 
 Analysts see little chance of the kind of rapid plunge into bankruptcy that struck Enron, Global Crossing and other go-go companies of the late 1990's. But Qwest, based in Denver, faces a cash squeeze severe enough to have forced the company to draw down a $4 billion credit line with banks. The company is also confronting doubts about its growth prospects and a controversy over its accounting practices that has generated shareholder lawsuits. 
 Some investors were further unnerved when Qwest reported early last month that the Securities and Exchange Commission had subpoenaed records of its transactions with Global Crossing as part of the S.E.C.'s investigation of Global Crossing's accounting. Qwest's shares, which traded at $64.50 two years ago, closed Friday at $8.99. 
The slump in confidence in Qwest comes at a delicate time in its relations with state and federal regulators. Starting this spring with Arizona and Colorado, Qwest expects to begin seeking permission to enter the long-distance phone business in the 14-state Western region in which it is the dominant local phone company. 
The applications represent the culmination of a $3 billion effort to upgrade services and link competitors to the network that Qwest acquired in its takeover of the regional Bell company U S West in 2000. The investments were aimed at satisfying Section 271 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which barred U S West and the other regional Bells from offering long-distance service in their territories unless they could demonstrate that competitors had access to the local networks the Bells monopolized. 
Analysts say Qwest, which had revenue of $19.7 billion last year, could pick up another $1.5 billion to $2 billion by adding long-distance business in its region. It already markets long-distance service in 25 areas outside its territory. 
State regulators in Qwest's region say they are impressed that the company has raised a network once widely derided as "U S Worst" to the top of the rankings for many service standards tracked by the Federal Communications Commission. The regulators say that neither Qwest's financial health nor its accounting practices are factors in the Section 271 reviews. But Qwest is not counting on rivals to miss any chance to raise challenges that could impede the process. 
"This stuff is like an N.B.A. game," said Afshin Mohebbi, Qwest's president and chief operating officer. "There's much more contact under the basket than you can see from the stands." 
Qwest's effort to reassure Wall Street has become nearly a full-time job for Joseph P. Nacchio, its chief executive, who has been holding weekly conference calls with investors and analysts since mid-February to "answer all questions and clear all the rumors." 
Mr. Nacchio has also been traveling to private meetings with large investors, reviewing Qwest's health with credit agencies and participating in negotiations for new financial agreements with banks.
Qwest's assets include a global network of 190,000 miles of high-capacity optical fiber, as well as the nation's fourth-largest long-distance business and extensive Web site operating and Internet service businesses. But 25 million of Qwest's 30 million customers and 75 percent of its revenue last year came from the U S West region, which sprawls from the state of Washington to Minnesota and Arizona.
Many industry analysts endorse Qwest's belief that the winners in its industry will be hybrid companies that meld new-economy broadband services on a global scale with traditional local phone operations. As the economy has slowed, though, Wall Street has grown increasingly skeptical that Qwest will emerge as a pacesetter. 
Some analysts also say that Qwest has vastly overestimated the earnings potential of the empire it borrowed so heavily to build. The most pessimistic say the telecommunications industry is destined for the kind of chronic overcapacity that has produced decades of losses in the capital-intensive steel industry. 
"The math of many business models simply does not work," Scott C. Clelland, an analyst at the Precursor Group in Washington, wrote in a recent report. 
Mr. Clelland said that Qwest was not in immediate danger of failing like numerous smaller communications companies but that it was too small to survive on its own in the long run. Despite the drop in its stock price, however, Qwest has too much debt to attract a suitor in the current economic climate, he said.
Most of the decline in Qwest's share price came last year as the telecommunications sector was tanking, but the 36.4 percent drop since the beginning of this year indicates that Qwest's credibility has dropped to new lows. 
"Enough is enough," said Blaine Marder, a portfolio manager for Iridian Asset Management in Westport, Conn. Iridian owned 7.1 million Qwest shares at the end of 2001, but sold the last of its holdings early last month. 
Part of the problem involves accounting procedures and transactions that have undermined faith in Qwest's reported sales, expense and profit figures. Qwest says it has adhered to generally accepted accounting principles. But some investors find less comfort than they used to from such explanations because Wall Street had heard the same claims from companies like Enron and Global Crossing.
For many investors, though, the most disturbing development came in mid-February, when reports emerged that Qwest was having trouble borrowing in the commercial paper markets. Those markets, in which companies sell interest-bearing notes for periods ranging from a few days to a few months to institutions like money market funds, are a major source of flexible, relatively low-cost cash. 
Ultimately, Qwest exited the commercial paper market and drew down its $4 billion credit line with banks. It was a stop-gap measure that put off a financial reckoning for a few months, but credit agencies responded by slicing the rating on its bonds to near junk status. 
Mr. Nacchio said yesterday that if no steps were taken to improve the balance sheet, the company would be in violation of its agreements with banks by the end of June. But, he said, Qwest is renegotiating those agreements, and, in any event, has numerous actions in progress to prevent such a default, reverse the most recent cut in the company's credit rating and re-enter the commercial paper market.
He said the company was considering raising $500 million to $1 billion by packaging receivables as securities that could be sold to investors. Qwest had previously said it might raise $1.25 billion by selling short-term bonds that automatically convert into stock -- so-called equity-linked securities. Other assets on the market include Qwest's highly profitable Yellow Pages business, which had revenue of $1.6 billion last year, and some rural phone lines that Qwest says may be attractive to small phone companies that are eligible for federal subsidies.
While Qwest might sell these assets, it could meet its financial needs by selling as little as half of any one of them, Mr. Mohebbi said. "We feel we are in a position to dictate terms," he said.

HEADLINE: Damning (Yet Desiring) Mickey and the Big Mac 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
"Why do they hate us?" One answer to that now familiar question may be its opposite: "Why do they love us?"
 American popular culture, American film, American pop music, American fast food and American television manage to inspire both love and hate, as if the two passions were inseparable parts of a single whole, evoking the video image last fall of Osama bin Laden wearing what appeared to be a Timex Ironman Triathlon watch. So while the Taliban tried to quash the cultural influences of the West -- hanging televisions from trees like electronic corpses -- Afghan women were risking their lives by secretly going to Western-style beauty parlors. 
 One explanation for this repulsion and attraction has become fairly common: American popular culture is capitalist culture. In capitalism commodities are produced that will spur desire for still more commodities. Capitalism seduces through sheer force of marketing and sheer promise of pleasure. What fundamentalist society would not be horrified by the ways in which traditions and rituals are subsumed by the filthy lucre of the marketplace? 
This view of popular culture has a long heritage. In "The Communist Manifesto" Marx and Engels described capitalism as intrinsically unsettling, disrupting social conditions, creating "everlasting uncertainty and agitation." Attacks by intellectuals on popular culture in the 1940's and 50's expanded this view. In 1953 Dwight Macdonald wrote in his famous essay "A Theory of Mass Culture" that mass culture was "imposed from above," that it created "passive consumers." 
"Like 19th-century capitalism," Macdonald wrote, "Mass Culture is a dynamic, revolutionary force, breaking down the old barriers of class, tradition, taste, and dissolving all cultural distinctions." It is a kind of cultural indenture imposed by what he called the "Lords of kitsch." The philosopher Theodor Adorno also argued that mass culture was an instrument of oppressive power. He believed that it had a totalitarian dimension; television, he said in a 1954 essay, was "a medium of undreamed-of psychological control." 
Those ideas have now become unquestioned axioms, elaborated on by other critics and analysts. Oddly, those views are also not that far from what Islamic fundamentalists themselves believe, or, for that matter, what the antiglobalization activists believe: pop culture succeeds because it is imperialist. 
The problem is that these images of passive victims of the capitalist maw, enthralled by a cavalcade of meaningless commodities, bears very little relationship to most people's experiences and does little to explain the allure of popular culture. The connection between popular culture and capitalism is hardly as definite as it may seem. As the sociologist Daniel Bell has pointed out, traditional capitalism, with its requirements for restraint and planning, is not easily reconciled with the unbounded desires and ambitions of popular culture. Capitalism has changed in response to culture just as culture has changed in response to capitalism. 
In addition, acceptance of capitalism does not require acceptance of popular culture. Fundamentalist governments and nondemocratic countries like China may seek the prosperity created by modified capitalism without changing their views of American cultural influence; capitalist France and Canada have, at different times, made cultural resistance national policy. 
So capitalism offers limited explanations. More powerful influences shape culture. Alexis de Tocqueville, for example, argued in "Democracy in America" that there was a fundamental difference between the artistic culture of an aristocracy and that of a democracy. In an aristocracy, members of the nobility form a small class with fixed interests, inspiring a uniform style among artisans and creators. Attention is paid to detailed craftsmanship, and artistry is a form of service.
But in a democracy, Tocqueville said, there are no restrictions of class or guild on either artisans or their public. Styles are less firmly defined; social arrangements are more fluid; human aspirations vary widely. So artisans offer what Tocqueville called "imperfect satisfaction" for diverse audiences rather than perfection for the few. Tocqueville also accurately anticipated the nature of pop culture: democracy, he wrote, shifts the preoccupation of art from the soul to the body, from the ideal to the real. 
Similar characteristics were described by John Stuart Mill in "On Liberty" as he heralded the growth of liberal culture. With equality and mobility, he wrote, citizens "now read the same things, listen to the same things, go to the same places, have their hopes and fears directed to the same objects, have the same rights and liberties, and the same means of asserting them." 
With this expansion of attention to the same things and places, commercial culture has also become more vital. Marshall McLuhan once recalled in a 1947 essay an American Army officer's pondering the difficulty of democratizing fascist Italy after World War II. "Democratic freedom," the officer argued, with tongue partly in cheek, required not worrying about politics but "worrying about the means of defeating underarm odor, scaly scalp, hairy legs, dull complexion, unruly hair, borderline anemia, athlete's foot, and sluggish bowels." Once relieved of concerns about caste and material need, the individual is free to address other issues.
McLuhan argued that these material concerns were not to be condemned. Rather, the "luxuriant and prurient chaos of human passions," he wrote, are unavoidable. These passions were acknowledged by the American founding fathers, McLuhan said, and the recognition of those desires helped shape both the realism and the utopianism of American culture. 
So American popular culture offers a powerful promise. Luxuriant and prurient passions are partially satisfied; desires for autonomy are offered fulfillment; material pleasures and possibilities become palpable. Choices are freely made. Who can resist such a siren song? But there is a cost to this shedding of restrictions; there is something inherently disruptive about popular culture. It undermines the elite values of aristocratic art, displaces the customs of folk culture and opposes any limitation on art's audiences or subjects. It asserts egalitarian tastes, encourages dissent and does not shun desire. 
"Mass Culture," Dwight Macdonald wrote, "is very, very democratic: it absolutely refuses to discriminate against, or between, anything or anybody." This is also a reason for intellectuals' fear of its onslaught. As the art critic Clement Greenberg pointed out in the 1940's when these issues first reared their heads, "all the verities involved by religion, authority, tradition, style, are thrown into question." With the coming of "universal literacy," he argued, came a debased form of art: kitsch. And kitsch, he uncannily observed, was going "on a triumphal tour of the world," creating what he called "the first universal culture ever beheld." 
This is even more true now than it was a half-century ago. Popular culture has become the standard-bearer for modernity, heralding its transformations. But for fundamentalists and many terrorists, that is the very problem. Even among mainstream intellectuals, some effects of popular culture are scorned. Popular culture may be hailed by left-wing critics for its liberating energy, but it is also condemned by others as an opiate; among conservatives, it is feared for its nihilistic influence on tastes and morals. 
What then, if anything, can or should be done, since the triumph of popular culture seems so inseparable from the virtues of democratic culture? Is there any way both to promise liberty and the pursuit of happiness while preserving some discrimination among desires and differences among cultures? Or are disgust and desire doomed to be intertwined? Answers are not likely to appease Islamic totalitarianism, but they are increasingly important for the evolution of American democracy and culture.

HEADLINE: State Department Post for Cheney Daughter 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1 

 BODY:
Liz Cheney, daughter of Vice President Dick Cheney, will start work at the State Department within weeks as a deputy assistant secretary of state in the Near East bureau, the agency's spokesman said today. 
 The spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said she would have an economic portfolio, which another United States official described as a mandate to promote economic liberalization and American trade and investment in the region. 
 Deputy assistant secretaries typically enter an executive corps distinct from most federal employees. According to government Web sites, the positions pay between $126,000 and $138,000 a year to workers based in Washington.
Mr. Boucher said Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had known Ms. Cheney for some time and that she was a "very highly skilled individual" who would bring important talents to the post, which had been vacant for more than a year.
"We're delighted to have Ms. Cheney join our team," Mr. Boucher said. "She brings a very strong legal and economic background to her new position, having previously served with both the private and government sectors, including with U.S.A.I.D. and the Department of State," Mr. Boucher said.
The United States Agency for International Development manages American aid programs abroad.

HEADLINE: Steel's 40 Percent Solution 

BYLINE:  By Barbara A. Mikulski; Senator Barbara A. Mikulski is a Democrat from Maryland.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
President George W. Bush faces an important choice on steel. He can act to level the playing field for American steel producers and workers. Or he can allow years of unfair foreign trade to destroy a critical domestic industry.
 Our nation's steel industry is in crisis. In the past four years, 31 companies have gone under, tens of thousands of workers have lost their jobs and hundreds of thousands of retirees may be in danger of losing their health benefits. 
 But this crisis goes beyond the realms of jobs and community. The industry is critical to our nation's defense. As President Bush told steelworkers last year: "Steel is an important job issue. It's also an important national security issue."
The cause of the current crisis is well known. In the words of Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans: "For over 50 years, foreign government intervention and foreign government subsidies have distorted the market for steel." The Russian government, for example, keeps approximately 1,000 unprofitable steel plants open through subsidies. And South Korea has nearly doubled its production capacity since 1990 -- without the domestic demand to support the increase. Altogether, millions of tons of foreign steel are dumped -- sold below production costs -- in the United States every year to keep such foreign mills in business. Last year, the United States imported 30 million tons of steel -- 24 percent of the steel we used -- from Russia, Japan, Brazil and Korea. In October, the United States International Trade Commission, an independent federal advisory group, unanimously found that America's steel industry has been substantially injured by increased imports.
A 40 percent tariff on a broad range of steel imports would give American producers a fighting chance. Indeed, without such a tariff, the remaining American steel companies won't have the breathing room they need to start consolidating instead of liquidating or laying off workers.
Right now, American steel companies and their employees are doing what it takes to be competitive. Companies have closed down inefficient mills and invested in new technology. Many mills -- such as Sparrows Point near Baltimore -- are among the most efficient in the world. Steelworkers, meanwhile, have made painful concessions in their contracts. Many have lost jobs as the industry has become more labor-efficient.
But none of this will matter if the American market continues to be a dumping ground for foreign steel. Now Washington must do its part.
President Bush rightly said that when steel is threatened, our economy and our national security are both threatened. American steel built the railroads and bridges that keep our country connected. Steel built our cities. And during World War II and the Vietnam War, American steel rolled out gun barrels, produced steel for grenades and supplied the shipyards that built the American fighting fleet. 
But saving the steel industry is not just an exercise in nostalgia. Most recently, Bethlehem Steel produced the armor to repair the U.S.S. Cole. As the war on terrorism continues, the industry may again be called on to contribute to our national defense. At times of war or national emergency, we can't afford to be vulnerable to the whims of foreign suppliers.
A 40 percent tariff will not only support our national security. It will also protect the welfare of our steelworkers. More than a million Americans -- active and retired steelworkers and their families -- depend on this industry for their livelihoods, pensions and health care. If President Bush will act now to stop the dumping, we can better secure the future of these workers and retirees.
I am not a fan of trade barriers. But opening up trade shouldn't be an excuse for destroying a basic American industry. Rarely has a case for tariffs been so clear cut. The usual rhetoric of "free" and "fair" trade is meaningless when some of our trading partners aren't playing by the same rules. American steel needs help now.

HEADLINE: Cigarette Tax Would Cost State Millions, Critic Says 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
Topping the list of things Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is asking for from Albany this year is permission to raise the cigarette tax to $1.50 a pack, a budget-balancing measure that the city is touting as pain-free for the state. But one budget critic, citing the city's own estimates, says the measure could cost the state more than $200 million in lost revenue.
 According to the city's estimates, the tax increase would raise $249 million even as it caused sales to drop by 165 million packs, or nearly 50 percent. That would cost the state, which also taxes cigarettes, $247.5 million; the loss could be partly made up if people went to other parts of the state, instead of, say, New Jersey, to buy their cigarettes. 
 "It illustrates the folly of simultaneously treating tobacco as a public health nuisance and a public finance treasure chest," said E. J. McMahon, a senior fellow of the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research group.
But the city defends its proposal. "Any loss of revenue by the state would be outweighed by lower health care costs brought on by a reduction in smoking-related illnesses," said Jordan Barowitz, a spokesman for the mayor. "The mayor has said he'd love to see the revenue on this tax go flat, to zero."
Part of the problem, Mr. McMahon says, is that both the city and the state are turning to the tobacco trough in these lean economic times. The city, which now levies a tax of 8 cents a pack, and the state, which takes $1.11, are each proposing to increase their tax to $1.50 a pack, the highest levy in the country. A pack of cigarettes in the city now costs about $5, including taxes. 
In the city, the proposed cigarette tax increase would take care of a large chunk of the $800 million in new money or taxing authority that Mr. Bloomberg says he needs from the state and federal governments to help close his budget gap. But state senators and some in the Pataki administration are already expressing concern that the cigarette market may be unable to sustain a sharp tax increase on both the state and local levels, an official in the Republican-led Senate said.
Spokesmen for the governor and both houses of the State Legislature said they had not yet analyzed the effects a city tax increase would have on the state. 
Gov. George E. Pataki's budget, written before the city's, projects that the state's tax increase on cigarettes would raise an extra $250 million that Mr. Pataki says is needed to pay for an expansion of health care. The projected drop in sales in the city, which currently accounts for 40 percent of cigarette sales statewide, could wipe out much of that increase.
Mr. McMahon and tobacco company spokesmen say that city smokers have many ways to avoid paying the taxes without smoking less.
"If you can go to New Jersey or to Connecticut or to an Indian reservation or to the Internet and buy it for three and a half bucks a pack less, which is $35 a carton, you have to think that people are going to consider that," said Tommy Payne, vice president for external relations at R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
Mr. Barowitz, the mayor's spokesman, was unable to say how much of the projected drop in sales would be attributable to an actual drop in consumption. A "small amount" of that drop would be accounted for by people buying their cigarettes elsewhere, he said.
Mr. McMahon warned that there might be other unforeseen consequences of the tax, like a sharp increase in bootlegging.
Illegal sales might also increase the availability of cigarettes to children, Mr. McMahon said, and the tax would hurt bodegas and other small businesses, where cigarette sales can account for more than a third of sales. 
The Manhattan Institute receives a small amount of its financing, less than 1 percent, from the tobacco industry, Mr. McMahon said, adding that the industry had nothing to do with this study.
Anti-tobacco advocates still favor the tax increase as a way to discourage smoking, saying enforcement against smuggling should be increased.

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine; Pg. 53

LENGTH: 2112 words

HEADLINE: CELEBRATION; 
Chicago

BYLINE:  By Stephen McCauley; Stephen McCauley's most recent novel is "True Enough" (Simon & Schuster).

 BODY:
When Chicago rose from the ashes of its devastating 1871 fire, architects flocked there to help rebuild and, ultimately, gave birth to the skyscraper. Although it's no longer America's second city (in 1984, Los Angeles surpassed it in population), Chicago is still one of the nation's most vibrant urban centers. But what else would you expect from the city that nurtured the invention of the zipper and the Hostess Twinkie?

THE MOOD
 A few hours before my arrival in Chicago, a spell of unseasonably warm and clear December weather was shoved out of town by a front that had come bullying across the Great Plains. The airplane descended slowly through what felt like miles of cloud cover, and the little I could see of the city had been drained of color. The desk clerk at my hotel gave me the weather report: cold drizzle, brisk winds and short, dark afternoons. "I'm afraid there's no improvement in the forecast," she said. 
 Her distress on my behalf was convincing, and her comment sounded so genuinely apologetic, I felt obliged to feign disappointment and bury my delight in the news that the sun was unlikely to shine.
Famous for its corrupt politicians, gangsters and stockyards -- and for Oprah Winfrey -- Chicago is currently in the eye of a storm of economic prosperity and urban revitalization. Buildings are going up everywhere you look. Cranes compete with the John Hancock Center and other soaring landmarks for a place on the skyline, and in many of the neighborhoods that branch off the Loop, the city's business and financial core, the pockmarks of urban blight are being plugged with high-end town houses. 
Mayor Richard M. Daley (that's Daley fils, for those losing track of American political dynasties) has pledged to make the city the greenest in the country, in both the political and the botanical sense. To that end, he has overseen the planting of a quarter of a million trees, bisected major boulevards with median strips spilling over with prairie grasses and colorful blooms and pledged to have the city using renewable sources for 20 percent of its energy needs within five years. A heat-absorbing, oxygen-producing garden has been installed on the roof of city hall.
There's hardly a neighborhood in this sprawling metropolis in which you don't see some sign of continuing beautification, artistic endeavor or community pride (for example, the rainbow-ringed sculptures placed by the city along the section of Halsted Street that runs through the largely gay-inhabited part of town).
And yet, on mild, cloudless days, the city is, to my way of thinking, still too bright, too brawny and, to borrow from Carl Sandburg, too big-shouldered. Sharp sunlight reflecting off all the glass and steel of the whole spectacular skyline can be blinding. In a sunny Chicago, it's easy to feel, like Dreiser's Sister Carrie, "a sense of helplessness amid so much evidence of power and force." If you try to escape by heading to the shore of Lake Michigan (Chicago boasts 29 miles of shoreline), the glistening aquamarine waters and white beaches can induce confusion by tricking you into believing you're closer to the Caribbean than to the American heartland.
In inclement weather, it's a world transformed, and, like a gloomy Venice or a snowy Montreal, one I find agreeable. Clouds lower the Chicago sky, caress and obscure the tops of the dizzyingly high buildings. Fog shrinks the city down to a more human scale. Rain encourages you to go inside the magnificent buildings of Louis Sullivan, Daniel Burnham, Frank Lloyd Wright and other signature American architects for a close-up look at the details of their interiors. There are, to name only a few, the Tiffany mosaics in the Marquette Building, the sleek Art Deco elevators, clocks and walkways in the lobby of the Chicago Board of Trade and the curved oak paneling and British Arts and Crafts fixtures of the Glessner House, a residence designed by H.H. Richardson in the Prairie Avenue district, south of the Loop.
To seek shelter from gusts of icy wind, you might wander into one of the lesser-known museums: the small and inviting Terra Museum of American Art along the Magnificent Mile, an important shopping street; the International Museum of Surgical Science, where you'll learn about trephination and gallstones; the National Vietnam Veterans Art Museum, with its moving collection of war-themed paintings, sculpture and photography by Vietnam veterans.
If you're less lucky than I was, and are dealt a rare string of lovely days, you can always find a shady spot in the French-Renaissance-styled Grant Park or elsewhere in this increasingly verdant city. But here's my advice: pray for rain.

THE FOOD
Chicago is a magnet for conventions. On my most recent visit, the city was host to more than 60,000 radiologists from around the world, a smaller group of plastic surgeons and members of the Plumbing Manufacturers Institute. The Hotel Inter-Continental Chicago, one of two hotels where I stayed, was overrun with name-tagged people speaking in a variety of languages and accents. Whether they were strolling past the tiled fountain in the hotel's Spanish Tea Court (the Inter-Continental was built in the 1920's to house the Shriners' Medinah Athletic Club and is a treasure-trove of eccentric ornamentation), sitting by the romantically lighted pool on the 13th floor where Johnny Weissmuller trained or waiting for the arrival of an elevator, they all seemed to be discussing food. I heard graphic accounts of immense steak dinners featuring Midwestern beef of legendary tenderness, the particulars of Chicago-style barbecue and, for nearly 10 minutes, the heart-stopping wonders of Chicago's infamous multilayered, sausage-packed deep-dish pizza.
Chicago institutions like the Berghoff (a German restaurant) and the Pump Room satisfy the carnivorous needs of even the hungriest conventioneers.
If you prefer lighter fare, or if, like me, you made the mistake of preparing for your trip by rereading the most lurid sections of "The Jungle," Upton Sinclair's expose of the Chicago meatpacking industry at the turn of the last century, there are plenty of other options.
Along West Randolph Street, just across the river from the Loop, you'll find a handful of stylish new restaurants tucked between warehouses and loading docks. The most striking is Blackbird. The decor could be more minimalist only if they figured out a way to do without tables and chairs. Here, the culinary offerings feature heirloom everything, local and organic in most cases, and intriguing juxtapositions of sweet and savory, as in a superb appetizer I had of Maine scallops, caramelized celery root and honey-thyme butter. There was plenty of meat on the menu (pork belly, venison, New York strip steak), but also a delicious gateau of sweet potato and cornmeal, flavored with wild mushrooms and caramelized greens.
A little farther afield, in the Wicker Park neighborhood north of downtown, is Mas, a warm, loud restaurant with golden walls and curtains made of beaded glass. Mas plays with "nuevo Latino" cooking, smashing together Brazilian, Cuban and Mexican influences to create some of the tastiest food I ate in Chicago. I had a fantastic seviche of bluefish and scallops marinated in a blend of citrus juices and a taco of grilled tuna, chopped papaya and rosemary and Dijon salsa. Each dish had a distinctive flavor that was exhilarating. Although, to be honest, my enthusiasm might have been unfairly stoked by a sampling of the restaurant's outstanding nuevo Latino cocktails: limey caipirinhas from Brazil and mint-infused Cuban mojitos. To name two I recall. Barely. But fondly.
Long before the neon mayhem of shopping-mall food courts, Marshall Field's department store was a cathedral to consumer goods where you could shop, eat and be merry all day long. 
The interior of the main store on State Street remains impressive, with a Tiffany dome made of 1.6 million pieces of iridescent glass. The grandest of several in-house restaurants is the Walnut Room on the seventh floor.
The day I was there, the Walnut Room was sparsely populated by women with shopping bags and hairdos who sat chatting in hushed tones while a small army of tuxedoed waiters and waitresses padded back and forth across acres of carpeting shouldering silver trays loaded down with covered dishes. As for what was under those covers, the less said, the better. The pleasures of the Walnut Room have little to do with its bland food and everything to do with its dark paneled walls and heavy drapes, and its atmosphere of carefully preserved tradition. You could easily imagine a Dreiser character eating here or, more likely, working in the kitchen.
I left satisfied that I'd had a genuine old-Chicago experience and hungry enough to hunt down one of the city's gut-busting pizzas.

THE STYLE
Across the street from Marshall Field's is the Reliance Building, an architectural landmark that was completed in 1895 by the firm of Burnham & Root. An ancestor of the modern skyscraper, the building has a steel-frame construction that allowed for its then-impressive height, 14 stories, and wall-to-wall windows. It is slim, light and modern in appearance, a marked contrast to many of its burly contemporaries. After decades of neglect, the city refurbished the exterior in the early 1990's, and a hotel company spent tens of millions of dollars restoring the interior. Now, the Reliance is home to the 122-room Hotel Burnham.
When I walked into the lobby and saw the mosaic-tile floor, multicolored marble walls and metal elevator grills, I braced myself. The Burnham is exactly the kind of high-fashion boutique hotel in which you'd expect a staff of hyperhip personnel, trained in the art of subtle condescension.
Not in Chicago. The desk clerk apologized for the weather, offered me a piece of candy and praised a pair of $5 gloves I'd bought at Filene's Basement the day before. This was the first of many encounters I had with outgoing, unaffected Chicago friendliness, a personal style that's distinctly different from the chilly reserve you find on one coast and the invasive chattiness you find on the other. ("We're the anti-California," a friend said of the city she's called home for 25 years.) On the whole, you get the feeling that Chicagoans are too self-possessed and uninterested in pretension -- too authentically cool, you might say -- to worry about being hip.
Like Chicago-style jazz, this open, down-to-earth spirit seems to have migrated north from the Mississippi Delta. Call it Southern manners filtered through urban immediacy, Midwestern pragmatism and immigrant enthusiasm. (Rumor or urban legend has it that at one time there were more Poles living in Chicago than in Warsaw. That might never have been strictly true, but the culture of the city is an amalgam of influences from all over Europe, the United States and, these days, Latin America.)
You run into it everywhere: in the art galleries scattered throughout the River North section of the city; in jazz clubs like the funky Checkerboard Lounge on the South Side or the Green Mill Cocktail Lounge to the north, a crowded, smoky club that's been around for almost 100 years and wears its age proudly.
You see it in the city's hard-working and inventive theater scene. The week I was in town, there were dozens of theatrical offerings, everything from Shakespeare and Sondheim to "H2O." This last was a play at the Neo-Futurarium, a theater above a funeral parlor in the Andersonville neighborhood. For an hour and a half, three actors commented on romantic relationships by alternately drinking water and tossing it at each other, all with a level of commitment and sincerity that banished the faint whiff of ancien avant-garde.
On my last morning in Chicago, the sun finally appeared, timidly at first, and then full force, banishing the fog and clearing out the sky. With only a couple of hours left, I went to the Hancock Center's observatory.
Looking east, you see the lake, shining and imponderably wide, and to the west, the flat expanse of endless sprawl. In between is the heart of the city with its lofty, jagged buildings. Some, like the curved 333 Wacker Drive, are graceful, almost sensuous. Others, like the Sears Tower, are merely assertive. 
But taken together, they create an urban landscape that is hypnotic in its variety and complexity.
These days, standing atop tall buildings isn't quite the giddy thrill it used to be, and I was told that since early September, crowds had been on the thin side. But somehow, in Chicago, it's easy to feel as if you have your feet planted firmly on the ground, even when you're standing on the 94th floor.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 18

HEADLINE: And Bear In Mind 

 BODY:
 (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

AMERICA'S FIRST DYNASTY: The Adamses, 1735-1918, by Richard Brookhiser. (Free Press, $25.) A succinct, skillful account of the lives of John, John Quincy, Charles Francis and Henry, four generations of men often brilliant but often shortsighted as well: two presidents, one diplomat and, finally, a historian who felt he had failed the ancestors.

THE FUTURE OF LIFE, by Edward O. Wilson. (Knopf, $22.) This distinguished biologist proposes that there is yet time to avoid a grand planetary environmental crash provided we get serious, acknowledge a duty of stewardship and recognize an emotional affiliation (biophilia, as he calls it) with other kinds of life.

BLOOD-DARK TRACK: A Family History, by Joseph O'Neill. (Granta, $27.95.) A smart, diligent inquiry into the World War II era and the (possibly culpable) activities of the author's grandfathers, one a Turk interned by the British in Palestine, the other an I.R.A. officer, perhaps a murderer.

FINGERSMITH, by Sarah Waters. (Riverhead, $25.95.) A fine Gothic ear is part of Waters's kit in this neo-Dickensian tale of a baby farmer and a foundling who is drawn into a fearful sexual intimacy as part of a scheme to defraud an heiress.

GRACEFULLY INSANE: The Rise and Fall of America's Premier Mental Hospital, by Alex Beam. (PublicAffairs, $26.) In its putatively mind-healthy bucolic setting, McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass., sheltered the well-born and the articulate bewildered for a couple of centuries; this entertaining narrative is short on the real desolation of mental illness but copious as to anecdote and changing clinical fashions.

ENEMY WOMEN, by Paulette Jiles. (Morrow, $24.95.) Love crosses the lines in this Civil War novel set in dubious Missouri, where an 18-year-old spitfire of rebel attachments is the prisoner of a Union officer whose interrogation of her turns into a prison romance.

SALT: A World History, by Mark Kurlansky. (Walker, $28.) There's more to salt than everybody knows; without it, people can't live. It's cheap now, and many people get too much, but that wasn't always so; Kurlansky gives the economic, political, chemical and industrial story of a substance once so valuable that "salary" is named for it.

HOUSE OF WOMEN, by Lynn Freed. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) Fairy-tale elements prevail in this novel in which a mother and a daughter fight to the death; Nalia, an opera singer and Holocaust survivor, reigns over Thea, who is quasi-abducted by a Bluebeardish Syrian in a narrative full of dream logic, psychoanalysis and the writing of journals for others to read.

A LIFE IN PIECES: The Making and Unmaking of Binjamin Wilkomirski, by Blake Eskin. (Norton, $25.95.) In 1997, Wilkomirski's "Fragments" was much admired as a masterpiece of Holocaust writing; since then, both author and book have faded into fraudulence. Eskin's research now illuminates not the Holocaust but the fantasy life of a disturbed young man with an unhappy childhood whose real name Eskin himself is not altogether sure of.

GRAPHIC: Photos (Jeanne Strongin; Lisa Klausner)
