HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Ethical Quandaries, Pivotal Boundaries

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
AS Italians say at election time, piazza pulita! -- let's clean up the square! The clearing of ground zero has proceeded much faster than expected, and it is not too soon to think about cleaning up the politics of redeveloping the site. Indeed, the 16-acre property is now a zone of convergence for our top two national crises: 9/11 and Enron. Architecture is a cultural medium in which this convergence will be conspicuously manifested.
 Secrecy and accountability: these are the two issues the convergence has raised. They are, of course, at odds. The status quo relies on secrecy to retain and enlarge power. ("Trust us; we're reliable.") In this sense, the climate of emergency fostered by the war on terrorism has been a godsend for every status quo. ("Certain things we can't talk about.") By the same token, the collapse of Enron threatens every status quo. It exposes secrecy as the currency that enables people and institutions to evade responsibility for their actions. 
 How much accountability can we stand? How willing or eager are we to be kept in the dark? How much ethical compromise does it take to keep the world from falling apart? And who gets to arbitrate such contentious issues, particularly in the cultural sphere? Like it or not, ground zero has become a theater where these questions will be played out. 
Over time, writers will probe every facet of the political, cultural and economic forces now jostling over places on the stage. For now, it may suffice to say: We are watching you! History will be judging you! If decisionmakers treat this project as no more than a local exercise in economic development, goosed up by fatuous public relations, they will be weighed in the scales and found wanting, for as long as history sustains a regard for truth.
In fact, the moving hand has already begun to inscribe some fairly lurid writing on the walls. Within days of the terrorist attacks, as the recovery of bodies from the towering wreckage was barely under way, ground zero was officially declared a construction site. This declaration was the direct cause of the scuffle between police officers and firefighters in November, when the latter group sought access to the ground where many of their colleagues had lost their lives.
This wasn't just a technicality. It announced not only that construction would go forward, but also that the site was officially privatized. You and I and the entire rest of the world might suppose that, by dint of cataclysm, we all might have a stake in this piece of property, but that was our problem. Rudolph Giuliani had declared that we must think like capitalists, not communists. Take that, comrades!
Obnoxious as the mayor's statement was, at least it placed the city on notice that a giant cash register had already materialized within the smoke. Why bother with a design competition? We could just build four stretch versions of the iconic National Cash Register Pavilion from the 1939 World's Fair. Nice Art Deco lines. Reduced to miniature size, it would make a fine piggy-bank souvenir. Ka-ching!
The acceptance of ground zero as a construction site began filtering into the media when the observation platform went up on Trinity Place. Visitors to ground zero deserved "something more than" a construction site, it was said. Never mind that no one was actually going there to see something they didn't even recognize as a construction site. Never mind that building construction is one of the great spectacles of Manhattan, or that few buildings are even remotely as interesting when completed as they are in construction. Usually, "something more" turns out to be immensely less.
In any case, as conceived by its designers, the platform was never intended for conventional sidewalk superintendents. It was meant to offer a vantage point on history, as it unfolded in real time. That history included the buildings that had stood there, among them those before the Twin Towers were built; the towers themselves and their destruction; the spectacle of clearing the site; fantasies about its future; and the hardening of fantasy into implementation. Above all, what people wanted to see was a site of military aggression. Not a battlefield, perhaps, but certainly a field of slaughter. (In fact, members of the Architectural History Foundation have proposed that Congress declare ground zero a historic battlefield and place it under federal supervision, whether or not it is commercially developed.)
Metaphorically, the platform serves the ideal of public oversight: the idea that public officials should be held accountable for their actions. By extension, the design signifies the idea that the public should be more assertive in holding officials accountable. Oversight, we should keep in mind, is not a passive occupation but a means of engaging with power.
Other commentators accused the platform of converting ground zero into a tourist attraction, as if it were a ride at Disney World. This remark should not be casually dismissed. In fact, it touches on a deeper truth than the commentators may have realized. The relationship between warfare and tourism is one of the open secrets of modern life. It was the topic of "Back to the Front: Tourisms of War," a 1994 book edited by two of the platform's designers, Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, who have been exploring the subject for years.
The development of battle sites as tourist attractions; the dependence of tourism on technology invented for military purposes; the similarity of war and tourism as instruments for the penetration of national borders: "See the World." See the World Trade Center. Architecture is not just the visual forms of buildings but also the cultural relationships they reflect.
In short, criticisms of the platform have degraded history, language and thought. Or, rather, they reflect the degree to which thought is routinely degraded by market values. This is not the same as economic corruption. And we would all naturally go into hiding should Congress open hearings on the corruption of ideas. Nonetheless, for those who haven't given up hope that the redevelopment of lower Manhattan will rise to a sense of historical occasion, cultural corruption is not a minor detail.
Real estate speculation in New York is governed by a concept called the "public-private partnership." In forthcoming columns, I will examine the workings of this concept as it applies to ground zero and to the agencies, private firms and civic and professional groups involved with the decisionmaking process. Here, I'll confine myself to sketching its general contour.
Public-private partnerships are an outgrowth of privatization. Typically, the private sector provides planning and design services along with capital investment. The public sector provides permits and assists with land acquisition and zoning interpretation. It may also require developers to provide improvements in the public interest, including parks and recreational areas; remodeled subway stations; and community centers, health clinics and other nonprofit services.
The public-private partnership has replaced the centralized model of city planning adopted during the Depression, and is generally regarded as an improvement on that model, or at least as less likely to produce the homogeneous, towers-in-a-park formula associated with low-income housing projects that proliferated in the postwar decades. It has been embraced here as an example of the so-called "third way," through which the public sector seeks to unburden itself from the costs and defects of the welfare state by elevating the social responsibility of private enterprise.
BATTERY PARK CITY and the redevelopment of 42nd Street are especially ambitious examples of public-private partnerships, though the concept is routinely applied as well in the development of individual buildings, including the future headquarters of The New York Times. It's fair to say that the concept is as good as the ideas driving its particular application. Its greatest strength, perhaps, is its capacity to try out new ideas -- to take risks and to learn from shortcomings as they materialize. Its greatest weakness is its tendency to curb public oversight by restricting access to the decisionmaking process.
By virtue of the powers invested in the newly created Lower Manhattan Development Authority, the rebuilding of the financial district will be the most important public-private development partnership in the city's history. Its domain is not limited to ground zero, but penetrates into surrounding neighborhoods as far north as Chambers Street. Quite apart from the historical magnitude of the events that led to its creation, the Authority has the power to transform the public face of Manhattan for future generations.
What ideas, if any, will drive the transformation? Where will the ideas come from? How and why will some ideas come to be preferred over others? And who will hold the decisionmakers accountable? To what extent, and in what form, should public oversight penetrate behind closed doors?
The pivotal issue here is that of boundaries. A public-private partnership is an economic and cultural ecotone -- an area of overlap between the public and private spheres. In nature, an ecotone can support life forms not found in its adjacent ecosystems. It can develop vibrant new structures of life. An ecotone may also foster new species of predators, however, including some with remarkable camouflage. In architecture, as in power companies, their eating habits deserve close observation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A symbol that haunts plans for the reconstruction of ground zero: the National Cash Register Pavilion, by Ely Jacques Kahn and Walter Dorwin Teague, at the New York World's Fair of 1939. (Museum of the City of New York)

HEADLINE: Taking Out the Trash . . . to the Big Cities 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KOLBER

 BODY:
WHEN Peter Davis became New Haven's river keeper 15 years ago, he removed 4 million pounds of debris from the city's waterways. But since this summer, the rate of illegal dumping in the city's rivers and parks has doubled, Mr. Davis said, and he has had to work nearly nonstop just to keep the car engines, shopping carts and tires from clogging the city's three rivers.
 "The key is this could add up so quickly if we don't get on top of it," Mr. Davis said. 
 Throughout the state, cities have seen a surge in illegally dumped rubbish in recent months and state environmental officials aren't sure why. They speculate that warm weather and lax enforcement have encouraged homeowners and contractors to take this path, which lets them avoid paying the fees that many dumps charge to accept large items. 
Officials said they believed the cities have become magnets because they have plenty of back alleys and highway underpasses where garbage can be discretely dumped.
On one point, Mr. Davis and his colleagues are fairly certain: many of the dumpers are coming from the suburbs.
"Hartford, in essence, has become a dumping ground for economic reasons," said Oscar Mejia of Hartford Areas Rally Together.
The State Department of Environmental Protection and local authorities have been able to trace some of the dumping to suburbanites through labels or identifying marks on the rubbish. A Waterbury official, for example, searched the contents of a discarded floppy disk to find a rogue dumper. The dumper was fined $300 and ordered to clean up the garbage.
In Hartford, Bryan West, the waste management superintendent, said he can tell the debris is coming from out of town because of its character -- trash collectors are finding piles of branches dumped in front of two-family homes that don't have any trees.
The problem has gotten so bad, particularly in Hartford, New Haven, and Waterbury, that in late January the D.E.P. and local authorities began nighttime stakeouts of dumping hot spots. They made only one arrest, perhaps because dumpers had heard about the stakeouts.
Jacquelyn Pernell, the dumping investigator in the D.E.P.'s environmental equity division, has been working with officials from cities to trace refuse and has been issuing summonses when she is able to find the dumpers.
"They're bringing boats, stoves, drugs, asbestos," Ms. Pernell said.
Since the D.E.P. crackdown began in January, Ms. Pernell said the rate of illegal dumping in city centers has slowed. Ms. Pernell said she has been able to trace some dumping back to auto body shops. In January, Ms. Pernell issued a summons to Larry Percy, the owner of Percy's Auto Body Shop on Walnut Street in Hartford. Ms. Pernell was able to use vehicle identification numbers on auto parts found under a Hartford bridge to trace the dumping back to Mr. Percy's shop. Mr. Percy said he had been bringing his discarded cars to a local dump until a few months ago, when it closed. 
Since then, he had been paying a man, whose name he did not know, around $20 to truck off his discarded parts to an out-of-town dump. When Ms. Pernell fined him, Mr. Percy said he realized the other man had just been dumping the auto parts on the street all along.
Mr. Percy said the trucker was pocketing the cash, instead of paying fees at the dump. Since he was fined, Mr. Percy said his company has taken its refuse to the dump on its own.
Bridgeport is in better condition than some other cities. There police seize the vehicles of people found illegally dumping, and since the city stopped bulk pick-ups a decade ago, there have been fewer instances of dumping, City Council President John Fabrizi said.
Bulk collection stopped since the city could no longer afford the $2.5 million annual cost, but the change has also benefited the city since suburban homeowners are no longer encouraged to bring their refuse into town, Mr. Fabrizi said. In Waterbury, new ordinances and increased vigilance by neighborhood groups have encouraged city departments to expend more effort on stopping illegal dumping.
"The cleanliness of the city has become one of the No. 1 complaints among quality of life complaints in the city of Waterbury," said Kathleen McNamara, president of the Waterbury Neighborhood Council, a coalition of 12 neighborhood groups.
Late last year Waterbury created an anti-litter and beautification commission to coordinate efforts between city departments. New ordinances created part-time litter control positions, but with the city's fiscal instability, even Ms. McNamara questions whether those new jobs can be filled.
Michael Gilmore, Waterbury's community development coordinator, said unconventional tactics like the nighttime stakeouts have been working. "We're getting a better grasp on it now," Mr. Gilmore said.
Nevertheless, the limited success of crackdowns on dumping may make further enforcement more difficult. Mr. Gilmore said dumpers are learning to remove identifying marks from the material.
"I think they're getting smarter," Mr. Gilmore said. "They take out the receipt from the Home Depot now."
Mr. Gilmore has found that some illegal dumping has been at the hands of contractors who agree to haul rubbish to dumps, but end up just throwing it in vacant lots or sidewalks.
A Waterbury man, Benjamin De Jesus, was fined $300 when items from his home were found dumped in downtown Waterbury Feb. 7. Mr. De Jesus said he paid a man $500 to clean out his garage. He expected the rubbish to be brought to the city dump, which would have accepted the items for free.
When Mr. De Jesus explained this in court, a judge dismissed the fine against Mr. De Jesus and investigators pursued the hauler. Mr. Gilmore was able to identify Mr. De Jesus because among the personal items dumped were bills addressed to him.
Mr. De Jesus said he has removed his items from the lot and disposed of them properly.
"I want to see it clean," Mr. De Jesus said. "This is criminal."
Waterbury's best hope for cleaning the city may be volunteer efforts.
Ms. McNamara said that during a recent clean-up her group organized, volunteers removed car engines and refrigerators from the Naugatuck River.
In Hartford, a community group met with the city in January to protest conditions on Wellington Street, which is near Interstate 84 and the south branch of the Park River. The road used to be filled with rusting cars and loose tires. After a recent cleanup, cement barricades were placed at each end of the street to prevent further dumping, but small items like furniture and clothing still litter the street.
"This is beautiful compared to what it was," Mr. Mejia said.
But in New Haven the situation isn't getting any better. On Feb. 1, Mr. Davis said he found the worst dumping he has seen yet.
Around 8 a.m., he discovered a 30-foot trailer abandoned on Poplar Street, near River Street. Inside were four 55-gallon drums filled with oil, two refrigerators and an underground storage tank. The D.E.P. removed the tanks and the state police are investigating.
New Haven officials said dumping problems have increased since the New Haven detective who was assigned to police illegal dumpers retired last year. His position is not expected to be filled due to the city's budget crunch.
But the police chief does plan to assign an officer to act as a liaison with other city agencies on dumping problems. Judith Mongillo, a spokeswoman for the New Haven Police Department, said all officers should be looking for illegal dumping on their beats.
"Essentially those matters are handled by patrol," Ms. Mongillo said.
Mr. Davis, who as New Haven river keeper organizes canoe trips of the Quinnipiac, West and Mill rivers and keeps them clean, spends much of his time removing large appliances from neighborhoods adjacent to the rivers because he is afraid that even legally dumped items that are awaiting collection could end up in the rivers at the hands of children.
"The kids love seeing the splash," Mr. Davis said. "It's too hard for them not to do it."
On a particularly warm Tuesday morning in January, Mr. Davis was able to fill the back of his truck with shopping carts, tires and children's bicycles he found discarded along the West and Quinnipiac rivers. He was about to call it a day when he saw a washing machine sitting in an empty lot at Front and Lombard streets, along the Quinnipiac in the city's Fair Haven neighborhood.
Mr. Davis wanted to pick up the machine immediately, "otherwise I need to get it out of the Quinnipiac and that's going to be harder."
He drove to the city's old landfill, which is now just used as a transfer station to ship trash to other cities, and unloaded the back of his Parks Department truck. He threw tires into a dumpster that will be shipped to Bridgeport, where the tires will be burned.
"Poor Bridgeport," Mr. Davis said.
By the end of the day he is covered with mud and dirt. His truck acquires the odors of the rubbish he collects.
"My wife makes me go in the back door and take off all my clothes before I come in," Mr. Davis said.
When he returned to Front Street to pick up the washing machine, Monte Lewis, who lived on Lombard Street, said people from outside the neighborhood frequently drop their trash there.
"Some contractors dump sheet rock here," Ms. Lewis said. "That doesn't surprise me."

HEADLINE: Chicago Developer Capitalizes on Transit Access 

BYLINE:  By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
A CHURCH-based community development corporation on Chicago's west side is using a recently modernized rail transit line as the backbone of an ambitious retail and single family home development plan that it hopes will transform some of this city's toughest streets. 
 One of the two pillars in Bethel New Life's development plan is Parkside Estates, an urban enclave of handsome two-story, three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath, single-family houses on North Hamlin Boulevard in the West Garfield Park neighborhood. They are two blocks from a busy shopping district on West Madison Street, one block from the elevated Lake-Pulaski rail station on Chicago's Green Line and across the street from Garfield Park. Both the neighborhood elementary and middle schools are within a 10-minute walk. 
 The other pillar is a planned $4 million, 23,000-square-foot Transit Center that is to include shops and restaurants on the first floor, a day-care center and employment office on the second floor and a walkway that connects the building to the Lake-Pulaski station. The Transit Center, which is to produce some of its own energy with photovoltaic generators, was designed by Doug Farr and Kevin Pierce, Chicago architects. 
The retail space is being marketed by James Matanky, whose firm, Matanky Realty Group, specializes in selling space in new and renovated inner city buildings and is also a joint venture partner with Bethel New Life in the Transit Center. 
Demolition of the existing store on the site is to start in mid-March, with construction scheduled to begin in early May. The bulk of the financing for the Transit Center project is to come from $3.5 million in city, state and federal grants. The balance -- $500,000 -- comes from a construction loan and from Bethel New Life. 
Together, Chicago city planners say, Parkside Estates and the Transit Center are proving that some of the same promising demographic and economic trends that are strengthening the Loop, Chicago's central business and retail district, are also helping to revive low-income and minority neighborhoods. 
"We've seen quite a renaissance downtown, and what we've been trying to do is push development west and repopulate neighborhoods like West Garfield Park," said Brenda McKenzie, Chicago's deputy commissioner of planning and development. "Parkside Estates does that and so will the Transit Center. The main thing in the urban development game is know-how and persistence. Bethel New Life and Mary Nelson, the director, have that." 
Founded in 1979 as the nonprofit social service arm of Bethel Lutheran Church, a prominent house of worship and a civic institution since it was founded in 1897, Bethel New Life has specialized in redeveloping existing inner city properties. Bethel New Life has renovated more than 1,000 apartments for the poor and elderly in West Garfield Park and transformed the shuttered St. Anne's Hospital and its 9.2-acre campus into a center of housing, job training, health care and performing arts. 
Those projects and several smaller ones, Bethel New Life says, have generated more than $100 million in economic activity in West Garfield Park, which is finally recovering from a series of race riots in the 1960's. The riots accelerated white flight to the suburbs and left the community with 23,000 residents, 60 percent below its peak population, and worrisome rates of drug abuse, crime and unemployment.
Parkside Estates and the Transit Center represent a refinement of Bethel's development strategy. The projects constitute the first test of the organization's ability to build new structures and are intended to help redefine the neighborhood's reputation. 
"Developing in city neighborhoods like this one takes a lot more than assembling land, financing and a marketing strategy," said Ms. Nelson, who has served as Bethel New Life's president since its founding. "You say to yourself and your partners, 'How do we incorporate all of the things that will make our development succeed in an environment where people have become accustomed to hardship and failure and lenders don't expect success?' "
PART of the answer, explained Ms. Nelson and members of her staff, is to be much more methodical, patient and farsighted than most developers can afford to be. Another part is to reach out to influential civic leaders, other nonprofit organizations, lenders and city agencies. 
By almost any standard, the custom-built homes at Parkside Estates, which start at $145,000 and sell at the rate of roughly eight a year, are a bargain. Sitting on 30-by-125-foot lots, the homes come with full basements and energy-efficient lighting and insulation that significantly reduces utility costs.
Bethel is developing the homes on its own, and buyers can qualify for grants of up to $40,000 from New Homes for Chicago, part of a $100 million bond-financed program sponsored by the city to encourage home ownership among low-income households. While Bethel is selling the homes to any interested buyer, with no income ceilings, grants from the city program are pegged to income. For families of four, the $40,000 grant would go to a household with a maximum income of $40,740, with decreasing amounts available for those with incomes of up to $61,000. 
In addition, buyers are eligible for "location efficient" mortgages, a two-year-old mortgage instrument backed by Fannie Mae, the nation's leading buyer of home loans, which enables buyers who use public transportation or have only one car to qualify for larger loans. Under the terms of the mortgages, lenders can stretch the standard debt-to-income ratios because borrowers are estimated to be saving $300 to $500 a month in auto-related expenses. For example, for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at 7 percent, having an additional $300 a month directed toward a mortgage payment instead of a car would yield a mortgage approximately $40,000 higher than otherwise. 
When completed, the 50-home development will have a total cost of $6.25 million. Home sales are financing most of the cost, with the balance coming from city housing grants, says Angela Vick, Bethel's vice president of real estate development.
Half of the lots were made available at no cost to Bethel New Life by the Chicago Department of Housing after vacant buildings were demolished. The other lots, many of them empty, were acquired by Bethel through tax sales and averaged less than $300 each. Half of Parkside Estates has been built, Ms. Vick said. 
Just as crucial as its success in helping low-income residents become homeowners is the role that Parkside Estates is playing in what Ms. Nelson calls a "bold and audacious" plan that Bethel has set in motion to improve the quality of life in the entire West Garfield Park neighborhood. That plan includes more than 100 more single-family homes in two other neighborhood developments that would be valued at nearly $20 million. Bethel has also been working to attract a bank to build a branch office on land partly owned by the agency near the train station and a supermarket for a site a block away.
The catalyst for Bethel's development plan, which urban specialists say is one of the most ambitious transit-oriented developments of any low-income urban neighborhood in the nation, was the Chicago Transit Authority. In 1992 the transit agency announced that because of declining ridership it wanted to close the entire Green Line.
Ms. Nelson joined a group of community leaders to call on the transit agency to modernize the line instead. In July 1993, the transit authority agreed and introduced a new $300 million capital project to rebuild the Green Line, which was completed in 1996.
Annual ridership of the line, which was 3.9 million in 1993, has increased about 10 percent a year since construction was completed, and was 6.2 million last year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Homes at Parkside Estates start at $145,000 and have basements and energy-efficient lighting and insulation. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times) Map of Chicago, Ill.

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
You Call This a Bank? Keep the Change

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
I LIVE in a town of about 8,000 people, which makes it a real small town, the kind that has a Memorial Day parade every year with antique cars and antique veterans. Later this month, there will be the annual pancake breakfast in the social hall of the local church, which will kick off the outdoor season. My town is small enough that I know the woman who sings "The Star-Spangled Banner" at the Memorial Day parade. The mayor's son is the star of my son's basketball team.
 There's also a little bank in the center of town, where I've been making deposits and withdrawals for the past dozen years and where, when my children were little, the tellers would give them lollipops. It's a tiny building, across from the train station, done up in a Greek Revival style, with fake white pillars and red brick. 
 When I moved here in 1989, it was still actually called the Glen Ridge Savings and Loan Association, and I'm sure that's why we chose it. There was a larger bank across the street, which I believe was a Midlantic branch at the time. Later my bank became Collective, a name that always made me think of a Soviet farm. Then it became Summit, and last year it turned into Fleet.
The bank across the street is now a PNC.
I don't know any of the children of the bankers who run Fleet, or share pancakes with them in March. In fact, according to Fleet's Web site, the Boston-based company is seventh-largest financial holding company in the country, with assets of more than $200 billion and 20 million customers.
You could say that I'm pretty much just a 10-digit account to them.
In fact, you can't even call the local Fleet branch directly. You have to call a 1-800 number and get connected to an operator in Scranton, Pa., who in turn will route you back to the branch a half-mile away.
The transition from Summit to Fleet didn't go all that smoothly, at least at my branch. For some reason, there was a shortage of tellers, and every time you went, you'd have to wait 20 minutes in a long, cranky line. I'd look at all the shiny green Fleet propaganda and want to scream, "Hey guys! Fleet means fast!" (According to my Webster's, a second definition for the adjectival form of the word is transient, which is probably closer to the truth.)
But I didn't think about it much until one day in October, when I was taking a historical tour of the local cemetery and the docent showed us the tombstone of man who had founded the local trust company. Ah, a town banker, I thought wistfully. Like most people, I get such images from "It's a Wonderful Life" with Jimmy Stewart as the endearing savings and loan chief who restores confidence after the stock market crash by giving away his own honeymoon money. These days, the iconic banker would have to be Derek Jeter, the Yankees shortstop who flogs Fleets online banking service in TV commercials. In fact, Derek Jeter was right there at my local branch asking for toy donations for needy children at Christmas. Well, his picture was there, anyway. But I wouldn't bet on him handing out his honeymoon money in a crisis.
I called our town's unpaid historian, Sally Meyer, to learn a little about the person she had mentioned during the cemetery tour. It turned out to be Abijah Rittenhouse Brewer, the second mayor of Glen Ridge, who founded the Glen Ridge Trust Company in 1912. Mrs. Meyer works out of a one-room museum that is like a treasure chest, and she has files and old pictures of everything, including my house. She had a picture of Mr. Brewer and quotations from his 1917 obituary. He was a "quiet man, abhorring ostentation," the article said.
But, alas, it turned out that the bank Mr. Brewer founded was the one across the street from my bank.
Still, there was a file on my bank too, which was founded two years after Mr. Brewer's. On its 50th anniversary, in 1964, the Glen Ridge Savings and Loan Association sent a special magazine to all its . . . well, what they called "members" then.
On the back of the magazine was a rendering of a scroll, and printed on it was a creed. The creed was as old-fashioned and small-town as a Memorial Day parade -- and as remote as the sepia-toned pictures of my town when Mayor Brewer was still alive.
"Our association is a fellowship of human beings for human beings," the creed said. "We exist for the common man, for those who work, economize and save."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
A New Plan to Revitalize Asbury Park Waterfront

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK 

 BODY:
A THRIVING vacation spot in the early- and mid-20th century, this city, with its mile-long oceanfront, has suffered from years of decline, shifting demographics and broken promises of renewal. But the latest in a string of plans has some officials hopeful that meaningful development might actually start next year.
 Ocean Front Acquisitions of Lakewood, which six months ago was named the redeveloper of a 56-acre wedge of waterfront land, is advancing a $1.25 billion plan for a waterside enclave of about 2,500 new town houses and condominiums as well as some 500 renovated units and 450,000 square feet of retail and entertainment space. There would also be recreational and open space, including public access to the shoreline, and some $30 million in infrastructure improvements, like sewage and utility connections. 
 Under the plan, which is still being completed and is expected to come to a city council vote in April, Ocean Front would divide the site into parcels, selling or leasing most to other builders to develop in phases over the next decade. A portion of the boardwalk has already been replaced and abandoned buildings have been demolished, paving the way for construction. 
Three separate neighborhoods, covering almost nine acres, totaling 744 units, priced from $200,000 to $400,000, could start by early in the summer of 2003, said Larry Fishman, chief operating officer of the company, a joint venture of M. D. Sass Municipal Partners and First New Jersey Real Property Management. Both have experience in refurbishing and marketing distressed properties in the state, including many in the last decade in the downtown district of Asbury Park.
After watching the checkered history of the city's waterfront from the sidelines for years, the partners decided to get involved because "we always thought it was a diamond in the rough," said Mr. Fishman as he gazed out the window of his boardwalk offices at the Atlantic Ocean. Though the difficulties of transforming Asbury Park are evident in the half-built condominium tower behind his office -- the legacy of an earlier failed development -- "circumstances came together to make a revival happen at this time," Mr. Fishman said.
In the last 18 months property values in this Monmouth County city have risen by roughly a third, to an estimated average of about $115,000, as an influx of house buyers have moved in to take advantage of very low prices for property at the seashore. The downtown business district, with little fanfare, has improved as existing stores have been renovated and new ones opened. And last summer, Mr. Fishman added, the political landscape changed when a new mayor and city council took office. 
In a city where politican strains and frequent turnover of officials has complicated redevelopment, there seems to be a sense that the new mayor and council are determined to move development ahead. Skeptics, however, warn that the current inexperienced council may not fare any better than previous officials.
MAYOR KEVIN G. SANDERS, a sixth-generation resident, remembers that the city had a a lively oceanfront when he was a teenager in the 1970's. It was frustrating to watch, he said, as the city's problems worsened and neighboring shore towns turned around. "We are committed to take back control of our own destiny," Mr. Sanders said.
In creating the current waterfront plan -- actually an amended version of an earlier one -- the city and the developer have tried to invite community input and to capitalize on the city's original 1873 design of open spaces, wide avenues, and streets that fan out at their ocean ends. The redevelopment is also aimed at providing sorely needed jobs and tax revenue.
The developer is paying $600,000 to $700,000 in annual taxes on the 15 acres it has so far acquired in the redevelopment area and put back on the tax rolls, according to city figures. And Mr. Fishman estimates that when the proposed new 3,000 housing units are completed, they will generate $12 million in new tax revenue. 
That would be sweet news for homeowners. "Let's face it, we have been paying the tax burden," said Sue Henderson, president of the Asbury Park Homeowners Association and a nine-year resident. As the city's economic base continues to erode, "we wait for the redevelopment" for relief, she said.
Last August the newly elected city council worked with Ocean Front Acquisitions to break the legal gridlock that had blocked the waterfront's redevelopment since 1992. That is when Carabetta Enterprises of Meriden, Conn., the previous developer, went bankrupt, derailing a plan for some 6,000 residences and igniting years of litigation.
Most of the legal disputes were settled when Ocean Front paid $7.5 million to buy the development rights to the beachfront from Carabetta and $6.5 million to the city for the tax liens on properties in the renewal area. With that money, Asbury Park closed a $4 million budget gap and ended the threat of a state takeover of its finances.
Still swirling over the city are a lawsuit on appeal by an earlier would-be developer in Federal District Court in Connecticut and rumors of an F.B.I. investigation of a previous city administration, which the agency's Newark office would not confirm. But neither of these matters, said James G. Aaron, the city special counsel and redevlopment lawyer, would "impede the current mayor and council from moving forward on the redevelopment of the waterfront."
The debate now is not whether the waterfront will be developed -- most of the city's 16,900 residents favor it -- but rather about how it will be developed. To be sure, community, civic and religious groups are advocating various causes, ranging from affordable housing and open space to the preservation of historic buildings. These sites include the Convention Hall and Casino, two timeworn Art Deco gems, as well as such more prosaic landmarks as the Palace Amusements building and the Stone Pony nightclub, where Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi performed. 
The developer and city officials said a significant difference in the process of presenting the current waterfront plan compared with earlier ones has been a determination to hold public sessions about the plan. The Miami-based firm of Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk, nationally known for their "new urbanism" approach to design, has been hired by the city to come up with rules that are to be followed in implementing the design of the development, governing such matters as building heights, open space, the use of multiple architects and the integration of landmarks. The plan's lead architect is a joint venture of Clarke Caton Hintz of Trenton and Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn of Manhattan. 
Nonetheless, the plan has drawn criticism from some Asbury Park residents, who say that building so much market-rate housing on the waterfront will do little to ease the troubles in other neighborhoods and lead to the creation of a separate community.
"This is a market-driven, not a community-driven, plan that kowtows to outsiders," said Kerry Margaret Butch, executive director of the nonprofit Asbury Park Consortium, which promotes citizen participation in local decision making. "There should be more opportunities built in for jobs and affordable housing for the people who live here."
John J. Hamilton Jr., a councilman, said he would also like to see more affordable housing included to ensure that people who will be displaced have a place to go.
OTHERS counter that the city already has a disproportionate amount of such housing. Councilman John Loffredo said that with just 20 percent of the city's population homeowners, it needs to increase its homeownership rate. Still, he said, there are plans under way for the developer to build some affordable units elsewhere in the city or provide money to have them built. 
The waterfront, Mayor Sanders said, is not the city's only "economic engine." 
Proponents also say this plan is more realistic than previous ones because it breaks the area into smaller districts, including a retail-entertainment area, to be developed by multiple builders. Doing so allows for greater variety and increases the likelihood that the development can weather harsh economic times, the architects said. 
Mr. Aaron, the city's redevelopment lawyer, said safeguards are being put in place to prevent a repeat of the development stagnation of the last decade. They include arbitration clauses for speedy resolution between developers and the city and development timeframes. 
Many also acknowledge that Ocean Front has been the only developer willing to risk its own money on the redevelopment. Mr. Fishman said the partners had invested $21 million since last August, much of it without firm guarantees that the city would allow it to proceed. 
"Because we are not the builder," he said, "we will derive our profits from adding value to the land by having it zoned and approved and then parceling it out to other builders." The hope, Mr. Fishman added, "is to put a new face on Asbury Park and take it into the 21st century."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The boardwalk would be renovated and 3,000 housing units built in a $1.25 billion plan to renew Asbury Park. (Clarke Caton Hintz) Map of Asbury Park, N.J.

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK 

BYLINE:  By Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Staffing Companies Vote Against L.I.A. With Feet
 The Long Island Staffing Coalition Task Force says that at least 10 of its companies have not renewed their memberships in the Long Island Association in protest of the association's decision to form a company that would compete against them. The coalition was formed in August, after the L.I.A. said it would create a company called LIA Staffing. 
 "It seems that the L.I.A. is determined to use any means, including competing with its members, to achieve its goal of increasing its revenues," said Merrill Banks, the chief executive of Lloyd Staffing of Melville, a task force member.
Matthew T. Crosson, the president of the Long Island Association, said: "LIA Staffing is doing good things for the community, and the overwhelming majority of staffing companies recognize that and are working with us. It is unfortunate that a small minority of staffing companies do not see it that way."

Pall's Earnings Fall
The Pall Corporation (NYSE: PLL) of East Hills said Tuesday that sales and earnings were down for the second fiscal quarter ended Jan. 26. Sales totaled $285.4 million, compared with $340.7 million for the same period last year. Earnings were $18.4 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $29.9 million, or 24 cents a share, for the same quarter last year.
Eric Krasnoff, the company's chairman and chief executive, said, "The slump in the semiconductor sector, commercial aerospace and a generally weak U.S. economy caused the shortfall in sales and earnings." Pall manufactures filtration products for the biotechnology, pharmaceutical, semiconductor, medical and aerospace industries. 

Around the Island
For Valentine's Day, 1-800-Flowers .com (Nasdaq: FLWS) of Westbury said that it set a company record with some 650,000 orders and six million separate visits to its Web site. . . . The National Association of Security Dealers in Washington said Wednesday that its regulatory arm had fined Schonfeld Securities of Jericho $15,000. The regulators contend that the company failed to maintain proper records for short-sale orders. The company has neither admitted nor denied the allegations; a spokeswoman said Wednesday that it was cooperating fully with the regulators. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
In the Districts, Costs + Cuts = Higher Taxes

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
CROTON-HARMON'S schools superintendent, Dr. Marjorie E. Castro, spent the recent winter school break working on a proposed 2002-2003 school budget that she feels her community can handle. 
 "This is the first time that we've been this late," Dr. Castro said last week, as she and her staff held meetings to prepare the budget to show to the community over the weekend. "We're all sharpening our pencils. We don't want to overburden the taxpayer, but with the flat increase in aid from the state, trying to do what state education asks us to do, and trying to strengthen the program with more and more kids in our system, a flat increase is like a cut." 
 Under the terms of Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed, no-growth budget, state aid to local school districts would effectively be frozen at last year's levels. The budget also proposes cuts in school construction aid. Building aid in the state has grown by $800 million to $1.4 billion since 1995 as school enrollments have risen. The proposed budget would cut the state's contribution for construction projects, approved by voters after July 1, with more districts receiving the minimum of 10 percent in building aid. 
Superintendents around the county are scrutinizing the numbers, looking for possible cuts, and steeling themselves to explain why proposed school tax rate increases are as high as 10 to 13 percent -- far higher than in recent memory. 
Taxpayers vote on the proposed budgets on May 21. Under the terms of recent state legislation, school boards must adopt a contingency budget when a proposed budget has been defeated twice by the voters. While teachers' salaries, transportation and extracurricular activities are considered ordinary expenses, items like new equipment and the public use of school buildings and grounds -- unless there is no cost to the district -- are not. 
"There are degrees of consternation," said David Ernst, director of communications and research for the New York State School Boards Association. "Districts that are generally wealthier are less dependent on state aid, and less hurt by the governor's no-growth budget. But coming off last year, when districts thought that the Legislature would come through -- and it didn't -- some districts had to go into their reserve funds. 
"If nothing additional were added to the arrays of programs, the Regents and the state comptroller have estimated that it would cost districts $1 billion; the governor has proposed $6 million in aid. This is one of the worst years. Some districts know austerity all too well, and others do not realize the implications."
In Rye, for example, where the proposed school budget tax rate increase is currently at 9.9 percent, Dr. Edward Shine, the superintendent, said: "The board is trying to keep the program together and keep costs down. In the past, we've had tax rate increases of 1.95 percent, or 2.38 percent. Last year, it was over 10 percent -- when you begin to string numbers like that, it is a manifestation of concern."
Most of the county's school districts, ever mindful of the complicated dance that goes on in Albany when it comes to budget matters, have practiced fiscal conservatism when making assumptions about just how much state aid to count on. For many of the wealthier communities, state aid has historically comprised such a low percentage of revenues that flat increases or cuts haven't had a substantial impact. And since in the past, legislators have overridden the governor's proposed budget for schools, and ended up giving them more money, some think the schools' reactions are premature. 
Still Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky said: "The governor's proposal is really a cut in building aid, which is much harder to reverse. If the governor's proposals become law, there will be problems."
The challenge is particularly difficult for districts where increasing enrollments add other pressures to school programs. In Irvington, where the district is probably looking at a double-digit tax rate increase, assistant superintendent of business, James Reese, said, "We're the fastest growing district south of Albany, with significant costs, and the state is not keeping up with that."
Even a so-called stand-still budget, one in which there are no increases in programming, carries with it significant fixed costs that would in most cases still carry at least a 5 percent tax rate increase. Contractual arrangements with faculty and staff, the costs of benefits and other obligations when combined with expanding enrollments and the increasing number of mandates and tests from the state -- make tax rate increases unavoidable. 
"Regretfully, we're proposing our third challenging budget," said Thomas M. Kelly, Valhalla's public schools superintendent. "We've been in double digits for the past two years. We're a Westchester school district where the community bears the burden. State education has upped the learning requirements, which is fine, but we don't get funding for it."
Given the uncertain economy, there is particular concern that school district residents will be especially reluctant to vote for double-digit tax rate increases. 
"We're all trying to get it down as low as we possibly can, while giving a quality education that the community can afford," said Dr. Castro, of Croton. "It's a tough go."

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
A Korean Composer With Loyalty to a Bridgeport Home Base

BYLINE:  By BRIAN WISE 

 BODY:
ASK any American who follows contemporary classical music to identify recent Asian composers, and you are likely to hear Chinese names like Bright Sheng, Chen Yi or Tan Dun, composer of the Oscar-winning score to Ang Lee's film, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon." Yet while Chinese, and to a lesser extent, Japanese composers have established a major presence on the American music scene, Korean classical music remains less known.
 That prospect hardly fazes Jin Hi Kim, a 43-year-old Korean-born composer, instrumentalist and multimedia artist who lives in Bridgeport. Her works have been performed worldwide by the Kronos Quartet, the American Composers Orchestra and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Major institutions -- including the Smithsonian Institution, Asia Society and the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington -- have collaborated with Ms. Kim over the past decade, as have avant-garde jazz artists like the saxophonist Oliver Lake, the guitarist Derek Bailey and the bassist William Parker. 
 Next Sunday at 3:00 p.m. at New York's Riverside Church, Ms. Kim's first orchestral composition "Eternal Rock" will be performed by the Riverside Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Helen Cha-Pyo. The work, which had its premiere last March at Carnegie Hall, features Ms. Kim as soloist performing on the komungo, a Korean fretted zither that dates to the fourth century.
"Acoustically her music is daring," said Gil Rose, artistic director of the Boston Modern Orchestra Project, which plans to present the premiere of Ms. Kim's second orchestral piece next year. "It's not as westernized in that it doesn't use traditional melodies, but I think it has a lot of bite and impact and it's really visceral."
Ms. Kim maintains a high profile in her home base of Bridgeport. She and her partner, the composer and double-reed player Joseph Celli, settled in the city's Black Rock neighborhood during the early 1990's, attracted by its diverse population of Laotian, Vietnamese, Cambodian, Indian and Puerto Rican immigrants. In 1993, they co-founded the Korean Performing Arts Institute, later renamed International Performing Arts, a nonprofit organization devoted to promoting non-Western art forms.
As artistic director of the group, Ms. Kim oversees its concert series and coordinates its research and advocacy programs. Operating on an annual budget of $250,000, the organization counts among its most visible initiatives the "Sounds of the World Concerts," a series that took place over the last three years, improbably, at the Harborview Market in Bridgeport.
"There aren't many auditoriums in this town, so we started a series in a grocery store," Ms. Kim said, laughing. The free, weekly concerts, which ended last fall, drew as many as 100 grocery-toting audience members every week. Ms. Kim said Bridgeport was an ideal laboratory to advocate Korean music alongside that of other cultures.
"There are so many immigrants here and their music is a wonderful vehicle for us to try and break down barriers," she said.
Mr. Celli offered a less rosy assessment of civic realities.
"Bridgeport offers a really challenging situation," he said. "It's the largest city in Connecticut and has very serious race, class and economic disparities. Our concert series are devoted to better understanding these cultures."
Ms. Kim can identify with the role of outsider. She grew up in Korea where, she said, traditional Korean music was largely rejected by the educational establishment in favor of Western classical music. Still, she earned a B.A. degree in Korean traditional music at Seoul National University before moving to the San Francisco area in 1980. With no money and little knowledge of English, she became immersed in the city's thriving contemporary music scene, studying with the composers Lou Harrison and Terry Riley, and receiving an M.F.A. from Mills College.
"The West Coast was a good place to be at the time," she recalled. "They were into Asian culture, and the San Francisco Bay area had a strong immigrant population."
Today, an outsider sensibility still permeates many of Ms. Kim's works for komungo, as its austere, elegant sonority is set against different sounds, instruments and styles. A telling example is "Eternal Rock," which was commissioned by the American Composers Orchestra. Its premiere at Carnegie Hall was part of the orchestra's festival of immigrant composers in America.
Reviewing the work in The New York Times, Anne Midgette said the piece "moved through the orchestra like a curious outsider, wondering at the range of sounds it can make and generally using it as an extension of the twangy vocabulary of the solo komungo."
Unlike many other Asian composers, Ms. Kim's goals extend beyond merely fusing Eastern and Western musical traditions.
"After 10 years of combining traditional Korean and Western classical music, I realized there are more important things to do," she said, adding that she had shifted her style in the early 1990's. "I made a conscious decision to not only combine Korean and Western music, but a lot of other cultures."
This decision is reflected in her theater piece, "Dragon Bond Rite," presented in 1997 by the Korea Society and the Kennedy Center. The work incorporates a cast of mask dancers, percussionists and vocalists. Another example is "Dong Dong Touching the Moons," a multimedia piece that unites Korean and Indian musicians and dancers with video images and computer processing. It had its premiere at the Kitchen in New York in May 2000.
"As an experiment, it was very effective," said Elise Bernhardt, the Kitchen's executive director. "She was strategically very smart because a lot of people don't think about working in a theater, in that you need to bring in old expertise and new expertise."
In reviewing the piece, Jon Pareles of The Times said "Ms. Kim's austere music centered the work."
To many in the classical music world, the fusion of different cultures and media is creatively problematic, because one thing or another must be sacrificed in the process. Others argue that Asian music's status in the West will never be more than a fad. Michael Geller, the executive director of the American Composers Orchestra, said, "Asian music's popularity in the West has ebbed and flowed over the years, going all the way back to Debussy."
In December of last year, Ms. Kim received one of twelve $24,000 grants from the Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, the New York-based institution created by the late conceptual composer John Cage and the artist Jasper Johns. 
Meanwhile, Ms. Kim said she remains dedicated to Connecticut. In January, her performing arts group announced that it will transform a former bank in downtown Bridgeport into a multicultural arts center that would hold 150 events, 500 classes and 25,000 visitors annually. The city is planning to buy the building and rent it to her group.
The center will include a performance space, gallery space, rehearsal spaces, classrooms and a cafe, she said. The group also plans to sublease space to other arts organizations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jin Hi Kim with her komungo, a Korean zither. Ms. Kim has lived in Bridgeport since the early 1990's. (Richard Perry/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Public Housing in Stamford Is Being Transformed

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN a project that is transforming a bleak Stamford neighborhood, the first 149-home phase of a $92 million redevelopment has been completed at the once-notorious Southfield Village housing project -- the initial step in the eventual replacement of 500 dilapidated units built in 1939. The redevelopment, under way since 1998, reflects current ideas of privatizing public housing and broadening its tenant base to include renters of market-rate units and buyers of homes, as well as extensive support services for residents. 
 Demolition has begun on another 11 buildings in Phase 2, with construction of 110 rental units to be completed in 2003. Phase 3, which is to be finished by 2005, is to have 56 rental units and 15 owner-occupied three-bedroom town houses with garages. 
 How the drug- and crime-infested warren near Exit 6 of Interstate 95 in downtown Stamford was changed into an attractive, diverse neighborhood renamed Southwood Square is a story about Hope VI, a nine-year-old program of the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
While state and local funds for subsidized and low-cost housing continue to shrink, Hope VI has made 165 grants to private-public partnerships developing mixed-income communities in 98 cities. Its contribution to the reconstruction or replacement of substandard public housing has totaled $4.55 billion across the nation, the agency says.
Ultimately, Southwood Square's 24 acres will contain a total of 330 units: 160 low-income public housing units; 70 moderate-income units, with an income ceiling of $69,300 a year for a family of four; 85 market-rate rentals units; and 15 homes for sale.
"Mixed" is the operative word in this approach to the problem. Mixed income levels of tenants; mixed public and private financing; mixed types and sizes of apartments, town houses and single family homes; a mix of architectural details, building materials and colors; and a mix of rental and owned units are producing lively neighborhoods where ugly "projects" once stood in isolation and hopelessness.
As a result, the role of housing authorities is changing. "I think they are going to play a very different role," said Dannel P. Malloy, mayor of Stamford. "They were defined as bad managers overseeing unsuccessful housing. Now they will be seen as partners in all kinds of housing and making it work."
Under Hope VI's Homeowner Assistance Program, Stamford residents in public or assisted housing whose earnings do not exceed certain levels can enroll in a six-month training program in home ownership. Afterward, they will be linked with realtors and mortgage lenders who will assist them in finding and purchasing homes in lower Fairfield County. So far 30 households have signed up for the current training session, and $1.4 million of the Southwood Square development funds have been set aside for training and mortgages for 40 homes. 
"Hope VI," said Richard D. Fox, executive director of the Stamford Housing Authority, "represents a revolution in conventional public housing. Historically, it provided bricks and sticks, but this is an investment in people as well -- in vocational training, counseling, help in getting a driver's license, doing what's necessary to make a person ready for the marketplace. It has a social side that never existed before."
One of the social shifts is the integration of ethnically and racially diverse residents. "We don't keep track," said Vincent J. Tufo, development coordinator for the Housing Authority, "but we have a racial mix now that never was before. It had been all black and Hispanic. The subsidized units are still mostly black and Hispanic -- the others are white and black."
Darren Scott, who grew up in Fairfield, and his roommate, employees of a financial services company in White Plains, took a two-bedroom, two-bath market-rate apartment last December, four months after the complex opened. By Dec. 31, it was completely leased. 
Deciding factors were price, a pool and fitness center, fully equipped kitchens and laundry machines in each unit. "This is not much more than we paid for much less in Norwalk, and it's $500 to $1,000 a month less" than other market-rate apartments, he said.
A two-bedroom, two-bath market-rate apartment at Southwood Square rents for $1,900; the moderate income rent is $1,374 for a family of four that does not earn more than 60 percent of the Stamford-Norwalk area median income of $115,500. For a family earning about 20 percent of the median, the rent is 30 percent of the tenant's income. Unit sizes range from 650 square feet for a one-bedroom apartment with one bath to 1,650 square feet for a four-bedroom unit with two and a half baths.
For the developer, Beacon/Corcoran Jennison of Boston, "Hope VI has brought more developers into the field of creating mixed-income communities," said Peter Wood, the company's redevelopment director. Mr. Wood meets regularly with the Southwood Residents' Council's nine-member board to address concerns. Its president, Blondyne Mikel, attributes a sharp drop in crime in the area to Mayor Malloy. "He started putting more police here before redevelopment," she said, "and a police substation in 1998. We meet in his office on Mayor's Nights to discuss our situation. Now, troublesome residents seem to realize their behavior won't be tolerated."
A handsomely refurbished community center houses a health clinic, computer center, gym and fitness center, senior and day care centers, home ownership classes, youth activities and sports, and access to job training. Hope VI pays for most of it, with additional grants from the Housing Authority and United Way as well as GE Capital, Citibank and other corporations.
Twenty-eight residents, including three women, worked on the construction of Phase 1, and six of them are continuing to work in construction trades. Three men and two women have been trained in asbestos abatement and are working on the buildings that are being demolished in Phase 2. In addition, resident students baby-sit in the day care center. "My daughter Jennifer works there with small children," said Valerie Wallace. "She's 17, goes to Westhill High. It helped her immensely. Her self-esteem improved and so did her grades."
Mrs. Wallace, like many of the residents, grew up in the old Southfield Village and moved into the new apartments. "I'm loving it -- it's the best place I've ever lived," she said. "It had gotten bad here in the 80's, when crack was introduced into the community. The neighborhood was full of bars." She added, "There's still a lot of drug dealing, but the neighborhood seems to look cosmetically better."
While the Housing Authority retains ownership of the land on a 99-year lease-back to the developer, Beacon/Corcoran Jennison owns and will manage the buildings. Two well-regarded architectural firms were the designers: Herbert S. Newman & Partners of New Haven and Russell-Scott, Steedle & Capone Architects of Cambridge, Mass.
Financing of $92.4 million was assembled by the developer, which has 40 years to repay $16 million in mortgage debt from the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority and 50 years to pay back loans of $10 million from the Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development and $3 million from the City of Stamford. HUD supplied a grant of $26.4 million, and $37 million was raised from the syndication of federal Low Income Housing Tax Credits. During the three-phase construction period, the developer collects management fees and rents, but profits are capped at 10 and 12 percent by the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority and HUD, respectively. 
Beacon/Corcoran Jennison is working on two additional Hope VI transformations: one in Pittsburgh and the other, in New Haven, called the Homes at Monterey. When the latter was built in 1941, it was called Elm Haven and had 805 subsidized units in six high-rise and a few low-rise buildings. African-Americans and whites were housed separately. "Out of every three buildings, two were for blacks, one was for whites," said Robert Solomon, interim executive director of the New Haven Housing Authority. "It was considered progressive then."
The complex will eventually have 350 mixed-income apartments, single family homes and housing for the elderly. About half are finished and occupied. Apartment rents average $850 for families of four, and four-bedroom homes sell for around $70,000. The ultimate cost will be about $100 million. "We are applying for another Hope VI grant for 750 units in four complexes," Mr. Solomon said. "The apartments at Monterey are already oversubscribed, and the nine home ownership units sold very quickly."
Hope VI expires at the end of this year, but it is budgeted by HUD for renewal in 2003. A spokeswoman at HUD said, "It's up to Congress to decide."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Wood, Blondyne Mikel and Richard D. Fox at Southwood Square, where 330 apartments and town houses are being built. (George Ruhe for The New York Times) Map of Stanford, Conn.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
Schools Scramble for Slices of the State Budget Pie

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
THE Irvington School District is bursting at the seams. With a growing enrollment, almost double the 1,080 students it had in 1990, there is a severe shortage of classroom space.
 "We now have 11 portable classrooms," said Vincent T. Beni, the district superintendent. "We look like a Florida retirement home." In 2000 the district began a $50 million project to build a new middle school and add a new wing, gymnasium and auditorium onto the high school. 
 Last year, the district learned that a change in the state budget would delay much of the state aid covering 18 percent of the project, forcing a hike in local taxes to raise several million dollars. 
"It was a major shock," said Mr. Beni, who described the hardships of relying on school aid that changes from year to year with the economic and political winds. "It's nerve-racking planning for education programs and not knowing where the money's coming from."
Mr. Beni has gotten parents to mount an intense lobbying campaign, drafting letters to elected officials, the governor and the state Education Department, for better financing. "They are getting more sophisticated and seeing how the lobbying and competition for school aid works," he said.
These days, he said, running a good school district involves not only educating students in the academics, but also giving parents a crash course in state politics, to mobilize them to help the district maximize its aid. 
Many districts across the county find themselves in situations similar to Irvington's. To handle soaring student enrollments, the districts took advantage of generous building-aid subsidies created in 1997 by Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature to encourage school construction. The districts approved bond acts to help finance their projects. But the state scaled back building aid last year, and much of the money was delayed to school districts. Now, many districts in mid-construction are in a financial bind and have no choice but to raise local taxes. 
And many districts are mobilizing parents, said Janet Walker, executive director of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association. As the political jousting in Albany begins heating up, fewer parents are sitting back waiting to see what their district will be allotted, Ms. Walker said. Instead, they are working to put pressure on elected officials to bring home the bacon. Richard L. Brodsky, a Democratic state assemblyman from Newburgh, led a fierce political battle against severe cuts to suburban districts last year. He recalled recently that it was an extensive letter-writing campaign by local district superintendents and parents that helped persuade Governor Pataki to soften the cuts somewhat. 
The road is perhaps more rocky this year, he said, because the governor is again offering an austere school aid budget with no increases to building aid. 
"It would be a dagger in the heart of schools across the county," Mr. Brodsky said. 
Now is the time of year that Rick Freyman, in the Lakeland Central School District, calls March Madness. Mr. Freyman, assistant superintendent for business in the district, uses the term to describe the frustrating act of "trying to vote on a budget when nobody knows what the state aid is going to be."
The Lakeland district has had several projects under way since 1998, totaling about $40 million in costs. The budgets have all been affected by the building aid cuts. 
"It's horrible, but what can we do?" he said. "We have to pay our bonds back. When we get less in building aid revenue, we just have to raise the local school taxes higher."
Officials at the state Education Department said last week that it is simply too early to tell how suburban districts will fare in school aid allocations this year.
The allocation of school aid has long been the most contentious part of state budget negotiations. The state uses a byzantine formula, supplemented with ferocious back-room bargaining, to divvy money between the city, the suburbs and upstate regions. The city and suburbs vie ferociously for money, with each side accusing the other of depriving it of money. 
The state provides about 44 percent of the money to educate students in New York City schools. Most Westchester districts receive a far smaller percentage of their budgets from the state, so local taxes make up the bulk of school budgets. Traditionally, suburban lawmakers have accused the city of spending too little on its own schools and relying too heavily on state aid. This, they contend, deprives the suburbs of their fair share. City lawmakers say the suburban districts spend much more per student, and have plenty of money for larger classrooms and smaller class enrollments. 
The territorial disputes have intensified this year, school leaders say. Money is tight overall. After Sept. 11, the governor presented an austere budget, which is scheduled to be approved by April 1. 
In January 2001, the state Supreme Court, in a landmark decision, ruled that the state has long shortchanged city students and ordered the state to revamp its education financing system. The state is appealing the decision, effectively forestalling compliance, but in December, the Board of Regents proposed cutting school aid by 5 to 15 percent in some of the state's wealthiest districts and sending more money to poorer urban school systems.
"Every year it's a major tug of war," said Mr. Beni, Irvington's superintendent..

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Fast Food? Not So Fast, Town Says

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLL 

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD 

 BODY:
CHICKEN and biscuits?
 No, stuff and nonsense, say a number of residents in this largely upscale village. 
 It seems Col. Harland Sanders wants to move into the neighborhood, but the southern gentleman is meeting opposition from some residents and local merchants.
Tricon Global Restaurants, the owners of the Kentucky Fried Chicken franchise, want to build a fast-food emporium on the lot of an abandoned gas station at Yale Street and Springfield Avenue in the College Hill section that is one part quiet tree-lined residential and one part busy commercial strip. 
"We need new business in the area, but a fast-food chain doesn't help economic development," said Ron Carter, who lives down the street from the site. "It starts a slide, not a growth."
But Mayor Vic DeLuca said the restaurant would be good for the revitalization of the area, which in no way resembles the quaint and bustling downtown juust minutes away.
"This is not going to be your typical fast-food type building or business," said Mr. DeLuca.
He described the proposed building as a two-story affair with red awnings and cafe-style windows, but void of the traditional large signs and advertisements normally associated with fast-food places. It would also be home to a Chock Express, a coffee chain. And at the rear of the building will be a refrigeration unit, rather than the traditional dumping container. 
Not that fast food is anything new to Maplewood. There is already a Burger King, built in 1970, just two blocks from the proposed 78-seat KFC. But after residents complained that litter from the Burger King dotted the area and attracted rodents, officials adopted an ordinance in the late 1980's banning further fast-food restaurants.
Mr. DeLuca contends that the language of the ordinance is "bulky" and needs to be cleaned up, and he insists that the proposed KFC does not fit the definition of a fast-food restaurant as currently written.
To be sure, not all residents are opposed to the KFC.
"We as a town spent a lot of money and have done a lot of things to reactivate the area and to bring businesses in and to make the street something that will bring people back to the area," said George Berkeley, 52, who lives nearby. "Now when we have that coming to fruition people protest simply because it's a KFC."
While the proposal still has several more hurdles before being approved by the town council, Mr. DeLuca says that it will become a reality even though some residents and local merchants are gearing up for a fight.
On March 12, residents will have a chance to voice their concerns to the town council and to representatives of KFC. If the council approves the plan, then the company must still get the approval from various construction boards and address any environmental concerns before there is a groundbreaking.
"We always try to work with the community and the towns to make sure what we put in goes along with their regulations," said Michael Tirerney, a spokesman for KFC. "Maplewood is no exception."
Still, two doors from the proposed fast-food restaurant, Kurt Anthony, owner of the Avenue Bakery Cafe and Le Jardin restaurant, expressed his concern about his possible new neighbor.
"Everyone is entitled to make a buck, but for my little coffee shop it will mean the end," said Mr. Anthony. "How often do you hear of a franchise going out of business compared to an independent coffee place?"
Given that sentiment, it is not hard to figure out why a chalkboard sign hangs near the entrance to his cafe promoting a "KFC bashing party" on March 14."We have two bands, fried chicken, mashed potatoes, and buttermilk biscuits," Mr. Anthony said. "We are also making a cake that will have an axe going through a KFC."
So far, Mr. Anthony said, he had received a big response from people who want to attend the party -- an affair whose proceeds will be donated to a local charity.
"I already have a ton of trash on my lawn from the Burger King," said one resident, who declined to be identified. "Now with the KFC it will be double the mess, double the rodents, and double the traffic. I can hardly wait."
The mayor says. however, that all of the concerns will be addressed and dealt with before final approval is granted. 
Beth MacDonald, executive director of the Springfield Avenue Partnership, a group dedicated to the rejuvenation of the area, is excited about the future of the two-mile commercial strip.
"This could be the first brand-new building to be erected in a long time," said Ms. MacDonald, "and I hope this will catch the eye of other developers and garner new interest in terms of getting new businesses onto the avenue."
She said she envisioned a strip lined with trees and lights to attract more people and provide a greater sense of community.
"With a few national stores to serve as anchors and a renewed interest in some locally owned retail stores, it will all be a reality," Ms. MacDonald said.
Not everybody shares her enthusiasm.
"Fast food brings people in and out and can cause traffic nightmares, said Carmine Petti, the owner of Realty 33 across the street from the site. "We'd be better off with a nice restaurant or something else in that spot."
