HEADLINE: A Rebound, Yes, but the Price May Be High 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
JUDGING from its recent financial results, Eckerd, the big drugstore chain owned by J. C. Penney, is going strong. J. Wayne Harris, Eckerd's relatively new chief executive, was hired to turn it around, and he appears to have done the job.
 But from another vantage point, Eckerd has hit some nasty bumps. At least two states are investigating the chain for possible overbilling in its pharmacies, and it is the subject of a class-action suit contending that the company routinely charged customers for medications they did not receive. In Texas, an insurance company sued Eckerd last November, contending that it overbilled for medications in workers' compensation claims. 
 Mr. Harris, it also turns out, has a troubled past. He was dismissed from his previous job as chief executive of the Grand Union Company, the grocery chain, in February 2000. According to two people with knowledge of the situation at Grand Union, the company under Mr. Harris made questionable deals with suppliers and its distributor that bolstered the company's immediate financial results but that harmed it long term. Grand Union filed for bankruptcy protection eight months after Mr. Harris left. 
Allen Questrom, the chief executive of J.C. Penney who hired Mr. Harris, said that two of Mr. Harris's previous employers had given him rave reviews and that questions about his performance at Grand Union were irrelevant. "Wayne has worked for us for a year and a half and I have nothing but outstanding reviews for him from within this company and my experience with him," he said. 
But the complaints about Eckerd are not easy to dismiss, and they have human dimensions as well. A retired North Carolina couple, for example, contend that Eckerd switched their prescriptions without their knowledge or approval.
Mr. Harris was hired to restart Eckerd's engines in late 2000. Just as Mr. Questrom has wowed Wall Street with his turnaround at Penney, Mr. Harris has transformed Eckerd, the nation's fourth-largest drugstore chain. At its 2,650 stores, Eckerd generated operating profit of $208 million for the accounting year that ended on Jan. 26, after a $76 million loss the previous year; sales rose 5.8 percent.
But these results are now being overshadowed by the allegations that Eckerd overbills its customers. Even as Penney announced earnings of $114 million from continuing operations last year, versus a loss of $568 million in fiscal 2001, the company's shares have drifted lower. Since the beginning of the year, the stock is down 26 percent.
In mid-February, the Florida attorney general's office said it had started a civil investigation into possible overbilling at Eckerd. In another civil investigation that began last month, the economic crimes division of the Florida attorney general's office is reviewing Eckerd's practice of giving customers a form to sign when they pick up prescriptions that supposedly provides verification that the medication was received and that the patient will accept prescription counseling by Eckerd. In much smaller type, the form says that by signing it, the customer agrees to, among other things, the release of prescription data to the parent company to provide "health and money-saving offers." Critics say the privacy of Eckerd's customers is being abused. 
OTHER states are also looking into Eckerd's billing practices. "It is on our radar screen," said Frank Adams, a spokesman for at the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services, "but we cannot comment on ongoing investigations."
Several civil lawsuits have been filed recently against Eckerd. One is a class action filed in February by an Eckerd customer in Florida who said that, from April to November of last year, the company overcharged him on seven prescriptions. Another suit, filed against Eckerd and three other chains in November by the Texas Mutual Insurance Company, asserts that Eckerd has routinely inflated bills it submitted to the insurer, in some cases billing more than two and a half times Eckerd's customary charge for the same drug.
Eckerd said it is cooperating with the investigations and is confident it complies with laws and regulations. It said both the class-action suit brought by the Florida consumer contending overbilling and the Texas Mutual suit were without merit. 
No allegations have been proved. But Eckerd has gotten into trouble for overbilling before. In July, it pleaded guilty to criminal charges brought by the United States Justice Department in the middle district of Florida and paid a fine of $1.7 million. That case involved a practice known as partial filling, in which Eckerd filled only a portion of a prescription but recorded it as having been filled entirely and billed Florida's Medicaid program for the full amount. In the plea, Eckerd agreed that the four violations identified by investigators were not isolated incidents. Prosecutors estimated that partial filling at Eckerd cost Florida Medicaid as much as $2.5 million.
At the time, Robert E. Lewis, Eckerd's general counsel, said: "We are disappointed that the Justice Department singled Eckerd out for an industrywide problem that we addressed a number of years ago." 
Carmen A. Catizone, executive director of the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy, said the rising number of cases accusing Eckerd of questionable practices might have its roots in the transformation of the pharmacy industry. Once a decentralized business of local practitioners, he said, it is now dominated by giant, publicly traded companies under pressure to produce profits.
"The pharmacies are operating to ensure that the company does well," Mr. Catizone said. "I think it presents a conflict at times where there is a question: Is this in the best interest of a patient?"
Eckerd has certainly felt pressure to produce profits in recent years. Acquired in 1997, it showed an operating profit of $254 million in 1998. The next year, that fell to $183 million, and by 2000 it had swung to a loss of $76 million. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization fell from 4.9 percent of sales in 1998 to 1.9 percent in 2000.
To reverse the trend, Mr. Harris made a money-saving move in July 2001, when Eckerd froze pension benefits for its drugstore associates and reduced and capped company contributions to retirement plans. The changes produced a gain of $11 million in the third quarter.
But overbilling can produce far greater profits. The customer who filed the class-action suit in Florida asserts that on certain medications, Eckerd's computers automatically rounded up dosages to the nearest whole number and charged for that amount even though the extra medication was not dispensed.
As a result, the lawsuit said, the customer overpaid by almost $10 each time he had his prescription filled. Because Eckerd has 2,650 stores in 20 states, the suit estimates that it reaped more than $100 million from overbilling over nine months.
When the suit was filed, Eckerd said that although the billings showed a larger amount of medication dispensed than the patient received, the billing amount was proper. It also said it had upgraded its pharmacy billing system.
The suit brought by Texas Mutual also indicates just how profitable overbilling could have been for Eckerd. According to the complaint, Texas Mutual found 26 prescriptions for which Eckerd billed far more than it did for walk-in customers insured by Texas Mutual buying the same medications. For example, according to the suit, Eckerd's customary charge for 40 cephalexin antibiotic tablets was $28.79, but it charged Texas Mutual $77; while Eckerd normally charged $8.19 for 30 prescription ibuprofen pain-relief tablets, it billed Texas Mutual $20.11.
The lawsuit says Texas Mutual's initial investigation found that Eckerd overcharged the insurer by an average of $11.48 a prescription. The court filing said Eckerd acknowledged to Texas Mutual that it charges different amounts for workers' compensation claims and other claims. Eckerd has continued to submit inflated bills to Texas Mutual even after the insurer contacted it about overbilling, the lawsuit said.
One Eckerd pharmacist who spoke on condition of anonymity said the company also tries to pad its financial results by persuading customers to switch to drugs that generate greater profits. "Every month we get a document from Eckerd with a list of generic opportunities," this pharmacist said. "The last one I got was a month ago." The pharmacist said, for example, that Eckerd encourages employees to switch customers from Lanoxin, a heart medication from GlaxoSmithKline, to a generic that is less expensive.
IF an Eckerd pharmacist can persuade a customer to switch to a generic, the company can profit in several ways. First, Eckerd will incur lower costs by carrying an inventory of cheaper medications. And, the pharmacist explained, generic drugs are much more profitable to pharmacies because the dispensing fees on a $25 patented drug prescription and a $5 generic one are similar. "In pharmacy, you take the cost of the drug and tack on the dispensing fee," this person said. As a result, pharmacy profits skyrocket when patients switch to generics.
Because of agreements with some drug companies, Eckerd receives money when it switched people to higher-priced, patent-protected drugs, this pharmacist said. Such a practice would explain the recent experience of Curtis and Jean Thompson, longtime Eckerd customers in Wake Forest, N.C.
Their physician had prescribed Prilosec, a drug for heartburn and ulcers, for both of them. The patent for Prilosec, manufactured by Merck for AstraZeneca under a partnership, expired in October.
In June, Mrs. Thompson received a letter from Eckerd advising her that the Food and Drug Administration had recently approved a new drug, Nexium, to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease. Saying the company considered itself "a partner in the management of your health care," the letter said Nexium provides many patients "complete resolution of their heartburn symptoms."
Enclosed was a coupon for a free seven-day trial of Nexium, which could be used only if her physician prescribed it. At the bottom of the letter was the following: "Funding for this educational mailing has been provided by AstraZeneca L.P."
Mrs. Thompson saved the letter but did nothing about it. Then, several months ago, the couple received a phone call at home from an Eckerd employee suggesting that Mr. Thompson switch from Prilosec to Nexium. Nexium is still covered by a patent and is more expensive.
Mrs. Thompson told the caller that her husband did not want to switch because his physician had specifically prescribed Prilosec. The call angered her, she said, so she telephoned her local Eckerd pharmacist, whom she trusted, to ask why she was being badgered to switch. He told her that it had not come from him and gave her the number of a consumer help line at Eckerd. She called that number, got no satisfaction and eventually called the Eckerd Therapeutic Support Center in Pittsburgh, which had sent her the letter.
"I said we did not like this and felt that someone there should put a stop to calling old people who were confused enough about their drugs," Mrs. Thompson said.
She went to Eckerd to pick up four of her husband's prescriptions, she said, and when she got home she found five drugs in the package. One vial contained Nexium and had cost more than $100.
"I called the local pharmacy and said, 'How did the Nexium get in there that hadn't been prescribed?' " Mr. Thompson recalled. "They said they had gotten a fax saying that the prescription was changed."
When Mrs. Thompson saw her doctor the next day, she asked about the Nexium. He told her someone had called him from Eckerd saying Mr. Thompson had approved the change. "The doctor was surprised to learn it was not our request," she said. 
An Eckerd spokeswoman said: "Like other drugstore chains we do have programs pursuant to which we provide our patients with timely information on products or treatments. We believe these programs comply fully with all laws and regulations." Mrs. Thompson is still angry about the switch. "It just wasn't the thing to do that I considered ethical," she said. "It may not be illegal but it is not ethical."
Many people eyeing Eckerd these days no doubt agree with her.

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Dodgeball, In Adult Hands

BYLINE:  By Robert Lipsyte 

 BODY:
As we are constantly being reminded, this is a dodgeball world. People are always trying to knock you out of the game, because they hate you or because they want to win or because they are so filled with rage that they write "To whom it may concern" on the ball before they throw it. You can look at the front pages or the sports pages and find your own examples.
 And now people are arguing about dodgeball itself. For those who missed this elemental elementary school game, which also goes by the name bombardment and killer ball, there are variations, team and individual. But, basically, children try to hit one another with a large rubber ball. Last kid left wins. In the current debate over the game, some grown-ups say it causes psychological damage, others that it hardens school kids for the real world, as if gym class isn't real enough. 
 There's no question dodgeball is reality programming, what my adviser, the pseudonymous Archie Armstrong, 34, author of a play, "Bombardment," calls a combination of Stalinist purge, "Rocky" and "Survivor." There is scapegoating, bullying, victimology, thinning the herd, humiliation and a subtle lesson as important as this one: kids who hide behind weaker kids to avoid getting hit eventually get hit, too. 
On the other hand, the television producer Lou Charlip, 45, says he "loved the game because it was an opportunity for fat kids, klutzy kids without developed athletic skills to play hard and have fun." Then he told a golden lifetime story in which the tough jock fumbled young Lou's soft throw and was out of the game.
The National Association for Sport and Physical Education, which represents more than 18,000 teachers and professors, has condemned dodgeball. A Cambridge, Mass., physical education teacher, Thomas Murphy, told The Boston Globe, "Any time you throw an object at somebody, it creates an environment of retaliation and resentment. There is nothing positive that can happen except a bully gets to beat up on little kids."
Those who defend dodgeball -- and that includes the relatively new National Amateur Dodgeball Association, which holds outdoor and indoor championships for adults in Schaumburg, Ill. -- say it develops the transferable sports skills of teamwork, quick movements and change of direction, and the importance of keeping your eye on the ball at all times. 
Why is this all surfacing now, we ask, and I'm sure thelipsite@aol.com will get its typically shrewd, skewed answers with allusions to such dodgeball imitations as the attack on the World Trade Center, the bombing of Afghanistan and the Enron rip-off. Let's stick with sports.
Is it because traditional gym classes, where dodgeball has always been an easy rest period for lazy and mean teachers, are failing pupils? Kids are fatter and more out of shape than ever. Is it because the traditional dodgeball-coaching style -- bullying and humiliation -- seems back in vogue? Bob Knight was hired by Texas Tech and is showing success. Or is it because three of the largest traditional dodgeball-style organizations, the International Olympic Committee, Nascar and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, seem to making honest efforts to take the ball out of the hands of bullies and give everyone a chance to play fairly?
When I.O.C. members sold the Winter Games to Salt Lake City, that was business as usual. Once the scandal became public, by taking no immediate systemic action, the I.O.C. was just continuing the Avery Brundage-Juan Antonio Samaranch standard practice of dealing with bribery, commercialism, nationalism and doping as surprising aberrations.
But the swift action of Dr. Jacques Rogge, the I.O.C. president, in the controversy over the awarding of pairs figure skating medals (whether or not the outrage was justified is beyond my judging powers) sent a welcome new message. He was admitting that something is basically amiss with Olympic officiating, at least in that sport, and something had to be done. Of course, skeptics will say, Rogge was really driven by the news media hype, which also boosted NBC's ratings.
All the speed at Nascar is usually on the track, and the stock-car organization was particularly slow in instituting safety reforms after the death of Dale Earnhardt. Some of that can be attributed to its stubborn and arrogant culture, some to its fear of appearing liable, at least in the court of fan opinion, if hard walls, rigid front ends and lax safety regulations were blamed. 
But there has been some greening on the banked track. Snipping a quarter-inch off the rear spoilers of the Fords before the Daytona 500 was an attempt to keep some competitive balance. Penalizing Sterling Marlin and Jeff Gordon -- front-runners in the race and in general -- for violations during a red-flag dead stop was another good try. Of course, say skeptics, in these tough economic times with sponsors pulling out, you had better penalize the deep-pocket teams or only a few drivers will win every race.
The N.C.A.A. has a long history of rarely penalizing important colleges, and certainly not hitting them hard. This may be changing. In the most notable of recent cases, the Alabama and Kentucky football teams lost scholarships and bowl appearances, heavy hits. At Alabama, recruits were given cars and cash by boosters. At Kentucky, the coach was bribing high school coaches and helping players cheat on classwork. Of course, the N.C.A.A. may be trying to clean up before the inevitable push to pay players over the table and a long overdue Congressional investigation.
But we never answered the original question: Is dodgeball good or bad?
Beats me.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Market Lifted by Economic Data

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
A barrage of positive economic reports propelled stocks higher last week, as investors bet that the data signaled the end of the recession.
 The week began with a report by the National Association of Realtors that existing-home sales surged 16.2 percent in January. 
Then came news of an increase in orders for durable goods in January and of an unexpected rise of 1.4 percent in the nation's gross domestic product for the fourth quarter of 2001. 
 Investors were further encouraged when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told a Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday that the economy appeared to be firming.
 A report on the nation's manufacturing sector, which recorded growth for the first time in 18 months, sent stocks on a broad-based rally on Friday.
 Semiconductor stocks gained ground after Intel and Novellus both issued positive comments. General Motors and Lowe's also recorded gains.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 400.71 points, or 4 percent, to 10,368.86. The Nasdaq composite index gained 78.20 points, or 4.5 percent, to 1,802.74. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 41.94 points, or 3.9 percent, to 1,131.78.

LENGTH: 681 words

HEADLINE: Crawling Out of Recession 

 BODY:
The major economies of the world are at present like trains side by side at a station. One or the other may be moving forward a bit, but it's hard for passengers looking out the window to tell whether it's their train or the one on the next track that is actually moving. Things are that slow, and may remain so for a time.
 At least in America's case, any backward movement has ceased. The Commerce Department announced Thursday that in the last quarter of 2001, the nation's economic output rose at an annual rate of 1.4 percent. That better-than-expected performance was driven by strong consumer spending and is a tribute to the resilience of the American economy in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks. In all of last year, the economy grew by a meager tenth of 1 percent. 
 If that is not reason enough to break out the champagne, consider this. There is now some question whether the country was ever really in a recession. The National Bureau of Economic Research -- the arbiter that looks at a wide range of data, including monthly employment and manufacturing numbers, to make its calls -- announced in November that a recession had begun last March, ending the country's longest-ever uninterrupted expansion. But the slowdown failed to meet the widely accepted rule-of-thumb definition for a recession, of two consecutive quarters of economic contraction. Only in the third quarter of 2001 did the economy actually shrink.
Making future projections is difficult. Most indicators, including manufacturing measures that have been depressed for over a year, are looking increasingly optimistic, and corporate profits are expected to start growing again in the second quarter. But few are predicting a typical recovery to follow what has been a most atypical stumble.
Past boom-and-bust cycles have been driven by consumer spending, but the spectacular slowdown in the last two years, after the tech-driven euphoria of the late 90's, broke the pattern. It was linked to a plunge in capital investments by businesses that had overinvested, particularly in areas like telecommunications, where the term recession hardly begins to describe the financial pain these days.
Meanwhile, contrary to what is supposed to happen in a downturn, spending by consumers has remained strong, despite people's losses in the stock market, rises in unemployment and the sense of insecurity that followed Sept. 11. The housing market has also remained strong.
The Federal Reserve Bank deserves a great deal of credit for helping to prop up the consumer in the face of adversity. Alan Greenspan oversaw the most aggressive interest-rate slashing in the Fed's history, dropping the nation's key short-term rate down to 1.75 percent, from 6.5 percent, with 11 cuts in a single year. The White House's claim that its regressive 10-year tax cut plan, passed by the Congress, also helped ameliorate the economic slowdown cannot be taken seriously. Indeed, by jeopardizing the country's fiscal health, the Bush tax cuts may have helped prevent long-term interest rates from falling in tandem with short-term rates.
It will take a resumption of business investment, instead of the usual burst of pent-up consumer demand, to drive this recovery. Mr. Greenspan sounded a cautious note of optimism when he testified before Congress last week, acknowledging that "influences unique to this business cycle" would temper the anticipated recovery. He is apparently in no hurry to start pushing rates back up. 
More than a million jobs have been lost to the slowdown in the last year, and Mr. Greenspan reflected the overwhelming consensus among economists when he said he expected the unemployment rate to continue rising, even during a recovery. That makes it all the more imperative for Republican leaders in the House of Representatives to stop holding an extension of unemployment benefits hostage to a package of further reckless tax cuts. 
What is true for the country at large is particularly true for the increasing numbers of unemployed Americans. This train is moving too slowly as it pulls out of the station.

HEADLINE: The World; 
The War on Terror Points a Country Toward Peace

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE

 BODY:
JUST over the horizon from Afghanistan, another war on terror may be drawing to a close. A week ago, the government of Sri Lanka and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, one of Asia's most ruthless and totalitarian rebel movements, agreed to a firm cease-fire, with the promise of peace talks to come. It is not a coincidence that this should occur within months of Sept. 11, many Sri Lankans and foreign experts say. A new international environment, born of the revulsion, shock or just plain fear engendered by attacks on the United States, has made it possible.
 The situation has parallels in Northern Ireland, where it has been widely assumed that a decision by the Irish Republican Army in October to start turning in arms was also related to a new atmosphere low on romanticism for violent causes. 
 But the new environment works two ways. In other areas, as worried human rights organizations point out, countries have felt emboldened to deal more harshly with rebel movements -- from Russia to Uzbekistan, India, China, Colombia and the Philippines. Far from pushing these conflicts toward negotiation, the zero-tolerance approach has worked to intensify the push for a military solution -- if only because both sides feel they can win.
Robert B. Oakley, a former American ambassador in Pakistan, Somalia and Congo and a former State Department counterterrorism director, says the American campaign against Al Qaeda "sort of puts a damper on a movement, and it encourages people to take a stronger stand against it." At the same time, he said, governments find it easier to label any rebel a terrorist. "It encourages people to say: 'Hey! Come help me deal with my internal problems because they all are terrorist related.' "
In Sri Lanka, there is no longer much dispute about the nature of the Tamil rebellion, which began as a movement to rectify discrimination by the country's ethnic Sinhalese majority and turned, under the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, into a brutal campaign of terror that annihilated the moderate opposition through assassination and dragooned children, who were taught to embrace suicide. At least 65,000 people have died.
Well before Sept. 11, the United States and Britain had declared the Tigers a terrorist organization; so had India, which once trained them but is now seeking the extradition of their leader, Velupillai Prabakharan, for plotting the assassination in 1991 of the Indian leader Rajiv Gandhi. Many governments have vowed to stop the rebels' global fund-raising.
An issue more relevant now to Sri Lankans and others in need of help to achieve peace is whether their wars on terrorism matter to important nations, most of all the United States. Last Monday, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe appealed for concrete outside help in keeping pressure on the Tigers to honor this truce, and in rebuilding the economy.
Sri Lankans know there are disadvantages in being far off the beaten track from the hunt for Al Qaeda. Not only are there no significant links to Muslim terrorists, a Sri Lankan official said. "We don't have oil. We are of no use to the United States or other powers." Nepal, facing a Maoist rebellion of intense violence, is also off the American radar. Instead, American troops have rushed to the southern Philippines to train Filipino troops battling Abu Sayaf, a less threatening group by many measures, except for reported links to Al Qaeda.
Most recently, the Bush administration began considering military assistance to Yemen, where suicide bombers killed 17 sailors on the destroyer Cole in 2000, and to Georgia, where a border area is believed to be the staging ground for Muslims who, with help from Al Qaeda fighters, are rebelling against Russian rule in Chechnya. But the possibility of putting American troops as trainers in that sensitive area sets off alarms in Russia -- and also among human rights groups, who fear it would only encourage Russia in its brutal tactics against Chechen separatists.
IN Colombia, President Andres Pastrana has abruptly abandoned a peace agreement after provocative rebel kidnappings and scattered attacks, and last week resumed war against leftist guerrillas allied with drug dealers. Victoria Sanford, an anthropology professor at the University of Notre Dame who has worked in Colombia recently, said American objectives there may actually be hindering peace moves. "I think that Pastrana deeply cares about peace in Colombia," she said, "but Pastrana can only implement and push for peace if he is supported by the United States. If the United States isn't going to back up his peace initiatives, they fall apart."
In Sri Lanka, Norway alone has come to the aid of the peace-minded government by talking the Tigers into a truce. Now cease-fire monitors from the Nordic countries are preparing bases, and roads are being opened to allow freer movement by Sri Lankans who have lived in privation under Tiger rule and a government economic embargo. That is only a small beginning, said Radikha Coomaraswamy, director of the International Center for Ethnic Studies in Colombo, adding that there will have to be a major international presence in Tiger territory. 
Teresita C. Schaffer, who was the American ambassador to Sri Lanka from 1992 to 1995, expressed reservations about how much foreign efforts to ban the Tigers and stop their money-raising would hinder the group, which has a worldwide network of front companies, its own shipping line, and a history of overrunning Sri Lankan army bases to steal arms.
STILL, she said, the Tigers may be weakened militarily, which could explain their inability to recapture Jaffna. "Why did they stop?" she said. "I have to believe it was because they couldn't go on."
In the end, that may be the deciding factor in whether the no-tolerance atmosphere toward terrorism pushes a particular conflict toward negotiation or war. Even if the Tigers are now hoping only to buy time for rearming and recruitment, as many Sri Lankans fear, there is a peace constituency in the country as well as an antiterrorism sentiment outside, Ms. Schaffer said. And in that country, at least, the combination may make this the moment to make an agreement stick.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Money Market Fund Yields Drop

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer

 BODY:
Yields on money market funds plunged to record lows last week, reflecting the lagging effects of the Federal Reserve's cuts in short-term interest rates last year.
 For the week ending Tuesday, the average seven-day yield for taxable funds fell to 1.39 percent from 1.41 percent a week earlier, according to iMoneyNet of Westborough, Mass. 
Tax-free funds fell to 0.89 percent from 0.9 percent. 
 Short-term interest rates have plummeted as a result of 11 rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Although the Fed has not cut rates since December, money market yields have continued to decline. 
None of the 783 money funds tracked by iMoneyNet now yield more than 2 percent, and several funds have cut the expenses they charge to investors to keep their returns positive.
The highest seven-day yield among taxable money funds belonged to the Bunker Hill Money Market fund and the Touchstone Money Market fund, both at 1.92 percent, followed by the PayPal Money Market fund at 1.88 percent, the agency said. 
Among tax-free money market funds, the highest seven-day yield was 1.40 percent, at Vanguard Ohio Tax-Exempt Money Market.

HEADLINE: The Transformation Of Accounting Firms 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Watchdog? Lap Dog? Why Have to Guess?" (Market Watch, Feb. 17) listed 16 companies that paid more than 90 percent of their fees to accounting firms for services other than auditing. The column noted that accounting firms' audit work, which brings lower fees, "could be jeopardized by the desire to maintain the more lucrative consulting relationship." 
 Even though major accounting firms have long disputed this position, they have finally recognized that perception is reality and have or are spinning off their consulting practices from the audit and tax practices. What are the ramifications of this unbundling process?
One clear result is that audit fees must be raised. They must rise to attract the best and brightest into a profession for which there is no substitute in our economic system. Audit fees must also be increased to offset the loss of higher-margin consulting services. Fees for audit services must now stand on their own and reflect the fair, proportionate cost of doing business in our increasingly complex business world.

EDWARD M. ROSE
Chapel Hill, N.C., Feb. 17

The writer is a retired partner at KPMG.

HEADLINE: Chester Journal; 
Track and Casino Turn a Rust Belt Town Green

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: CHESTER, W.Va., Feb. 27 

 BODY:
The sense of mortality can seem overwhelming along the depressed Ohio River Valley as Big Steel heads into the Big Sleep and hundreds of dish and pottery factories -- the valley's old artisan glory -- dwindle to a precious few.
 But wait: a gray-haired retiree bused in from Pittsburgh has just hit the big payoff in nickels over at the video slots in a flourishing gambling oasis called Speakeasy. 
 Outside, beyond the gleeful bonging and beeping of the 2,000 slot machines, an ultramodern racetrack is being groomed for another night of Thoroughbred betting by blue-collar commuters from Ohio searching for merciful odds along a riverfront dotted with snow patches and abandoned factories.
Downtown at Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 6450, even the veterans' long-illicit civic boon of modest gambling for money and charity has come out of the closet, legalized at last with new video slots ready for the growing market. 
Somehow, Chester, W.Va., population 2,723, is becoming known as a "destination resort" for gamblers, with Tony Bennett, Kenny Rogers and other high-roller saloon singers booked to croon where the action is, down at the growing Mountaineer Race Track and Gaming Resort.
Tucked away at the crest of West Virginia's narrow northern panhandle, this tiny city is at the heart of an economic renaissance that is drawing 35,000 gamblers a week from nearby Pennsylvania and Ohio, where slot machine action is illegal. West Virginia is only a few miles wide at this point, but it beckons like El Dorado.
"We used to think gambling was a sin around here," said Shirley Barnhart, the city clerk, amused at all the virtue that Chester and surrounding communities are discovering in slot machines and pari mutuel betting.
Ten years ago, Mountaineer was a failing backwater track known as Waterford Downs. The crowds were sparse and the purses laughable, as cheap claimers tried to outrun the abattoir. Its tired venue matched the region's rusting steel mills.
But then Edson Arneault, better known as Ted, arrived like a rainmaker and turned a small state experiment with limited video gambling at the track into a low-roller slice of Las Vegas that has created hundreds of jobs and fed tens of millions of dollars in fresh revenue into government coffers. Tapping into a blue-collar market of eight million people within a two-hour drive, Mr. Arneault's company is rated one of the nation's fastest growing by Forbes and Fortune, generating $218 million in revenues last year and $19 million in profits in an area rife with the symptoms of depression.
"I call it a Joe Six-Pack crowd," Mr. Arneault said of his customers, who can bet modestly, from 5 cents to $5, at Mountaineer. "They're great. They don't have the whims and whimsy of big players in Vegas, and they tend to be shielded from tremendous changes in the economy and stock market. For them, it's entertainment."
Mr. Arneault managed to get the legislature to allow a big slot-machine casino to be added to the racetrack, with a convention center, a spa and more than 300 hotel rooms. The gambling mecca has become a regional monopoly, 35 miles from Pittsburgh and 60 miles from Akron. It contributed more than $50 million to West Virginia last year, while local governments gained $3.5 million.
His company, the MTR Gaming Group, has put money back into the track and its purses and entered the larger lucrative world of off-track betting. In five years, Mountaineer's sales have increased an average of 43 percent and earnings 54 percent.
"Before this, all that we were known for was the World's Largest Teapot out on the highway," said Mayor Ken Morris, a steelworker, referring to Chester's lingering identity as the home of Fiesta Ware. Now gambling dwarfs the teapot, with more than a quarter of the city's $400,000 budget from Mountaineer revenue.
"And they just gave us a new police car, too," Mr. Morris said gratefully, noting that the state had become relaxed enough about gambling to permit video slots to other institutions, like the V.F.W. hall. "Now it's legal, and everybody gets their cut."
The cut's ramifications are many. Not only is Dana Picciarelli, a member of the City Council, working for Mountaineer in the vault department, but Geoff Rovin, a substance abuse therapist in nearby Weirton, is busier, too. He is one of 50 counselors on call for gambling addicts who turn to the Problem Gamblers Help Network of West Virginia.
"Gamblers tend to think they have a cash flow problem, not an addiction problem," said Mia Moran-Cooper, the Problem Gamblers program director, estimating that one in five gamblers has a problem.
But like the health hazards of the dead steel mills, such is the cost of doing business. The traffic remains steady outside City Hall as the bridge from Ohio and the mountain road from Pennsylvania funnel fresh gamblers onto the streets of Chester in a beeline to the slots.
"I kind of wish we stayed back in the old economy," Ms. Barnhart, the city clerk, said wistfully, though hardly moralizing about the Chester renaissance. "It was nice when we were the pottery center of the U.S."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chester, W.Va., draws gamblers from nearby Ohio and Pennsylvania. Kay Cunningham came from Greensburg, Pa., to play the slots. (Jason Cohn for The New York Times) Map of West Virginia highlighting Chester: Tiny Chester beckons out-of-state gamblers like El Dorado.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Bangladeshis Hold Suburban Dream Together, Without Buttons

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: HUDSON, N.Y. 

 BODY:
FOR a while, it looked as if Bangla was on its way to becoming this city's official second language.
 Few of Hudson's 8,000 residents realized it at the time. All the attention went to the antique stores popping up along Warren Street, to the culture clash that ensued when a dying-but-not-dead industrial town was overrun by artsy types and second-home buyers from Manhattan. 
 But on the drug-infested north side, hard by the Hudson River, a wholly different migration was bringing the inflections and aromas of Dhaka, and of Jackson Heights, to scores of second-story apartments and creaking clapboard houses. 
It started sometime after 1986, when the Emsig Manufacturing Corporation, the nation's largest maker of buttons -- an old but little-known giant of the garment industry -- abandoned its ancient West 60th Street plant in Manhattan after a fire. With incentives from the state, Emsig opened a new factory on a reclaimed landfill here, a two-hour drive up the Thruway.
As the story goes, a man named Abutale was the first Bangladeshi to take a job there. Aminul Hoque was the sixth, arriving from Queens in August 1994 with his wife and daughter, a good command of English, and a deep desire to help his countrymen escape the crime and high cost of living in New York City.
At Emsig, the diligent Mr. Hoque was quickly put in charge of training new workers. Turnover was so high, fueled by rampant cocaine and heroin use, that he was as exhausted as his bosses were frustrated. "I'd have to work my work, and when I was training someone, I'd have to do his work, too," said Mr. Hoque, now 43. "And the next week, or the next day, they don't show up."
The bosses asked if Mr. Hoque knew any more Bangladeshis with his kind of work ethic. So Mr. Hoque became Worker Zero, bringing at least 10 families to Hudson from New York or from his homeland. Indirectly, he says, he is responsible for nearly 75 of the roughly 200 of his countrymen who eventually moved here.
With monthly rents as low as $275 -- before being split among several workers -- the Bangladeshi community flourished. A basement was turned into a mosque, a part-time imam lured from an apple-packaging plant in New Paltz to work alongside his flock on the Emsig assembly line.
And the button factory, bolstered by a stable work force, spat out four million buttons a day over three shifts, the sweet smell of polyester resin fumes overtaking the odors of the old landfill. In 1998, the factory was enlarged, with help from the state and city: a $1.6 million low-interest loan, 15-year tax abatements and discounts on electricity.
BUT buttons imported from China and, to a lesser extent, button-free fashions, were eating away at Emsig's sales. In 1999, according to records shown to officials of Unite, the garment industry union, Emsig lost $860,000. Losses reached $1 million in 2000. The overnight shift was laid off first. Then, late last year, the rumors were confirmed: Feb. 5 would be the factory's last day.
Now, as Mr. Hoque helps his countrymen once more -- this time to pursue unemployment benefits, alternative medical coverage, accrued sick and vacation pay, and settlements from the union pension plan -- the fate of this Bangladeshi colony is suddenly in doubt.
The Dewan family may have lost the most. "I hurt so much that I'm numb," said Dewan H. Ullah, 55, who left a job in a Manhattan parking lot to run a laser engraver on the first shift. His wife, Dewan Azima Khatun, 45, plucked out poor-quality buttons on the second shift. Their son, daughter and son-in-law worked there too, for hourly wages of $9.10 to $10.50.
Some Bangladeshis have already moved away, but the Dewans hope to stay. Mr. Dewan loves the fresh air here. And his children have put down roots beyond a mortgage. Bashar, 22, the only adult child who never worked at Emsig, married his Hudson High School sweetheart, Elsie. They have a 3-year-old toddler, Jasmine.
Eleven in all, the Dewans bought a house. From the outside it looks like a remnant of an urban renewal effort given up long ago: prefabricated, two-story, tumbledown. But inside is a palace of plush carpets and oriental rugs, three freezers full of whole carp, hilsa shad and buffalo fish, and savory samosas teeming from the oven.
It is a palace worth preserving. Tomorrow, Mr. Dewan will drive to a factory in Kingston, 40 miles away, in a car with four other former button men. Mrs. Dewan, acknowledged as the community's best cook, wants to start catering, and if that works, perhaps open a Bengali restaurant.
A Mexican restaurant that opened here did not survive, but Mrs. Dewan is undeterred. "I'll try anything," she said.

HEADLINE: TV Executive Defeats Police Chief To Become Mayor of New Orleans 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
A cable television executive with no political experience was elected mayor of New Orleans yesterday, sweeping past the city's police chief in a come-from-behind victory.
 The executive, C. Ray Nagin, 45, will succeed Mayor Marc A. Morial, who was barred by law from seeking a third term. Mr. Morial made no endorsement in the race, declining to support Richard J. Pennington, the police chief he brought from Washington in 1994. 
 Unofficial results last night showed Mr. Nagin with 58 percent of the vote and Mr. Pennington, who led in polls when the campaign began, with 42 percent.
"New Orleans is going to do things different," Mr. Nagin told cheering supporters after Mr. Pennington conceded Saturday night. I'm not in it for the money, I'm in it for our children and grandchildren."
 Although both men are Democrats and black, each presented a different approach to running one of the country's poorest large cities. Mr. Nagin, who is on leave as a vice president of Cox Communications, which operates the local cable system, emphasized his business background as a foundation for rebuilding the city's economy and creating jobs. Having entered the race late with little name recognition, he spent freely, and proposed selling or leasing Louis Armstrong International Airport and using the revenue to rebuild decaying infrastructure and create jobs.
Mr. Pennington ran on his record of reducing the city's murder rate, vowing to bring similar improvements to education.
But opinion polls showed that Mr. Nagin's business experience, and lack of political ties, held significant appeal for many voters in the city's black middle-class and white neighborhoods. 
Mr. Pennington was seen by many voters as too close to the city's political establishment, with its history of cronyism and sweetheart contracts.
The campaign turned nasty in the last few weeks of the runoff campaign, with Mr. Pennington accusing Mr. Nagin of Republican tendencies, and Mr. Nagin saying the police chief had been on public assistance his entire career. 
Mr. Nagin later apologized for the remark.

Sol Stein of Miami, FL. He died on March 1, 2002, at the age of 96. Born in Vilna, Lithuania, Dr. Stein is survived by his beloved son, and was predeceased by his wife Luba. HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 3-03-02: DOCUMENT; 
Rambo Takes a Hit

BYLINE:  By Cameron Stracher 

 BODY:
It's not easy facing the twilight years in an Enron economy. First, Ken Lay had to sell the house in Aspen. Now, another aging pensioner is shocked -- shocked! -- by the financial shenanigans going on under his very own nose. In a lawsuit filed on Feb. 14 in California Superior Court in Los Angeles, Sylvester (Sly) Stallone alleges that he was led financially astray by one Kenneth Starr -- not the Clinton nemesis but Stallone's business manager and investment adviser. Stallone, a litigious fellow who has sued not only his father-in-law for mishandling his money but also his former nannies, landscapers, car dealers, real-estate agents, art dealers, producers and wives, accuses Starr of duping him into holding onto shares of Planet Hollywood stock until it was virtually worthless. 
 The suit depicts Stallone as a conservative investor, averse to risk, who considered the inside of a mattress the perfect investment vehicle. "When Stallone first retained Starr & Company as his business manager/investment adviser, he advised Kenneth Starr that he wanted to be invested only in conservative investments that were liquid . . . and that he wanted most of his investments to be in the form of cash, cash equivalents and other low-risk, liquid investments that would allow him peace of mind and easy access to his funds." 
 As a founder of Planet Hollywood, however, he didn't want to be cut out of the action. " Stallone wanted to make sure that he would receive substantial monetary compensation for the services he had rendered and was continuing to render to Planet Hollywood International for which Plaintiffs were issued the shares of stock. Stallone was advised by Kenneth Starr not to sell the stock, that by doing so he would be hurting the company . . . as he would be sending the wrong message to the market, and that the price of the Planet Hollywood International stock could be expected to go much higher." 
Stallone contends that he was sacrificed in favor of one of Starr's other clients, Keith Barish, a member of Planet Hollywood's board. "Kenneth Starr was aware that if Plaintiffs sold their stock, such a sale might depress the stock price, which would jeopardize or lessen the value of the holdings of Starr & Company's other client, Keith Barish." Barish, the suit alleges, was the real insider, while Stallone never got to peak behind the velvet rope.
Ultimately, of course, it's all about money. "Plaintiffs have sustained damages in an unknown amount, but believed to be in excess of $10 million, based upon the sale price they could have received had Kenneth Starr and Starr & Company acted in Stallone's best interest and advised him to sell the shares of Planet Hollywood International stock at then prevailing market prices." Instead, he was forced to cash out for a meager $295,000. Sounds like coupon-clipping time for Sly and the family Stallone. Cameron Stracher

CORRECTION-DATE: March 3, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Page 28 of The Times Magazine today about a current lawsuit filed by Sylvester Stallone misidentifies one of the people involved in a previous Stallone lawsuit. It was his former stepfather, not his father-in-law.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
Only Japan's Wealthy Welcome at This Bank

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
TO Koichiro Kitade, Japan is part paradise, part paradox. Mr. Kitade, director of the Citigroup Private Bank here, has the enviable task of finding clients who hold part of the country's vast $10.5 trillion in personal savings. There are plenty of wealthy people here, but battered by recession, deflation and a lack of choices, the Japanese are among the world's most tightfisted investors. More than half their money is stashed in savings accounts that earn almost no interest.
 By most reckoning, though, Mr. Kitade appears to have solved a riddle that has perplexed bankers here for years: how to persuade the Japanese to move even a fraction of their money into potentially more rewarding investments. Amid the rubble of Japan's financial system, sales at Citigroup's private banking services, which are open to investors with assets of at least 300 million yen ($2.3 million), have grown more than 25 percent a year for four years. 
 That puts Citigroup's private bank in a league with the insurer Aflac Japan, the investment firm Goldman Sachs and a handful of other foreign companies that have carved out a niche in Japan's insular and sometimes hostile financial markets. In fact, Citigroup is growing just as Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and others retreat from retail finance in Japan. Those companies pulled up stakes in recent months after attempts to woo individual investors fell flat. 
Their exit reinforced the Japanese stereotype of American companies as fair-weather opportunists. But Citigroup promotes itself as a stable alternative to those brokers, who swaggered with confidence in the late 1990's. Its longevity -- it has been in Japan a century -- and its low-key image apparently worked: Citigroup's fortunes have risen as stock and real estate prices have fallen to near two-decade lows and reports have surfaced daily raising questions about the health of the nation's banks.
Therein lies the key to its success. The further that confidence in domestic lenders slips, the better opportunity that global companies with deep pockets have to sell security to conservative investors. "We provide safety, while most local banks have difficulty even maintaining their existence," Mr. Kitade said.
Sitting in a well-appointed meeting room with plush sofas and an unobstructed view of the Imperial Palace, Mr. Kitade outlines another, entirely un-Japanese feature of his bank: its sales pitch. In a country where 9 out of 10 people consider themselves middle class, banks often move in lock step by offering one-size-fits-all financial products. The Japanese affinity for understatement also means that even the wealthiest people visit the corner A.T.M.
But Citigroup, like its foreign rivals here, focuses on an emerging class of savers who travel overseas and understand the Western notion that wealth bestows a better brand of service. That is why Citigroup's private bank has its own office, separate from its retail operation across the street in Tokyo's Otemachi financial district.
"Citigroup is private and global, so as a customer you become part of a self-selected elite," said Robert Kopech, managing director at Oliver, Wyman & Company, an international financial services consultant. "This is a novel approach in Japan, where historically the trend has been toward homogeneity."
The approach carries into marketing. Comparative advertising is often shunned as crass in Japan, where companies of all stripes try to project a "friend next door" image of reliability and plainness. So when Mr. Kitade took over the private-banking operation in 1997 and ran advertisements asking only the wealthy to apply, Japanese banks accused him of discrimination.
The weekly ads, however, were an instant hit, with 20 percent of the respondents signing on as customers. The number of clients doubled in 1998 and has since grown 20 percent a year, to about 7,500. Assets under management have more than tripled, to $12 billion, helping the private banking group earn about $30 million after taxes last year, according to Henry McVey, a Morgan Stanley analyst.
By 2005, Mr. Kitade hopes to more than double his client list, to 20,000. 
Getting to this point, however, has not been easy. Citigroup started offering private banking services in 1986, during Japan's bubble years, when millionaires were born daily on the stock market and banks were for pensioners. The subsequent crash sent shell-shocked investors scurrying for cash and bonds, not fancy derivatives and dollar accounts. And private banks here, unlike those in the United States, cannot charge consulting fees. Kicked to the side, Citigroup's private bank division lost money its first 11 years.
But the situation turned around in 1997, when financial reforms in Japan started pulling down the walls that long protected banks, brokers and insurers from one another. Commissions on stock trades were deregulated, and banks lost their monopoly on foreign exchange transactions. Those two steps have forced financial institutions to develop unique products at lower prices.
At the same time, the collapse of several large banks and brokers focused investors' attention on stability. Citigroup's international bank, Citibank, with a double-A credit rating that is just two notches below the top possible grade, became a magnet for investors seeking safety and an easier path to moving money offshore. To that end, Citigroup, like many private banks, employs Japanese speakers at its branches in New York, London, Geneva, Singapore, Hong Kong and Honolulu.
THIS global reach is what brought Kohei Yamanaka in the door. Mr. Yamanaka, 57, now an adviser to the Hoya Corporation, an industrial glassmaker, traveled abroad monthly while he worked his way up the ladder at the company, with regular stops in Frankfurt, Hong Kong and New York. (Rome and Hawaii were reserved for holidays.) He opened a savings account in 1995 so he could use his A.T.M. card overseas.
Kentaro Kaneko, one of Citigroup's 70 private bankers in Japan, approached Mr. Yamanaka, who opened a private banking account after four months. Mr. Yamanaka, like most Japanese, knew nothing about private banking, so Mr. Kaneko guided him through the basics. 
The hard work, however, started after the account was opened. Most Japanese have a high proportion of their savings tied up in businesses, homes and insurance policies. They are often reluctant to sell assets. People like Mr. Yamanaka, who own huge amounts of stock accumulated over decades, face stiff capital gains taxes when they sell. 
Over all, according to a PricewaterhouseCoopers study, wealthy Asian households, on average, have 40 percent of their money in deposits, 20 percent in real estate, 20 percent in managed funds and just 10 percent in securities. Rich Americans, by contrast, keep most of their money in equities and a small amount in cash.
In Mr. Yamanaka's case, almost all his wealth was wrapped up in his company's stock, which he accumulated over many years. So Citigroup helped him shift 15 percent of his money gradually into global equity funds, bonds, Japanese stock index funds, real estate investment trusts and foreign currency time deposits, especially those in dollars. "Since Japan's economy is getting worse," he said, "money in Japanese banks can't generate decent returns, so I thought it was time to leave the nest and seek better returns overseas."
Mr. Yamanaka was also introduced to Cititrust, a unit of Citigroup that manages trust accounts. Cititrust helped him buy an apartment building in Tokyo; the rent from the property produces a 7 percent return. He has also availed himself of the extra perks that private banks shower on clients, like fireworks displays and jazz concerts. He is also angling for tickets to the Masters golf tournament in Augusta, Ga. Citigroup's branch in Honolulu is helping him look for a home on the islands.
OF course, Japanese private banks fawn over their clients, too, but with less fanfare. Their main selling point is their nationwide networks and ability to leverage property into other liquid assets. Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, with 310 domestic branches, also works with a major homebuilder to spot potential clients. "You have to understand the nature of the Japanese and the large amount of land they hold," said Sunao Hirai, head of the private banking group at Dai-Ichi Kangyo.
Citigroup casts a smaller, finer net. Instead of trying to find clients who want a little better service at home, the bank seeks those more interested in moving money overseas. In effect, it is offering to bump up clients to business class, but also to charter them a whole new jet.

HEADLINE: Saving at Wal-Mart, But Paying a Price 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Enriched by Working Class, Wal-Mart Eyes BMW Crowd" (front page, Feb. 24) did not mention a significant reason behind Wal-Mart's success: the company's overt anti-unionism and the low wages paid to its employees. 
 Wal-Mart's grocery prices do often undercut those at competing supermarkets, and this is to a large degree because the retail food industry tends to be unionized and thus to pay workers a living wage and decent benefits. 
Wal-Mart's sales associates tend to earn minimum wage with few benefits. 
 This saves the company money on payroll and perhaps also keeps the customers coming, because Wal-Mart's more than one million employees can't afford to shop anywhere else.

KATHERINE L. HUGHES
New York, Feb. 27, 2002

The writer is a senior research associate, Institute on Education and the Economy, Columbia University.

HEADLINE: A Far-Right Militia's Far-Fetched Plot Draws Some Serious Attention 

BYLINE:  By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: KALISPELL, Mont., March 2 

 BODY:
As its secrets began to spill out here this week, Project 7 sounded suspiciously like a Monty Python sketch.
 A dogcatcher was on its list of 26 local law enforcement officials who needed killing. The chief intelligence gatherer for the furtive far-right militia cell was a cleaning woman, according to Sheriff James R. Dupont of Flathead County, who himself made the hit list of Project 7. The militia's name comes from the Montana license plate numbering system, which uses the numeral 7 to identify residents of Flathead. 
 The cleaning woman, Tracy Brockway, 32, was having an affair with the leader of Project 7 in a house bristling with 35 guns and thousands of rounds of ammunition, the sheriff said. He identified the militia's leader as David Earl Burgert, 38, whose last known job was renting snowmobiles, who could often be heard carping about judges on a local right-wing radio station and who has a long history of being annoying. At Christmas, when his neighbors lined streets with paper bags containing lighted candles, Mr. Burgert mounted his snowmobile and snuffed them out. 
"If you picture a schoolyard bully who has a big mouth, that would be Burgert," said Bruce Parish, a detective in the sheriff's office.
This far northwest corner of Montana, along with the nearby northern neck of Idaho, has for decades been incubating right-wing militias, conspiracy theorists and white supremacists. Many of them have demonstrated an outsize appetite for military hardware and survival gear.
Kalispell (population 17,000) might seem an unlikely staging ground for militias bearing grudges. It is the county seat of Flathead County, one of the fastest-growing communities in Montana and a pristine outdoor destination that includes half of Glacier National Park and more than a million acres of mountain wilderness. The town is near the northern end of Flathead Lake, the largest freshwater lake in the West and one of the cleanest lakes in the world.
Yet a decades-old decline in an economy based on logging and mining, combined with the rise of a New West culture dominated by affluent professionals and retirees who go outside not to work but to recreate, has left many local people confused, resentful and looking for someone to blame. Project 7 appears to have set a new standard, both for zany scapegoating and for industrial-strength firepower.
"This is the weirdest, most violence-prone thing we have seen in Montana for a long time," said Ken Toole, a Democratic state senator who runs the Montana Human Rights Network, which studies right-wing movements in Montana and Idaho. "There is a comic element to these people," Mr. Toole said. "But it washes away pretty quickly because of the guns."
The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms are taking it all seriously.
On Friday, after a long meeting with the county sheriff and the police chief in Kalispell, the F.B.I. took charge of the conspiracy investigation into possible links that Mr. Burgert may have had with other right-wing groups. The A.T.F. took charge of tracking all the weapons.
After a tip early last month from a Project 7 defector, the sheriff's department found two trailers packed with 30,000 rounds of ammunition, a broad array of small arms, body armor, pipe bombs, exploding booby traps, bomb-making chemicals and a vast inventory of survivalist gear and military rations.
"I think it would have taken hundreds of thousands of dollars to buy all that stuff at once," Detective Parish said. "So it is very possible that it was built up over several years."
What Project 7 was gearing up for, said the defector who tipped off the sheriff, was a round of assassinations in early summer. The sheriff's department discovered a list of what appeared to be targets that included local judges, the county prosecutor, the Kalispell chief of police, members of a police swat team and the dogcatcher.
Some of the targets worked at a police station in the nearby town of Whitefish, where Mrs. Brockway was employed. The sheriff said she had apparently sifted through trash baskets, gleaning information about where some officers filled their prescriptions and how others struggled with their weight. The sheriff's department found information sheets detailing her discoveries.
"The logic of their plan, if you can call it logic, was that by killing local law enforcement people, the state of Montana would have no choice but to send in the National Guard," Sheriff Dupont said. "Then they hoped to wipe out the National Guard. And then they hoped that NATO troops would be sent in and that would trigger an all-out revolution."
The sheriff and Detective Parish rolled their eyes incredulously as they explained what Project 7 hoped to accomplish. They suggested that Mr. Burgert was a blowhard who had bitten off more than he could chew.
Investigators from the sheriff's department say they have identified four or perhaps five local people who were involved in the plot. Two of them, Mr. Burgert and Mrs. Brockway, are in custody. Two of the others have told investigators that while they knew about Project 7, they had no intention of killing anyone.
Sheriff Dupont learned of the plot in early February, after Mr. Burgert disappeared for nearly a month. Mr. Burgert's wife reported him mysteriously absent on Jan. 9. His pickup truck was found near a local river, with his fishing pole. His wife hinted to the sheriff's department that maybe he had drowned.
The sheriff's department, though, smelled a rat. Mr. Burgert had no hook on his fishing line and his tackle box, deputies said, was filled with lures that no respectable Montana fisherman would ever use.
On Feb. 7, Mr. Burgert, who had become a fugitive after failing to show up for a hearing on charges that he punched a sheriff's deputy in early 2001, was spotted coming out of Mrs. Brockway's home.
Her husband, Alan Brockway, also a suspect in the militia plot, left Montana for Israel several months ago. "The information we have is that he left because of the affair between his wife and Mr. Burgert," Detective Parish said.
After Mr. Burgert was spotted, sheriff's deputies staked out the house. When he and Mrs. Brockway drove off in a heavy snowstorm, deputies gave chase. Mr. Burgert slid off the road, but fled into the woods, carrying a rifle. After trackers found him and after an all-night standoff, during which Mr. Burgert held the gun under is chin and threatened to shoot himself, he surrendered.
All this happened in early February, which was when local investigators first got wind of Project 7 and the assassination plot. The sheriff's office kept the lid on its investigation, as computer experts from the state police tried -- and, so far, failed -- to crack encrypted information found on Mr. Burgert's home computer.
The lid came off on Tuesday, when Mrs. Brockway went to court for a bond hearing. On the witness stand, she announced the existence of Project 7 and local reporters began asking questions. Sheriff Dupont and other local law enforcement officials quickly decided to reveal the inquiry. 
"The real scary part of this whole deal is, what if we had not got onto Mr. Burgert?" the sheriff asked in an interview on Friday evening in his office. "Could he have recruited enough people to execute the plan?"
Answering his own question, the sheriff said he doubted Mr. Burgert's conspiratorial skills. "It was always his mouth that got him in trouble," the sheriff said.

HEADLINE: Big Burden for Ex-Workers of Enron 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, March 1 

 BODY:
It has come to this for Laura Chapa: After sending out more than 300 resumes since losing her job at Enron three months ago, she had gotten exactly two interviews and no jobs. Then she got a tip from her daughter, Bernadette, who works in a jobs program for college students that needed more people.
 So Ms. Chapa, 40, who had been a software tester at Enron, drove to an interview on Thursday. She was one of 12 applicants for four positions. She wore a black business suit; the other candidates wore jeans. If she is accepted, the one-way trip from her suburban home will be 47 miles. 
 It would bring no benefits, no vacation, no sick days and half her salary at Enron. She would be required to enroll in a local college. But she is praying she gets it. 
"It's a job, how's that?" Ms. Chapa explained.
For most of the 4,000 former workers who were laid off at Enron's headquarters here when the company filed for bankruptcy in December, the search for new jobs has been slow, painful and frustrating. Part of the problem is the slack local job market, which absorbed 20,000 layoffs last year. But many former Enron employees also say they believe that company's now-infamous tilted "E" logo, once a symbol of excellence but now synonymous with corporate corruption, has become a scarlet letter on their resumes.
Precise figures on the employment status of ex-Enron workers are not available. Some have found jobs, others are starting businesses. But the overwhelming majority are still believed to be jobless, most of them low- and midlevel employees who saw their retirement accounts decimated and are now struggling to pay their bills. 
Some have sent hundreds of resumes without getting an interview. Others say that, during interviews, they have been quizzed about their ethics or chastised about Enron's corporate culture.
"You really can't find a job," said Gwen Gray, 42, who spent three years at Enron working as a senior human resources assistant and has already lost one clerical job because of her ties to the company. "I've been sending out resumes like crazy."
The frustration boiled over last Monday during a town hall meeting of about 320 ex-Enron workers with the company's acting chief executive, Stephen F. Cooper. The audience peppered Mr. Cooper with questions, including one man who rose to describe how Enron had not only left many of them penniless but had also unfairly stigmatized them in the eyes of other employers. The crowd gave him a raucous cheer of support.
A day earlier, a help-wanted advertisement in The Houston Chronicle seemed to smack of blacklisting. The Houston unit of a financial printing and information management business, Bowne & Company, was inviting applicants for legal clerking positions to attend two job fairs, with specific exemptions. "No current or former employees of Enron, Arthur Andersen or the U.S. Government will be considered," the notice stated.
But a Bowne senior vice president, Joseph O. Miles, said the jobs involved working on a temporary, confidential assignment with Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm embroiled in the Enron scandal. He said the caveat was necessary to avoid a possible conflict of interest, but that ex-Enron workers were eligible for other positions. 
"We deeply regret any misunderstanding regarding that job fair," he said.
Local headhunters say they have been inundated with Enron resumes and noted that, in general, finding a new job often takes several months or longer, particularly for higher-level positions. One new nonprofit organization, the Resource Alliance Group of Houston, has been formed to help former Enron workers start new businesses. 
Kathie Nordt, a headhunter who specializes in Internet technology, said most ex-Enron people have been well received but acknowledged that the corporation itself was resented by some other companies in town.
"There are a lot of people who were offended by the arrogance of Enron in the business world," Ms. Nordt said. Asked about a possible backlash against former workers, she said, "There may be a little bit of that."
As one former Enron employee who lives outside Texas put it, "The word Enron raises all kinds of negative things an employer might balk at." The former employee, who asked not to be named, is now a finalist for a job that would involve interaction with the media as well as with elected officials. He had no connection with or knowledge of the Enron scandal, but he said he could not escape it.
"They've told me directly that the one thing that I'll have to address about my background is the Enron factor," he said. "Either be prepared to defend it or at least understand that it is a factor that works against me."
Ms. Chapa, the software tester, had been recruited by Enron in December 2000 after spending two years as a software tester for a company doing research at the NASA space center in Houston. She had jumped at the offer because Enron doubled her salary and carried a cachet. Her resume was pretty slim, since she had spent 15 years raising her three children. Now the biggest name on that resume, Enron, is hurting her.
"A lot of recruiters will ask you exactly what you know about this fiasco," she said. "I don't know anything."
Enron was known for paying top salaries and awarding generous bonuses, a positive that suddenly looks like a negative to many employers and job recruiters. Ms. Chapa said one recruiter complained that Enron employees were spoiled by high salaries and added, "Nobody gave me a job when I lost my job."
Cheryl Kuehl, an administrative assistant for Enron Energy Services, is still jobless after six interviews. "They say, 'We don't know what was going on there, but you guys were very overpaid,' " Ms. Kuehl said. "I think that's because none can offer as much as Enron did."
She said she is willing to take less money, but that even those lower-paying jobs are in high demand. In December, she received several calls for interviews, but now the market is tighter. She interviewed for one clerical position that paid $10 an hour but found that seven other people were also interviewing.
"I made four times that amount at Enron," she said.
As yet, the impact of Enron's collapse on the overall Houston economy has been difficult to gauge. Mine Yucel, a senior economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said unemployment, when seasonally adjusted, had barely risen in Houston, to 5.2 percent in January from 5 percent in December. For all of 2001, unemployment rose 1.5 percent in the city.
"Houston is a huge economy," Ms. Yucel said. "Yes, 4,000 jobs is quite a lot and a big hit, but compared to the whole, the effect is not that big."
The reception of ex-Enron employees by other energy companies in Houston has been mixed. Enron's collapse had an effect on companies like Dynegy Inc., the El Paso Corporation and the Duke Energy Corporation when the industry was in the midst of a downturn and had slowed hiring. Executives at these companies have taken pains to try to distance themselves from Enron's aggressive corporate culture. But they are also doing some hiring, particularly for energy traders.
Terry Francisco, a spokesman for Duke Energy, said the company had received more than 700 resumes from former Enron workers and had hired 50. He said many of the new hires were "people who had a professional relationship with our traders, who had some knowledge of their work habits and professionalism."
Edward K. Mills, the president of Aquila Inc., an energy marketing company based in Kansas City, Mo., said his company had received scores of Enron resumes and had hired about 20 people, some in Europe and others in the United States. "We're looking for their 'A' players who can embrace our culture," he said.
Robert C. Green Jr., the chief executive of UtiliCorp United Inc., Aquila's corporate parent, expanded on that thought: "We don't think we know everything. It may have been the culture issue that got them in trouble."
Adrian Woolcock, 29, ran right into that sort of skepticism. He had joined Enron directly out of Rice University, and after losing his job at Enron had several interviews with energy companies in Houston. But he is now moving to a new job as a power trader in Minnesota. He said the energy companies in Houston were just too wary of his Enron ties.
"The constant theme was, 'What happened? Did you know? What were you doing over there?' " he said.
