HEADLINE: The Way Out of Here 

BYLINE:  By Gerald Early; Gerald Early, the director of the International Writers Center at Washington University in St. Louis, is the John Hope Franklin senior fellow at the National Humanities Center in Research Triangle Park, N.C., this year.

 BODY:
 NIGGER
The Strange Career
of a Troublesome Word.
By Randall Kennedy.
226 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $22.

THE ENVY
OF THE WORLD
On Being a Black Man in America.
By Ellis Cose.
163 pp. New York:
Washington Square Press. $22.

THE ANATOMY OF
RACIAL INEQUALITY
By Glenn C. Loury.
226 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $22.95.
 THE Martin Luther King holiday and Black History Month offer African-American intellectuals something like a season, not only a marketing device but also an occasion of some moment, a moment almost exclusively the creation of African-Americans themselves. (Blacks pushed for the King holiday, and the black historian Carter G. Woodson originated Negro History Week in 1926. It has since morphed into a month, a result of black advocacy.) 
On the other hand, there is something about this that smacks a bit of separate-but-equal, and something that seems to put African-American intellectuals in a ghetto that limits, in both subtle and blatant ways, what they can talk about and when it is best for them to do so. But in the United States it is probably better to have a niche one needs to rebel against than to have no niche at all, better, as James Baldwin suggested in 1955, to have a "special space in this scheme" than to "have no place in any scheme."
Three new books share the concern of race, of being "raced" as stigma, of blackness as a socially and politically compromised identity. But their approaches, through their subject matter and arguments, are quite energetically different.
Randall Kennedy's "Nigger: The Strange Career of a Troublesome Word" has everything to make it popular: it is short, easy to read and provocative. But a book must be more than that to be good or to have been worth writing. On its face, the topic seems worthy. After all, Kennedy, a Harvard law professor, is writing about one of the most powerful obscene words ever invented. As he notes: "If nigger represented only an insulting slur and was associated only with racial animus, this book would not exist; rather, "nigger is fascinating precisely because it has been put to a variety of uses and can radiate a wide array of meanings."
But isn't this true of other obscene words? Would there be much profit in writing books about the history of one or another of them, using the word as the title to force self-respecting folk to say it if they wish to refer to the book? Maybe. But there is also something about these enterprises that seems a bit like urinating in the punchbowl at a fancy party or mooning in a church.
Kennedy starts out by giving us the history of the word nigger, challenging the view that it arose, in part, as a mispronunciation of Negro. As he makes clear, by the 1830's, when the abolitionist movement had become a significant political threat to the South, the word was unquestionably a racial insult. In fact, it became pervasive, with expressions like nigger hair (scouring pads), niggertoes (Brazil nuts), nigger hams (watermelons) and the like. It became an important part of white American humor in the 19th and early 20th centuries. It is, of course, still used this way today, in some quarters. 
But Kennedy goes on to talk about other uses of the word, particularly among African-Americans, who employ it sometimes as an insult but often as a term of friendship and endearment or humor -- the way many black comedians, most famously Richard Pryor and Chris Rock, do -- and frequently in rap music. Its use in literature also comes up; indeed, as I remember, several works by black authors have nigger in the title: "Nigger" and "Up From Nigger," by Dick Gregory; "The Nigger Bible," by Robert H. deCoy; "Die, Nigger, Die," by H. Rap Brown; "The Nigger Factory," by Gil Scott-Heron; "The Life and Loves of Mr. Jiveass Nigger," by Cecil Brown; "The Electronic Nigger," by Ed Bullins.
Kennedy takes two strong positions throughout: he opposes any attempt to erase the word from the English language or to ban its use, and he opposes any ethnic-group ownership of the word. Anyone can use it. 
The second chapter, the strongest in the book, looks at the impact of the word in court cases of four sorts: defendants seeking to have convictions overturned because a criminal justice official connected with the case used the word; defendants seeking reduced punishment in cases where they assaulted or killed someone because they were provoked by the use of the word; complainants seeking damages under tort or antidiscrimination law because they were abused by the word; and cases in which judges must decide whether to inform jurors about whether witnesses or litigants have ever used it. On the the fighting-words defense, for instance, Kennedy's view is that "bright-line limits" shouldn't be applied to provocations. The jury should decide whether a defendant lost control, and if, therefore, punishment should be mitigated. But he supports the judge's decision in the O. J. Simpson case, that Detective Mark Fuhrman could be asked by the defense if he ever used the word. 
Kennedy then turns to the phenomenon of black overreaction, citing, among other examples, the exception taken to Quentin Tarantino's films, in which the word appears liberally; the uproar over the white city bureaucrat in Washington who said "niggardly" in the course of a budget discussion, which expression put him temporarily out of a job; and attacks on "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," which probably sets a record for the word's use in a literary work, 215 times.
Kennedy's book feels a bit like an inflated essay and a bit hastily composed. It is often engaging and informative, but the arguments don't seem quite telling or quite convincing. "The N-word is not self-defining," Kennedy writes. "Its actual meaning in any given instance always depends on surrounding circumstances." But isn't this true of other obscene words as well? The seeming multiplicity of uses of nigger is driven by its power as an insult, as an extraordinary stigmatizing word, a power that all speakers acknowledge and actually defer to, however they use the word. "Still," Kennedy says, "there is much to be gained by allowing people of all backgrounds to yank nigger away from white supremacists." 
But why is that better than having black people exercise the power of self-determination to eliminate the word or curtail its use? Does this word exist through some cultural necessity? Or perhaps we should rehabilitate all our cuss words and thus achieve our psychological salvation through rap stars, raunchy comedians and tart-tongued authors. Can stigma be destigmatized -- the true subject of Kennedy's book -- through making a word like nigger kinder and gentler? 
This is a real question, but I am not sure Kennedy answers it convincingly because in some ways he rather simplified the context of his inquiry. I think the subject would have better served had Kennedy done a broader study of racial or social blasphemy, or had he examined the word in connection with a study of what African-Americans have been called, both by themselves and by whites.
"The Envy of the World: On Being a Black Man in America," by the Newsweek columnist Ellis Cose, shares with "Nigger" the qualities of being short, easy to read and provocative. But Cose's book lacks an unsettling title. The phrase "envy of the world" was taken from a passage in Toni Morrison's 1973 novel, "Sula"; Cose's book is a journalist's report on the state of the black male (and black masculinity) at the start of the 21st century. "We begin by recognizing a simple fact: Though this may be the best time ever to be a black man in America (and here comes the all-important fine print), you only prosper if you make it through the gantlet," Cose writes. "Your best chance at life lies in rejecting what they -- what much of America -- tell you that you are." This quotation tells us two things: first, that Cose intends to offer his readers advice and, second, that his advice is largely how to deal with the stigma of being a black man. To the white public, "we are athletes, rappers, preachers, singers -- and precious little else." We are also robbers, rapists, mentally deficient and sexually well endowed. For Cose, the problem is that so many young black men have come to believe these ideas about themselves.
He opens with the stories of two black men who have achieved success in unexpected places, "slayers of stereotypes": Maurice Ashley, a grandmaster in chess, and Franklin Delano Raines, President Bill Clinton's director of the Office of Management and Budget and now the chief executive of Fannie Mae.
After this grand overture of inspiration and accomplishment, we get several chapters detailing the black male crisis. (Nearly all contemporary books on race and public affairs have crisis as their stock in trade, and thus often feel the same.) There is a chapter on masculinity and the street, where many black men accept a distorted view of masculine prowess. This view has been fed by the white media and white intellectuals like Norman Mailer, in, for example, his 1957 essay "The White Negro," as well as by the middle-class black fascination -- as old as the bourgeoisie itself -- with the lower class and the criminal as more authentic and anticonformist. So, black men seem nothing more than the personification of a criminal libido and creative psychopathology. 
Cose then goes on to detail the black male story in certain institutions: school (where we underachieve, in part, according to Cose, because we have internalized the stereotype that being smart is for white folk), prison (where a tragically high number of black men are now housed because of the illegal drug trade) and the family (where many black men seem to have failed in their responsibilities as fathers and husbands). 
Cose provides personal narratives, expert testimony and statistics as he blames the country for its failure to deal with many of these problems. He also reminds his reader that racism is far from dead. But in the end the advice he offers, like the analysis he performs, is largely personal, probably because he is aware that his black readers want to have their sense of agency reaffirmed. Sounding like a black version of Dr. Laura Schlessinger will make the book appealing. "The Envy of the World" is, finally, something of a self-help book, which gives it a manipulative, pontificating air. This is central to its appeal.
The left and the hard-core black nationalists will criticize Cose for not providing more of a structural analysis, and he will probably be accused of missing the implication of his own reporting; all the people he describes are working for organizations, however modest, that are trying to improve life for the black male. In other words, some will say that personal advice is beside the point; Cose's message should have been organize, organize and organize some more 
(A. Philip Randolph's mantra) and challenge the way things are ever more vigorously. In the end, Cose wishes simultaneously to alarm and to reassure his readers, to provide a pep talk and a jeremiad -- also standard features of contemporary race books by black authors.
Structural analysis is the meat of Glenn C. Loury's "Anatomy of Racial Inequality," the most intellectually rigorous and deeply thoughtful of these three books. Those familiar with Loury's career will remember that he made a splash with his doctoral dissertation, which helped promulgate the concept of social capital -- the web of connections and relationships that account for success as much as talent or money, the lack of which puts blacks at a competitive disadvantage; he later worked for the Reagan administration and became a formidable conservative critic of the so-called civil rights establishment. He has since parted ways with the conservatives, resigning from the American Enterprise Institute in 1995 over its support of Dinesh D'Souza's book "The End of Racism." There is much in Loury's career that brings to mind black intellectuals like George Schuyler and Amiri Baraka, both of whom were famous for dramatically changing their views in midstream and both of whom were temperamentally, like Loury, fiercely independent contrarians fiercely buffeted by ideology. 
"The Anatomy of Racial Inequality," as much as anything, might be considered Loury's declaration of independence, his fully articulated position as a neoliberal. Like "Nigger" and "The Envy of the World," Loury's book deals with racial stigma quite directly, but in its political and philosophical aspects as a cause of black disadvantage. "I endeavor to fathom the deeper causes of racial inequality so that, ultimately, I can assess the public morality of American social policy on this issue," Loury tells us. 
Loury carefully and intricately frames his argument (sometimes a bit repetitiously): that race is an important social convention, even if it has no scientific basis, and that it has been of undeniable importance in the distribution of rewards in the United States. Race as a category, in his view, is an expression of power, with one group being able to assign qualities or characteristics (stereotypes) to another and then have these qualities affirmed by the behavior of the stereotyped group through institutional structures designed to predict and confirm that behavior. What is worse for blacks is that the stereotype, because of the degradation and devaluation of their humanness under slavery and segregation, is a form of stigma or "spoiled identity." The effect lingers today and is, in fact, reinforced by social structures: this explains why blacks, despite advances, are still at the bottom on many social and economic indexes, and why traditional individual-based, colorblind liberalism will not solve the problem. 
Blacks were victimized by more than just procedural discrimination -- rather, by soul-crushing, psychological disfigurement. So what Loury ultimately argues for is a public policy that promotes racial egalitarianism. This sounds a great deal like the arguments of liberal sociologists in the 1940's and 50's that led to the Brown decision: a humane "damaged goods" theory about blacks. It is similar also to the rhetoric of Martin Luther King Jr., who argued for a Marshall Plan for racial equity. The moralizing tone of Loury's work -- why don't we care about the black poor? -- also sounds a great deal like the civil rights and liberal church rhetoric of the heady days of the Movement.
There are a few problems with Loury's book: first, he needs to tell us more about "the conservative line" than that it is "simplistic" and "ahistorical." In fact, the book needs to distinguish concisely between various forms of conservatism in the United States, their historical transformations and how these forms of conservatism have influenced American public policy on race. Perhaps a short but thorough critical overview of D'Souza's "End of Racism," the major conservative statement about racism and racial identity in American history, or "America in Black and White," by Stephan Thernstrom and Abigail Thernstrom, or Charles Murray's "Losing Ground," might have helped greatly. Conservatism, popularly understood, may be simplistic, ahistorical, even racist, but Loury owes it to his readers to argue this fully and not simply display a smug intellectual disdain or philosophical airiness. 
Second, I am not entirely convinced by Loury's separation of personal attitudes and social meaning: one has only to look at the transformation of jazz from a stigmatized music to a respected art form to see the vital connection between personal attitudes (of musicians and the audience) and social meaning (how and where this music was played and interpreted). 
Third, most blacks would agree with Loury's positions. (Some would probably wish that he would support formal reparations, which he does not.) Few would deny that structural racism impedes their progress and supports racial stigma; however, the idea of making it on our own is enormously appealing, deeply and richly historical and lies at the heart of strains of black nationalism that still resonate deeply in some black communities. As Ellis Cose knows, blacks want sermons about exercising agency, not elaborate analyses about how they are hopelessly stigmatized; there is something about "The Anatomy of Racial Inequality" that, like the philosopher's God, gives cold comfort to the faithful. Loury's plea for a more socially conscious public policy and "social vision" seems so earnest in its moral rectitude as to be almost quixotic. Why and how should white people's hearts and consciences change -- and Loury's hope depends a great deal on this -- if their general indifference is the cause of the problem? What would change them? Loury almost seems to be making a naive appeal to reason or moral suasion, which the very structures of the society he so tellingly describes would seem to limit, compromise or co-opt because, as he argues, personal attitudes have little effect on social meaning. Despite arguing itself into a cul-de-sac, "The Anatomy of Racial Inequality" is an incisive, erudite book by a major thinker.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
String Players Young, Gifted And Black

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
I WANT to be the Tiger Woods of classical music," Gareth Johnson said recently. Classical music could use a Tiger Woods, no question, and Mr. Johnson may well fit the bill.
 A 16-year-old violinist from Wellington, Fla., he was between performances at the Sphinx Competition for black and Latino string players here, having won first prize in the junior division by playing a movement of Mozart's G major Concerto with finesse and flair. It seemed inconceivable that he had played the violin for only six years. 
 "I started at 10," he said. "I saw and heard someone play the violin and figured I'd like to do it. My parents said to hold off awhile, but I saved some money and bought a violin in a pawn shop for $80." 
The rest, though not yet history, may soon be. Mr. Johnson has prodigious musical gifts, good looks and a warm, winning personality. Like Joshua Bell or Maxim Vengerov, he projects a slightly cocky air in performance, which melts into a big, beaming grin; in short, he dominates a stage.
Mr. Johnson was one of 18 finalists in the Sphinx Competition. Another, Shelby Latin, a 20-year-old violinist in the senior division, played parts of the Tchaikovsky Concerto beautifully in a master class with the violist George Taylor, only to be told how to improve on them. She had a different though equally astounding tale to tell.
"I started when I was 1 1/2," she said. "Don't get me wrong, I was really big for my age." Ms. Latin is eager not only to play solo but also to explore chamber music and teaching.
"I don't want to tie myself down to one aspiration," she said. But she wants someday to start a music school.
Might Mr. Johnson or Ms. Latin want to play in an orchestra? Although neither volunteered as much, it is a primary goal of the Sphinx Organization to make membership in an orchestra seem not so much a fallback as a viable and attractive option in itself.
"I'm the last person who would say that any of our kids cannot be a soloist," said Aaron Dworkin, the 31-year-old president of Sphinx. "But we want to prepare them for the reality of the music world, and the reality is, most of them will not be soloists. We try to prepare them to just have a life in music. We tell them to pursue whatever it is they want to do, but also know the reality, and therefore know the reality of how much work you'll have to do. And know that that may not happen, and then you'll have these other options."
For members of certain minorities, an orchestral career could afford a ready opportunity to serve as a role model. Blacks and Latinos are woefully underrepresented in American orchestras.
Why is it, for example, that New Yorkers who annually become exercised by the absence of women in the Vienna Philharmonic rarely question why the New York Philharmonic has only one black player? In other cities, donors and the orchestras themselves have begun to sit up and take notice of similar deficiencies. Certainly the audiences the orchestras are avidly courting do. But so far, results have been limited.
Wounds are still fresh here at the Detroit Symphony; the Michigan legislature threatened in 1989 to withdraw state financing, which amounted to as much as $4.5 million a year, if the orchestra did not immediately add five blacks to the two it had. At the time, Deborah Borda -- now the managing director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and from 1991 to 1999 the executive director of the New York Philharmonic -- was the executive director in Detroit. She pre-emptively made a substitute player, a black double bassist, a permanent employee without recourse to auditions, causing a momentary firestorm that extended into the pages of The New York Times. But the unorthodox move ultimately defused the situation.
"I would do it again, absolutely," Ms. Borda said recently, though sounding shell-shocked by the incident even today. Detroit now has three black players and, each year, a black fellow: this year a bassoonist, for whom the orchestra has no permanent opening.
The Cleveland Orchestra, in its lofty perch in University Circle, far from the problems of the city center, began a period of soul-searching a number of years ago, setting up a task force on community relations. It heard complaints loud and quiet, like the one from a black woman who had held season tickets for 25 years but threatened to cancel because she was tired of waiting for the orchestra to add a third black musician.
The orchestra has been studying the issue of black hiring through a series of surveys. In one, it examined the makeup of 16 orchestras and found that a mere 1.6 percent of the players were black.
A broader survey by the American Symphony Orchestra League, conducted in the 1991-92 season and cited in Sphinx's literature, obtained similar results, finding that 1.6 percent of orchestral players are black, 1.5 percent Latino. (Definitions become difficult, especially at a time when institutions strain to protect the privacy of their employees and clients: by Sphinx's criteria, one or the other parent must be of black or Latino heritage.)
This reporter's own recent survey of 16 leading orchestras, employing 1,608 players in all, turned up 30 blacks (1.9 percent) and 27 Latinos (1.7 percent). Although all 16 orchestras registered in at least one category, two have no blacks (Chicago Symphony, San Francisco Symphony), and four have no Latinos (New York Philharmonic, Detroit Symphony, Dallas Symphony, Houston Symphony).
"There's a very small number of players," said Richard J. Bogomolny, the president of the Cleveland Orchestra, "and it doesn't do any good for us to steal three players from Detroit or another orchestra."
The problem, Mr. Bogomolny and others suggest, is in the pipeline. He explained that the Cleveland Orchestra and its personnel manager, Ralph Curry, a black cellist, have made strenuous efforts to find qualified black candidates for auditions but were unable to supply substantial numbers. That word "qualified" is crucial. No one on any side of these issues advocates a lowering of standards or seems to think it should be necessary, if educational opportunities are spread widely enough.
In another survey, the Cleveland Orchestra examined the feeder system, the major music schools and conservatories, and found that of 1,313 students working on orchestral instruments, 33 (2.5 percent) were black.
Not everyone sees a major problem here.
"Look at the number of black singers who have careers today," said Zarin Mehta, the executive director of the New York Philharmonic. "It's a question of who goes in to study the instruments of the orchestra. If people are not studying those instruments, then they don't care enough to want to be a part of an orchestra. The selection process gives absolutely equal opportunity. It's done on the basis of how well they play, and that's all there is to it."
It is perhaps not surprising that in the plugged-in culture of the 21st century, many children, white as well as black, shy away from seemingly antiquated pursuits like playing the violin. Asians and Asian-Americans evidently have no such qualms, and many have found the orchestra an ideal vehicle for advancement. 
Still, many professionals are deeply concerned about the black and Latino issue. "It's getting late for excuses," said Ms. Borda. Obviously, there are no ready solutions in a field where talent is best nurtured from the cradle up (despite the success of a relative latecomer like Mr. Johnson). Ms. Borda's orchestra in Los Angeles has four black players and two Latinos.
"We can't just fix it because we're of good will and we want it fixed," said Steven Monder, the president of the Cincinnati Symphony. "We have to be proactive about it."
Many orchestras, coming to the same realization, have created educational programs or partnerships with inner-city schools to drum up interest in classical music among minority children in the absence of school programs. The Boston Symphony has had notable success with its Project Step, which screens children in kindergarten and provides lessons for especially talented ones for up to 12 years. That project produced one of the Sphinx finalists this year, Mariana Green, a 23-year-old violinist living in New York.
Now the Boston Symphony and 19 other orchestras have entered into a partnership with Sphinx, even if it often means little more than presenting a competition winner as a concert soloist. "A big goal of ours," said Mr. Dworkin, "is to increase the numbers across the board, in audiences and in orchestras and in music schools and faculty, and hopefully, potentially as a soloist." Mr. Dworkin, himself black and a violinist, has taken on a Herculean task.
"When Aaron approached me with his idea seven years ago, I thought it would be absolutely impossible to pull off something like this in less than a quarter of a century," Willis Patterson, a former associate dean of the School of Music at the University of Michigan, told a Sphinx gathering here. "As I look back, I still think it's impossible."
Mr. Dworkin was born in upstate New York in 1970 (on the newly infamous Sept. 11) and was adopted and raised in Manhattan. (He recently located his biological parents after a lifelong search, and his birth mother attended the competition along with his adoptive parents.) When he was 5, he heard his mother, an amateur violinist, play solo works by Bach. "I just loved it," he said, "and I picked it up right away."
The family moved to Hershey, Pa., when he was 10, and he finished high school at the Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan. After leaving Penn State University for financial reasons and gaining four years' entrepreneurial experience in support for the homeless, in retail sales promotion and in publishing, he earned bachelor's and master's degrees at the University of Michigan. He founded Sphinx in 1996, while finishing graduate studies in Ann Arbor.
"Obviously, in all of the musical situations that I've been in, from New York to Hershey to . . . everywhere, I was either the only minority or one of less than a handful," he said. "Returning after four years off, I started thinking about that a lot more, and what could be done about it. So, out of that came this idea of how to increase the representation of minorities in the audience and onstage, and I thought a competition would be a good vehicle."
But this is by no means a typical competition. It is calculated to bring the contestants together rather than divide them. They attend concerts and seminars together and combine to play chamber music. The environment is nurturing. "Our mantra is, we apply the same requirements to them that the professional world will," Mr. Dworkin said, "but we explain to them what's happening while it's happening."
The organization grew over the years to include other activities and a year-round program. It now finds scholarships for the finalists at summer schools and festivals, arranges community concerts in Michigan and performances in elementary schools around the country, and presents a recital series at Borders bookstores. It has also set up an instrument fund to allow the players to perform on excellent instruments.
"Good instruments can make all the difference in auditions," Ms. Borda said. One Sphinx finalist this year, Eric Thompson III, an 18-year-old double bassist from Decatur, Ga., won third prize in the junior division on an instrument that may or may not have seen better days. Happily, his mentor, Ralph Jones, the principal bass player of the Atlanta Symphony, is helping Mr. Thompson arrange financing for a new instrument.
Sphinx assembles a fine orchestra of black and Latino professionals from orchestras across the nation for the competition. The conductor here was Leslie B. Dunner, and the concertmaster was Sanford Allen, the New York Philharmonic's lone black member.
This year, the organization also commissioned a work for the competition, "Symphony of the Sphinx," by Coleridge-Taylor Perkinson to a text by Nikki Giovanni.
All these activities are accomplished on a shoestring. The Sphinx Organization has an annual budget of $750,000: $260,000 in in-kind contributions (summer scholarships, hotel rooms, instruments provided on loan) and $490,000 in cash. Even that small amount is increasingly hard to come by.
"We are not on secure footing, and the reason is twofold," Mr. Dworkin said. "One, just the overall economy. We're at that emerging-nonprofit point, and we just can't compete with the Detroit Symphony and other institutions for funding. Second, we are at the end of a three-year commitment from Texaco. Texaco has been bought by Chevron, and that has put how we might move forward in question. So we're entering into a new economic environment and losing a quarter of our budget at the same time."
There are almost no donations from individuals, in part because the staff is too small to do the necessary groundwork. It consists of three people: Mr. Dworkin; his wife, Carrie A. Dworkin, the director of communications; and Afa Sadykhly, the artistic director. Only its achievements are large.
 SPHINX has really changed my life," Patrice Jackson, a 19-year-old cellist from New Haven, said, even before she won the senior competition. (She competed in the junior division in 1999.)
"I can't express how it is to learn that you're not alone, that there are other African-Americans your age doing the same thing," she explained. "My goal is to be the first African-American soloist on the cello. I want to keep my options open. I want to be able to do everything."
As with Tiger Johnson, you probably don't want to bet against her.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the Sphinx Competition for young black and Latino string players misidentified the lone black player in the New York Philharmonic. He is Jerome Ashby, a horn player; Sanford Allen, a violinist, who is also black, is a former member of the Philharmonic.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: A New Governor Works Out The Kinks 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA FITZGERALD 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
IN the lonely hours before dawn, there is a good chance that Gov. James E. McGreevey is poring over papers, punching numbers into his cell phone and living the mantra dictated by his father, a Marine drill instructor: Plan your work and work your plan.
 That explains why after a recent day when legislators failed to move some of his main budget proposals out of committee, Mr. McGreevey called one young aide at 4:30 the next morning to schedule visits to the Democrat and Republican legislative caucuses. 
 "I see myself as a C.E.O," he said in a recent interview. "I'm very hands on. Most would say to a fault. I'm not going to change. It's what I am and what I've done my whole life. The importance is to be hands on. The critical decision is to know what to be hands on about." 
This sort of micromanaging seemed to work for Mr. McGreevey when he was mayor of Woodbridge, a township of 97,000 with a budget of $80 million. Now, however, he is one of the more powerful of the nation's governor's in a state with more than 8 million residents that is facing its biggest fiscal crisis in balancing a $23 billion budget.
The question is whether the state -- and a divided Legislature -- will adapt to his style or whether he is going to modify his approach to get what he wants done.
In truth, electing James E. McGreevey was like getting two governors for the price of one because his work days and schedules are so densely packed. One of the things he says he most enjoys about his new job is meeting with leaders in business, government, science and technology to discuss the pressing issues of the day. Those who knew Mr. McGreevey as a bachelor recall days at the shore when he could be found off by himself reading about politics or management.
He is already poised to become a significant voice in the national debate over education. Some advocates say he has done more in his first month in office to ensure that less-advantaged students in New Jersey get a good education -- creating an early literacy task force, setting aside $40 million for reading coaches and creating a new council to implement rather than fight court-ordered reforms in disadvantaged schools -- than the previous administration did in two terms. And he is determined to make cancer research -- a topic of pressing concern in a state with the most Superfund sites in the nation and a cancer cluster in Toms River that has primarily affected children -- a major focus of his administration.
But as Jimmy Carter learned during his one term as president, there is a danger of becoming too enmeshed in details and losing the overall focus, particularly when it comes to dealing with the Legislature. Unlike his predecessor, Christie Whitman, Governor McGreevey's party does not control both chambers. While Democrats maintain a 44-36 advantage in the Assembly, the Senate is evenly divided 20-20. Nor does it help that some lawmakers see Mr. McGreevey's tenure as a state legislator as largely unremarkable; they are now finding it difficult to take orders from a man they had viewed as a backbencher.
As a candidate, his success was in uniting various and opposing forces into a single McGreevey-for-governor-coalition. Now he finds himself with the unenviable job of trying to keep those factions satisfied, a task dd made especially difficult in light of the state's projected $6 billion budget deficit next year. Indeed, he is already running into problems.
Some legislators say Mr. McGreevey is still in a campaign mode, and point to the fact that his main campaign consultants -- Steve DeMicco and Brad Lawrence -- have been retained to polish his speeches. For their part, Republicans are incensed that he has constantly blamed them for the state's severe budget problems. And some Democrats are irked because they say he has failed to keep them informed of major appointments, initiatives or budget cuts, causing some embarrassment when the news comes without warning.
The more political capital Mr. McGreevey squanders through partisan rhetoric and lack of communication, lawmakers say, the less he will have in reserve to push his political initiatives through the Legislature.
"This is a collaborative effort," said one Democratic consultant. "He doesn't have the kind of padding with a super majority in the Legislature to just dictate what he wants to get done. He can't afford to have everybody mad at him."
Mr. McGreevey does not see it that way.
"I am among the least partisan individuals," he said. "Fiscally, I'm a moderate if not a conservative. So I look forward to working on a bipartisan basis. When I ran in Woodbridge, if only Republicans voted, I would have won."
There is also a sense that Mr. McGreevey is not always effective at communicating with some political supporters when unpleasant news arises. While the slights might not cause him much harm initially, it might make it easier for some lawmakers to turn against him should he start to lose public support.
The most obvious example involves Joe Doria, the powerful Hudson County Democrat who led his party in the Assembly for the past 10 years. Though Mr. Doria said that Mr. McGreevey pledged to support him for the post of Assembly speaker, after the election Mr. McGreevey instead backed a relative newcomer, Assemblyman Albio Sires.
Then there was the Senate Democratic leader, Richard Codey, who was under the impression last fall that Mr. McGreevey was going to name Michael Rowe -- a former president of the New Jersey Nets and his own choice -- as chief executive of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. Instead, the governor selected George Zoffinger, chairman and chief executive of Constellation Capital Corp. in New Brunswick. Mr. Codey said that the governor later explained that the situation had changed since they had spoken in November, but Mr. Codey was still miffed that he was never told that Mr. Rowe was out before Mr. Zoffinger's name was made public.
Others are upset that Mr. McGreevey appears to be trying to install Charles Kushner, his single largest campaign contributor, as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Some Democrats thought the job had already been promised to Jack Sinagra, a retired Republican state senator and close ally of John Lynch, the influential Democratic chairman of Middlesex County.
In South Jersey, lawmakers initially appeared to be out of the loop because they had no idea that steep budget cuts to their districts were coming before they were announced. The reductions included $3.5 million in aid to the former battleship New Jersey, which is now a floating museum, $9 million for a Salem County sewer treatment plant and $300,000 for the Boys and Girls Club of Camden County.
Lawmakers are not the only ones irked these days.
There are also an increasing number of complaints from reporters that Governor McGreevey's office is not as responsive to the news media as previous governors. The State House press corps says that there have already been many occasions when repeated phone calls are not returned and that in the course of a day it is difficult to find out exactly what the governor's position is on specific issues.
One reporter who complained that a budget briefing -- a meeting where budget cuts are explained -- should not have been off the record was told that the next time he would not be invited. He responded that he was representing the public and had a right to be there. The governor's office corrected him: "Jim McGreevey represents the public. You just represent your shareholders."
To be sure, some complaints are the inevitable result of an administration in its infancy as the new managers learn to cope with the myriad demands put on the governor's office.
To be sure, some complaints are the inevitable result of an administration in its infancy as the new managers learn to cope with the myriad demands put on the governor's office. But administration officials say more staff members are being hired, and the problems with the media should soon abate.
Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, which conducts research on state issues, and a former spokesman for Gov. Jim Florio, said that there were bound to be bumps in the road when any new governor took office and that judgments now were premature. "As a reporter, I remember writing stories about how Tom Kean was destined to be a one-term governor," Mr. Shure said.
For his part, Mr. McGreevey said he was aware of the complaints and was working on addressing them, adding, "We can always do better."
During the campaign, Mr. McGreevey went out of his way to try to please everyone, a trait that is part of his political nature. As a political survivor, his record is nearly flawless. First he trounced Representative Rob Andrews, the odds-on favorite to win the Democratic gubernatorial primary in 1997, and nearly upset the incumbent, Mrs. Whitman, in the general election. Then he muscled Senator Robert Torricelli out of the way when it seemed as if Mr. Torricelli was out to grab the 2001 nomination from him, although some credit Mr. Lynch with the political maneuvering. 
Governor McGreevey said he understood the role of mayor was vastly different than that of governor, and that he had been making the transition ever since he was defeated by Mrs. Whitman. "Losing in 1997 was a blessing," he said. "It provided me with an opportunity to begin to shift that focus. I would not have been anywhere near as prepared as I am today."
After he lost, Mr. McGreevey said he began to educate himself on how other states were dealing with difficult issues like education in the event he decided to run again.
As mayor, Mr. McGreevey routinely toured neighborhoods on garbage pickup days to make sure that haulers had put the lids back on the cans, or drove around at night to see if all the street lights were on.
"With all due respect, that's why you win with 83 percent of the vote," he said.
As governor his priorities, of course, have shifted. Accountability is paramount, but "obviously" he adds, it's not about garbage pickup anymore. 
"There are three relatively straightforward directives," Mr. McGreevey said of his job during his first term as governor. "That state government lives within its means, educational excellence and the security and safety of our families and neighborhoods."
To help him achieve those goals, he has surrounded himself with four top aides who are charged with hammering out his plans on a daily basis: Gary Taffet, chief of staff; James Davy, chief of management and operations; Paul Levinsohn, his chief counsel, and Jo Astrid Glading, his chief of communications and policy.
Mr. Taffet and Mr. Davy worked with Mr. McGreevey in Woodbridge, while Mr. Levinsohn and Ms. Glading came on board during the campaign. Today the four serve as the governor's political and managerial arms. Yet while they have served in government, there is little collective experience in running the state's top executive office. 
"He's got a good staff, but they are young," said former Gov. Tom Kean. "They'll be learning together."
For their part, the four top aides are already used to the governor's hectic schedule. As Mr. Taffet put it: "There is only one pace. All out."
Mr. McGreevey is a man who considers work a recreational sport, even more so now that he is recuperating from a broken leg and unable to run his customary five miles a day. Confined to a hospital bed in his living room at night, he says he is rising earlier, his mind buzzing with thoughts about the day. 
Then there is what some close to the young governor him describe as a temperamental nature, a mix of combustible ire leavened with a self-deprecating wit.
As the governor's chief of staff, Mr. Taffet has the toughest job in the administration, and one that historically sends people packing after about two years.
The 35-year-old Mr. Taffet, who was Mr. McGreevey's chief aide in Woodbridge, is "exceptionally bright, able and understands political considerations," the governor said. "Literally, there is no one better. He operates almost flawlessly and he understands the legislative process. He is particularly good at it whereas I am not. I am more the executive branch."
Returning the compliment, Mr. Taffet said the governor could be a demanding boss but one that brought out the best and the most creative side of an employee.
"He's challenging and motivates the staff up to the next level," Mr. Taffet said.
Mr. McGreevey said the 48-year-old Mr. Davy, his chief of operations, is "the best manager I've ever encountered" and that "he has a phenomenal ability to set clear objectives."
Yet Mr. Davy's role, in which he also serves as a sort of manager of the state's many departments, is one that has the potential to stifle some of an individual cabinet member's power and influence.
"Cabinet members and commissioners typically prefer as a condition of acceptance to their position a pledge of direct access to the governor," said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University. "They don't like to have their views and interests filtered by a staff member. The governor is going to have to monitor that carefully."
As for Ms. Glading, his communications and policy director, Mr. McGreevey said she "serves as a conscience" reminding him of the moral and ethical obligations of budget cuts and other issues. He said she had a "tremendous sense of intuition" and that he valued her analytical skills. 
And his chief counsel, Mr. Levinsohn, 33, was described by the governor as "literally among my closest personal friends."
"I value his integrity, decency, acuity and his ability to say 'no' to me," he said.
The advice often goes unheeded.
"When he tells me why I can't do something," the governor joked, "it ensures I'll be more passionate about getting it done."
A second tier of staff members, whom some have criticized as owing their jobs to political cronyism, function as Mr. McGreevey's advisors or "point people." These include Golan Cipel, a 33-year-old Israeli, a former campaign aide who has been hired as the governor's counterterroism expert; Lucille Davy, the wife of James Davy; Curtis Fischer, a former director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group; Beth Sztuk, a former deputy director of the Economic Development Authority; and Mitch Ostrer, an attorney.
Yet Mr. McGreevey has been criticized for having multiple layers of managers at a time when he has vowed to make state government run more efficiently.
Defending his coterie of young advisers, the governor said: "These individuals have been hired because of their intellectual capital, their prowess. Mitchell Ostrer is literally one of the brightest human beings I've had the pleasure of knowing, but to ask him a political question would be an absurdity."
The governor is also a fan of special advisory boards -- mini think tanks -- to develop ideas and solutions for such overarching issues as the budget and education.
While some think it makes decision-making cumbersome, the governor likes the input. 
"Governor McGreevey has always maintained the unique ability to engender participation from the corporate community and meld those ideas with his own staff advisors and ultimately develop his own positions," Mr. Taffet said. "He's very engaged and hands-on in the process. He is a strong believer that we must tap into those resources."
To that end, Mr. McGreevey also looks to two former governors -- Tom Kean, a Republican, and Brendan Byrne, a Democrat -- for practical advice. Mr. Lynch, his political mentor, also exerts a great deal of influence in sorting out decisions. And his father, while perhaps not an influence, certain remains a presence.
"I've been doing what I consider to be important," Governor McGreevey said. "That is not necessarily what the press thinks is important, what bureaucracy thinks is important or the Legislature thinks is important. But I need to develop the structural foundations for four years."
He added: "The point is not to worry about the day, not to necessarily over-engage in a mythical 100-day sprint . . . but to set the structural underpinnings for the long term and not to be overly concerned with the political skirmish of the day. You know, this too shall pass."
Governor McGreevey said he saw his job as "understanding the importance of the greater good, creating the structural foundations for a state government" and to move forward his focus on balancing the budget, improving education and making the state more secure "on a concurrent, consistent and measured basis."
And as he stretched out on a chair in the solarium of the governor's mansion in Princeton, with the sun rising behind his back and the view of impeccably manicured grounds and gardens stretching lazily behind him, he added, almost as an afterthought, "and to enjoy life."

HEADLINE: Business; 
What's That Rumble In Venture Capital Funds?

BYLINE:  By NORM ALSTER

 BODY:
VENTURE capital and other private equity investors, generally known for their patient long-term outlook, are getting more than a little restless. Increasingly, they want to escape the heavy capital commitments they made at the height of the technology investing frenzy. Some are suing to recover losses.
 An outbreak of litigation in this relatively closed world is one clear sign of investor frustration over the tens of billions of dollars that have been committed but not put to use. 
 The mood contrasts sharply with that of the long bull march of the 1980's and 90's, when venture capitalists and their investors earned an average of more than 18 percent a year by selling stakes in companies they had nurtured to technology-hungry public and corporate buyers. 
But with initial public offerings now scarce and with the stock market soured on technology, tensions are rising between the general partners who run private equity funds and their limited partners -- the banks, endowments, pension funds and millionaires who supply most of their capital.
Limited partners have grown impatient over both poor performance and high management fees. Perhaps more significant, many limited partners now say venture capital firms are sitting on far more capital than they can invest profitably. With the air out of technology valuations and no fashionable investment themes, the industry has $75 billion of uninvested capital, according to Venture Economics, a unit of Thomson Financial that tracks venture capital data. That amount easily exceeds total venture investment from 1990 to 1998.
The manager of one large university endowment on the East Coast, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he was particularly angry that some venture capital firms had asked him and other limited partners to back companies that had been assigned rich valuations but were now worth much less. "They raised too much capital," the manager said. "They paid too much for the deals." 
Some general partners acknowledge the tension with limited partners. "There are some limited partners who feel venture capitalists drove hard bargains on the way up," said C. Kevin Landry, the chief executive of TA Associates, a large venture capital firm in Boston. "Now the pendulum is swinging the other way." 
Because venture partnerships are largely free of public disclosure requirements, most disputes have been settled privately, with partner agreements that dictate confidentiality. Venture capitalists, recently lionized as catalysts of technological advancement and economic productivity, are typically reluctant to concede that their investors have grown edgy as their portfolio values have shrunk. But it will be tough to conceal disputes as some boil over into litigation.
In January, a group of minority investors that includes Dell Computer and the T. Rowe Price Science and Technology mutual fund filed a $1 billion lawsuit against Idealab Inc., the once-heralded venture incubator. Another minority investor, the William Morris Agency Inc., joined the lawsuit last week. Accusing Bill Gross, Idealab's chairman and chief executive, of mismanagement, the plaintiffs, who have seen half of their roughly $1 billion investment disappear in the smoke of dot-bombs like eToys and Eve.com, want Idealab liquidated and its remaining assets disbursed. Mr. Gross is fighting the lawsuit.
"The Idealab case suggests there could be more litigation to come," said Carl E. Metzger, an authority on litigation risk in private equity, and a partner at the Boston law firm of Testa, Hurwitz & Thibeault.
Last week, the treasurer of Connecticut, Denise L. Nappier, who manages $20 billion in pension plans and trust funds for the state, sued Forstmann Little & Company, seeking to recover more than two-thirds of the state's $200 million investment, which she contends has been handled improperly. Forstmann Little has vowed to fight the suit. 
Litigation is only the most public form of contention between general and limited partners. Many limited partners are prodding general partners to release them from some share of their pledged commitments, cajoling them to reduce management fees and, with increasing frequency and sometimes with desperation, unloading their venture stakes at discounts in a bustling secondary market. 
Not all limited partners are unhappy. Having enjoyed a long run of superior returns, some are philosophical about high prices paid as the market peaked. "I sat down and negotiated a deal. A deal's a deal," said Gary Bruebaker, chief investment officer of the Washington State Investment Board, which manages $53.7 billion.
BUT others are asking general partners, "What have you done for me lately?" Venture investments have produced negative returns, on average, for five consecutive quarters, and distribution of profits to limited partners has slowed to a trickle, according to Venture Economics.
Because many venture capital firms have been slow in writing down the value of their assets, the red ink is bound to thicken. "There's more carnage to come," said Michael D. Granoff, chief executive of Pomona Capital, a private equity investment firm in New York.
Some limited partners say funds are much too large, given the absence of any "next big thing" opportunities, and want to be let off the hook for some of the capital they have pledged. Connecticut has sought release from $475 million in private equity commitments and has been obliged with the return of more than $160 million, Ms. Nappier said. 
Alfred J. Giuffrida, managing director at Horsley Bridge, a private equity investor in San Francisco, said he had asked two funds in which it is a limited partner to reduce their size, and, as a result, individual commitments. Mr. Giuffrida said he was turned down in one case but successful in the other. 
The manager of a large university endowment in the Bay Area, who asked not to be identified, said he had held discussions with a number of funds about cutting back. 
But general partners say they have no legal obligation to release limited partners from their commitments. Besides, downsizing can look like an acknowledgment of error. And many general partners contend that the markets are only cyclically weak, with promising investment opportunities just around the corner. 
Additionally, management fees charged by general partners are typically based on the volume of capital commitments. Bloated fund size, however, could hurt general partners later if it tempts them to chase weak investment opportunities. Rob Chaplinsky, a general partner at Mohr, Davidow Ventures in Menlo Park, Calif., says the important question is this: "What's the right size fund to generate the highest return?"
Mohr, Davidow recently released limited partners from 20 percent of their commitments as it downsized an $850 million fund to $675 million. Matthew T. Cowan, a general partner at BayStar Capital in San Francisco, said he thought more venture capital firms would have to follow suit. "You're going to see fund size shrink," he said. 
Limited partners have been especially irritated by annual management fees, which can exceed 2 percent of committed capital even if it has not yet been invested. One firm that has responded to complaints, according to several limited partners, is ComVentures of Palo Alto, Calif., which recently lowered its fees from 2.5 percent to 2 percent. ComVentures, citing a confidentiality agreement with its limited partners, declined to comment. 
Limited partners are bracing for more bad news as general partners write down the value of their portfolios. Many venture funds have been slow to do so, even though such adjustments would reflect the market path of technology stocks in the last two years. Funds have little incentive to hurry the write-downs, and some have reason to postpone them. Accounting rules governing the speed of such write-downs are vague, and some venture fund management fees are tied to the values of these assets.
Still, there is an awful lot of writing down to do. Venture Economics has reported that the value of venture assets in the four quarters ended Sept. 30, its most recent data, fell by 32 percent. That compares with a 60 percent decline over the same period for the Nasdaq market, which is heavy with young technology stocks backed by the venture capital industry.
The comparison suggests that the worst is yet to come in asset write-downs. "We're going to see another four quarters of downward valuation," said Peter Lawrence, a managing partner with Flag Venture Management, a private equity investment firm in Stamford, Conn.
The slow write-down pace could open new doors to litigation. "Venture capital firms face legal exposure for failure to mark down the value of their private equity holdings in timely fashion," Mr. Metzger, the Boston lawyer, said. 
Potential litigants may include secondary-market buyers of limited partners' stakes, as well as limited partners like pension funds that may plan payments to pensioners based on unrealistic valuations.
Whether displeased with their investments or just needing cash, many limited partners are looking to sell their venture stakes. Although general partners have veto power over proposed sales and are understandably eager to maintain a stable investor base, turnover is rising. Banks, including J. P. Morgan Chase and Bank of America, have been sellers. Wider bank selling is expected because the Federal Reserve is tightening cash reserve requirements on the private equity investments of banks. 
But with so much uncertainty over portfolio value, many who want to sell cannot find buyers. Timothy Jones, investment director at Coller Capital, a London-based buyer in the secondary market, forecasts $4 billion to $5 billion in secondary-market sales this year, up from an estimated $3 billion in 2001. But he also estimated that $20 billion in assets would be available for sale this year, which leaves "people with $15 billion or more in assets that can't find buyers."

LENGTH: 607 words

HEADLINE: The Uses of American Power 

 BODY:
If Congress cranks up the Pentagon's budget as much as President Bush would like, the United States will soon be spending more on defense than all the other countries of the world combined. That is just one measure of America's armed might -- and a global imbalance of power the likes of which has probably not been seen since the height of the Roman empire. While the United States is used to regarding itself as a global power, and its status as the sole superpower has steadily grown since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the overwhelming disparity is still a big change. So is the country's willingness to exercise its power in the wake of Sept. 11. Before President Bush decides where next to take the war against terrorism, he and the American people ought to pause for a moment to think about how we intend to behave in this new and awesome role. 
 The advantages of being an unchallengeable military superpower are obvious. The opponents will not always be as easily routed as the Taliban and Al Qaeda forces in Afghanistan, and some conflicts are certain to produce many more casualties on all sides, but American might dwarfs the capacity of almost any foe we may face in the war against terrorism. And we have learned that there are instances when the use of force is necessary. Sept. 11 taught us what harm can come from complacency and inaction in the face of cold-blooded enemies determined to destroy the United States. 
 But in a high-tech world, even a superpower cannot protect itself without the help of other countries. Much of the world already resents the United States because of its size and wealth. Even our allies hate being made to feel as if they live on a planet in which only one country's opinion matters. The biggest challenge for the United States is not how to win the next military encounter, but how to conduct itself so that other nations willingly accept its leadership.
The most effective way to make other countries comfortable with American military power is to demonstrate that the United States has their best interests at heart, too. They will not be impressed by the offer of a kind of Pax Americana, in which Washington makes the world safe for everyone on its own terms. The United States must buy into the goals that its allies and potential allies have already identified as important. That includes making inroads against poverty, infectious disease and malnourishment around the globe, undermining dictatorships with education and development, and curbing both the spread of horrific unconventional weapons and the dangers of global warming.
The opportunities today are great. America's relations with Russia are more promising than they have been in decades, China's leaders are newly eager to advertise their friendship, ties with India have notably warmed, and Pakistan, after a long estrangement, is again an important ally of the United States. Even in a recession, America is the world's economic engine. Its return to health will set the pace for Europe's recovery and China's continued development.
The power of American arms, impressive as it is, has limits. Military action is only part of the foreign policy equation, as current developments in Afghanistan illustrate. Washington still expects other nations to participate in such vital tasks as economic reconstruction and peacekeeping and to help confer diplomatic and political legitimacy on governments secured by American military action. For those practical reasons, the interests of other countries cannot be ignored. A stable world order must be built on a broad international consensus, not American military action alone.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Optimism Weakens On Accounting Worries

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer

 BODY:
Investor optimism declined sharply in February, largely because of concerns about accounting problems raised by the collapse of the Enron Corporation, according to a survey conducted for UBS.
 The survey found that optimism declined 20 percent from the first two weeks in January to the first two weeks in February. 
The survey, of 1,001 people, has been conducted by the Gallup Organization during the first two weeks of each month since October 1996. 
 Nearly 90 percent of those polled said they were familiar with the Enron debacle and with the company's accounting irregularities. Seventy-nine percent said accounting problems are hurting the investment climate in the United States, and 62 percent said they believed that dubious accounting was widespread in American business. 
"Despite an improving earnings outlook, the drop in optimism clearly shows that investors are affected by the Enron bankruptcy and the ongoing questions it raises about corporate accounting practices," said Mary Farrell, senior investment strategist at UBS PaineWebber. 
The investors, on average, said they expected stock market returns over the next 12 months to be 9.5 percent, down from 10.2 percent in the survey the previous month. Expected returns among investors under the age of 40 rose to 13.2 percent from 10.3 percent. In contrast, expectations among investors over 40 declined to 8.4 percent from 10.3 percent.
