SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 4786 words

HEADLINE: Quickly, a Saudi Peace Idea Gains Momentum in Mideast 

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 2 

 BODY:
After rapidly gaining momentum through the Middle East and Europe since its soft launching two weeks ago, the Saudi Arabian peace idea will descend on Washington when the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, comes calling on Tuesday.
 At week's end, Vice President Dick Cheney will be heading for the Middle East, where, whatever his original agenda may have been, he is certain to be badgered relentlessly for some sign of American interest in the initiative, which comes during some of the worst violence to engulf the region in years. 
 As if to hammer home the menace, a bomb exploded this evening on a street in Jerusalem crowded with Orthodox Jews returning from prayers, killing at least nine people. 
In the West Bank, Israeli troops, backed by armor and helicopters, took the war to a new front, raiding congested Palestinian refugee camps in Jenin and Nablus this week in search of militants and arms caches.
Israeli officials said at least 30 Palestinians and two Israelis were killed. 
The Mubarak and Cheney missions are only part of the swirl that has developed around the unexpected proposal that the crown prince and effective ruler of Saudi Arabia, Abdullah, first made in an interview with a New York Times columnist on Feb. 17. Prince Abdullah suggested that the Arab world would offer Israel full normalization of relations in exchange for its withdrawal from all occupied territories. He said he had intended to ask the entire 22-nation Arab League to join in the offer at its summit meeting in Beirut on March 27 and 28.
Though the fate of the endeavor is far from certain, the speed with which it has swelled from a little-noted idea in a newspaper column into a serious force in the Middle East reflects the despair and the dangers that the conflict has spread through the region, and the longing to seize on anything that might point to a way out. 
Skeptics -- including some in the Bush administration -- initially gave the floated proposals short shrift. It was not really an initiative, they suggested, but at best a nice idea. It was not new. It was basically a public relations gambit by the Saudis to polish their tarnished image in the United States. It would raise dangerous expectations. The Arabs would never follow through, the Israelis would never agree. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell at first said it was one of some "minor developments that we might be able to work on."
But with Israelis and Palestinians in a state of despair over ever finding peace after 17 months of unrelenting conflict, and with the Bush administration seemingly determined not to get embroiled, the Saudi proposal brought a long-absent gleam of hope. 
It is not only the timing that gave the initiative its impetus. It was also the fact that it came from Saudi Arabia, the richest and most influential Arab state, and the hallowed home of Islam's two most sacred shrines. 
From this grand pulpit, Crown Prince Abdullah spoke not only of diplomatic recognition, not only of peace, but of a "full normalization of relations."
That meant the fulfillment of a dream most Israelis had all but abandoned: "economic and cultural cooperation; falafel in Damascus and stalls in the international market of Dubai; an Israeli flag in Riyadh, programming engineers in Bahrain and gas from Qatar," as Zvi Bar'el, the Middle East analyst for the Haaretz newspaper, sketched the vision.
"I wanted to find a way to make clear to the Israeli people that the Arabs don't reject or despise them," the crown prince told Thomas L. Friedman, the New York Times columnist. "But the Arab people do reject what their leadership is now doing to the Palestinians, which is inhumane and oppressive."
The idea went unnoticed at first. But then some commentators, experts and diplomats picked it up, the Israeli press began to pay heed, and before long senior officials were reacting seriously. Arab, European and United Nations diplomats began scurrying from capital to capital, many of them knocking on Prince Abdullah's door in search of confirmation and explanation.
Finally President Bush took heed. He telephoned Prince Abdullah to welcome the Saudi proposal, then dispatched George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, and William J. Burns Jr., assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs, to the Saudi capital, Riyadh.
Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, was also said to be skeptical about the plan, but as Israelis seized on the glimmer of hope, he signaled that he was quietly exploring it even as the battles raged. 
The Palestinians openly greeted the initiative. A senior Palestinian official, Nabil Shaath, went off to Jidda over the weekend to see the crown prince, following on the heels of Javier Solana, the European Union commissioner for foreign affairs, and the American team.
Amr Moussa, the secretary general of the Arab League, toured Arab capitals to gauge attitudes in advance of the Arab summit meeting. The mission was critical, since the Arab League works through consensus, and the presumption was that Prince Abdullah could keep his speech in the drawer, where it was when Mr. Friedman called on him, unless it was guaranteed acceptance by all the Arabs.
But in the coming week all eyes will be on Washington. There is an almost universal sense in the Middle East that it is now the United States, the Bush administration, that has to breathe life into the Saudi idea. The Israelis and Palestinians have lost any shred of mutual trust; Mr. Sharon is not likely to budge except under American prodding, and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, is grounded by the Israelis in Ramallah.
"If the United States assumes the primary role, it will give the process great credibility and effectiveness," Prince Abdullah told Time magazine, adding, "If the U.S. has no desire to contribute to this, it should let others do it."
Mr. Arafat also expressed his hope, in an interview with The New York Times this week, that President Bush "will complete this very international, historical initiative."
"For this there must be a very important and very strong and very quick push from outside," the Palestinian leader said, giving as an example the pressure Mr. Bush's father had exerted on Yitzhak Shamir, an earlier Israeli hard-line prime minister, to attend the 1991 Madrid conference on the Middle East. 
That is also the message that the Egyptian president will press on Mr. Bush when he meets him on Tuesday. 
Mr. Mubarak has been relatively reserved about the Saudi initiative in public, but according to experts on the region, he and King Abdullah of Jordan -- leaders of the only two Arab countries that have diplomatic relations with Israel -- were involved with the Saudi crown prince as his idea took shape.
"If that idea goes to the Arab summit, and it is endorsed in a language well written and well formulated to cover not only the Palestinian lands but the Golan, then the Israelis will have to respond, and the Americans will have to activate a process," said Ahmed Aboul-Gheit, the Egyptian ambassador to the United Nations, referring also to the disputed Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria during the 1967 war. 
"Now it is the moment of truth," Mr. Aboul-Gheit said. "The Arabs are coming forward saying 'land for peace' -- a concept the Americans embraced 10 years ago. The situation has to move forward, because we have seen 9/11, we have seen the results of intifada, the anger the Arab and Islamic world is feeling."

The Genesis
A Proposal Born Of Arab Frustration
A Saudi push for peace, as the experts were quick to point out after Prince Abdullah discussed his proposal, is not unprecedented. In 1981, the crown prince at the time, Fahd -- now king and incapacitated by a stroke -- presented eight principles for peace, though absent an offer of normalization. The plan was accepted by the Arab League, but subsequently foundered.
But it was a far different context that prompted Prince Abdullah to renew the effort. Even before Sept. 11, the constant violence in Israel, played day after day on Arab television, was building dangerous emotions and pressures, and placing an ever greater strain on Arab relations with the United States -- the only country, in the Arab view, with any influence in Israel.
Nothing has so inflamed the Arabs as the images of American-built jet fighters or helicopters firing on Palestinians, or the razing of houses, or the endless bloodied victims being rushed to hospitals or morgues in a frenzy of fear and panic.
The images are one-sided, to be sure, and there are credible reports of the frustration of some Arab leaders with Mr. Arafat for letting the violence drag on and on. But the fact reported by all Western travelers to the Middle East is the rage of the streets, and the corresponding spread of anti-Americanism.
In a recent Gallup poll of nearly 10,000 Muslims in nine countries -- five of them Arab -- respondents overwhelmingly described the United States as "ruthless, aggressive, conceited, arrogant, easily provoked, biased." Saudi Arabia was among the countries where people registered the most negative views.
Already in August, according to various Saudi and American sources, Prince Abdullah sent Prince Bandar, the Saudi ambassador to Washington, to deliver a harsh message for President Bush via the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. That message said that relations between the two nations were at a crossroads, and asked for American help in the Mideast. A few days later, Mr. Bush responded, saying he believed the solution lay in creating a Palestinian state, but there could be no progress unless the violence was stopped.
The encounter led to an exchange of letters between Mr. Bush and the Saudis and in November, at the United Nations General Assembly, the President spoke directly of his wish that "two states -- Israel and Palestine -- live peacefully together within secure and recognized borders."
But by then the terror attacks of Sept. 11 had completely altered the dynamics. The large number of Saudis among the attackers and in Al Qaeda -- whose leader, Osama bin Laden, is the scion of one of the wealthiest Saudi families, although he has been exiled and stripped of his citizenship -- led to a closer and more critical scrutiny of the Saudi kingdom, its educational programs, its money, its policies, its religion, the depth of its commitment to an alliance with the United States. 
The Bush administration now had new, far more pressing priorities, and the perception that Mr. Arafat was not doing enough against "terrorism" moved to the fore. Eventually, Washington was seeming to endorse whatever actions Mr. Sharon wanted to take -- including some that had been hitherto taboo, like the regular use of American warplanes and helicopters against Palestinian targets, reoccupation of Palestinian-controlled areas and the grounding of Mr. Arafat in Ramallah. The administration's special envoy, Anthony C. Zinni, was pulled back.
With relations in crisis, moderate Arab leaders became increasingly aware of an urgent need to break the deadlock. At the World Economic Forum in New York in early February, which was attended by a large number of Arab representatives, the notion took shape that the Arab League would do well to float its own peace initiative, especially since the Israelis and Americans had already done so. Jordan had suggested the idea in a letter to President Bush before Sept. 11. But at the forum, the Arabs concluded that unless the initiative came from one of the two major Arab powers, Saudi Arabia or Egypt, it would stand little chance of acceptance by the Arab world.
Mr. Friedman, the Times columnist and an authority on the Middle East, took part in some of the discussions at the forum, and wrote a column, which appeared on Feb. 6, urging the Arab League to make a clear-cut proposal to Israel.
Soon afterward he traveled to Saudi Arabia, a visit that he described as "part of the Saudi opening to try to explain themselves better to the world in light of the fact that 15 Saudis were involved in the Sept. 11 attacks."
Over dinner with Crown Prince Abdullah, Mr. Friedman decided to test the idea of an Arab proposal to Israel.
"I knew that Jordan, Morocco and some key Arab League officials had been talking about this idea in private, but had not dared to broach it publicly until one of the 'big boys' -- Saudi Arabia or Egypt -- took the lead," Mr. Friedman wrote.
According to Mr. Friedman's published account, the prince said: "Have you broken into my desk? The reason I ask is that this is exactly the idea I had in mind -- full withdrawal from all the occupied territories, in accordance with U.N. resolutions, including in Jerusalem, for full normalization of relations."
The crown prince said that he had prepared the ideas for presentation before the Arab meeting in Beirut, but that he had changed his mind about delivering the speech in protest at the level of violence and oppression to which, he said, Mr. Sharon had climbed.
In subsequent interviews and conversations, Prince Abdullah indicated that he could still launch his idea at the Beirut summit.
According to Arab diplomats familiar with the initiative, the crown prince did not consult any of his brothers, or the Saudi Embassy in Washington, before unveiling his ideas.
How they view it is not clear. At a special session of the United Nations Security Council this week, the Saudi ambassador, Fawzi Shobokshi, made only one reference to the Abdullah proposal and devoted most of his speech to attacking Israel's "systematic terrorism." A translation of Mr. Shobokshi's speech also referred to the offer of "peace and good-neighborly relations," and not the full normalization proffered by Prince Abdullah.
The crown prince's reasons for the declaration and the timing are open to speculation. That he is seriously alarmed by the impact of the Palestinian violence on his own kingdom is clear, with the images of violence spreading radicalism among Saudi youths. 
There is also the problem of worsening relations with the United States, a crucial oil customer and ally of the House of Saud for decades.
There are also war drums beating in Washington for a new push against Saddam Hussein of Iraq, a prospect that Arabs fear will only feed the anti-American sentiments. Mr. Cheney apparently scheduled his Middle East trip with Iraq uppermost in his mind -- a pre-emptive peace initiative in the Middle East may have appeared a promising way to slow the apparent American juggernaut.
In any case, Arab leaders said it had not been the Saudi intention to present a detailed plan, but to establish a tempting horizon toward which the Israelis and Palestinians could start working, or, in Mr. Arafat's words, a "platform" for concrete talks. Even a senior Saudi official has been careful to call the proposals "more a vision than a plan or an initiative."
The crown prince's proposal was broad and subject to interpretation. He spoke to Mr. Friedman of a "full withdrawal from all the occupied territories," which would imply the 1967 borders -- an arrangement unacceptable to the Israelis. But the prince also said "in accordance with U.N. resolutions," in which the extent of withdrawal is deliberately left imprecise.
Adel al-Jubeir, Prince Abdullah's policy adviser, said in Washington this week: "We are not in the real estate or zoning business. It's really up to Israel, the Palestinians, Lebanon and Syria to negotiate, because it's their land. The idea is to send a signal to the Israeli public that peace is possible."
In an Op-Ed article in The New York Times on Feb. 21, Henry Siegman, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, quoted unnamed Saudi officials to the effect that the Saudi idea did not preclude Israeli sovereignty over the Western Wall and Jewish neighborhoods in east Jerusalem, or some territorial swaps.
If the territorial message was not entirely clear, then on a central point of dispute -- the fate of Palestinian refugees -- Crown Prince Abdullah was entirely silent. It was a silence noted by both Israel and some Arabs, most specifically Lebanon, whose greatest interest in any settlement would be to unload itself of more than 300,000 Palestinians living in refugee camps.
There was also no suggestion how the final settlement, and the full normalization, should be reached -- for example, whether it had to be all at once, and all or nothing.

Arabs React
Responses Reflect National Interests
From most of the Arab world, the official reaction was positive. For most Arab states -- especially Qatar, Oman, Mauritania, Morocco and Tunisia, which had had some level of relations with Israel -- there was no reason to oppose the plan. Israel posed a problem to them only inasmuch as it roused passions among their people, and any solution that had a Saudi stamp of approval -- and particularly that of Abdullah, who has a reputation as an Arab nationalist -- was fine by them.
Of those with a vested interest in the outcome, Syria kept silent, and ordered its newspapers to do the same. The reason, experts suggested, was that Damascus needed to be sure that the return of the Golan Heights would be part of any initiative. Lebanon, Syria's ward, offered a cautious nod, but probably out of a sense of obligation as the host of the forthcoming Arab summit. Jordan and Egypt had a clear interest in the initiative, since it served to validate the agreements they had reached earlier with Israel, and for which they had been excoriated by many Arabs.
There was no immediate reaction from the hard-core rejectionists, most notably Iraq. Middle East experts bandied about a variety of motives to try to predict Saddam Hussein's eventual reaction -- he might reject the move in order to enhance his image as a true champion of the Arab cause, or he might accept it to deflect the United States from attacking him.
Those Arab newspapers with sufficient freedom to do so argued on both sides of the issue -- though offering no support for the notation that Israel could be integrated into the Middle East. 
Whatever the perspective from the region's elites, the view from the street is imbued with a profound skepticism. 
"This plan is good but we know that Israel is going to reject it," said Samir Youssef, 48, an Egyptian engineer, as he puffed on a water pipe at a cafe on Cairo's central Tahrir Square. "Israel has no intention to make peace because it has the upper hand. They are the powerful side, so they make the decisions. What Israel is doing to the Palestinians is worse than what happened on Sept. 11." 
Just around the corner, at a McDonald's opposite the American University in Cairo, Wala'a Mahrous, 22, a postgraduate student, had more forceful views. "With Israel whatever was taken by force will only be returned by force," she said. "Only war can regain land. We want peace but they don't, so there's no choice."

Israel
An Anxious Public Seeks Signs of Hope
In Israel, as elsewhere, the Saudi initiative went largely unnoticed at first. But having noted it, some officials and commentators seized on it. With most Israelis dismissing Mr. Arafat as a potential negotiating partner, and with little hope that the violence might end soon, these Israelis began anxiously scanning the Saudi signal for signs of hope.
The press filled with reports of reactions and feelers, and commentators explored the myriad shapes the initiative could, or could not, take. Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said he would discuss the plan in Paris, while the president, Moshe Katzav, whose role is largely ceremonial, offered to travel to Riyadh. 
Mr. Sharon was said to be skeptical about the Saudi gesture. His terse response to a cabinet minister who urged that the government invite Prince Abdullah to Jerusalem, was: "I have already done some things about this matter." That was taken to mean that he was sounding out the Americans and tapping his private channels to Jordan and Egypt.
"The prime minister is not going to disregard this completely, because even though we may not attach a lot of credence to the initiative, any Israeli government will not leave any stone unturned if there is a chance of peace," said one of Mr. Sharon's political advisers, Zalman Shoval, a former ambassador to Washington. "Having said that, I do not think that the results of these inquiries will be worth the effort. This is my private view. I think the motivation behind the Abdullah initiative is fairly obvious." That, he said, was to mend fences with Washington.
Other associates of Mr. Sharon sought to punch holes in the possibility of a Saudi-sponsored breakthrough for peace. They noted that no formal proposal had been made, complained that the Saudis had gone to the press and not contacted Israel directly, and suggested that the true goal might be to throw Mr. Sharon on the defense diplomatically, by putting him in the position of rejecting a vague but seemingly innovative offer.
In the end, some said, persistent differences over territory and rights remained as profound as ever. Dore Gold, another spokesman for Mr. Sharon, said that the Saudi initiative, as reported in the press, suggested a division of lands, and of Jerusalem, that Mr. Sharon has categorically rejected.
"You know, there's the expression, 'I'll make you an offer you can't refuse?' " he said. "This looks more like an offer that any Israeli government would have a very hard time accepting."
Whatever his impression of it, the initiative poses a serious challenge to Mr. Sharon, who has repeatedly promised not to negotiate while the violence continues. 
The notion of returning all the occupied territories, or even most of them, runs deeply against his grain, and even toying with the idea of entering talks on that premise would probably prompt the hard-line members of his cabinet to bolt. Such is their mood in the current war with the Palestinians that they almost bolted last weekend at the mere suggestion of lifting restrictions on Mr. Arafat.
Yet dismissing the proposal risked alienating the left-leaning members of Mr. Sharon's government, who are already musing when to abandon the coalition and start looking to the next elections.
Most important, there was the anxious public, which was beginning to show doubts about Mr. Sharon's motives and abilities. For the first 11 of his 12 months in office, Mr. Sharon enjoyed strong public support.
But over the last month, escalating clashes have fed the sense that he has no more answers to terrorism, and a tepid speech "to the nation" on Feb. 21, in which he talked unconvincingly of building buffer zones against the Palestinians, only strengthened the perception.
A poll by the newspaper Maariv, published on Friday, found a decrease in the number of people satisfied with the prime minister's performance, to 42 percent from 49 percent. Seventy-three percent of the respondents said Mr. Sharon had not fulfilled his promises to the voters.
Israel's doves, who collapsed along with the Camp David talks in 2000, are reviving. More than 250 members of the Israeli reserve forces have signed a letter saying they would refuse to serve in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and Peace Now has started a new drive under the slogan "Get out of the territories/Return to ourselves." The notion of a unilateral Israeli withdrawal from the Palestinian territories is gathering some force across the political spectrum; it apparently contributed to Mr. Sharon's announcement of buffer zones to achieve "security separation."
At the same time, Palestinian militants have stepped up their attacks on soldiers and settlers in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, the lands Israel occupied in the 1967 war. They are hoping to draw more international support for their cause, while persuading Israelis that those territories are not worth the trouble.
So Mr. Sharon's challenge, a familiar one in Israeli politics, is to move both left and right. In this case, that probably would mean trying to shape the Saudi initiative to his own ends.
"If you take the idea as is, it's a nonstarter for Sharon," said Nahum Barnea, a leading political commentator with Yediot Ahronot. "But Sharon is not foolish. He understands he can play with it. He can say, Look, every party will bring to the table his prejudices, his basic views, and we'll negotiate. He wants to look to the Americans as a statesman, as someone ready to consider every option."

The Americans
An Idea Greeted With Caution
Initially, the American stance was not that different from Mr. Sharon's. When administration officials referred to the Saudi idea, it was usually to stress that it was not a formal proposal, followed by a repetition of the established policy: that it is necessary to end violence according to scenarios devised by a former senator, George Mitchell, and Mr. Tenet -- and, of course, for Mr. Arafat to demonstrate he is serious about combating terrorism.
"We do keep coming back to 'Johnny one note,' " acknowledged a senior administration official. "But none of it jells unless the Palestinians take effective steps to stop the violence and the Israelis are committed to respond.
"I don't think it's wariness," the official added. "We want to be careful about how we describe it. The Saudis have been careful about how they describe it. But it's a vision that's consistent with ours, and therefore it's important to have it out there."
The administration's caution appeared to derive in part from its determination not to end up where President Clinton did, with high hopes for peace turning abruptly into a spasm of violence.
Martin Indyk, Mr. Clinton's ambassador to Israel and now a senior fellow with the Brookings Institution, argued that it was the Bush administration's reluctance to become engaged in the Middle East that was the problem, and that the United States should now exploit the symbolic force of the Saudi prince's ideas, and their potential for quelling the violence.
"What the U.S. should do, what this administration won't do, is to try to work the symbolic side of this, because it has a great advantage in terms of widening the circle and raising the horizon of a possible peace with the Arab world," Mr. Indyk said. "It's a vision, not a plan, and we need to enhance the vision. It should be Powell instead of Solana suggesting that Abdullah should come pray at the Al Aksa mosque with Arafat.
"In other words, instead of looking at the down side, we should be looking at how we can turn it to our advantage."
Rarely mentioned, but hanging over all deliberations on the Middle East, is the question of the administration's intentions toward Iraq.
There is a widespread presumption that the administration wants to keep the Israel-Palestinian conflict on a back burner while it weighs its options on ousting Mr. Hussein, and there are those who see the timing of the Saudi statement as trying to forestall an American strike on Iraq. 
On this view, it would be harder to bash Mr. Hussein against the wishes of the Arabs if at the same time they were stretching an olive branch toward Israel.

Uncertain Future
Holding Out Hope For a Long Shot
For now, neither the skeptics nor the optimists have any real notion how the Saudi vision will play out against the violence and hatred that has become the norm. The house-to-house fighting in West Bank refugee camps -- the first Israeli raids into areas synonymous with Palestinian rage and frustration -- seemed likely to generate only more violence and anger. Each side claimed its killings were retaliation, and each killing demanded a greater response.
Yet that same cycle has created a desperation in which any new idea sparks a glimmer of hope. The growing violence has forced American officials to focus more and more just on halting it, rather than pushing specific notions in the Mitchell and Tenet plans for what follows. 
The Saudi idea offers the hope of a world in which Palestinians would not be endlessly humiliated, and Israelis would not be pariahs.
It remains a long shot. The proposal could die in a paroxysm of killing, or it could perish in the maze of Arab politics in Beirut, or before the summit meeting there, or it could wither in the absence of American or Israeli engagement. 
But the very fact that so basic and old a notion as land for peace could garner so much attention has lent it a strength of its own.
"I think the vast majority of people on both sides of the line are looking for a way out," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.
"Is this the plan to get them out? I am an optimist by occupational requirement, I hope it's possible, I wouldn't bet a single thing on it, and if I had to bet, I'd say the chances are slim. 
"But there's no other game in town."

PUB-DATE: March 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 8; Column 1; Sports Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 872 words

HEADLINE: Garden's Spring Prospects Look Like Slim Pickings 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The last time it happened, Jimmy Carter was in the White House, Rod Gilbert was a Ranger and Bob McAdoo was a Knick. John Ferguson had taken over for Ron Stewart behind the Rangers' bench, and Red Holzman was in the final year of his first stint as Knicks head coach.
 It was the 1976-77 season and Madison Square Garden, then the property of Gulf and Western, was empty at playoff time for the second consecutive year because the Knicks and the Rangers had failed to make the playoffs. 
 The Garden, which is owned by Cablevision, faces a similar fate today. The Knicks appear destined for the draft lottery for the worst teams in the N.B.A., especially with center Marcus Camby out for the season. The Rangers, who beat Philadelphia, 6-5, yesterday to end a three-game losing streak, are clinging to the eighth and final playoff spot in the N.H.L.'s Eastern Conference. 
Bob Gutkowski, the former president of the Garden and the former head of MSG Network, said it would have been considered unacceptable for one team to miss the playoffs. "If both teams missed, not only would I have been fired, but they would have cut my head off and rolled it down Seventh Avenue to the Gulf and Western Building and Marty Davis would have come down and stepped on it." Davis was the chairman of Gulf and Western.
For Cablevision, the possibility that both its teams will miss the postseason is primarily a financial problem. But it is also an image problem for the self-proclaimed "world's most famous arena," which has always boasted of providing the best in the country's most diverse, demanding sports market.
"We're talking about a facility, an organization that people view as No. 1," said Brandon Steiner, who runs a sports marketing company. "And all at once, in the spring, there will be no Knicks, maybe no Rangers and no Yankees on MSG. What will the MSG Network show?"
Gutkowski added: "It's catastrophic. It's a financial and image hit for its presence in the world of sports. It's embarrassing as can be."
Although the Garden's financial figures are private, it is believed that each playoff game there generates at least $2 million in revenue (from tickets, concessions, merchandise, arena advertising and commercial time on MSG), and, after expenses, spins off profits that range from $750,000 to $900,000.
Consider that from 1990 to 2001, the Garden was host to an average of nine playoff games a year (a figure that was skewed in 1994 when the Knicks and Rangers each playedhost to 13 games). The profit lost in subtracting nine games can range from $6.75 million to $8.1 million.
"It's a large financial loss, but not just because of the loss to the teams, but the loss of advertising to the MSG Network without the pre- and postgame programs," said Marc Ganis, a sports industry consultant based in Chicago. "Those are the kinds of synergies you're supposed to get from owning the Garden."
In early 1993, the Garden's owner projected potential profits for the playoffs, based on the minimum and maximum number of home games for the Knicks and the Rangers.
According to the projection, if each team went all the way by sweeping all series, total profits were estimated at $11.6 million. If they won their league titles by playing the most games possible, the total rose to $23.4 million. Only the Knicks reached the postseason that year, losing the Eastern Conference finals to the Chicago Bulls in six games.
Although a Garden spokesman declined to discuss the arena's playoff finances, the slow reduction of postseason revenues has affected Cablevision. When the company reported that its cash flow had fallen 11 percent, to $39.7 million, for the three months ended last June 30 (the period coinciding with the playoffs), it cited the Knicks' first-round loss to the Toronto Raptors and the Rangers' absence from the postseason as two reasons. In 2000, the Garden played host to eight playoff games, all involving the Knicks.
The Garden is in a predicament shared by Philips Arena in Atlanta, where the N.B.A.'s Hawks and the N.H.L.'s Thrashers are even less likely than the Knicks and the Rangers to make the playoffs. The Hawks last made the playoffs in 1999; that same year, the Thrashers entered the N.H.L., two years after the Rangers most recent playoff appearance.
 "Of course it's a disappointment," said Stan Kasten, the vice president of Turner Sports Teams, which puts him in charge of the Hawks, the Thrashers and baseball's Braves, as well as Philips Arena and Turner Field. "In our case, we have the Thrashers, an expansion team, and the Hawks, which have been racked by injuries. It's important economically to make the playoffs, but we never budget for them. I don't even budget for the Braves to make the playoffs. If we do, it's gravy."
 The slim prospect that one or both teams will make the playoffs can also hurt the Garden because locking in dates for basketball or hockey games limits the arena's ability to make money from other attractions.
"You can't book those two-week ice skating shows, but you might be able to add some second-tier events on maybe two weeks' notice," said Dan Migala, co-author of "Great Sports Promotions," a publication of Team Marketing Report. "But you also need time to promote them."

HEADLINE: County Battles Federal Cuts 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
JUST how affluent is Westchester County? That question is now the center of a dispute over a proposed cut in federal financing in the county.
 County officials learned recently that Westchester could take a large cut in federal community aid next year, essentially because the county is too wealthy. 
 The National Association of County, Community and Economic Development in Washington notified county officials by an e-mail message of the proposed cuts. The group's executive director, John C. Murphy, last week called the cuts ill conceived. "We're opposed to it and actively working against it," he said. "As it exists, the funds now go to areas based on need, poverty levels, the age and cost of housing." 
Under President George W. Bush's recently proposed budget for 2003, Westchester would receive only $3.5 million in community development block grants, roughly half the $7 million it received under the 2002 budget.
The budget, which is subject to a vote by Congress, uses a "Robin Hood" method of redistributing aid, decreasing financing to wealthy counties and redirecting it to needier ones. Specifically, money would be diverted from areas in the country with the highest average incomes, and steered to impoverished communities along the Mexican border.
"C.D.B.G. money is intended for low-income communities," said Amy Call, a spokeswoman for the White House Office of Management and Budget. "Westchester, which has twice the national average income, doesn't qualify as low-income."
Ms. Call said that the cuts were reserved for about 10 counties that had an average income at least twice the national average. Of these areas, listed in the budget, Greenwich is ranked the wealthiest, with 3.2 times the national average per capita income. Westchester is ranked 10th, with 2.1 times the national average.
Under the proposed budget, Greenwich stands to lose half of its $1.2 million in community funds, Ms. Call said.
Westchester officials complained that the county is in desperate need of all $7 million. The grants are used for a wide range of things including affordable housing, playgrounds, and centers for children and the elderly.
"They're looking to save $3.5 million and send it to the Mexican border, and we certainly don't think that's right," said Donna Greene, a spokeswoman for County Executive Andrew J. Spano. "We're the only community in New York State singled out for this cut because of our supposed high income. They do not take into consideration that we have the highest per capita homeless rate in the country, and we have a tremendous social services need in the area."
Ms. Greene added that the federal budget fails to take into account the high cost of housing in Westchester and the vital need for the financing for affordable housing. She noted that, according to the National Low Income Coalition, Westchester is ranked as the sixth least affordable area in the country.
She said that the county applies for this financing on behalf of 40 of its municipalities, excluding some of the larger cities here, which apply individually.
Mr. Spano's office plans on holding a news conference on Tuesday to urge local elected officials to oppose the president's plan.
Ms. Call explained that the money pulled from the wealthier counties would total roughly $16 million and be sent to help projects in the communities, mostly in Texas, that have a predominantly Hispanic population. Some are the poorest areas in the United States.
An explanation in the budget says that the community development block grant program had become "diluted by the inclusion of some of the richest cities in the country." The reorganization is intended "to return its focus to low-income communities by redirecting funds from the wealthiest, highest-income communities to lower-income areas." Redirecting money to "those communities with the greatest need will make the program truer to its intended purpose and less like a general revenue sharing program."

HEADLINE: Under Duress, Executives Take Jobs on a Lower Rung 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA R. OLSEN 

 BODY:
IT happens in every recession, and this one is no exception: out-of-work professionals, and even some corporate executives, drive taxis or make cold calls to make ends meet.
 "I tell people that it's not going to be forever," said a New York career coach, Deborah Brown, who said that the number of professionals who have sought her advice has doubled since Sept. 11. A main task for her is stroking egos and telling executives that it is all right to accept a lower-level position until the job market opens up, she said. "But the truth is, some callers are embarrassed and feel like a failure," Ms. Brown added. 
 Paul Hahn, who lost his job in May as a senior consultant for the Computer Sciences Corporation, did painting and electrical work for a while until finally landing a "real" job, driving a limousine for Hunterdon Connection Limousine in his hometown of Flemington, N.J. 
He made six figures plus bonuses in his old job, analyzing the computer systems of clients like the Bank of Montreal, Phillips-Van Heusen and AT&T and making recommendations. "I was totally in shock when I was laid off," he said. "We stopped our house projects and put off any thought of vacations. We even agonized about having another child." He had been with the company only three years, so his pension was not vested, and the company returned the money he had contributed to his 401(k).
The final insult was a class he attended at the outplacement firm his company had selected. The woman running the class was just out of college and excessively perky. "Hey, guys," he says she told Mr. Hahn and his colleagues, "what a great opportunity for a career change."
Now he calls his early-morning customers the night before, arrives at their homes 15 minutes early, rings the doorbell and wakes up the whole house, and carries their suitcases to the car. Most people are friendly on the way to the airport, but some can be obnoxious. One man said outright, "I don't want to talk, O.K.?" he recalled.
He makes, on average, $35 a trip, including a tip. For this he has to wear a suit and tie.
Before getting his driver's job, Mr. Hahn, 36, considered working the aisles of a big retailer like Staples or Home Depot, but was unnerved by the thought of running into former colleagues. But it would not bother him a bit if he picked up an old associate, he said. In fact, whenever an executive rides in his limousine, he talks himself up and hands out his resume. "I wasn't meeting them any other way," he said.
Efrat Mansdorf has also taken a step down in the job market, though the step seems more like an entire stairway, she says. Ms. Mansdorf, 26, was a project manager with iClips, a Manhattan Internet company that produced streaming media for the Web sites of clients like NBCi, the Internet division of NBC and Yahoo.com. Her duties included managing budgets and schedules and supervising a staff of five.
A major perk was having so much responsibility at her age. "I interviewed and hired people, and I made the typical big Internet salary," she said. Then, after six months on the job, her department was shut down last May just before the company went out of business. "I was so frustrated," she said.
She took it easy for a month or so, taking up biking, enrolling in a Spanish class and catching up on errands. Then Ms. Mansdorf went job hunting. She landed a couple of project-management interviews, but they did not lead anywhere. Her friends with secure jobs could not understand why someone with her background could not get back on her feet.
Finally, in August, she was hired as a research consultant at the National Finder's Service in Manhattan, a company that helps recover assets for individuals and companies that are unaware of their ownership, like money left to heirs in a will.
"I have a master's in communications and four years' management experience," she said. "Someone in junior college could do this job. It's all phone work, and each call is the same. There's no room for creativity. What I'm doing requires zero management skills."
She took the job thinking that the job market would pick up soon. Six months later she is still there. On the bright side, her hours are flexible and her boss, knowing her ambition to return to the corporate world, has no objections to letting her off for job interviews on short notice.
Anybody can get a pink slip, even a job recruiter. Andrew Sequeira, who worked for BroadBand Office, a Falls Church, Va., provider of voice and high-speed data services, found that out when the company filed for bankruptcy protection last May and laid him off along with scores of others.
Mr. Sequeira, 35, who was responsible for hiring a national sales force for BroadBand Office, was the company's sole recruiter at one point after it started slashing jobs. As a pre-I.P.O. company, it needed to show substantial revenue to go public. "My job, getting the right people in place so the company could get that revenue, was pretty important," he said.
All that is behind him now; after moving back to New Jersey, his home state, he was hired last December to sell commercial and industrial signs for JHM Communications in Phillipsburg.
He does not hide his dissatisfaction. "I'm on commission, and I'm not critical to this company's operation," he said. "I supported two vice presidents and six sales managers in my old job, and I dealt with salespeople who had a high level of technical knowledge and were pretty sharp." Now he visits sign franchise companies and tries to arrange subcontracts with them.
Not surprisingly, many former managers down on their luck are reluctant to publicize their plight. Mickey B., who insisted that his last name not be used, is a former Wall Street trader who is now driving a taxi in New York. His firm merged with another last spring, he said, and he chose to leave.
At least, he said, he is in good company. "You can tell the Wall Streeters when you get into a cab," he joked. "We're the ones listening to Bloomberg."
Not many professionals are able to find humor in their descent on the career ladder, though. Ms. Brown, the career coach, recalls a client who felt compelled to clarify her situation to everyone she met. "I'm an administrative assistant, but that's not really what I do," she would say, according to Ms. Brown. "I'm a marketing executive."
Many clients, like a former director of a New York area outplacement firm who now waits tables, use the same phrase in trying to come to grips with their reduced circumstances, she said: "I never thought this would happen to me."
It is unlikely that many managers will be stuck in dead-end jobs forever, of course. After all, while the unemployment rate for executives, administrators and managers has shot up, to 3.3 percent in January from 1.8 percent a year earlier, it is well below the national jobless rate of 5.6 percent. And their prospects for moving back up as the economy pulls out of recession look bright.
Take Mr. Hahn, the limousine chauffeur. He has not gotten any job offers from executives in the back seat, but he was recently offered a job at Levi, Ray & Shoup, an Illinois information technology company, on the same level as his old one at Computer Sciences. While his story has a happy ending, he is keeping the limo job part time. He has to, he said, to make up the salary difference.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Hahn, a computer consultant, has been driving a limousine for a living. (Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sort of Deserving; 
Helping the Poor in the Post-Welfare Era

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
SIX years ago, one of the most bitterly contested laws of recent times set out to reinvent the welfare system -- or, as President Clinton put it, "to end welfare as we know it." It also ended the political debate about poverty as we knew it, both on the left and on the right.
 Almost no one is making the case these days for restoring the longstanding federal guarantee of assistance to poor families, the entitlement abolished by the 1996 law. And welfare mothers are no longer routinely and disdainfully described as multigenerational dependents of the government. 
 The virtues of putting poor people to work -- "Working Toward Independence!" was the cheerful slogan of the Bush administration last week -- are now widely celebrated. As Isabel Sawhill, an expert on welfare at the Brookings Institution, put it, "a new conversation on poverty" has begun, reflecting a political consensus that would have been hard to imagine in 1995 or 1996. 
This conversation focuses, in large part, on what happens after welfare recipients enter the work force. And many of the same questions are being asked by Democrats and Republicans, although the answers may differ. How can the government help people move up the economic ladder, beyond the lowest paying jobs? Are the "work supports" -- like child care -- adequate for these fragile families? What about the problems that cannot be solved by a job alone, like absent fathers and the high proportion of out-of-wedlock births that stack the odds against so many poor children?
As Congress and the administration begin reviewing the 1996 welfare law, much of which expires this year, the fight is over money and details of specific programs, not the fundamentals. Work requirements and time limits for people on welfare, which generated so much anguished opposition six years ago, are widely considered to be a given; the debate will likely be over how flexible those requirements should be. 
"The overwhelming feeling is, how do you fine tune the program, not how do you create a new welfare system for the country," said Representative Ben Cardin of Maryland, who will lead House Democrats on welfare issues this year.
The world, in short, has changed. Bruce Reed, the former chief domestic policy advisor to President Clinton, and a leading force in welfare legislation, concluded, "The right has moved away from punishing the poor, and the left has moved away from sheltering them." 
Indeed, Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of health and human services, described his bipartisan welfare meetings on Capitol Hill last week as almost suspiciously chummy, a reflection, he says, of the success of the 1996 law. "This has been one of the most successful social changes in 60 years and I think people want to be part of it," and Mr. Thompson, who as governor of Wisconsin was a leader in welfare reform.
Not everyone would go that far. But in fact, since the passage of the current welfare law, known pointedly as the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996, caseloads have dropped by half nationwide and poverty rates have declined as well. Experts argue, endlessly, about how much the long economic boom of the 1990's fueled these trends, and how much the current economic downturn will affect them; already, some states are reporting increases in their caseloads.
But overall, as Ms. Sawhill, a former Clinton administration official, puts it, "Almost all of the data is moving in the right direction: caseloads down, employment up, poverty rates down, particularly among children and minority children."
Liberals, having lost the fight to preserve the old entitlement, have launched a new crusade on behalf of the working poor. Studies show that many who have moved from welfare to work are stuck in low-wage jobs, often without employer-provided health benefits or paid sick leave, according to the Center for Law and Social Policy. Advocates for low-income people want the reduction of poverty to be an explicit goal of the new welfare bill, and to reward states that do so. 
"We're going to say, 'Great, absolutely, it's much better when people can work. But here's the investments you have to make,' " said Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota. And the entitlement? "Politically, that's not where the energy of the debate is going to go," he said.
Conservatives, having won the fight on time limits and work requirements, are beginning another battle on the values front. Reducing out-of-wedlock births and encouraging the formation of two-parent families was a central goal for conservatives in 1996, but one that proved much harder than reducing the welfare rolls. The transformative power of work had its limits. More than a third of all births were to unmarried women in 2000, including 68.5 percent of the births among blacks. So conservatives want to write incentives to promote marriage into the new welfare law.
What is striking about the current debate over welfare, at least so far, is the lack of anger, in comparison to 1995-96. Political strategists say much of the public's anger about antipoverty programs has disappeared as welfare moms became working moms -- and therefore, much harder to demonize. That, indeed, was the result predicted by some of those who advocated doing away with the welfare entitlement to begin with.
DURING the long, polarized debate that led to the passage of the 1996 law, some conservatives on the floor of the House compared poor people to alligators and wolves. Leading liberals resigned from the Clinton administration because Mr. Clinton signed a bill that went far to the right of what he or his advisors originally envisioned. Old Democratic lions like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan warned that the legislation would drive poor families into the streets, invoking dark, Dickensian visions of children "sleeping on grates."
Mary Jo Bane, who resigned in protest as an assistant secretary at Health and Human Services, declared at the time that the legislation "poses serious dangers to poor children." Today, she reflects, "My current take is that the country was enormously lucky that welfare reform was implemented in the midst of the best economic expansion this country has had in decades." Still, she said, "It is possible that the dramatic change of 1996 made it possible to say, 'O.K., we've done that. We've brought responsibility back to the welfare system. Now, let's look at what kinds of supports we can provide.' "
In addition to child care, many in both parties are seeking more emphasis on education and training. But critics assert that training programs in the past were often notoriously ineffective, and sometimes a comfortable substitute for real jobs. 
This "new conversation" will undoubtedly have its ideological moments: The administration's proposal to spend up to $300 million a year on experiments aimed at promoting and supporting marriage has already stirred outrage in feminist camps. 
But much of the edge is gone. And in an election year, with key players in competitive races for re-election, both parties have an interest in passing another "welfare reform" law.
The Bush administration clearly senses the change in the air. President Bush opened the legislative bidding last week with a demand that 70 percent of all welfare recipients be required to work by 2007; currently, about 30 percent of the caseload is working in a typical state. He also proposed extending the hours that an individual is required to work, from 30 to 40 a week, although up to two of those days could be spent on education and training.
Critics assailed that proposal as under-financed and unrealistic, and some Democrats on Capitol Hill complained that he was over-reaching, pushing this new consensus too far. Even so, other Democrats already saw the makings of a legislative deal, given more money, more flexibility and more education and training possibilities for the poor.
Peter Edelman, who also resigned in 1996 from his position as an assistant secretary of H.H.S., said he was "mystified and disappointed" by Mr. Bush's approach. "We asked people to go to work, and they went to work," he said. "They went to work in droves. Now, the president comes around and says, that isn't good enough, we need tougher work requirements."
Mr. Edelman also said that he does not think he was wrong about the 1996 law. He said he still thinks it hurt poor people, but understands the political world has judged it a success.

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 21

HEADLINE: Bargains Everywhere but on Wall Street 

BYLINE:  By James Grant; James Grant is the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.

 BODY:
In 1962, the late Sam Walton opened the first Wal-Mart store in Rogers, Ark. Forty years later -- just the other day -- Wal-Mart overtook Exxon Mobil Corp. to become the world's biggest corporation as measured by sales. A Wal-Mart spokesman attributed this triumph to an "emphasis on value shopping."
 Reaching into their wallets, consumers demand value. Investing other people's money, professional money managers are less discriminating. The great and growing anomaly of American capitalism is the detachment of individual investors from their own investment dollars. Enron is only the most visible consequence of this estrangement. 
 You would expect that, by now, Wall Street, like Wal-Mart, would have slashed prices. A recession began a year ago, and though some optimists claim it has already ended, economic growth remains anemic. The stock market peaked two years ago. Yet the investment merchandise remains prohibitively expensive.
Of course, there is no one conclusive measure of business value. It's harder to appraise a share of stock than a tube of toothpaste. Is the price of a share reasonable in relation to the earnings of the underlying enterprise? In relation to its dividend (i.e., that portion of the earnings actually distributed to the owners)? In relation to what the stockholders own (i.e., the corporation's net assets)? In relation to interest rates? By none of these measures are the prices quoted for America's biggest companies anything but stupendously high.
Big companies are especially overvalued because the stewards of other people's money have hundreds of billions of dollars they must invest. If Microsoft, Coca-Cola and, yes, Wal-Mart, didn't exist, the Janus and Alliance and Fidelity funds of the world would almost have to invent them. It is the iconic American corporations that constitute the familiar market indices, and it is those indices that define professional investment success.
The Leuthold Group, a Minneapolis-based research firm, computes a valuation measure that weighs share prices against earnings, both historical and estimated. What it finds is that, even now, during what many on Wall Street contend is a savage bear market, the Standard & Poor's 500 index changes hands at about 25 times earnings. It would have to fall by 41 percent to reach the median valuation prevailing since 1957. If Wal-Mart sold common stocks, it wouldn't be selling Yahoo! (at 277 times earnings), nor would it be selling its own (at 42 times earnings).
The mantra that common stocks are the best investment is neither true nor false. Unless modified by three little words -- "at a price" -- it is meaningless. In general, when purchased at Wal-Mart prices, common stocks deliver excellent returns over time. At Tiffany prices, they tend to disappoint.
Fifty years ago, the business of professional money management hardly existed. According to Federal Reserve data, American individuals owned 97 percent of their shares outright. Today, they directly hold a little less than half. The proportion of investment decisions made by mutual funds, pension funds and the like has drastically increased.
No doubt, many fiduciaries care deeply about the funds entrusted to them. They feel almost as if the money were their own. However, empathetic as they might be, their interests are not the same as those of their clients. As a successful investor once told me, the primary objective of most money managers is not to make money for the client. It is to keep the client. And the way to do that, of course, is to look good.
Thus has professional investing become a kind of performance art. A mutual-fund manager looks good by outperforming his or her relevant "benchmark" -- for instance, the S&P 500. To compete successfully, a contestant must run with the market wherever it goes, even over a cliff. Are stocks overvalued? In professional circles, the question is not so much inadmissable as it is irrelevant. On Wall Street, simply avoiding loss is not success. What makes a career in a time like this is losing a little less than the competition.
Concluding his inquest into the crash of 1929, Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the Senate Banking Committee, prescribed the remedy of full disclosure. Give investors the facts, he reasoned, and they would make informed decisions.
What Mr. Pecora did not anticipate was that the investors would not bother to read the annual reports. The great bull market of the 1990's, preceded by the great bull market of the 1980's, annihilated skepticism on Wall Street. In keeping with the letter of the Depression-era securities laws, companies disclosed the facts (or, at any rate, most of them). However, Wall Street didn't want the facts so much as the earnings, insubstantial and revision-prone as they might be. Corporate America obligingly produced them -- eagerly, in fact, as more and more executives got rich on stock options.
It is understandable that amateurs would fail to notice the alarming divergence between the fundamental value of American businesses on the one hand, and the prices assigned to the pieces of paper conferring ownership of those businesses on the other. What is reprehensible is that the professionals did not.
Alfred Harrison, vice chairman of Alliance Capital Management and manager of the $11 billion Alliance Premier Growth Fund, spoke for many when he confessed in December that "nobody really dug into footnotes" of the Enron financial statements. Mr. Harrison's firm, as of Sept. 30, owned 43 million Enron shares, which raises a question. If a 43-million share investment wasn't enough to command the attention of our leading fiduciaries, what would have been?
In the boom, investing was made to seem effortless. The Beardstown Ladies, meeting once a month, on Thursdays, became best-selling authors by explaining how their investment club had supposedly beat the tar out of the S&P 500. In fact, they did no such thing. (A settlement of litigation over claims to the contrary was disclosed last week.)
There is one way to succeed on Wall Street. It is, in fact, the way Warren Buffett got rich. Pay low prices for the shares of good businesses. Buy them when the rest of the world wants to sell them. Keep your wits about you. Have the courage of your convictions. Sound easy?

HEADLINE: Madison Avenue Is Seeing Glint of a Recovery 

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
After more than a year of misery, Madison Avenue is beginning to glimpse hopeful signs that a rebound in advertising spending is near.
 The indications of an emerging recovery are palpable in growing demand for commercial time during various programs on broadcast and cable television networks. Several advertisers in competitive categories like automobiles and movies have increased their ad budgets. And there have been reports of higher revenue for some large national radio networks. 
 The return of optimism at ad agencies and media companies is also being fed by a rising tide of positive economic news involving consumers, like gains in personal income and the biggest surge in buying big-ticket merchandise since 1987. How willing shoppers are to spend helps determine how willing marketers are to open their wallets.
"The outlook is improving, but whether it holds is the question," said Gordon Hodge, an analyst who follows media companies for Thomas Weisel Partners in San Francisco. 
To be sure, the improvements are patchy so far. Conditions continue to be difficult for many agencies and media owners because most advertisers are reluctant to increase ad spending, which they scaled back in response to the softening economy and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
For every network, magazine or newspaper that reports gains in ad revenue, there is another that reports no relief in sight. And agencies in cities hit harder by the downturn, like Boston, New York and San Francisco, are still laying off employees. That is why most forecasters are sticking with estimates made last fall that a sustained recovery will not begin until the second half of 2002.
Even so, some analysts, agency executives and leaders of ad and media trade associations say they are discovering reasons to be guardedly optimistic after ad spending fell last year by 6 to 7 percent, the worst decline since 1938.
"There are signs of a bottom in the first quarter, signs of hope in the second quarter and signs of light in the third quarter," said Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York who follows advertising and broadcasting stocks.
"To date, radio seems to be leading the way," he added. "Print is still tough. TV is the hardest to describe. The tie-breaking vote, however, is cast by the economic data, which so far is encouraging." How much consumers spend is crucial because they account for two-thirds of economic activity.
"I take heart that we're starting to see light at the end of the tunnel," said Joe Mandese, editor of Media Buyer's Daily in New York, a newsletter published by Primedia, "even if it's in different sectors at different times.
"We've hit some of the bottoms in some of the media sectors," Mr. Mandese said, like commercial time on children's programs on broadcast television, where there is surprisingly robust demand. "For other sectors, like newspapers, the trend is still downward, but the margin of erosion is narrowing."
At some point, increases will appear that are broader and more sustained, "once corporate profits stabilize and marketers can afford to spend," he said. That should become clearer as companies begin to report first quarter earnings -- or the lack thereof -- in April and after. 
Mr. Hodge said that while "television and radio seem to be faring well, and media budgets for Hispanic-targeted advertising are up," there is "no sense of recovery for interactive spending, though it appears to be getting less worse.
"Outdoor advertising has stabilized, but is not better yet," he added, "and the publishing business is still fairly challenged."
Executives at the associations representing the print media agree with that assessment.
"We are seeing some signs of bouncing along the bottom, with upturns in sectors like real estate and automotive," said John Kimball, senior vice president and chief marketing officer at the Newspaper Association of America. "Consumer confidence remains really strong, and that's what gives us confidence."
But because problems persist in big categories like recruitment, he said, papers will see "slow, gradual improvement, with modest growth in the less than 1 percent range."
His counterpart at the Magazine Publishers of America in New York, Ellen Oppenheim, executive vice president and chief marketing officer, said: "The first quarter is tricky and the second quarter is shaky, but for the second half there's cautious optimism. Advertisers appear as if they want to try and stay the course on ad spending, yet there is more conservative budgeting as they make decisions more month-to-month than long-term."
"A lot also depends on the category you're in," Ms. Oppenheim said. "Our travel magazines are operating in a different environment than magazines in the food and home categories." Publications in categories like business and high technology are also still suffering steep declines in ad pages because of cutbacks by their largest advertisers.
"Tourism and telecommunications spending is lagging badly," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive at the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York, "though other categories are coming along very nicely."
"We're not seeing big amounts of new money from increased budgets coming into the market, but in this climate you don't have to spend more to get more," he added. "You can get more for less because of lower media prices."
As a result, Mr. Drake said, "I think we've hit bottom in the first quarter, and I'm reasonably optimistic about a pickup."
Jack Myers, chief economist at Jack Myers L.L.C. in New York, which publishes media and research newsletters, said that those lower ad rates may lead "some marketers to move spending plans forward from later in the year, to take advantage of the soft market."
One important indication of where ad spending is headed, Mr. Myers said, will be the negotiations between agencies and networks to buy commercial time ahead of the 2002-2003 TV season, which will begin in late spring. Those talks, known as the upfront market, "look to be among the most uncertain ever," he added.
Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at West End Communications/Consulting in New York, put it this way: "The ad business got so big so fast that it overheated. It could come back as quickly as it ebbed. As soon as the clients reckon they can sell more if they advertise more, they will."

HEADLINE: The Corner Internet Network vs. the Cellular Giants 

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 

 BODY:
The informal Wi-Fi networks that inexpensively provide wireless Internet access are fine, as far as they go -- which is generally a few hundred feet. But what happens when there are enough of them to weave together in a blanket of Internet coverage?
 What begins to appear is a high-speed wireless data network built from the bottom up, rather than the top-down wireless cellular data networks now being established by giant telecommunications companies. 
 Many Silicon Valley engineers now believe that it will be possible to take the tens of thousands of inexpensive wireless network connections that are popping up in homes and coffee shops all over the country and lash them together into a single anarchic wireless network. Connections could theoretically be passed from one Wi-Fi node to another, similar to the way wireless phone signals pass from cell to cell, thereby significantly extending the wired Internet. 
Modeled closely on the original nature of the Internet, which grew by chaining together separate computer networks, the technology -- known as wireless mesh routing -- is being rapidly embraced in the United States as well as in the developing world, where it is viewed as a low-cost method for quickly building network infrastructure. 
If the engineers are right, the popular and inexpensive Wi-Fi wireless standard, also known as 802.11, could serve as the wedge for the next-generation Internet, enabling a new wave of wireless portable gadgets that ultimately blanket homes, schools and shopping malls with Internet access. 
Currently most 802.11 networks serve as individual beacons that provide wireless Internet connections to portable computers situated within 200 feet or so of an 802.11 transmitter. What wireless mesh routing offers is the promise of a vastly more powerful collaboration driven by the same forces that originally built the Internet. 
"The good news is that broadband wireless access will finally explode," said Nicholas Negroponte, the director of the M.I.T Media Laboratory. "The social contract is simple: you can use mine when you are in the vicinity of Mount Vernon Street, Boston. But I want to be able to use yours when I am near you."
The technology is being driven both by a gaggle of ambitious start-up companies in Silicon Valley and elsewhere and by a hobbyist movement that mimics the original Homebrew Club that led to the personal computer industry.
Today, Tim Pozar and several of his friends are seizing the high ground, literally and figuratively, in a movement that could undercut the nation's cellular companies, which are investing tens of millions of dollars in top-down, heavily engineered, digital cellular networks.
Mr. Pozar, a radio engineer, is a member of the Bay Area Wireless Users Group, an active band of hobbyists who have been building free networks in communities through the region. Mr. Pozar and some of his friends have quietly begun obtaining the rights to place $2,000 wireless network access stations on the mountains and hilltops that encircle San Francisco Bay. If he succeeds, the network will be a starting point for a wireless data network that could eventually spread all over the Bay Area. 
Significantly, what will set Mr. Pozar's planned Sunset Network and those like it apart from the commercial cellular networks now being constructed at great expense is that they will "self assemble" -- expanding from one neighborhood to the next as individuals and businesses join by buying their own cheap antennas that either attach to the wired Internet or pass a signal on to another wireless node.
Mr. Pozar has even come up with a new acronym to describe his plan. In addition to the existing terminology of LAN's and WAN's -- local and wide area networks -- he is proposing the idea of NAN's, or neighborhood area networks. 
The so-called Nanny Networks are rapidly becoming the hottest thing in Silicon Valley and internationally. There are now at least 19 companies developing proprietary wireless mesh routing technologies, all trying to replicate the original Internet in a wireless form.
It is not an easy task because the companies are engineering for a new kind of design, with which they must route data packets over paths where network nodes constantly pop up and disappear. 
Moreover, wireless networks must overcome an array of environmental obstacles that do not plague wired networks, including hills, rain and trees. 
Such networks, however, do have the critical advantage of economy of scale. In contrast to the cellular data networks, in which every customer is an added cost, in some respects in wireless mesh networks the more users who join the better the network performs.
In the jargon of Silicon Valley, wireless mesh routing is potentially a "disruptive technology," a new technology that is likely to upset the existing order by using the same powerful economics of cost and scale that initially drove the growth of the commercial Internet.
Already, companies like Mesh Networks, based in Maitland, Fla., are selling systems of wireless routers, making it possible to create self-assembling and self-healing networks that would cover an urban area. 
There are also companies like Boingo Wireless and Sputnik, which focus on software and services that make it possible for wireless users to roam among networks. Similar technologies were crucial in the development of the original nationwide analog cellular voice networks. 
In Silicon Valley, companies like Skypilot Network, FHP Wireless, Ultradevices, CoWave Networks, SRI's Packet Hop and others are all developing networks that have the potential to weave together networks made up of wireless antennas.
"We're going to start seeing more mom-and-pop Internet service providers buying access points that will support 802.11," Mr. Pozar said. "At first I thought it was going to just be geeks doing wireless, but now everyone has one of these things deployed."

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Corporations are now spending more on computer services than on computers themselves.

BYLINE:  By Steve Lohr 

 BODY:
THE new new thing, to borrow a phrase, is the old old thing: corporate computing.
 In industry jargon, the corporate market is known as "the enterprise," and it is to the mother ship that the people and the money are returning. "Can you blame me?" asked Eileen Richardson, the former chief executive of Napster, who has become the president of Infravio, a promising Silicon Valley start-up in the once-again hot field of enterprise software. 
 Venture capitalists, who not long ago threw money at entrepreneurs promising revolution and new digital industries, are now bankrolling start-ups that sell technology tools to established corporations and help them cut costs, manage operations and serve customers more efficiently. Dreary stuff, perhaps, by the standards of the deceased dot-com era. 
Still, the utilitarian promise of information technology to business has been much the same since 1964, when I.B.M. introduced its 360 mainframe, a flexible machine capable of tackling all kinds of data-processing chores in business. The I.B.M. 360 ushered computing into the corporate mainstream.
Today's focus on the pragmatic problem-solving side of corporate computing is best exemplified by the rise of computer services. These services include just about everything computer-related except the hardware and software products themselves. Services include maintenance, installation, help-desk support and training, as well as consultation on how to use the technology. 
Sometimes, companies hire others to run all or part of their computing systems. This large and fast-growing slice of the services market is the corporate equivalent of rich people hiring maids and chefs to do their cleaning and cooking.
Last year, for the first time, companies worldwide spent more on computer services than on hardware, according to International Data Corporation, part of the International Data Group. To be sure, that was in part because of the steep drop in the purchase of computers as information technology investment slumped. But John Gantz, director of research at I.D.C., expects spending on services to continue well ahead of hardware, reaching an estimated $650 billion in 2005, up from $427 billion last year.
Another sign of the ascent of services, and the comparative decline of hardware, will come today with the announcement of Fujitsu Technology Solutions, a new services operation based in Sunnyvale, Calif. The 2,000-person North American and European unit of Fujitsu Limited will consist in part of the services staff of the Amdahl Corporation, the former maker of I.B.M.-compatible mainframe computers, which Fujitsu acquired in 1997. The company services mainframes, but it no longer sells them.
Fujitsu says it comes to the services market with a new organization, its own distinctive methodology and a new Web site. One old asset is being dropped: the Amdahl brand. "The time had come to retire the Amdahl name and move on," said J. L. Fillmer, the president of Fujitsu Technology Solutions.
The decision was probably inevitable, and scarcely surprising, but there does seem something symbolic to the extinction of a brand linked to one of the industry's great computer designers, Gene Amdahl. He was a principal architect of the 704, 360 and 370 machines at I.B.M., before he departed in 1970 to start his own company.
The services strategy, of course, is a big part of the rationale behind the bid by Hewlett-Packard to acquire Compaq Computer. In promoting her merger plan to a gathering of analysts and investors last week, Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, declared, "The pure product era is over." 
In the future, Ms. Fiorina said, corporate customers will want to buy information technology in a package of equipment, software and especially services to solve specific business problems, instead of being sold the vendors' latest hot products. "This merger allows us to capitalize on this future," she said.
Industry analysts question how strong a services unit the merged company would have, but the move would make that unit far larger. Hewlett-Packard would double its services work force to 65,000 people, moving the company from No. 8 to No. 3 in size. "We will get invited to the table because we are bigger," said Ann Livermore, the head of Hewlett-Packard's services business.
The services leaders, the ones most often at the corporate table, are I.B.M. and E.D.S. I.B.M. in particular has transformed its services business from one that was essentially maintaining I.B.M. machines to a broad-based services operation no longer serving only I.B.M. product groups. The I.B.M. services business now has 150,000 workers, after hiring more than 10,000 people a year for the last five years. By last year, I.B.M.'s global services unit had become a $35 billion business and contributed 49 percent of the company's pretax profits. 
"What we can say to customers is that we have the scale and skills to run parts of your information technology infrastructure more efficiently than you," said Douglas Elix, senior vice president in charge of I.B.M.'s services business.
American Express came to that view after a yearlong review of its information technology needs and strategy. Last week, American Express announced that it had entered into a seven-year outsourcing agreement with I.B.M. valued at more than $4 billion. It is the largest of the utility-like agreements in computer services, in which customers pay for computing services and resources as they use them, much like electricity.
Only a big computing power plant like I.B.M. can offer that service to a company like American Express, a huge corporate consumer of information technology. "They have more scale than we do," said Glen Salow, the chief information officer of American Express. "As we looked ahead, we did not want to have our own information technology infrastructure to be the critical path, or gatekeeper, to our growth."
