HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Hartford Life turns from humor to family concerns in focusing its latest campaign.

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
THE idea: a soft sell, one that emphasizes stability, honesty and reliability. Not a revolutionary concept for a company selling financial services, perhaps, but one that seems well suited to today's recessionary, post-dot-com, post-Sept. 11, post-Enron times.
 At least that is the thinking at Hartford Life, the part of the Hartford Financial Services Group that sells life insurance and investment products (the other part of the company is a property and casualty insurer). The Hartford, as it is known, has put the brakes on "Bring It On," an aggressive, often funny campaign that it ran in the heady economic days of the recent past. 
 A new, lower-key effort will replace it: "Always Thinking Ahead."
Hartford Life has assets of $151.6 billion, said a company spokeswoman, Marnie Goodman. According to A. M. Best, an insurance research company, Hartford is the nation's fourth-largest life company, ranking just behind industry giants like MetLife and Prudential. Best also calls Hartford the fastest-growing major life insurer in the country.
But Hartford Life also has deep roots, with a parent company that has been around since 1810. And that is a potential plus in the eyes of today's somewhat shell-shocked investors, who are looking for reassurance that the Hartford is as stable and, yes, conservative as they are, according to the company's senior vice president for marketing, Ann B. Glover. 
"Times have changed," she said, recalling a commercial shown last year that seems inappropriate now. Set in a lawyer's office, it showed a will-reading where a first wife learns her deceased former spouse has left her his boat. The current wife then learns that she is heir to his Hartford life insurance policy. As the spot closes, the first wife thinks of a modest pleasure craft while the second imagines an ocean liner.
"The economy was booming then, and it was novel to use humor as a way of demystifying financial services," Ms. Glover said, explaining the Hartford's former strategy.
Today, however, "people are seeking a return to stronger values," she said, and "want to do business with a company that shares their sense of integrity."
Hence the new focus. "It gives you reason to pause and think about your goals," said Ron Lawner, chairman and chief creative officer of Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas Advertising. The agency is responsible for both "Bring It On" and the new campaign. "It's more real."
Indeed, the new ads all feature families, using slice-of-life vignettes that stress the reasons why people invest in the first place -- for college or retirement, for example.
The campaign has broadcast and print components, with the print ads playing off the television commercials. For now there are three TV ads, with slightly dissonant music and quick cuts that are shot in a jerky, hand-held camera style that make them look almost as if they were culled from home videos. 
The first of them, called "Growth Chart," shows a mother and father and their three young daughters as the girls line up and have their heights measured and marked alongside a kitchen door. "Will you have college tuition taken care of here," asks the ad, in writing (there is no voiceover), as a pointer indicates a line high up on the door. "Or here?" it continues, pointing to a lower line.
In the second spot, a mother, father and son are seen running through a blissful, suburban autumn landscape. Dad has the boy on his shoulders as they make their way to the commuter station. Mom hands dad his briefcase and he gets on a train. As he heads to what presumably is a city job and a set of worldly responsibilities, his wife and child smile and wave from the platform. Dad presses his hand against the train window, and we see the lines in his palm.
"Would you like to retire here," viewers are asked, as the pointer shows a spot along the so-called lifeline on the father's palm. "Or here?" -- here being the very end of the lifeline.
Finally, there is "Going Home." A harried female executive is depicted at the end of a long day as she packs up her papers and stuffs them into her bag. As she leaves her office, a drawing that hangs on the office wall is seen. Obviously made by a child, it shows a little girl standing next to her mother. In one of mom's hands is a briefcase. "When you get home will your mind be here?" (pointer indicates briefcase in drawing), "or here?" (pointer indicates child).
All three of the commercials end with the words "The Hartford" and the image of the large stag that has long been the company's symbol. Together with the "Always Thinking Ahead" tagline, a final message is superimposed on the screen: "Investments. Insurance. 190 Years of Wisdom."
The print ads are appearing in periodicals, including The Wall Street Journal, the New Yorker and the Atlantic Monthly. The television spots began running yesterday during N.C.A.A. basketball games and will also be seen on "The West Wing," "60 Minutes" and "E.R." -- programs where they can be seen by the affluent consumers at whom they are aimed, according to Mr. Lawner of Arnold Worldwide.
But won't such viewers find the ads a trifle corny? Maybe, said the Hartford's Ms. Glover, but that's all right.
"We're telling them that it's hip to be square," she said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 5, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about a campaign created for the Hartford Financial Services Group, misstated the scope. It covers the company as a whole, not just its life insurance unit.

HEADLINE: Peanut Proposals Put a New Wrinkle on Farm Subsidies 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3 

 BODY:
Buried in the proposed farm bill is an entirely new $3 billion subsidy for peanut farmers, a 10-year entitlement of direct cash payments meant to help American peanut farmers adjust to competition unleashed by the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 But that is not all. 
 The government would pay an additional $1.3 billion to "buy out" many of those same farmers and others who hold lucrative licenses, known as quotas, to grow peanuts. Under the current 70-year-old subsidy system, only 1.5 million acres can be used for planting peanuts for domestic consumption, and the quotas to farm those acres have grown increasingly valuable. Under the new plan, the government would buy up those quotas from their owners, who could then continue growing peanuts under the new subsidy system. 
Agricultural economists say they can think of no parallel for such a plan.
"It is like the Maryland tobacco buyout, where farmers were given a large one-time payment to stop growing tobacco," said Bruce L. Gardner, a University of Maryland professor and former assistant secretary for economics at the Agriculture Department under the first President Bush. "But these farmers will continue to grow peanuts under a new program."
Blame Canadian peanut butter for the proposals.
Since Nafta, the trade agreement, was signed, American farmers no longer had an effective monopoly on peanuts for American consumption. Imports of lower-priced Canadian brands have increased 45-fold. Raw Mexican peanuts have also started to take a share of the American market.
If something is not done by 2005, when all peanut tariffs will effectively disappear, the price supports, or guaranteed prices for the farmers from the industry, will end. American peanuts and peanut butter would price themselves out of their own market.
Lawmakers looked for a plan that would comply with the trade rules of the global marketplace, lower the price of American peanuts to make them competitive and still provide peanut farmers with a cash safety net. Their answer was to get the taxpayers to subsidize the farmers.
"This is another example of moving away from the old price support system that was paid for by the food industry and consumers and passing that burden on to the taxpayer," a senior Agriculture Department official said.
The buyout program addresses a different problem.
Over the years, the federal peanut program evolved from a basic price support program to one in which quotas to grow peanuts could be traded and rented.
Some quotas are even part of investment portfolios, owned by people who have no intention of farming peanuts.
The biggest owner of these quotas is not a peanut farmer but the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston.
The giant company could receive up to $2.1 million from the government to give up its licenses controlling 3.8 million pounds of peanuts grown in Georgia, according to data compiled by the nonprofit Environmental Working Group from government documents retrieved through a Freedom of Information Act request.
A spokesman for the parent company, now known as John Hancock Financial Services Inc., said he was unable to comment on the proposed buyout.
Lawmakers from the House and Senate have begun hammering out the differences in their separate versions of the omnibus $171 billion farm bill, arguing over where to cut money. 
Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, which is home to some of the country's largest peanut farms, said that he and his fellow House conferees would cut money for food stamps and conservation programs rather than reduce subsidy programs for commodity crops like corn, wheat and peanuts. 
"It just makes more sense when we're looking at a budget deficit," Mr. Stenholm said.
But Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, who is also a conferee, said he had "precisely the opposite point of view of Mr. Stenholm."
"It would be an unfortunate compromise to boost crop subsidies," Mr. Lugar said, "and not retain the advances the Senate has made on improving conservation and nutrition payments." 
This new $4 billion program would benefit farmers in the South: Texas, Alabama, North Carolina and Georgia, the center of American peanut production. While Jimmy Carter, the former president and peanut farmer, made Georgia peanuts famous, his name does not appear on the list of those who hold licenses or quotas.
However, the chief proponent of the new program is Senator Zell Miller, Democrat of Georgia.
"Right or wrong,"Mr. Miller said, "this peanut quota was created by the government. It is unfair to portray quota holders as just large corporations. The long list includes small landowners, widows and aging minority farmers in our country's poorest counties."
The nonprofit group that compiled the peanut data said, though, that it had made the information public to demonstrate how the top 10 percent of peanut farmers control 60 percent of country's peanut farming. "They're hiding behind the poor farmers when in fact this buyout is nothing short of a boondoggle for the biggest farmers," said Anne Keys, vice president of the Environmental Working Group. "Faced with a choice, we hope Congress chooses conservation programs that help all farmers."
Among the most prominent names on the list are the descendants of George Washington Heard, who began peanut farming in southern Georgia in the 19th century, said Waymon Heard, his 71-year-old grandson.
Together the family holds quotas for 8.86 million pounds of peanuts and could receive $3.8 million in the buyout, according to both Mr. Heard and the database. His nephew, Glenn Heard of Brinson, Ga., could be eligible for $1.5 million in the buyout alone and $1.67 million in subsidies. 
Waymon Heard said the family was uneasy about giving up the old peanut quota system, which guarantees them $610 a ton for their peanuts, roughly twice the world price, and a sizable share of the American domestic market. Now, they will face the uncertainties of foreign competition and taxpayer subsidies controlled by Congress.
"There's no telling what will happen before the smoke settles," said Mr. Heard, who has retired from farming and is turning his operation over to his son. "Nafta is the worst thing that ever happened to this country. Quality is going down. Canadian peanut butter. Mexican peanuts. Worst thing that happened."

HEADLINE: An Alaskan Hot Spot, Even at 50 Below Zero 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: CHENA HOT SPRINGS, Alaska, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
Haruna and Taketoshi Harada thought about honeymooning in Paris. They considered Hawaii. But in the end, they journeyed here, to a frigid mountaintop near the Arctic Circle in Alaska, where they nuzzled at 2 o'clock the other morning while gazing at the starry dome of the sky. They were not disappointed. 
 "It's like a curtain of colors, dancing across the sky," Mr. Harada said of the northern lights. "Very vibrant," Mrs. Harada said. "Very beautiful." 
 That same elation struck several other visitors to the mountain, 60 miles east of Fairbanks, despite temperatures well below zero. Kazuhiro Omura, a young medical student from Tokyo, was so happy when the ghostly green lights suddenly appeared and danced above him that he rolled in the snow, laughing. Then he lay on his back and watched the show, proclaiming in Japanese how beautiful it was.
Having long marketed itself as a prime destination for summer tourists, Alaska has been surprisingly successful in recent years luring vacationers in winter as well, many of them from Japan, where the aurora borealis seems to exert an almost mystical pull and where many newlyweds consider a viewing of the lights to be the height of romance and an auspicious sign for a marriage.
The area in and around Fairbanks is recognized as one of the best places on earth to see the shimmering lights. With a variety of other winter activities, including dog-mushing schools and the annual World Ice Art Championships, which begins on Tuesday in Fairbanks, the city has billed itself as a must-see at this time of year, despite the often biting cold.
"Our line on that is, 'Yes, but it's a dry cold,' " said Karen Lundquist, communications manager for the Fairbanks Convention and Visitors Bureau. "But it is cold. It's hard, when it's 50 below, to say that it's not cold. I don't know how you get around that."
Actually, despite Fairbanks's slogan -- "Winter: Always Guaranteed!" -- Alaska has been subject to the same moderation of normal temperatures that much of the Northeast has experienced this year. Night temperatures here in recent weeks have reached a positively balmy zero degrees. 
Many Alaskans are not celebrating: they like it as cold as possible in the winter, and increasing temperatures have set off a wave of alarm about rising sea levels that could threaten coastal villages and thawing in the permafrost that could wreak havoc with roads and even huge structures like the trans-Alaska pipeline.
For now, though, the visitors are coming, and no place is more popular with Japanese tourists than Chena Hot Springs, a remote old lodge reachable on a paved road from Fairbanks.
For the Japanese in particular, the Alaskan wilderness seems to offer a temporary escape pod. 
"I love Tokyo, but in Tokyo you cannot feel nature, there are so many artificial things," said Mr. Omura, 22, who traveled here during his winter break with two fellow students from Jikei University, Kentaro Yamakawa and Eriko Kamada, and spent each of the last five nights searching the night skies for the northern lights. 
Miss Kamada said, "Here, it is just so silent." 
Despite the downturn in the Japanese economy, bookings are strong at the Chena Hot Springs Resort, with about 3,500 Japanese expected to visit this winter, said Joe Juszkiewicz, the general manager, who has hired three Japanese-speaking guides, as well as a dog-mushing instructor and marketing director who are also fluent in the language. Alaska can be reached relatively cheaply via a Korean Air Lines flight through Seoul that connects to Anchorage. 
At the resort, February and March are actually considered the "high season," even busier than July and August, although that is still highly unusual for any tourism-related concern in Alaska. Certainly, the number of summer vacationers here, which the state's Department of Community and Economic Development estimates to be about 900,000, dwarfs the winter counterparts. 
Yet the number of winter travelers who describe "vacation and pleasure" as their primary reason for coming has more than doubled in the state's surveys over the last decade, to 45,000 in 2000-2001 from 21,800 in 1990. 
State tourism officials and resorts have advertised intensively in Japan. The state has also sponsored an advertising campaign in the Southwest United States for an "Alaska Winter White Sale," although officials concede that their mission can be a tough sell. 
One major draw is the sled dog racing, including the Yukon Quest and the Iditarod. Another, of course, is the northern lights, though Alaska competes with Canada, Greenland and Norway to entice visitors to come see them.
The aurora, ribbons of moving, bright lights caused by charged solar particles that congregate through magnetic pull toward the earth's poles, is not a sure thing on any given night. Cloudy skies can obscure it for days on end. But in late February and March here, the odds are pretty good for a spectacular display. 
That happened here this evening, sending a dozen or so tourists charging out of a snow machine that brought them to a ridge high above Chena Hot Springs.
Some couples wandered off to be alone. Masaaki Tsuruoka, an air-conditioning engineer from Tokyo, quickly went to work with his camera. A few tourists quickly made for a heated yurt and fortified themselves with hot cider and ramen noodles. The three medical students from Tokyo just lay on the snow, looking up.
"It is an amazing thing," said Kentaro Yamakawa, 23. "Beautiful. Mysterious. I don't want it to stop."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Visitors from Tokyo viewed a display of the aurora borealis from a snowy field in Chena Dome, Alaska. (Michael Dinneen for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Argentine Estates Decay With Economy 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CANADA DE GOMEZ, Argentina 

 BODY:
As a child growing up in the 1940's, Carlos Emilio Lamas always thought that his grandfather's 12,000-acre estate here on the pampas was a magical place. There were hundreds of horses and thousands of cattle, and on weekends a steady stream of visiting relatives and friends.
 "Life was very comfortable for us then," he recalled recently. "We would play polo in the morning, go hunting for partridges in the afternoon, and in the evening, the dining room was always full, never with less than 15 people." 
 Today, Mr. Lamas, now 60, is the owner of the estate, the Estancia Delsel -- or rather, the little that remains. Less than a tenth of the original acreage is still in his hands, and the cost of maintaining the stately 7,200-square-foot manor house, with its six bedrooms, six bathrooms, pool, wine cellar and coach house, "is not on the same scale as my income," he said. 
Instead of 400 horses, the estate here, about 230 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, now has only 40, all but 10 of which belong to boarders who pay Mr. Lamas a monthly fee. Where cattle once grazed on some of the most fertile pastureland in the world, Mr. Lamas now hopes to build small cottages where horse lovers can stay on weekends and ride or hike.
For more than a century, the estancia, or rural estate, has been one of the most elegant symbols of Argentina, as well as one of its principal sources of wealth. But the landed gentry who own those properties have long been in decline, and the country's current economic crisis, the worst in its turbulent history, is only accelerating that process.
"My grandfather used to say that even though the countryside squeezes, it doesn't strangle," Mr. Lamas said. "But we're at the breaking point. The rural producing class is in debt up to its neck and struggling to survive."
Nearly 11 years ago, Argentina made the peso and the American dollar virtually interchangeable. That policy, which lasted until January, when the link was severed and the peso devalued by more than 50 percent, was intended to catapult a closed economy into the modern age by attracting foreign investment and forcing Argentine producers to become more efficient and competitive.
Landowners responded as it was hoped they would, by investing heavily in new equipment and technology with the aim of capturing new markets abroad. Grain harvests doubled, to 70 million tons a year, but the prices that producers get for beef and for other agricultural exports like wheat, corn and soybeans have lagged far behind the cost of machinery, fertilizers and other supplies.
"The distortion in relative prices has been tremendous," said Jose Ignacio de Mendiguren, who is the minister of production in the government that took power early in January, also the owner of a country estate. "Four years ago, with the earnings from two pounds of meat you could buy a gallon of diesel fuel. By last year, you needed nine pounds of meat to buy that same gallon of diesel."
Farm producers ended the decade with $6 billion in accumulated debt, according to the Argentine Rural Society, a landowners group. "When you've got zero inflation and are paying interest rates of up to 20 percent in dollars, you're going to be hit hard, no matter how fertile and productive your land may be," said Luciano Miguens, a vice president of the group and a member of a prominent landowning family.
Mr. Lamas said he had managed to stay out of debt, unlike his neighbors, "90 percent of whom are in a state of collapse." But in his struggle to stay afloat, he has been forced to turn to many of the same moneymaking schemes as they have, activities that have little to do with agriculture or his own expertise.
Initially, he intended to turn his manor house into a bed-and-breakfast for tourists, as many landowning families near Buenos Aires and other large cities have done, and invested heavily in a remodeling project. But his estancia is too far from a big city to be attractive to tourists and, as he quickly discovered, "you have to give up too much of your own privacy."
Instead, Mr. Lamas now rents out the house for corporate conferences, weddings and birthdays. He talks of building a hotel on the property. He has bred a flock of pheasants to attract weekend hunters and is trying to sell part of his land to a group that wants to an industrial park. He has even acquired a llama, an ostrich and a bevy of peacocks in hopes of attracting visitors.
"I'm looking for every opportunity I can find," he said. "Between the two of them, my grandfathers owned more than 300,000 acres of land. But the days when you could finance a long trip to Europe simply by selling a few thousand head of cattle, those days are gone forever, never to return."
On a smaller estate in Ibarlucea, nearly 50 miles from here, the Albertengo family is trying another approach. They continue to grow wheat, corn and soybeans, but they are converting a 70-acre piece of their 1,100-acre estate into a housing development to be called Los Alamos, subdivided for 103 homes.
"Our plan is to gradually get out of agriculture altogether and turn the entire estate into a series of housing developments," said Mario Jose Albertengo, a 43-year-old agronomist. "We have discovered that land is more valuable when sold by the square foot than when sold by the acre."
Their location, a 20-minute drive from Rosario, the country's third-largest city, would seem ideal. But Argentina's economic situation is so bad right now, mainly as a result of a freeze on bank accounts imposed by the government early in December, that the real estate and construction industries are paralyzed.
"If the country lends us a helping hand by stabilizing the economy, we can make a go of this," said Marcelo Mascetti, Mr. Albertengo's cousin and an architect working on the project. "But this is a delicate moment, and right now the bank freeze is simply killing us."
Farther south, in Patagonia, where estates of 100,000 acres or more are not uncommon and the cost of upkeep is even higher, the situation may be even worse. By one recent tally, half the 1,200 estancias in the province of Santa Cruz have simply been abandoned, their manor houses left to decay in a windy and frigid climate because their owners cannot make ends meet.
Historically, Patagonia is the country's leading sheep-growing and wool-producing region. But farms there have been driven out of business not only by the same economic conditions that afflict other Argentine estates but also by the growing popularity of artificial fibers, which drove down wool prices in the 1990's.
Many of the remaining estates have been sold to foreign entrepreneurs like Ted Turner, to be made into lodges for tourists, or acquired by large corporations and merged into semi-industrialized plantations. According to the Argentine Wool Federation, the country's leading wool producer is now Benetton, the Italian clothing manufacturer.
"With their numbers in the red, many estate owners have simply gotten rid of their sheep, and so the wool culture is gone with them," Joaquin Allolio, an official of the federation, said. "Nowadays you can't even find gauchos who know how to handle sheep."
As he surveys the peacocks strutting across his lawn here, Mr. Lamas worries about the future, too. He has four children, and doubts that any of them will be able to inherit a property that has been in his family for more than 80 years.
"I've been very fortunate to be able to have lived like this, and I'm not complaining," he said. "I know that there are people who will not lament the passing of this way of life, but to me, what is happening seems very cruel. Argentina is a lottery, and we simply don't have the winning numbers anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In time, these young members of the Albertengo family in Ibarlucea, Argentina, may see the family estate split into housing developments. (Horacio Paone for The New York Times)

PERSON: David Hawkins 

HEADLINE: David Hawkins, 88, Historian For Manhattan Project in 1940's 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:
David Hawkins, a philosopher of science who was an assistant to J. Robert Oppenheimer when he directed the Manhattan Project to build an atomic bomb and the official historian of the project, died on Feb. 24 at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 88. 
 After the project, of which he was later very critical, he spent the balance of his life teaching and writing about the philosophy of science and training teachers in the education of children in science and math. 
 He received a MacArthur Foundation "genius" grant in 1986, the first year of the awards, for work in philosophy and childhood science education.
David Hawkins was born on Feb. 28, 1913, in El Paso, the youngest of seven children of William Ashton Hawkins, a railroad lawyer and a founder of the city of Alamogordo, N.M., and Clara Gardiner Hawkins. 
He attended the Hotchkiss School in Connecticut, leaving after his junior year to enroll at Stanford University, where he majored in philosophy. After receiving a B.A. in 1934 and an M.A. in 1937, he went to the University of California, earning a Ph.D. in probability theory in 1940. 
In 1937, he married Frances Pockman, a teacher and writer. He taught at Berkeley until May 1943, when he went to Los Alamos, N.M., as the official government historian of the Manhattan Project and liaison officer to the War Department, as well as Dr. Oppenheimer's aide. 
From Los Alamos, he went to Washington in 1946 to teach at George Washington University. The next year he was hired as an associate professor of philosophy at the University of Colorado, where he spent the rest of his teaching career. In 1949, he developed, along with Herbert Simon, an economist, a theory known as the Hawkins-Simon condition, which is still taught in advanced macroeconomic courses. The theory helped economists understand the interconnectedness of various sectors of an economy.
In December 1950, Dr. Hawkins was called before the House Committee on Un-American Activities in its investigation of reports of Communist infiltration at the University of California's radiation laboratory and atomic bomb projects. He testified that while at Berkeley he joined the Communist Party in 1938 and left it in the spring of 1943. Both he and his wife, who also testified, refused to name any people they had known to be Communists unless their names had already been cited by the committee. He denied that there was a Communist cell at the radiation laboratory. 
His grandson Scott Fisher said that in a vote on his future employment, the regents of the University of Colorado split evenly, but his job was saved when one of them died.
Dr. Hawkins published "The Language of Nature: An Essay on the Philosophy of Science" (1957), among other books. In 1995, he gave the Robert Oppenheimer Memorial Lecture at Los Alamos on the 50th anniversary of the Manhattan Project.
In addition to his wife and Mr. Fisher, of Hoboken, N.J., he is survived by his daughter, Julie Fisher Peck of Lebanon, Ohio; and another grandson, Thomas Fisher, of Portland, Me. 
Dr. Hawkins was reared in the New Mexico desert and is credited with having chosen the drop site for the first test of the bomb, but he felt little enthusiasm for the project. 
As he told an interviewer in 1995, after the bomb was dropped he no longer felt a doomsday weapon was needed, and he was disturbed by the scientists' casual hallway debate over the possibility, however slim, that the blast might ignite nitrogen in the atmosphere and literally blow up the world. 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 6, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about David Hawkins, historian of the Manhattan Project, misstated the year in which he won a MacArthur Foundation "genius" grant. It was 1981, not 1986.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE STREETS; 
A Secured Kandahar Is Now Safe Enough For Some Night Life

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, March 3 

 BODY:
A group of men, neither police officers nor soldiers, walk through a shadowy bazaar, oblivious of the time. That is a remarkable state for them to be in, given that this is Afghanistan and it is 10:52 p.m.
 Since 1979, when the Soviets invaded the country, Kandahar and every other city has lived under a nighttime curfew of at latest 10 p.m., and often earlier. Afghans have become as used to truncated nights as they have to war. A whole generation knows nothing of night life. 
 But two weeks ago, as a sign of faith in his city's safety, the provincial governor lifted the curfew here, the first place in the country where that has been done. 
While the streets are still mostly deserted after 10, more people -- more men, that is -- are creeping out, astonished at their own freedom.
"I am 24 years old, and this is the first time in my life I feel security is good in Kandahar, that I can walk on the streets freely whenever I want," said Abdullah, the owner of a video shop. It was 11:30 p.m. as he walked home.
A few months ago no one would have picked Kandahar to be first to this starting gate. The Taliban founded their movement largely because the city was so anarchic in the early 1990's. And when the Taliban government ended late last year, it did so nowhere more chaotically than here.
American bombs pounded the city as the Taliban dug in. Rival anti-Taliban commanders vied for control as gunmen cruised the streets. Later, a group of Al Qaeda fighters barricaded themselves in a hospital, grenades strapped to their bodies, in a standoff that lasted for weeks.
But little by little the city of Kandahar, and increasingly the countryside around it, have calmed. Crime is relatively under control, political violence noticeably absent. As the country sometimes seems to be sliding toward disarray, Kandahar's mild success bears noting.
"The security situation is surprisingly positive," said Leslie Oqvist, the United Nations regional coordinator for southern Afghanistan. A United Nations Development Program security report says that security "has improved tremendously in the past two weeks" and that access has been opened to a much bigger area of the region.
The stability is fragile. Pockets of Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters remain. There are thousands of unpaid soldiers who may be tempted to commit crimes or may be manipulated by political opportunists. The government plans to eradicate thousands of acres of poppies this month, which could prompt an angry response. The police are catching robbers and murderers, but there is no court system to deal with them.
Officials here, like those across the country, are pushing for an international peacekeeping force because, said Yusuf Pashtoon, an aide to the governor, after 22 years of war there is no trust. "If two major commanders don't trust each other, there can be an explosion," he said.
But for now, said Lal Mohammad, 60, a shopkeeper, "The security's very good." Women said they felt safe in the city.
So what is the secret? Unlike the ethnically diverse north, Kandahar has a population that is almost entirely Pashtun, which eliminates many of the ethnic grievances or revenge crimes that are causing problems elsewhere.
Recognizing the strength of Pashtun bonds, and looking to consolidate his power rather than create resistance, the governor, Gul Agha Shirzai, is taking a fairly tender approach toward former Taliban. Unless atrocities can be proved, he has insisted that those captured -- including the former Taliban foreign minister, Mullah Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil -- be released to the Afghan people.
Mr. Shirzai was governor from 1992 to 1994 before going into exile in Pakistan. By the time he left, things were so bad that residents say they were afraid to walk from one store to another with money in their pockets. Rape and looting were common, all of which fed the Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar's vision of a force that would restore order.
Mr. Shirzai seems determined to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past. Unlike, for example, leaders in Jalalabad, where warlords have worked hard to squeeze each other out, Mr. Shirzai has worked closely with his rivals, who include the brother of Hamid Karzai, the country's interim leader.
"There is a balance between power groups," said an aide to Mr. Shirzai, Yusuf Pashtoon. "The power groups are tribes, and if they are secure enough, the rivalries aren't there." Those rivalries have also been quelled, average Afghans and aid officials agree, by the active presence of the American military. Having 4,000 American soldiers stationed at Kandahar Airport has a deterrent effect. 
Troops do "first light" and "last light" patrols on the outskirts of the city. Members of the American Special Forces eat lunch in the Kandahar Restaurant with semiautomatic weapons slung over their shoulders or laid next to them on the floor. The Special Forces bivouac behind the governor's palace and, as heavily armed bodyguards, are never far from Mr. Shirzai's side.
For now, said Habibullah Wadji, an education worker with an international aid organization, the Afghans accept the troops' presence, because they believe that the Americans will build roads, fix hospitals and create jobs.
Many say that there is plenty of American money coming in, but that most of it is going to Mr. Shirzai to distribute among commanders to buy their allegiance, and their quiet. 
That is impossible to prove, but many soldiers do carry American-provided Kalashnikovs, which were airdropped during the fight against the Taliban. There are few commanders without their own Thuraya satellite phones.
"The Americans are telling them don't fight or the money won't come in," one aid official said. "They are literally holding their hands and saying don't fight." The reason, they say, is that it is almost as important to show that Kandahar can work as Kabul: it was the Taliban's heartland and the home of Mr. Karzai, who has been backed by Washington.
But the Afghans are also making their own concerted drive toward law and order here. The army has been confined to barracks, and soldiers from different factions have been integrated into the police force. They have been given uniforms, which they wear most of the time. Occasionally they march through the city in camouflage uniforms with white epaulets, a random strand of order in a city more prone to its opposite. They are being given some basic training.
"The police system was not working, and we worked hard to organize the police forces," said the new chief, Muhammad Javed Akram.
The government has moved quickly to collect weapons, giving a deadline for their voluntary surrender. It has begun acting on tips and says it will do house-to-house searches.
Isireli Dugu, the security officer for the United Nations Development Program, noted that probably only a fraction of the weapons in the city had been turned in. But, he said, the effort has had a deterrent effect, in that people holding on to weapons are less likely to use them, because they might be confiscated.
The result is that "there's hardly anyone with a weapon in civilian clothes," Mr. Dugu said.
Unless they happen to be American Special Forces, of course. That contradiction has prompted worry that the American presence could ultimately provoke violence. 
In the last three weeks there has been a firefight at the airport's edge and two Russian-made rockets fired toward the base there. Last Friday, at least one Afghan soldier was killed when he stepped on a land mine a mile from the airport. The Americans say there were reports of two men digging in the area before the blast, suggesting that the mine might have been newly planted.
There is also the question of what happens when the Americans leave, and whether those they have armed and supported act in the Afghans' interest or their own. 
"Let's hope the Americans don't repeat the mistake of the war against the Russians," said Mr. Wadji, the education worker. "The warlords were a product of that era. America supported warlords in the name of the mujahedeen, and later they supported a nightmare for Afghanistan."

HEADLINE: A Russian Trademark Dispute Sends a Vodka Brand Fleeing 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 3 

 BODY:
Sitting on a lonely dock in the Russian port city of Kaliningrad, a load of Stolichnaya and Moskovskaya vodka awaits shipment to bars and liquor stores in the United States and other foreign watering holes because of a trademark dispute between a Russian company and the Ministry of Agriculture.
 The company, Soyuzplodimport, has struck back by moving its Russian production of Stolichnaya to Latvia -- to Russians the rough equivalent of raising Russian sables in Guadalajara. 
 The crux of the dispute is that the Russian government believes that the trademarks for Stolichnaya, the No. 2 imported vodka in America, and Moskovskaya, which is popular in Western Europe, were obtained for a pittance and that they want the trademarks back. The company claims government officials are trying to wrest away its rights to the Stolichnaya name for their own dark motives. "It goes against logic and justice," said Andrei Skurikhin, general director of the company, during an interview in his Moscow office. "It's a huge violation. You can't just take away property." 
The fight represents one of the worst fears of Russian capitalists, many of whom took advantage of the economic chaos after the fall of the Soviet Union to buy up companies and trademarks. 
Small entrepreneurs often must battle the government to keep their assets out of the hands of acquisitive government officials. Mr. Skurikhin blames the personal interests of a small number of powerful officials for his current problems. 
Whatever the reason, the vodka dispute intensified last year, when a court ruled that the company, known by its acronym, S.P.I., was not the legal heir to the brand names of 43 popular Russian vodkas, including Stolichnaya, a major national symbol. The company fought back and won the return of most of the brands. But as frequently happens in Russia, that was not the end of it.
Russia's general prosecutor began criminal cases against S.P.I. vodka factories in Russia. Last month, in what seemed the ultimate insult, a second Stolichnaya brand -- approved by the Agriculture Ministry -- mysteriously popped up at a food show here. Ten days ago, the government refused to let the vodka move from the loading dock.
The Agriculture Ministry argues that rights to the names of the 43 vodkas were snapped up illegally, and far too cheaply, when Russia began its program of selling off state industries in the early 1990's.
Mr. Skurikhin, 31, played no role in that transaction. But when SPI acquired the trademarks in 1997, officials here say, it bought responsibility for the way the trademarks were purchased some five years earlier.
Mr. Skurikhin acknowledged that the brands came cheaply -- $300,000, to be exact -- but he said they were worth little then because no money had been put into promoting them. Also, in the turmoil after the fall of the Soviet Union, the vodka business was virtually unregulated and knockoffs of brands like Stolichnaya popped up across the nation. 
"Those were the rules of the game in the market," he said, referring to what he paid for the trademarks. "The whole country was living by those rules."
Russia's Supreme Court would seem to agree, having ruled in 1999 that the brands had been acquired legally. Moreover, S.P.I. has a photocopy of a 1992 letter signed by the then first deputy minister of agriculture stating that the brands were property of the company eventually bought by Mr. Skurikhin.
But industry experts in the government are not so sure. SPI was set up on the bankrupt carcass of its predecessor to avoid losing the trademarks to a hungry creditor in Latvia. SPI did not bother changing the company's name. It took the Soviet-era acronym, Soyuzplodoimport, and dropped one of the O's in the name.
"It's the same as me setting up a factory here called Ford, but changing one letter," said Nikolai I. Koryazhkin, deputy general director of Rosspirtprom, the state agency that manages the portion of this country's vodka industry that is still government owned. "How would that look?"
Worst of all, officials say, Mr. Skurikhin has begun producing Stolichnaya at a factory in Latvia, a former Soviet republic that is now one of Russia's least friendly neighbors.
Mr. Skurikhin says his company helped fight illegal production in Russia to protect its trademarks. It has registered trademarks of Stolichnaya and Moskovskaya in more than 100 countries, and has contracts with foreign distributors, including Allied Domecq of Britain which distributes Stolichnaya in the United States. The company expected vodka sales worldwide of up to $400 million this year, Mr. Skurikhin said.
He wrote a letter to Russia's president Vladimir V. Putin last year, but he did not receive a reply. So with a shipment tied up in Kaliningrad the Latvian factory will pick up the slack, Mr. Skurikhin said, to keep vodka flowing.
Russians in the vodka business were nonplused.
"Russian vodka not produced in Russia?" said Pavel Shapkin, chairman of Russia's National Alcohol Association. "I think that will be a problem."

HEADLINE: Is The Observer for Sale? Always, At a Dollar Apiece, Its Owner Says 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
One can be forgiven for speculating about Arthur L. Carter and his plans for The New York Observer. After all, who doesn't speculate? The salmon-pink bundle of news and attitude preys on the imagination and fears of powerful New Yorkers in a way that few other publications of its size -- it says it has a circulation of about 50,000 -- can match. 
 When it expanded with an extra section about three years ago, there were rumors that Mr. Carter was thinking of selling The Observer, a weekly that he had dedicated to the proposition that all men -- and some women -- are created pretentious, and that puncturing those pretensions is worth losing a few million dollars every year. 
 Now that he has been cutting the staff, the heft of the paper and even its physical size, the rumors are back: that he is consumed with sculpturing and does not care about the newspaper; or that his sale of The Litchfield County Times, the paper in the genteel reaches of central Connecticut, where celebrities go to hide and to buy high-end garden equipment, just goes to show that he does not care about newspapers anymore.
Even Mr. Carter speculates about his own intentions. In a recent interview, the sometimes reticent financier-turned-publisher said: "My commercial side is stronger than I wish it were. I wish I were less commercial. But you can't change your spots. So from time to time the commercial side rears its ugly head and says: 'Why are you losing all this money? Your father would have had a fit.' Do I say that to myself from time to time? Absolutely."
The last time he said it often, the newspaper almost ended up in the hands of Conrad M. Black, the chief executive of Hollinger International, the Canadian publishing giant. That courtship fell apart at the altar, and Mr. Black is now a backer of The New York Sun, a daily newspaper scheduled to start publication this spring. 
Reminiscing about his six-year dalliance with Mr. Black, Mr. Carter concluded by saying that he intends to keep The Observer for himself. For now.
Not that anybody really believes it. After all, Mr. Carter sold The Litchfield County Times last year, and The Nation, a liberal magazine, in 1995. Representatives of at least three of the city's major investment banking firms have come calling in the past three months, since the rumors heated up, looking to broker a deal, according to representatives of those firms, who spoke on condition that their names not be used. 
"There's always been people circling The Observer," Mr. Carter said. "A lot of bees circle the paper and say, 'Is Carter selling the newspaper?' We get inquiries from time to time from brokers and investment bankers." This time around, he said, the rumors were a logical outgrowth of a period when advertisers have gone to ground and one publication after another has closed.
"I'm sure it had to do with the very poor economic climate, a poor advertising climate. The closing of Talk and Brill's Content and Mademoiselle. And we're making cuts like everyone else, because our revenues are down 15 percent." Then, in a humorous voice that seemed proud and disgusted in equal measure, he added, "We're a small organization, but when we lay off three people it's bigger news here than when U.S. Steel lays off 20,000."
He added that 15 years ago, when he started The Observer near the end of the next-to-last big economic boom, in the 1980's, he had some hopes of making money. "I don't think I went into it necessarily thinking I would make a lot of money. I hoped I would, and hope springs eternal."
After 15 years?
"Well, after 15 years, you begin to feel you are destined to be a publication that never makes money. You're like Harvard, Yale and Princeton."
But they have endowments, don't they?
"The Observer has an endowment. Me. I'm the endowment."
And how many endowment directors have the pleasure of fielding angry calls from leading politicians, or being told off at dinner parties by the likes of Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publisher of The Daily News and a habitual subject of Observer articles that are habitually unflattering.
All of which, of course, would suggest that Mr. Carter, 70, has given up his plans to sell the newspaper. Not exactly. Minority partners, he said, are always an option. And, asked if he would say flatly that he never intends to sell it and devote himself only to his other vocation, sculpturing, Mr. Carter said quickly:
"I could say it. I'm not sure it would be true. The answer is: I don't have an intent to sell it for the foreseeable future.
"I love what it does. I'm not sure -- I've had conversations with people who say, 'You could stay on and own a piece of it.' We've had those conversations."
But in the end, he said, "anyone who owns 51 percent can tell you goodbye." He added, "If you want to guarantee that you're working on a day-to-day basis, you can't sell it."
The economic pain of producing The Observer is likely to stay sharp. The New York Sun may write about different things -- more school vouchers, less Hamptons real estate -- but it is aiming for an intelligent audience that wants an alternative to The New York Times, The New York Post and The Daily News. That makes the new daily newspaper a competitor.
"Anyone who is going after ad dollars or subscription dollars is a competitor," Mr. Carter said. "For some period of time they are going to be taking business from those of us who have it."
Does that increase the likelihood that he will find his sculpture -- which doesn't talk back -- a more desirable companion than his journalists? "There are practicalities in life," he said. "If I didn't have the resources to support The Observer, I wouldn't do it. As long as the resources are there, I will do it."

HEADLINE: R and R for an Old Fort; 
A Harbor Outpost Faces Renovation as a Resort

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: FORT HANCOCK, N.J., March 1 

 BODY:
Like a column of tired old soldiers eager to brag of faded glories, the brick centurions that housed generations of military men here are proud, imposing, but withered by time, their sagging rooflines and rotting porches hinting of a more regal past. 
 Built at the mouth of New York Harbor as a bulwark against maritime invaders, Fort Hancock was the premier fortification for the nation's premier city and port. The British found this sandy spit invaluable when they seized Manhattan in 1776. So did the Eisenhower-era tacticians who placed Nike missiles in the dunes in the 1950's, a potential foil to Soviet warplanes. 
 But since 1974, when the Pentagon deactivated this Army base at the tip of Sandy Hook and handed it over to the National Park Service, most of Fort Hancock's colonial-style barracks, stables and gun batteries have been mothballed, awaiting the bold ideas and federal largess that would bring them back to life. For 28 years, the public financing failed to materialize and rehabilitation schemes died amid concerns that the wrong kind of development would ruin an astounding relic of American military history. 
Now, faced with the rapid decay of more than 280 structures, the National Park Service has chosen a private developer to transform Fort Hancock into a combination resort, office center and cultural hub, all set amid the 19th-century buildings that housed thousands of soldiers between the Spanish-American and Vietnam Wars.
No suburban office park, the 140-acre sand-and-lawn campus would be swept with delicious sea breezes in the summer and icy gusts in the winter. On clear days, it would have faraway views of the Lower Manhattan skyline. Water, of course, would be visible at every turn, and frequent ferries would connect Fort Hancock to the city, 45 minutes away.
The plan by Sandy Hook Partners of Middletown, N.J., was chosen from among 22 proposals, some of which envisioned golf courses, skeet-shooting platforms, housing for the elderly and conference centers. Mindful of potential critics, park officials point out that the winning project would neither remove existing structures nor add new ones, except for a maintenance garage and a building modeled on a handsome hospital that burned two decades ago.
"This place is really a hidden jewel," said Richard E. Wells, Fort Hancock's deputy superintendent, looking across the windswept parade grounds. "But if we don't act quickly, these buildings will continue to deteriorate and they could be lost forever."
With $5 billion in park service projects languishing across the country, Mr. Wells said, there was little hope that Congress would provide the $60 million to $90 million needed to restore Fort Hancock. "It's not like the American people have that kind of money in their back pocket," he said. "We can't do this alone."
So far, there has been little criticism of the proposed plan, which faces a modest approval process. Some environmentalists have expressed concern that 800 additional cars and the 1,500 people who will be drawn to the new Fort Hancock could harm a fragile ecosystem. Others are uncomfortable with the privatization of national park land.
"Sandy Hook is basically an unreinforced sandbar and the last piece of undeveloped coastline within 55 miles of New York," said Brian Unger, regional director of the Surfers' Environmental Alliance. "More cars, more parking lots and more people can't be good for it."
Most, however, say the park service has been careful to balance history, economics and the environment. "Other than just abandoning or bulldozing the place, we see this is a good fit," said Ray Cosgrove, president of the Sandy Hook Foundation, which works to preserve the peninsula's delicate flora as well as Fort Hancock's decaying structures. Over the years, the group has helped restore the camp's W.P.A.-era theater and a lighthouse, built in 1764, that is the country's oldest. "My feeling is that the National Park Service loves this place as much as we do," Mr. Cosgrove said.
Ground could be broken as early as fall of 2002.
Army veterans who served at Fort Hancock are eagerly awaiting its rebirth as well. Al Zwiazek, 83, who spent three years here during the late 1930's, still comes with his wife for nostalgic drives through the grounds. "Oh, it was a busy place," he said, speaking from his home in Garfield, N.J. "It was a self-contained world, but it could also be cold and desolate." 
Mr. Zwiazek, who arrived here as an 18-year-old infantryman, recalled visits by Charles Lindbergh, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and King George VI and Queen Elizabeth. He also remembers the day in 1937 when the doomed Hindenburg floated overhead on its way to Lakehurst. 
Although the United States military began fortifications during the War of 1812, much of what remains was built in 1898, all of it dressed in a sober colonial revival uniform. Most striking is the orderly procession of mustard-colored houses that stand along Sandy Hook Bay, their wooden porches well positioned for sunset viewing. Three of the 18 houses will be turned into boutique inns and others will find a new life as offices. A nearby mule barn, hay still strewn around its stalls, will become a restaurant for day trippers. 
Behind "Officers Row" and scattered around the parade grounds are an assortment of matching structures: mess halls, a chapel, a bowling alley, a post office and barracks for nearly 1,000 men. One of the most impressive structures, the Officers Club, is a rambling ruin overlooking the Atlantic, its floors buckled by water damage, the tin ceilings rusted from years of salt spray. Built in 1878, the building will become a bed and breakfast, with about a dozen rooms above and an upscale restaurant below in the former ballroom. 
"I'm stunned by the condition but amazed by the beauty," said Jim Wassel, the head of Sandy Hook Partners. As he descended the double staircase, mounds of paint flakes crunched underfoot. Mr. Wassel, a veteran developer, had a hand in historical restorations like those of Faneuil Hall in Boston and South Street Seaport in New York.
According to his plan, one-third of the fort's structures will be leased to commercial tenants and cultural groups, while another third will be kept by the half-dozen maritime and environmental organizations that have been using them for years. The last third will be retained by the park service for offices and staff housing. 
At its peak during World War II, as many as 12,000 soldiers stayed here before shipping off to Europe. Thousands of others, elated and exhausted, arrived at Fort Hancock after V-E Day. It was an all-male world until 1942, when the Army established the Women's Army Corps, whose members began filling slots as dental assistants, secretaries and mess hall cooks. 
The edges of Fort Hancock are sprinkled with concrete gun batteries from the days when Sandy Hook was one of the nation's foremost proving grounds for new weapons; a Nike missile site is one of the park's biggest draws. Mr. Zwiazek said the thud of exploding ordnance and the smell of gunpowder were almost always in the air. "We used to keep the windows open; otherwise the concussion would break the glass," he said. "We'd often have cotton in our ears." 
Much of the area where artillery shells once fell is now precious habitat for piping plovers and ospreys, and for rare plants like wild wormwood. As part of the development, park officials will restore the natural landscape by turning a former rail yard into habitat for nesting birds. Windmills, wastewater recycling and a natural gas pipeline are to be introduced as part of an environment-friendly development package. 
As a merciless wind howled through an empty barracks earlier in the week, Mr. Wells acknowledged that working or staying at Fort Hancock in winter might not appeal to everyone. Still, for those accustomed to working in jam-packed Manhattan or suburban office pods, there is nothing like a desk with an ocean view, he said. "Sure it can be gray and miserable; the wind cuts through you," he said, making his way across the parade ground. "But isn't it exhilarating?"

HEADLINE: Pocketing Soft Money Till Pocket Is Sewn Up 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3 

 BODY:
With the Senate likely to approve landmark restrictions on political fund-raising and with Congress up for grabs, Republicans and Democrats are mounting an aggressive, last-ditch drive to collect unrestricted checks from wealthy donors before such donations are banned.
 The Republicans are exploiting three marquee figures to attract the large contributions: a popular wartime president, his strategically reclusive vice president and an iconic former mayor of New York. 
 The schedule for President Bush includes two fund-raising events a week for the next few months. Last week, he went to North Carolina, where he headlined a $1 million lunch, and Iowa, and on Monday he travels to Minnesota.
Vice President Dick Cheney, fresh from a dinner at which he raised $1 million from 35 couples for the California Republican Party, is on a similar drive. He has scheduled some 60 fund-raising events from now to November, or about two a week. 
Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has become one of the most sought-after fund-raisers in Republican history, welcomed in places where no New York mayor, in office or out, has raised money before. He is headlining a "Salute to America's Heroes" this month to raise $5 million for House Republicans. 
Lest anyone think it unseemly for them to use their sky-high approval ratings from the war to light up the money circuit, Mr. Bush now routinely brings up the subject.
"Somebody said to me the other day, or actually asked me today, am I going to campaign?" Mr. Bush said on Wednesday at the fund-raising lunch in North Carolina. "Here we are in a war, do you think it's all right for the president to go campaign?"
"Yes," he said simply. "I do."
Driven by a hunger for a Republican Congress, bolstered by unusually high approval ratings and fully aware that the door could close on the big donations known as soft money, the Bush-Cheney-Giuliani triumvirate is striking while the iron is hot. They are raising both the big soft money -- which includes donations from corporations, unions and the wealthy -- and smaller, more regulated contributions for an array of candidates and state parties. 
"This may be the last year to reap those unlimited soft-money donations," said Larry Makinson, a senior fellow at the Center for Responsive Politics, "and you can bet both parties are doing absolutely everything they can." Mr. Makinson added, "It's like last call at the bar, and it's going to last for eight months."
Democrats, who usually lag in fund-raising, are also in overdrive. The bill before the Senate, if signed into law, would go into effect after this year's Congressional elections.
"One of the few things the parties have in common is we're making a huge, huge push on fund-raising," said Maria Cordova, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee. The Democrats' big draw? Bill Clinton, scheduled for a spring gala at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.
Even some of the Democrats' most ardent proponents of eliminating soft money are unabashed.
"We've got to play by the rules we have now," Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader and one such opponent, said as Democrats took in more than $4.5 million last week at a $10,000-a-head dinner featuring Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, who gave the Democrats the majority when he switched from Republican to independent.
"And the rules are that soft money will be part of the campaign of 2002," Mr. Daschle said. "I'm not going to tie one or both arms behind my back and expect to compete effectively with my Republican colleagues."
If the Senate gives final passage this month to a wide-ranging change in campaign law, it will be a watershed moment in a long struggle. The bill, championed by Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, would radically change the campaign finance system, leaving all sides uncertain which party would ultimately benefit.
The bill would prohibit the national political parties from accepting the kinds of donations they have increasingly come to rely on. It would also restrict outside groups from running thinly disguised campaign commercials for or against a particular candidate 30 days before a primary or 60 days before a general election.
In exchange for eliminating soft money, the bill would allow increases in smaller, more tightly regulated contributions, known as hard money, for the first time since 1974.
Individuals would be able to give $2,000 per election to candidates instead of $1,000, and the top limits would increase with inflation. Other limits would also rise. For example, a person would be allowed to give up to $95,000, spread among candidates and political parties, in each two-year election cycle, instead of the current $25,000 in a year.
State and local parties would be able to take donations of up to $10,000 per year per person for vote drives.
This is far from the first time Congress has tried to cut ties between special interests and politics. Since 1907, when Theodore Roosevelt signed into law a ban on contributions by corporations and banks, Congress has made sporadic efforts to control the flow of big money.
Usually the impulse is born of scandal. The last successful push for change came in 1974, after the disclosures of Richard M. Nixon's illicit fund-raising. Congress enacted the most comprehensive campaign regulatory system ever, an intricate system of checks and balances.
To stop wealthy interests from buying access, the law put into place an array of caps on contributions, including a limit of $1,000 per election on donations to federal candidates by individuals. To ease the pressure to raise money, it set limits on candidate spending.
The law also provided some public financing for presidential elections. The Federal Election Commission was created to police the bill's mandates that all contributions above $200 be fully and publicly disclosed.
But the system began to unravel quickly because of court cases, regulatory rulings, Congress and ever more inventive politicians, interest groups and financiers. As political operatives contemplate this year's proposed restrictions, there are already predictions that new loopholes will be found to subvert the law. 
After the 1974 changes, the Supreme Court struck down spending limits as an unconstitutional infringement on free speech unless candidates voluntarily accepted them to qualify for public financing.
The decision put federal candidates in a relentless money chase. Spending limits vanished, but limits on raising money remained. The parties and candidates soon found a way around these strictures: soft money.
A 1978 ruling by the elections agency opened the door for the parties to use corporate and union funds for party-building activities, like get-out-the-vote drives. This so-called soft money was not to be spent directly to aid particular federal candidates.
It took some time for the parties to exploit this loophole. But by the 1988 presidential election, big money was back. The Republican candidate, Mr. Bush's father, and his Democratic opponent, Michael S. Dukakis, benefited from donor clubs of $100,000 contributors established by the Republican and Democratic National Committees. The parties raised $45 million in soft money that year.
In 1996, President Clinton took soft-money fund-raising to new heights. He held dinners with $100,000 donors. He rewarded donors with overnight stays in the Lincoln Bedroom.
"The reality is that now we really have expenditure limits in name only in federal elections," said David B. Magleby, a campaign finance scholar and dean of social sciences at Brigham Young University.
The 1996 election brought another significant change. Mr. Clinton and his campaign adviser Dick Morris pioneered an aggressive use of soft money, for party issue advertising, that helped the president build a formidable early lead over Bob Dole in 1995. His lawyers contended that the use of $32 million in soft money for such advertisements was legal because the commercials stopped just short of saying, "Vote for Bill Clinton." In 1996, Mr. Dole followed suit, turning to the Republican Party to broadcast more than $20 million in issue advertisements on his behalf.
By the last presidential election, the parties had raised nearly $500 million in soft money, a record. Losing all that money is bound to be wrenching; indeed many Republicans argue that the power of the national parties will be sharply reduced in a post-soft-money world.
"At the end of the day, said Senator Bill Frist, a Tennessee Republican and chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, afund-raising vehicle, "what it's really doing is cutting the power of both of them in half." 
The parties are already trying to increase their smaller, hard-dollar bases. This will pose a particular challenge to Democrats, who have had more trouble raising such funds.
Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, conceded that his party was at a disadvantage against such a proven fund-raiser as Mr. Bush. But he added, "That stuff doesn't scare me."
Like the Republicans, the Democrats have been preparing for the day the national parties can no longer raise soft money. Mr. McAuliffe said Democrats were shifting focus from glittery top-dollar events to a more grass-roots, targeted approach.
One person who probably will not be hurt by the changes is Mr. Bush. In 2000, he proved such a potent fund-raiser that he did not take federal matching funds for his campaign. He still raised more money than his Democratic opponent, Al Gore.
Some fund-raisers expect the biggest change to be that the large contributions now going directly to the parties will instead go to ideological groups aligned with them, like the National Rifle Association or the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League. Or the money could go through special committees set up especially to raise money for television commercials.
"This money doesn't dry up," said Representative Thomas M. Davis III, the Virginia Republican who leads the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee. "It stays there. Instead of going to the parties, it goes somewhere else."
Steve Rosenthal, the political director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., one of the most effective forces in politics, agreed. "For those who want to give, there will always be ways of giving," Mr. Rosenthal said. 
Mr. McCain acknowledged that clever campaign lawyers and donors were likely to find ways around his bill in future years. "There will be a period of time of relatively clean elections -- I emphasize relative -- and then we will find some smart people who find smart ways around it," he said.
That, he predicted, will simply spawn another drive to clean up the system. "Twenty years from now," he said, "there will be two more senators who will be arguing for reform because we've gone continuously through cycles of corruption and reform."

HEADLINE: Magazines; 
Those Jaunty Issues Of the New Economy Take a Sober Turn

BYLINE:  By DAVID CARR 

 BODY:
Few things age faster than the future, and few things embody that fact more acutely than the September 2000 issue of Red Herring. 
 A brawny artifact of a bygone era, the issue weighed in at 552 ad-stuffed pages -- more than two pounds of hubris that would kill a small cat if it fell off a table. Its cover was anchored by an Oz-like Bill Gates, and both the ads and editorial content announced that the geeks had triumphed. The prebust issue of the magazine was a temple to what one of its stories called "a style of business pioneered in Silicon Valley, but it's now practiced everywhere: sunny, optimistic and endlessly creative." 
 Poof.
The March 2002 issue of Red Herring features Bill Gates's second, Steven A. Ballmer, in a wedding dress, to suggest he has been left at the altar by technology.
He's not the only one. The March issue, all 6.5 ounces of it, runs a scant 100 pages, and that includes public-service ads for the Girl Scouts and the United Way, along with 6 pages of the magazine advertising itself. One of its main features tells how investors are in open revolt against venture capitalists who have thrown their money down a digital rat hole.
Having set down the pom-poms that were very much a part of technology-sector coverage, the spate of magazines that lived off the Internet boom have turned into a journalistic rust belt, lurching in search of not just survival, but a compelling story. Magazines that had celebrated the limitlessness of human endeavors are now a sober, stern read tracking the broader business climate with charts where all the graphs go down and pictures where the subjects raise their right hand to testify.
The fizzy vocabulary that had become part of the genre is now of little use in telling the stories of Cisco's inventory debacle, the evaporation of investment and the unwillingness of traditional businesses to hire dot-com veterans. There is really no enjoyable way to talk about a trip to the gallows, after all.
In a generally brutal publishing economy, special punishment has been reserved for the new-economy magazines. The Industry Standard, the sector's weekly bible -- and ironically the most skeptical in its coverage -- died an early death last summer that now looks like a mercy killing. Business 2.0 died and was promptly married to Time Inc.'s unfortunately named eCompany Now, which promptly took on the acquired's name. Fast Company, which was always more about human capital than venture capital, is still stuck with a bandwidth of buzzwords that seem quaint in the current context. Red Herring is covering a venture capital community that is busy sitting on its wallet, while Upside is finding out that downside is a very tough thing to cover.
Even so, the bull market in optimism -- Silicon Valley's most durable export -- continues. As it turns out, their editors say, these next-generation business magazines were never just about the new economy.
"Our magazine did more to sort of highlight the stupidities of what was going on than just about any other magazine," said the editor and president of Business 2.0, Ned Desmond. "The big question now is how do you do business well?" Or in the instance of the March issue of Business 2.0, how to do it without going to jail. "Why would anyone believe you?" asks a cover story about Enron and corporate credibility, illustrated with a Pinocchio-nosed Kenneth L. Lay.
That is a fair question as well for a magazine that offered up Enron's Jeffrey K. Skilling as a revolutionary just last September. Mr. Desmond chose to address the issue directly in his editor's note, saying that the magazine "just plain got suckered. For that we apologize."
Mr. Desmond's note is a breathtaking acknowledgment. People have historically bought tech-oriented magazines to help see over the hill, and the serial apologies that now run through coverage do little to inspire reader confidence in that mission.
Technology reporters often felt like they were part of what they were covering, and that is one hard fact that has not changed. The crash they covered landed on them as well. The survivors now have a much less interesting beat; after all, there are just so many eBays to go around. 
All the eat-your-vegetables tutorials can make for dreary reading. In Business 2.0, the Brazen Careerist column suggests that the reader "set your sights lower or you will be unemployed long after the unemployment checks stop coming." So much for the Brand Called You.
What remains is an exercise in journalistic taxidermy, stuffing the carcass of the digital economy with lessons learned. "The story of technologically driven business as the pre-eminent feature of American culture is gone," said John Battelle, the former chairman of Standard Media International.
Mr. Desmond argues that "the magazine has a much deeper mission than to just grab a hold of the zeitgeist," pointing to the success of Gruner+Jahr USA Publishing's Fast Company as an indication that "the audience of business readers has changed dramatically. They came out of the blue with a radically different approach and something clicked."
Fast Company's emphasis on cultural, rather than technological, engines of change has made for a softer landing. The magazine continues to add readers, even as its ad base and most of its profit erode.
"Our fundamental mission," said Alan M. Webber, a founding co-editor, "is to help people make sense out of the rapidly changing business, give them the tools to compete and help them see what was coming next before it got here."
Red Herring, christened in less serious times, now sounds like a prescient name. The magazine, like so many of the venture capitalists it features, remains in search of the next big whatever. "Even some economists say that a wider use of broadband could lead the U.S. economy out of recession," it says in arguing for a Marshall Plan for government-financed info highways.
Jason Pontin, editor of Red Herring, said his magazine is agnostic about specific technologies and is finding good articles by following the money that is being invested.
"We are covering stories that rival the Internet," Mr. Pontin said. "Changes in biotech and nanotech that will shift the paradigm."
Upside's chief executive, John Carroll, says, hopefully, that the darkest hour is over. "So many bad things have happened at once in this area of publishing, that it's bound to get better," he said. "It has been like the guy who goes into the hospital to get a broken leg treated and after he gets fixed up, he comes walking out of the hospital and gets run over by a car. How many times is that going to happen?"
