HEADLINE: Unusual Route to Diplomacy; 
Columbia Trains Standouts From a Community College

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The students sitting around the small seminar table at Hostos Community College last Friday were pleased to be part of an unusual experiment to send nontraditional and minority students into American foreign-policy careers by way of the Ivy League. 
 But the students were agitated as they listened to Mercedes Moscat, a counselor at Hostos, who told them that if they were going to succeed, they needed to cut out everything that got in the way: student activities, social life, even family. 
 "If you think Hostos is hard," she said, "imagine what it will be like when you go to Columbia." 
The session was one in a series of workshops to ease the transition from Hostos to Columbia University and then to international jobs. But for some of the students -- a handpicked group of motivated achievers -- the order to prioritize stymied them. Already, every moment of their lives was accounted for. 
"There are five of us taking six to eight classes, working and being parents," said Carolyn Castro, a single mother with two sons under the age of 6, who said she starts her homework at 8:30 p.m. -- after she reads to her children at bedtime -- and does not finish until almost 2 a.m. 
"I cannot let go," she said, as others nodded knowingly. "I cannot quit my job. I cannot let go of my family. And I cannot stop being a student. People kid me that since I'm in this program, I'd better take pictures of my kids, because I won't see them."
These stressed students will be given a shot to break into diplomacy, which has long recruited sophisticated polished students from the best schools, many of them white and upper class. But with the help of $2.3 million in government grants last year, Jose E. Serrano, the Bronx congressman, is determined to change this. Standout students from Hostos, a community college in his South Bronx district, will be channeled into Columbia in Upper Manhattan, one of the universities that have traditionally served as pipelines to America's diplomatic corps and other international careers. Congressman Serrano said he hoped that many would enter the Foreign Service and bring their own sensibilities to it.
Eligible Hostos graduates, known as Serrano scholars, will transfer to Columbia to earn their bachelor's degrees at Columbia's School of General Studies and then master's degrees at Columbia's School of International and Public Affairs. Their tuition will be paid and they will also be given living stipends: $500 a semester while at Hostos, and $1,450 a month while at Columbia.
To qualify, students must be American citizens, maintain a 3.0 average and have a good command of English and one other language. Students have to apply separately for each step in the program; admission to each of the two Columbia programs is not automatic.
For many of the dozen students at Hostos, it is a leap. Columbia College generally takes some of the best students in the nation and throws them into a rigorous core curriculum where they must read hundreds of pages of classic literature and history a week and write extensive essays and research papers.
Many Hostos students, in contrast, start their studies with basic composition and math courses. The community college has been a magnet for high school dropouts, single mothers, impoverished immigrants and other untraditional students. Only 8 percent of its entering full-time students earn their associate's degree within three years. Five years ago, City University trustees and other critics charged that the college was allowing students to graduate without a firm command of English.
But Hostos officials, including Dolores M. Fernandez, its president, say that while Hostos undoubtedly has some weak students, it also has many strong ones -- like their nursing graduates, who often have some of the highest passing rates on certification exams in New York State, and like the 12 students they have chosen as their first Serrano Scholars.
There is Jeannette Berrios, a bubbly 24-year-old single mother in the program who scored above 1,400 on her SAT's but who lived in a homeless shelter with her 2-year-old son, Raymond, for more than a year after their apartment burned down. She graduated from Hostos last month with a 3.85 average.
And there is Luis Rivera, 22, who dropped out of his Brooklyn high school before graduation, enrolled at Hostos after he lost his job towing cars and now has a straight A average.
Ziograin Correa, 23, enrolled at Hostos after he was injured while working as a security guard. He is taking the most challenging courses he can find, including Shakespeare and pre-calculus, but has managed to make the dean's list and honor roll every semester. "My friends think I'm crazy," Mr. Correa said. "But I'm proud of myself. I've done what I wanted and a little more."
Hostos officials are confident they have more than enough students to make it at Columbia.
"All of these students have the intelligence and the ability," said Alice Blanch, the program's director. She says the workshops -- in everything from speaking and writing to interviewing techniques and self-esteem -- are aimed not at changing the students so much as "honing skills that are already there."
The program places students in Columbia's School of General Studies, which has about 1,200 students, about half of them part-time; the average age at General Studies is 28. Many General Studies students come from community colleges, so the school provides intensive advising and tutoring. General Studies students have some of their own core courses; otherwise they attend classes side by side with Columbia College students.
"This isn't new to us," said Peter J. Awn, dean of general studies, who noted that the school also runs another program for economically disadvantaged students. "The greatest challenge is really admissions, to say the potential is really here to measure up to the same demands that every other college student is asked to meet. We are on the mark 90 to 95 percent of the time." He said that the four Hostos graduates already in the Serrano program at Columbia were doing well. 
Luz Maria Lambert, a self-assured Dominican immigrant in her late 30's, is one of them; she graduated from Hostos in 1999 and was president of the student government there.
Ms. Lambert said she had found many differences between Hostos and Columbia. The Columbia student body, she said, is both more diversified -- two-thirds of Hostos students are of Hispanic descent -- and less of a community. Educationally, she said, Columbia courses are tougher and students are expected to be more self-sufficient. 
"At Hostos you were taken by the hand," she said. "At Columbia, if you need information, don't ask a teacher. They will say: 'That's a good question. Now go find the answer.' "
She said that professors sometimes make references that she misses. In one class, when a teacher referred to inductive and deductive reasoning, she hesitated to ask what it meant, because everyone else seemed to understand. She asked later.
For the most part, she jumps in. 
"It's a lot more demanding here," she said, "especially for a non-native English speaker. We are competing with the best students from top high schools. They have been trained for life and we really have to grow."

PERSON: Marvin E. Frankel 

HEADLINE: Marvin Frankel, Federal Judge and Pioneer of Sentencing Guidelines, Dies at 81 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Marvin E. Frankel, an outspoken litigator, judge and legal scholar whose views helped to establish sentencing guidelines for the federal courts, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81. 
 The cause was prostate cancer, his daughter Mara said. 
 In a career of more than 50 years Judge Frankel, a former member of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, made his mark as a widely traveled campaigner for human rights and as an advocate before the Supreme Court. He was instrumental in drafting the brief for The New York Times in the landmark First Amendment case, Times v. Sullivan, which set sharp limits on libel suits brought by public figures. His final appearance before the high court was last month. 
While on the bench, he wrote "Criminal Sentences, Law Without Order" with Gary Naftalis, a book that argued that judges seemed to mete out sentences with more caprice than rules. He once called federal sentencing "a nonsystem in which every judge is a law unto himself or herself and the sentence a defendant gets depends on the judge he or she gets."
The book provided the intellectual impetus for federal sentencing guidelines, which, despite their many detractors, sought to bring order to the highly subjective sentencing process. 
In all, he wrote five books and more than 40 major articles, and there, too, he did not pull punches. 
In 1973, when President Nixon accused judges of being soft-headed and called for harsher sentences, Judge Frankel wrote: "With all deference to the top Federal officer, his theories on reducing crime are open to serious question and his strictures against softness in judges are without basis in hard fact. His proposals for severity are neither new nor useful, but only invite us to official cruelties unlikely to accomplish anything beneficial."
Marvin Earle Frankel was born on July 26, 1920, in New York City. His father, Charles, was a salesman, and his mother, the former Anne Brody, was a beautician. He grew up in Newark and graduated at 16 from Weequahic High School, made famous by Philip Roth.
He set off into the world on his own and soon joined the Civilian Conservation Corps, working in Lake Placid's zero-degree cold in the winter and in Las Vegas's 100-degree heat in the summer.
He returned to the East Coast and began studying economics at Queens College. To pay for his schooling, he drove taxis and ice cream trucks and pushed clothes racks in the garment district of Manhattan.
With World War II raging, he joined the Army in 1942 -- his Queens College diploma did not arrive until the following year. A badly damaged knee forced him to leave Officers Training School, but he rose to staff sergeant and spent much of the war doing supply work in Accra in West Africa.
In 1945, he married Betty Streich. They were divorced in 1965, and that year he married the former Alice Kross, chief psychiatrist of child development of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. She survives him, as does a daughter from his first marriage, Eleanor Perlman, of East Northport, N.Y., a daughter from his second marriage, Mara Wallace, of Palo Alto, Calif.; two stepchildren, Ellen Schorr of New York and David K. Schorr of Washington; a sister, Marjorie Frankel, of New York City, and six grandchildren.
After the war he went to Columbia University to study political science, but he switched to the law school. He graduated in two years, in 1948, and was editor in chief of the law review.
The following year, he went to work for the Solicitor General's office in Washington, helping to write briefs and argue cases before the Supreme Court. He argued his first case before the high court in March 1952.
From 1956 to 1962, he was a partner in the New York law firm, Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn. He began teaching at Columbia University Law School in 1962 and it was there that he came to play a major role in the Times v. Sullivan decision, helping the constitutional scholar Herbert Wechsler write a brief that was presented to the Supreme Court.
In March 1960, with sit-ins and civil rights marches spreading across the South, The New York Times ran an advertisement seeking contributions for the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders. The advertisement included several inaccuracies: it incorrectly said, for example, that a student dining hall had been padlocked to starve students into submission.
A jury found the ad libelous, but the Supreme Court, in a unanimous 1964 decision, overruled that decision, saying the press could not satisfy the need for vigorous debate of issues if it had to prove the accuracy of every statement about a public official. Public officials, the court wrote, could win damages only by showing a libelous statement had been made with knowledge that it was false, or reckless disregard of whether it was false or not. 
With the backing of Robert F. Kennedy, he was nominated to the federal bench and took his place in New York's southern district in 1965. As a judge, he presided over a wide range of cases and was known for his penetrating but literary style in his decisions. 
He did not shrink from making controversial rulings. In 1973, he found that the Wood, Wire and Metal Lathers Union had discriminated against members of minority groups so he ordered the union to grant half its new positions to them.
In 1976, he gave a four-month prison sentence to Bernard Bergman, a rabbi who was the central figure in a New York City nursing scandal, a sentence that prosecutors attacked as lenient.
Judge Frankel surprised the legal community in 1978 by returning to private practice, at Proskauer Rose, until 1983. From that year until his death he worked as a partner at Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel, a Manhattan law firm, where he was litigation director for many years.
After leaving the courtroom, he quickly transformed himself into a human rights crusader, becoming chairman of the board of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. He traveled to the Soviet Union and criticized repression of Jews, and to Israel, where he said living conditions for political prisoners were "quite terrible." He went to South Africa to criticize apartheid and to Argentina and Zaire to publicize kidnappings and murders by military regimes.
In 1988, when he went to Kenya to attend an inquest into the death of an opposition leader who had perished in police custody, he was arrested for two days.
"He was a model for people who believe that law should be used as a tool to protect human rights," said Michael Posner, executive director of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. "He embodied everything we stood for so we tried to use him as much as we could."
Twelve days ago, using in a wheelchair because of his cancer, he made a last argument before the Supreme Court, saying that the use of school vouchers in Cleveland was an improper entanglement of church and state. That argument came just days before the 50th anniversary of his first argument before the court.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marvin E. Frankel (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times, 1986)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: COMPENSATION; 
U.S. MAY APPROVE MORE AID FOR KIN OF SEPT. 11 DEAD

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
After months of criticism from the families of those killed on Sept. 11, the Bush administration is close to a decision on several changes in the Victims Compensation Fund that could result in scores of families' receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars more than the fund's original rules would have allowed.
 The new rules would also open the fund to hundreds of additional rescue workers and World Trade Center employees who were injured in the attack, including those who suffered disabling lung ailments. 
 Administration officials with knowledge of the discussions said several big changes were all but certain to be in the final rules. In the most significant financial adjustment, the amount to spouses and children for noneconomic damages like loss of companionship would go to $100,000 from $50,000.
Some officials in New York and New Jersey have also expressed cautious optimism that the $250,000 payments to cover the pain and suffering of those who died might also be increased, although the final rules do not yet include any such increase. 
The new rules would also reduce various deductions that have the potential of cutting awards by hundreds of thousands of dollars. Social Security death benefits for widows would not be deducted under the revised rules, nor would most workers' compensation benefits to surviving spouses, victim advocates have been told by White House officials.
The draft version of the rules said that only civilians injured within 12 hours of the attack were eligible for the fund, but the final rules contemplated by Kenneth R. Feinberg, the fund's special master, would extend that to 72 hours for those who worked at the World Trade Center and would remove the time limit for the uniformed rescue workers who responded to the attack.
Combined, these changes could add hundreds of millions to the final cost of the fund, previously estimated at $6 billion.
The final rules, scheduled to be released this week, are still subject to last-minute change by the White House and by Mr. Feinberg, who was appointed to oversee the fund by Attorney General John Ashcroft.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Feinberg refused to discuss many of the specifics of the new rules, emphasizing that several crucial details had yet to be decided. But he stressed that new fund rules, some of which were first reported in this week's edition of Newsweek, have been extensively revised or clarified to address as many criticisms as possible from families and their representatives in Congress.
"I want to make it as attractive as possible, and I hope I've done so," he said of the fund. "That is a formidable task when dealing with these families, but I'm trying to make it attractive. That is the goal."
Also under discussion are final rules that would include special protections for the families of illegal immigrants, including written assurances that immigration authorities would not try to penalize their families, according to New York officials who have been monitoring the rules. The original rules had required families to waive their right to sue before filing a claim, but the final rules would let families first obtain a "ballpark" estimate of their award from fund officials before having to make such a decision.
"These proposed modifications are designed primarily with the lower- and middle-income wage earner in mind," Mr. Feinberg said. "I am most concerned in this program with the families at the bottom end."
But the administration and Mr. Feinberg have also made changes to address complaints by powerful interests, from the Association of Trial Lawyers of America to New York politicians, including Gov. George E. Pataki, and the state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer.
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Spitzer objected to a proposed rule that would have given families only two hours to present their cases to Mr. Feinberg's hearing officers. That language has been struck, according to several people who have spoken to Mr. Feinberg. The new rules will give families whatever time they need.
Likewise, Leo V. Boyle, president of the trial lawyers group, expressed concerns that the draft rules improperly limited Mr. Feinberg's authority to make awards as he deemed appropriate. The new rules make clear Mr. Feinberg's discretion in several areas, Congressional staff members said. 
"There has been a willing and open ear from both the administration and Feinberg to the concerns of both the victims and those who argue their case," said Senator Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey.
The Victims Compensation Fund was established in September as part of emergency legislation to bail out the airline industry. The fund covers families of those who died, and anyone physically injured by the attacks. Those who file claims with the fund are guaranteed payment for their economic and noneconomic losses within 120 days of their formal filing. But they must also waive their right to file lawsuits against the airlines and other potential defendants.
The law gave Mr. Feinberg enormous power over families affected by the disaster. There are no appeals from his awards, and he has broad authority to interpret the regulations. In December, when Mr. Feinberg announced draft rules for the fund, he estimated that, on average, families of those who died would receive awards of $1.6 million, although he cautioned that the law also required him to deduct life insurance and government benefits. 
Families and the leaders of victims' groups heaped criticism on the proposed rules, and have since campaigned for dozens of changes by staging protest rallies, meeting with members of Congress and bombarding Mr. Feinberg and the Justice Department with proposed revisions. But by far, their most vehement objections have focused on a single provision: the proposed awards for noneconomic losses, which they have called insulting and degrading.
In meeting after meeting, Mr. Feinberg has steadfastly defended his proposed noneconomic awards, $250,000 per death with an additional $50,000 for each spouse and each dependent. He said he was open to compromise on a host of other fund rules, but he said that the noneconomic awards were unlikely to change.
But in discussions with victims' groups and leaders from New York and New Jersey, Mr. Feinberg and White House officials have signaled they are preparing to double the $50,000 payments. For a mother of two children, that change would increase her family's overall award for noneconomic losses by $150,000, to a total of $550,000.
Mr. Corzine said that based on his recent conversations with the White House he was hopeful that the proposed $250,000 award would be increased, perhaps substantially.
By some calculations, the combination of higher noneconomic awards and reduced deductions could result in average awards as much as $200,000 higher than those previously projected.
Yesterday afternoon, in a meeting with 50 or so victims and relatives, Mr. Feinberg described several revisions that would greatly expand the number of injured people eligible for awards. 
Under the draft rules, a person had to have been injured within 12 hours of the attacks and treated by a doctor within 24 hours. Rescue and recovery workers were covered if their injury was sustained within 96 hours of the attacks. In any event, victims had to have "contemporaneous" medical records documenting the injury.
But the final rules, Mr. Feinberg said, increase the limit for civilians to 72 hours from 12 hours. The 96-hour limit for rescue workers would be eliminated altogether. Even those rescue workers who waited weeks to seek medical care would be eligible, so long as their injury resulted in a disability. What's more, he said, the final rules would eliminate the requirement for contemporaneous medical records. 
"If you didn't get a record right away, that's O.K. as long as you eventually got the record," he said. The audience applauded enthusiastically.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Companies try a new approach and a smaller screen for product placements: video games.

BYLINE:  By Karen J. Bannan 

 BODY:
AS anyone who bought Reese's Pieces after watching "ET" knows, product placement can be an effective marketing tool. Fast forward 20 years as the concept has moved to video games.
 Enter Quiksilver, a niche clothing manufacturer, whose intended customers are extreme-sport participants, teenagers and young adults who want to look like the skateboarders and snowboarders who snap up the company's board shorts and sunglasses. 
 The company advertised its wares by sponsoring and dressing popular extreme sports athletes. But then last fall, Quiksilver broadened its marketing by putting its shirts and shorts into several top-selling video games, produced by Activision Inc. 
Today, even though Quiksilver items are not sold at mass merchants like Wal-Mart and Target, it uses those stores as a way to get its message out, says Taylor Whisenand, the company's director for marketing. When teenagers and young adults buy games like Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 at Target, they are also buying a virtual catalog of Quiksilver's clothing and accessories.
"The alignment with Activision enables us to get into the core shops," Mr. Whisenand said. "Most gamers go to Wal-Mart, and now we're there, too."
Quiksilver, which is based in Huntington Beach, Calif., joins a growing list of companies including PepsiCo, DaimlerChrysler and Nokia that are using video game product placement and advertising as a way to increase brand awareness.
And with revenue of video games closing in on yearly domestic movie box-office receipts -- video game software sales reached $6 billion last year while movie tickets topped the $8.4 billion mark, according to the market research firm NPD -- the list of advertisers is only expected to grow.
According to Forrester Research, video game product placements will generate $705 million by 2005, money that can ease the cost of video game development.
Today, the bulk of video game advertising involves bartered product placements like the Activision deal with Quiksilver. Under the agreement, Quiksilver's products including T-shirts and board shorts are placed within Activision's Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 and Kelly Slater's Pro Surfer games.
In return, Activision can distribute its games in Quiksilver retail stores. Buyers can play Activision games on a kiosk and buy the games if they like.
Paid product placements are also catching on, changing the way advertisers do business. In contrast to newspapers, radio or television, with video games there is no quantitative way of finding out how many eyeballs are looking. Advertisers and publishers can base rates on unit sales projections, but since most video games are used in group situations and some video games have longer shelf lives than others, it is not always practical. This creates the need for a new advertising pricing structure, said Beth Larson, vice president for advertising sales for Electronic Arts, the game developer based in Redwood City, Calif. 
"We've gone to marketers and said, 'Help us figure out how to define the impressions and how we can do the auditing.' " Ms. Larson said.
"We've done quite a bit of research about how many players touch the games and how many hours each game is played," Ms. Larson added. Electronic Arts expects to earn $1 million in product placements this year alone, she said.
Ads can be as basic as a billboard or banner that appears during the game and as complex as sponsored hidden levels that users can only reach by visiting an advertiser's Web site.
When video game consoles gain online connectivity -- something expected to occur later this year -- in-game advertising could include sponsored networked video game tournaments and direct links to online shopping sites, video game developers say.
But unlike movie or television product placements, video game advertising draws the user into becoming part of the entertainment. The difference is pretty clear: instead of just seeing a brand or product, video game players can interact with it, again and again and again.
Take Darkened Skye, due out for Nintendo's GameCube console later this year. The role-playing game has plenty of monsters and fighting, but it also uses Skittles candy from Mars Inc. as a magical catalyst. Given that most games can take several hundred hours to complete, that is a lot of brain candy reaching consumers.
Advertisers and agencies see the value in such deals. 
"It's fantastic," said Jeff Odiorne, founder of the San Francisco-based advertising agency Odiorne, Wilde, Narraway, & Partners. "The reason is, you're not invading their space like a TV commercial or a radio commercial that interrupts something that they are enjoying."
Although there has been no official research on the effectiveness of video game advertising, game developers say their own research shows young users respond to in-game advertising in a positive manner. 
"If a kid breaks through a sheet of glass that's got a Doritos logo on it, they associate that brand with something cool," Ms. Larson said. "Because the end user is interacting with the brand in a fun way, they tend to notice it more."
Indeed, some innovative placements take on lives of their own. For example, Electronic Arts placed an ad for Duff beer -- a fictional brand from "The Simpsons" -- in its baseball game Triple Play 2000. The small ad spurred Web pages and discussions that went on for months.
One executive says such advertising is integral to the video games because it makes them more realistic.
"Endemic brands in action and sports games lend authenticity," said Will Kassoy, senior director of global brand management for Activision's action sports division. "We've found the more games represent the real world, the cooler the game is perceived to be."
Virtual baseball stadiums therefore need billboards behind second base and race cars need sponsor logos on their doors and hoods.
But another executive cautions that video game advertising is only as effective as its presentation.
"It's both an art and a science," said Perrin Kaplan, vice president for corporate affairs for Nintendo of Japan, who is based in Redmond, Wash. "You have to look at how the ad was done and whether or not it's going to stick," she said.
So far, placements in general seem to be sticking. As a result, video game developers say there is no shortage of advertisers looking for placements or in-game ads.
"This is one of the first years we've got major agencies coming to us and asking us if they can place ads in our games," Mr. Kassoy said. "They are finally realizing that games reach a desirable audience."

HEADLINE: Credit Agency Drops Rating On the Debt Of New Jersey 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 4 

 BODY:
Warning that the stock market's sluggish performance was likely to suppress New Jersey's tax revenues for years to come, a major credit rating agency lowered the rating today on more than $14 billion in state bonds.
 The downgrade by Moody's Investors Service came after New Jersey reported that income tax receipts for December and January were $700 million less than expected when the budget was adopted last summer. 
 In announcing the move, analysts commended Gov. James E. McGreevey for his plan to balance this year's budget by imposing across-the-board spending cuts and by using surpluses in several pension and health care accounts. But New Jersey faces a projected shortfall of more than $5 billion for the fiscal year that begins on July 1, and with the stock market showing few signs of a sustained rally, financial analysts said the state must take more drastic steps to address longer-term deficits. 
Timothy Blake, a municipal analyst for Moody's, said that New Jersey's budget was heavily dependent on income taxes paid by people whose earnings come from stock dividends or profits or who work on Wall Street and receive large bonuses tied to the stock market's performance.
"We don't think the kind of revenue we saw in the 90's will be seen for another four or five years," Mr. Blake said. "The whole economic environment has changed, and the state's whole spending plan needs to be adjusted to reflect that sizable, fundamental shift."
Mr. McGreevey, who has been warning about the budget problems since he won election last fall, said the downgrade underscored the need for New Jersey's state and local officials to drastically curtail spending. Mr. McGreevey is scheduled to offer his budget proposal on March 26, and he has already warned local communities and school boards that they will not receive the increases in state aid they were expecting.
Moody's downgraded $3.5 billion of the state's general obligation bonds from Aa1 to Aa2, its third-highest rating. The agency also reduced the rating on $7.2 billion of state lease and appropriation-backed debt to Aa3, from Aa2, and $4.1 billion of lease and appropriation-backed debt to A1, from Aa3.
Mr. Blake said that New Jersey's bond rating was still higher than that of 34 other states because of the state's high per capita income and diverse economy. But he said that financial analysts were concerned because the state had increased its debt significantly during the past decade and had committed itself to expensive long-term projects to rebuild its schools and roads.
Mr. McGreevey has also pledged not to raise taxes, eliminating one possible remedy for the deficit, and even with his effort to hold down spending, the state is expecting increased costs for health care, education, transportation, pensions and interest on outstanding debts.
The downgrading of New Jersey's bonds could also aggravate the budget problem by increasing the cost of borrowing. In addition to its existing debt, the McGreevey administration is hoping to raise as much as $2 billion next fiscal year by borrowing against its $7 billion share of the settlement with tobacco companies.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Software: Aether ToCut 25% Of Work Force 

BYLINE:  The New York Times (Compiled by Gary Bradford) 

 BODY:
 Aether Systems, which develops software and wireless data products and services, said it would cut about 225 jobs, or about 25 percent of its work force, because of the economic downturn and a slower adoption of wireless data technologies than the company expected. 
Aether said it would cut expenses, consolidate sites and streamline its European venture, Sila Communications, in an effort to cut operating costs and become profitable. The company, in Owings Mills, Md., said it would take a charge of about $11 million in the first quarter for the revamping. Aether said operating expenses would decrease throughout the year, from about $40 million in the first quarter to roughly $20 million for the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: For Executives, Nest Egg Is Wrapped in a Security Blanket 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
General Electric allows its top executives to contribute money to a retirement fund on which the company recently guaranteed an annual return of at least 10 percent, far better than a typical G.E. worker saving money in the company's 401(k) plan can expect.
 Tenneco Automotive, which makes shock absorbers, permits its executives to receive a full pension at age 55, seven years before the company's other employees can. 
 When Louis V. Gerstner retired as I.B.M.'s chief executive last week, he became eligible for an annual pension of at least $1.1 million, precisely what the company promised in his contract when he joined eight years ago. As part of a 1999 cost-cutting program, however, many I.B.M. employees are set to receive smaller pensions and retirement health insurance benefits than they were promised when they were hired.
Such contrasts have become the norm over the last two decades, as the United States has increasingly developed a two-tier pension system. Companies seeking to increase profits have cut retirement benefits, leaving many members of the baby boom generation unprepared for life after age 65 despite the long bull market, economists say. 
But executives have persuaded their directors to reward them with ever-larger pay packages. On top of millions in salary, bonus and stock options, many top managers have received pensions that are more generous than they once were and are often devoid of the risk inherent in the typical 401(k) plans that have replaced the old company pension for many workers.
Some companies give their executives large annual payments and guaranteed investment returns. Others, including Bank of America and Estee Lauder, pay the premiums on life insurance policies for executives, allowing them, or their heirs, to collect cash payments decades after retirement. Delta Air Lines and the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, as well as other companies give executives credit for many more years of service than they actually have, increasing their pensions.
In recent weeks, policy makers have focused attention on the plight of workers at Enron and Global Crossing, who had invested most of their retirement savings in company stock that is now almost worthless. Many executives escaped in much better shape, having received multimillion-dollar payments or sold many shares before the companies filed for bankruptcy and their share prices plummeted.
Far more common, however, are the diverging of fortunes at healthy companies like G.E. and I.B.M. From 1983 to 1998, the last year for which the government has published data, the amount of retirement money held by the typical household with people from age 47 to 64 fell 11 percent after being adjusted for inflation, according to a recent study by Prof. Edward N. Wolff, an economist at New York University. That number includes private pensions and the value of anticipated Social Security benefits.
The decline occurred as many companies replaced traditional pensions, which pay a predetermined annual benefit, with voluntary savings programs like the 401(k). While higher-income workers were able to save a significant part of their salaries and benefit from the stock market's run-up, many other workers found it hard to set aside money for retirement. At the same time, companies were cutting their retirement contributions as they switched to 401(k) programs.
Expected Social Security benefits have also declined since the early 1980's because inflation-adjusted earnings have fallen for most workers. 
"A lot of families are going to have to work more years to build up their pension accounts and generate enough income for retirement," Professor Wolff said. "It's basically a decrease in living standards."
Executives, meanwhile, have sweetened their pensions, ensuring that the plans will be generous even if the company's stock, or the market as a whole, is suffering, pay consultants say. 
Judith Fischer, managing director of Executive Compensation Advisory Services, said, "In the early 90's, when risk reared its ugly head" and a recession brought down many share prices, "executives went back to their companies and said, 'Look, let's add a little something extra to abate the risk.' "
As a result, Ms. Fischer added, "Executive retirement plans and employee retirement plans are really no longer recognizable as related."
There are no broad statistics on executive retirement programs, in part because companies are not required to publish many of the details. While companies must report the salary, bonus and stock award for each of the top five executives, they can lump together pension liabilities without specifying how much is owed to executives and how much is owed to other employees.
The boom in executive pensions began in the 1980's, after the federal government enacted a law limiting the amount of an employee's salary that a company can consider when contributing to pension coffers. Executives quickly flipped the purpose of the law by establishing separate retirement plans for themselves, divorcing their financial interests from company pensions.
In many cases, executive pensions give benefits that are far more generous than rank-and-file workers receive, even after the differences in salaries are taken into account. Bank One adopted a plan in 1998 that pays top executives up to 60 percent of the average of the final five years of their salary, according to a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Tenneco, in calculating pensions, multiplies its employees' compensation by the number of years they have worked at the company. Top executives receive up to 4 percent of this sum annually; other employees receive up to 1.6 percent.
Fewer than one-fifth of all workers in the United States have a traditional defined-benefit pension, said Annika Sunden, an economist at the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College. The typical private pension pays about $6,000 a year.
At some companies, including the Interpublic Group, an advertising agency, and Mattel, the toymaker, executives can begin receiving a full pension at age 60. 
According to the original contract for Mr. Gerstner, who is 60, his pension will be at least $1.1 million a year. The company will announce any additional benefits in a filing later this year, an I.B.M. spokesman, Rob Wilson, said.
That has angered some of I.B.M.'s 319,000 employees, many of whom lost benefits in 1999 when the company changed its pension program.
"It's just horrible that these companies are getting away with this," said Lynda P. French, a 57-year-old former I.B.M. software analyst in Austin, Tex., who used the Internet to organize employee opposition to the pension changes. "These C.E.O.'s are escalating their golden parachutes while they're cutting from the workers."
Ms. French said that I.B.M. had recently raised her health care premiums and that when her husband retires from the company, their health care benefits would be less generous than those received by previous generations of retirees.
Phil Nigh, a 41-year-old engineer in Essex Junction, Vt., who has worked for I.B.M. since 1983, said his pension would probably be 25 percent to 40 percent lower than it would have been before the company changed the plan.
"In my opinion, people lost a lot of trust in executive decisions" after the change, Mr. Nigh said. "They assumed I.B.M. would live up to its promises, and this kind of woke everybody up."
Mr. Wilson, the I.B.M. spokesman, said Mr. Gerstner's pension was not affected by the 1999 change because it was part of the contract between him and the company. "They are two separate things," Mr. Wilson said, referring to Mr. Gerstner's pension and that of other employees.
Since Enron's collapse, both Republican and Democratic lawmakers have said that some pension rules should be changed to prevent bankruptcy filings from hurting only lower-level employees. But the most prominent proposals, including President Bush's, would not alter basic rules covering executive pensions.
Pay consultants say the issue is often difficult to understand because many benefits are not made public, and those that are disclosed can be complicated. 
One common perk is a life insurance policy on which a company pays the premiums. Executives can cash out of the policy while they are still alive or the benefits will be paid to heirs. Before the insurance company pays the benefits, it subtracts the combined amount of the premiums and pays this amount to the company -- minus any interest.
"It's like the company is making an interest-free loan," said David M. Leach, the director of the compensation practice at Buck Consultants in New York. "It's losing the use of its money."
Many other executive benefits remain hidden from investors and employees because the S.E.C. does not require that all plans be fully explained.
"These are obligations that companies have that they are not disclosing to shareholders," said Carol Bowie, a director at the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington. "With executives, you're dealing with a group of people who have very few controls on what they can do."

HEADLINE: Bush Edging Toward Decision on Steel Imports 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4 

 BODY:
The White House edged toward a final decision today to impose tariffs on imported steel, as President Bush weighed recommendations from his advisers and last-minute pleas from an array of competing interests.
 Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Bush intended to make his decision by Wednesday but had not yet signed off on all the elements of a plan. Administration officials have signaled that Mr. Bush is leaning toward a combination of tariffs and quotas that would vary with the specific type of steel involved and that would probably exempt some developing nations as well as Mexico and Canada. "It's not a settled matter at this time," Mr. Fleischer said. 
 People involved in the debate over how far the United States should go in protecting the industry -- and the jobs it provides in political battleground states like West Virginia, Pennsylvania and Ohio -- said the issue's complexity was underscored for Mr. Bush last week when Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain raised it with him in a phone call.
Mr. Blair, who has made Britain perhaps the staunchest ally of the United States in the war on terrorism, suggested to Mr. Bush that restricting imports would not be the right response to the problems facing the steel industry in the United States, people who have been briefed on the discussion said.
Today, the British Trade Secretary, Patricia Hewitt, said Britain would support trade retaliation by the European Union if the United States imposed tariffs on steel. 
Trade officials on both sides of the Atlantic -- as well as those in China and Russia -- are already bracing for a knockdown fight over steel, one that they are concerned could slow the already halting progress toward a new round of world trade liberalization talks.
But the most immediate calculations facing Mr. Bush are domestic.
Having floated the outlines of its approach recently, the administration heard today from steel makers, unions, users of steel and other groups with an interest in the outcome. The general message was that any effort to find a middle ground would leave all sides unhappy.
Mr. Fleischer acknowledged as much, likening the issue to a Rubik's Cube, where any move to help one side causes problems with another. "The president understands how very many sides there are on this issue," he said.
The nation's remaining big steel makers, which have seen their ranks mowed down by a succession of bankruptcies, are pushing the administration to impose tariffs of up to 40 percent on most types of steel imports from all over the world. 
The big companies, led by U.S. Steel, say a period of protection from what they consider unfair foreign competition would allow them to regroup, consolidate and invest in more efficient equipment that would enable them to survive. Without the help, they say, most of the industry will wither away, along with tens of thousands of jobs.
Users of steel, however, say that steep tariffs and the ensuing rise in steel prices would drive up their costs, leading to job losses across a wide swath of industry.
Representatives of the big steel companies said the administration would be making a mistake if it exempted developing countries from the tariffs and allowed some portion of the steel from other countries to come in free of tariffs. They said the practical effect of such a compromise would be to set tariff levels so low that they would be ineffectual.
If developing nations are exempted and if a portion of the unfinished slab steel coming into the United States is not subject to the tariffs, the domestic industry "would get close to no relief," said Robert Lighthizer, a Washington trade lawyer who represents U.S. Steel and some of the other steel makers.
Leo Gerard, president of the steel workers' union, said exemption of developing countries would have to be accompanied by a strict program to guard against a surge of imports from them and to keep developed countries from evading the tariffs by shipping their steel through the developing nations.
But representatives of groups lobbying the administration not to impose heavy tariffs said the compromise floated by the White House would still extract much too heavy a price from the economy.

HEADLINE: Pataki Avoids Vow to Serve Full 3rd Term If Re-elected 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 4 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki, who has at times entertained thoughts of a run for national office, today would not commit to serving a full four-year term if he is re-elected this year.
 The governor, speaking at a news conference in the State Capitol, sought to quell reports that he might find a new running mate to replace Lt. Gov. Mary O. Donohue, who would become governor if he were to leave office early. 
 But when asked if he would promise to serve out a third term, he said: "Let's take things step by step. And the next political decision is to announce that we're running. Beyond that, we'll make those determinations when we get to them."
He offered a similar caveat minutes earlier when asked about Ms. Donohue's status, but followed it with a far more definitive reply. "If I do" run, he said, "I fully expect that Mary Donohue would be the running mate."
Whenever the subject of his political plans is raised, Mr. Pataki insists that he has not definitively decided to run again, and suggests that any discussion of his future is premature. Yet he routinely concedes that he is likely to seek re-election -- "I expect that I will," he said today. His allies say it is a foregone conclusion, and he acts every bit the candidate, raising money at a daunting clip and making alliances with various political figures and interest groups.
Mr. Pataki tested the presidential waters in 1999 with a brief foray to New Hampshire and speeches in nationally prominent forums. A year later, his advisers said, he hoped George W. Bush would offer him the vice-presidential nomination. And people close to the governor say he would like to be considered for such an offer again in 2004, if Vice President Dick Cheney does not run.
His Democratic critics jumped at Mr. Pataki's evasion today, accusing him of looking past New York to Washington at a time when his state is battered by financial trouble. Both Democratic candidates for governor, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo, the former United States housing secretary, have vowed to serve a full term if elected.
"He's creating budget problems for New York, and he refuses to commit to be here to clean up the mess he's creating," Hank Sheinkopf, Mr. McCall's chief strategist, said of Mr. Pataki.
The news about the state budget got worse today, as the governor's office reported that state revenues for January and February were $500 million below even the pessimistic estimates it made in mid-January. That is in addition to an estimated $7 billion shortfall over 18 months caused by the recession and the World Trade Center attack. "We still have a real financial crisis," Mr. Pataki said.
Josh Isay, Mr. Cuomo's campaign manager, dismissed any talk of Mr. Pataki on the national ticket as "a joke."
"Sixty percent of eighth graders read below grade level, upstate New York has the slowest job growth in the nation, and we have the highest state and local tax burden in the country," he said.
It is not clear that Mr. Pataki would be hurt politically by a continued refusal to pledge to serve his entire term. He declined to make such a promise in 1998, yet won re-election handily. He has said he does not feel bound by his 1994 promise to serve no more than two terms, yet remains highly popular.
Mr. Cuomo's father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, also declined to promise to serve out his terms and was widely expected to run for president, yet he easily won re-election in 1986 and 1990. In fact, since the 19th century, New Yorkers have taken for granted the idea that their governors are White House contenders, and many voters like it that way.
Democrats said the danger to the governor might lie not in his national aspirations but in the possibility that by refusing to promise to serve his entire term, Mr. Pataki is reinforcing the perception -- avidly fed by those same Democrats -- that he has lost interest in the job. Mr. Sheinkopf drew a parallel to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, who resigned in 1973 with a year left on his term, departing just as a fiscal crisis was about to envelop New York.
Mr. Pataki dropped his first lieutenant governor, Betsy McCaughey Ross, from the ticket in 1998, and several published reports have had him and his advisers weighing doing the same to Ms. Donohue, and considering various replacements.
But Ms. Donohue, a former prosecutor and judge, has kept a low profile and has not embarrassed Mr. Pataki with the kind of public disagreements and odd behavior Ms. McCaughey Ross became known for. The governor's aides have insisted all along that Ms. Donohue was not going anywhere.

HEADLINE: Playing Politics With Trade 

 BODY:
Many corporate chieftains around the country must be scratching their heads in amazement, wondering why they worked so hard to elect a market-loving, free-trading Republican administration. Democrats are supposed to be the ones who pander to labor unions. Yet it is President Bush who is considering the ill-advised move of slapping tariffs on steel imports, one that his Democratic predecessor responsibly resisted. 
 Any such tariffs, essentially a new tax on a broad array of manufactured goods, will hurt the American economy as it struggles to rebound. The move would cost far more jobs at companies that consume steel, such as auto parts makers, than those it might save at inefficient steel companies. Moreover, such brazen protectionism could plunge the world into a bruising trade war capable of derailing the administration's ostensible goal of lifting living standards at home and abroad by breaking down barriers through a series of new trade agreements. 
 America's International Trade Commission has ruled, at the administration's behest, that imports have financially hurt the nation's steel producers. It set tomorrow as a deadline for the president to decide on what steps, if any, he will take to protect the industry. On the merits, rejecting the protectionist impulse would seem easy, as the president's top economic advisers have reportedly argued. 
They will probably be overruled, however, by politics. Some scoffed at the Bush campaign's efforts to woo steelworkers during the 2000 campaign, but Mr. Bush ultimately carried traditionally Democratic West Virginia. Without that upset Mr. Bush would still be in Austin, such was his razor-thin margin of victory. He would like to add the rich electoral prize of Pennsylvania to his win column in 2004, and help Republican Congressional candidates from steel-producing states this November. 
Yet in trying to balance the nation's economic and foreign policy concerns against his political interests, Mr. Bush might still damage the former without advancing the latter. He is reportedly going to reject Big Steel's call for a 40 percent across-the-board tariff, settling for a mix of quotas and lower tariffs that vary according to the steel product. Some poorer nations, along with Mexico and Canada, might be exempted.
That may seem like a reasonable compromise to those involved in drafting it, but it is unlikely to satisfy Big Steel. In addition to the 40 percent tariff, the industry wants a $12 billion taxpayer bailout of its troubled companies' lavish retiree pension and health care benefits. The industry says this would free steelmakers to consolidate and become more efficient. Even an administration eager to cater to West Virginia cannot support such a fanciful end run around the nation's bankruptcy laws. The president's rejection of this plea, combined with his embrace of more modest tariffs, is likely to strike those wooed steelworkers as a betrayal.
In truth, steel imports have been drastically declining since the glut caused by the Asian financial crisis. International negotiations are making progress at cutting excess capacity worldwide, and American steel production capacity remains strong. Many steel companies have gone bankrupt in recent years, admittedly, but they are as much the victims of newer, more efficient domestic competitors as of foreign competitors.
A senseless rush to impose tariffs will reinforce suspicions around the world that the United States does not believe its own preaching about the paramount importance of embracing free trade, regardless of whatever transitional pain it inflicts on some economic sectors. European and Asian nations will surely retaliate.

HEADLINE: Despite Complaining About Pay, Justices Won't Review a Ruling That Blocks Raises 

BYLINE:  By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4 

 BODY:
After years of complaining about inadequate pay for federal judges, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist was finally in a position to do something about it when a significant constitutional challenge to the failure by Congress to give judges promised cost-of-living increases reached the court's docket last fall.
 But the chief justice did not act, and as a result the Supreme Court fell one vote short today of accepting the case and of taking the judicial pay question into its own hands. 
 The court let stand a 2001 ruling by a federal appeals court here that Congress did not act unconstitutionally when it blocked raises for judges that would have taken place automatically four times in the last six years.
The appeals court held that the lawmakers had not violated the provision in Article III of the Constitution that guarantees to federal judges "a compensation which shall not be diminished during their continuance in office." 
The three justices who voted to hear the appeal, Stephen G. Breyer, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy, dissented from the denial of review with 14 pages of legal argument and three multicolored graphs showing that federal judges have lost more to inflation than public and private employees in other occupations. The Supreme Court's rules require the votes of four justices to accept a case for review.
"This case is not about what judges' labor should be worth," the three dissenters said in an opinion by Justice Breyer. "It is about a Congressional decision in 1989 to protect federal judges against undue diminishment in real pay by providing cost-of-living adjustments to guarantee that their salaries would not fall too far behind inflation."
While Congress was free to set the level of judicial pay, Justice Breyer said, "the Compensation Clause assures judges that, once Congress has made such a decision, a later Congress cannot overturn it." The Constitution's framers viewed the clause as an essential protection for judicial independence, he said.
The case was brought as a class-action suit by 20 federal judges, led by Spencer Williams, a senior district judge in San Francisco. They argued that in passing the Ethics Reform Act of 1989, Congress had struck a bargain with the judiciary on which it could not constitutionally renege.
The essence of the bargain, which included an immediate one-time 25 percent pay raise to make up for years of frozen judicial salaries, was that judges would give up the right to earn outside income, except for a small amount permitted for teaching. In return, they would join members of Congress and a group of high-level executive branch officials who would get annual cost-of-living raises of up to 5 percent, to be based on the federal index of private-sector salaries.
The raise would be automatic any time the General Schedule of federal civil servants received cost-of-living increases, which were to be annual unless the president declared a national emergency or the existence of "serious economic conditions" under which ordinary federal workers would receive no raises.
For the first several years under the law, the judges, along with members of Congress and top government officials, received their increases.
In the 1994 budget crisis, President Bill Clinton suspended all federal raises. And after the Republicans took control of both houses, Congress passed resolutions blocking the Congressional, judicial and executive raises in 1995, 1996, 1997 and 1999, though ordinary civil servants received their increases. That led to the judges' lawsuit.
The judges won a ruling in July 1999 in federal district court here that the promised cost-of-living adjustments were "part of the judges' compensation due and payable" and could not constitutionally be withheld. A 2-to-1 decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit overturned the ruling on the ground that the closest Supreme Court precedent, a 1980 ruling on judicial pay in the case of United States v. Will, treated judicial pay increases as not "vesting" for constitutional purposes until judges had started receiving the money.
In his dissent today in Williams v. United States, No. 01-175, Justice Breyer said the appeals court decision was based on a questionable interpretation of the Will case that only the Supreme Court could resolve.
Federal judges did receive a 3.4 percent cost-of-living increase on Jan. 1, bringing the salaries of district judges to $150,000. Court of appeals judges now receive $159,100; associate Supreme Court justices, $184,400; and the chief justice, $192,600.
In his annual report on the federal judiciary, issued on Dec. 31, Chief Justice Rehnquist said the judges were "grateful" for the increase, but noted that "it only keeps judges from falling further behind the median income of the profession." He warned that it was becoming harder to recruit and retain qualified judges.
A year earlier, the chief justice said that continuing erosion of judicial pay was "the most pressing issue facing the judiciary," a statement quoted by the American Bar Association in a friend-of-the-court brief urging the justices to accept the judges' appeal.
The Supreme Court had had the appeal under active consideration since November, an unusually long time. While there is no way of knowing why the three dissenters did not pick up a fourth vote from Justice Rehnquist or any of the other five justices, one hint came in Justice Breyer's reference to concerns that "we face the serious embarrassment of deciding a matter that would directly affect our own pocketbooks." 
But reflecting what must have been the behind-the-scenes argument, he continued: "Whenever a court considers a matter where public sentiment is strong, it risks public alienation. But the American public has understood the need and the importance of judges deciding important constitutional issues without regard to considerations of popularity."

HEADLINE: Enron Pensions Still Under Old Management 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4 

 BODY:
Despite an agreement three weeks ago to replace the executives who oversee Enron's pension plans with an independent official, the retirement plans are still being supervised by the executives who did little when Enron stock plummeted last year, a senior Democratic lawmaker said today.
 Representative George Miller of California, the ranking minority member on the House Education and Work Force Committee, said he was "deeply troubled" that the executives had not been replaced. 
 Enron's 401(k) retirement plan was heavy with company stock, and employees saw the value of that plan lose more than $1 billion last year when the stock price collapsed. On Feb. 13, Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao announced an agreement to replace the officials with an independent official, paid for by Enron.
"There is convincing evidence that Enron fiduciaries had significant warning of Enron's financial collapse but failed to act to protect employees' retirement savings," Mr. Miller said. "I am deeply troubled that the administration has failed to act to protect the remaining retirement savings at Enron despite its earlier pledge to so."
Labor Department officials said they were working to secure an independent fiduciary who can take over the three pension plans and provide company employees and retirees confidence that their interests will be protected. A spokeswoman for the department said officials were optimistic an announcement would be made soon.

HEADLINE: In Manhattan, A U.N. Dispute On Real Estate (What Else?) 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
It is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's first diplomatic flap.
 This being New York, it is not about the decimation of the Brazilian rain forest, or drought in Africa, but about real estate. 
 In a series of communiques and summit meetings, United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan has expressed his "concerns" about the city's pending contract to sell three office towers at First Avenue and 44th Street that house a variety of United Nations agencies, including Unicef. The United Nations wants the buildings to remain in public hands sympathetic to its mission. 
The deal could bring $50 million into the city's cash-starved coffers and more than $7 million a year in annual taxes once the properties are on the tax rolls. But Mr. Bloomberg, the state and the federal government do not want to alienate the United Nations at a time when all sides are seeking to establish a newly cordial relationship in the aftermath of Sept. 11.
There are issues of public policy at stake, but no tale involving real estate and diplomacy would be complete without some sort of background maneuvering. Some executives involved in the sale wonder whether George Klein, the developer who heads the agency that was supposed to sell the buildings, actually inspired the United Nations' opposition.
Whatever the case, the deal, which was supposed to close by Feb. 6, languishes, despite the city's worsening fiscal condition and a longstanding plan to sell the properties.
"We are continuing discussions with the U.N.," Daniel Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, said yesterday. "We're making progress. The U.N. is a very important part of New York, and we're treating them like a valued partner."
Yesterday afternoon, Toshiyuki Niwa, the assistant secretary general of the United Nations, met with the prospective buyer of the buildings, a New York subsidiary of VSP Capital Holdings of Israel. Mr. Niwa said the United Nations -- in addition to concerns about having a private entity as a landlord -- is also concerned that if the sale is completed, the agency that built the towers, the United Nations Development Corporation, would go out of business and be unable to assist the United Nations in its proposed $1 billion renovation project.
"We expressed our concerns about the ownership transfer," Mr. Niwa said. "We feel the current arrangement should stay in place. "The U.N.D.C. symbolizes the special relationship between the United Nations and the city and state," Mr. Niwa said. "I get the impression there is a difference of opinion within the administration" of Mayor Bloomberg.
The buildings are the only remaining assets of the U.N.D.C., created decades ago by the city and the state to assist the United Nations in developing office space for its agencies. Beginning in the mid-1990's, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki sought to privatize the agency's real estate by selling the buildings.
The first one on the auction block was the United Nations Plaza Hotel, sold in 1997. The deal produced $85 million for the city and an estimated $6 million in annual taxes. The agency later sold office space in the building at 633 Third Ave. for about $52 million, or $5.5 million after the mortgage was paid off. Two small buildings on First Avenue sold for less than $6 million.
A year ago, the U.N.D.C. voted at the urging of Mayor Giuliani and Governor Pataki to sell the three office buildings known as 1, 2 and 3 U.N. Plaza. Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate company, began marketing the buildings. Publicly, everyone was in agreement.
But at the board meetings of the U.N.D.C., Mr. Klein, the developer who has long chaired the agency, clashed with Leo Kayser, a lawyer appointed by Governor Pataki, over privatization, according to several directors at the agency.
"Kayser and George Klein would just go after each other," one former U.N.D.C. director said. "The arguments were about how to do it, never about whether to do it. If George had ever raised the issue of not selling, he would not have been allowed to stay on as chairman."
Mr. Klein, who has told executives that he favors public ownership of the buildings, declined comment, as did Roy Goodman, the U.N.D.C. president appointed by Mr. Bloomberg. Some current and former directors suggested that Mr. Klein did not want to see what one called his "fiefdom" disappear with the sale.
"It's a well-functioning patronage operation," said one former director who had been appointed by Mr. Giuliani. "You put your friends there."
On Oct. 24, Mr. Annan wrote letters to both the city and the state objecting to the sale. The agency went ahead anyway on Dec. 6 and signed a contract to sell the buildings for about $160 million to VSP Capital, which also agreed to put another $12 million on improvements.
But with Mr. Giuliani on his way out of office, the United Nations stepped up its opposition, joined by the United States ambassador to the organization, John Negroponte. Several people involved in the sale suggested that the United Nations had been stirred into action by Mr. Klein.
Mr. Niwa did not say that Mr. Klein had instigated the letters from Mr. Annan. But, Mr. Niwa added, "He certainly welcomed our initiative."
"My feeling all along is that Mr. Klein favored the status quo," he said. "But at the same time, a sales contract was signed. The letters were a last ditch effort to remind the city and the state about how we feel."
Mr. Doctoroff acknowledged that Mr. Klein had been raising questions about the sale after having voted in favor of it. "But he's backed off that," Mr. Doctoroff said.
Mr. Doctoroff said he is now trying to correct some misconceptions about the deal and understand it economically. "We are sensitive to the issues and concerns of the U.N.," he said.

HEADLINE: Australia Is Riding Its Own Cycle 

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, March 3 

 BODY:
What global slowdown?
 Almost alone among modern economies, Australia sailed unscathed through 2001 and will probably grow steadily for the rest of 2002, according to the central bank, market economists and the latest statistics. 
 Bullishness is everywhere. A new survey of the spending plans of Australian companies found that in aggregate they intended to invest 21 percent more in the coming fiscal year, which begins on July 1, than they planned to spend in the current year when surveyed in early 2001. That is the biggest jump in a decade. 
More jobs were created in January than in any other month in the last decade. The stock market is near its high. The economy is growing at a robust pace of nearly 4 percent a year. Inflation is low to moderate. 
"The economy has held up quite well in the face of international weakness, and it should continue to do so for some time at least," said Glenn Stevens, deputy governor of Australia's central bank.
That Australia is bucking the global trend is all the more remarkable given the country's dependence on exports of commodities and raw materials. In the past, that situation has made Australia acutely sensitive to the economic health of its trading partners. 
"In past periods of global downturn, Australia has rarely outperformed the major countries," Mr. Stevens said. "Historically, our tendency was to have a period of weakness that was, if anything, more pronounced."
Australia's exports have indeed been affected by the slowdown elsewhere, remaining flat last year after growth rates as high as 25 percent in earlier years. 
But this time around, both household and business investment remained steady, and company profits held up as exports slowed. That has lifted the stock market here while other countries' exchanges suffered retreats of 20 to 30 percent from the levels of early 2000.
"In Australia, signs of increased confidence in financial markets have, in many respects, been more pronounced than in other countries," the central bank said in a recent statement.
Much of the credit for the country's continued vibrancy goes, economists say, to the weakness of the Australian dollar. Its value has hovered around 48 American cents for more than a year, near the cheapest it has ever been.
The cheap currency "has been a competitive advantage for Australia," said Tony Meer, a senior economist at Deutsche Bank. 
Most of the country's commodity exports, like copper and gold, are priced and sold in American dollars, but producers pay most of their costs in Australian dollars, so the exchange-rate trend has swelled their profits.
"Revenue has been good, which underpins profit, which underpins investment," Mark Rider, chief economist at UBS Warburg in Sydney, said of the country's mining industry, one of its most important sectors.
But business investment has not run amok, a common problem in boom times.
As a portion of gross domestic product, spending on new plants and equipment remains well below peak levels of the 1990's; it has helped sustain the economy but has not sent it into overdrive, economists say.
For consumers, the weaker currency made imports expensive, but consumers switched to buying domestic goods rather than cutting back, another boon for the economy. "Household spending has continued to grow at a solid pace," the central bank said.
Another factor has been the timing of a federal election. Critics worried that politically motivated tax cuts and extra spending approved by Prime Minister John Howard in the months leading up to voting would overstimulate the economy.
The measures undoubtedly won votes for Mr. Howard, now in his third term, though they drained away a government budget surplus. But as it happened, Mr. Meer said, "the election pork-barreling that we had turned out to be quite fortuitous," giving Australia a small boost just as much of the global economy was braking after the terror attacks of Sept. 11.
The Australian central bank also relaxed interest rates six times in 2001, after moves by the Federal Reserve and others.
But one of the biggest factors pushing the Australian economy has been a housing boom, caused in part by a program of sizable grants to first-time buyers. The program will soon expire, but the extra construction activity and jobs it created should persist for another six months or so, economists said.
Overall strength in the real estate market has bred consumer confidence and higher investment.
Average home prices in Australia are high relative to average household incomes, and two-thirds of Australians' personal wealth is in their homes.
In the United States, the average homeowner has net home equity equivalent to about 1.5 years of disposable income; the Australian average is more than 3.5 years, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia.
Unlike Americans, Australians have not borrowed to the hilt. "Household and corporate balance sheets are, by and large, in pretty good shape," Mr. Stevens said.
Even consumer prices, usually the No. 1 worry in boom times, are tame here. Inflation is expected to taper off from its current 3.1 percent pace to around 2.5 percent for the full year, according to the central bank. Economists expect rapidly rising productivity to offset rises in labor costs.
There are still signs of risk on the edges of the central bank's monitor, however, notably in the direction of Japan, and it is hard to forecast when or how the rest of the world will recover from the present slowdown.
"No economy can remain insulated from global problems indefinitely," Mr. Stevens said.
Even so, robust optimism can be detected filtering through the subdued and qualified central banker's language Mr. Stevens generally uses. If recent positive signs in the United States and elsewhere gather momentum, he allowed, "Australia's prospects are pretty good."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Because Australia is highly dependent on commodity exports, its growth in a global slowdown is all the more unusual. A truck with a payload of 226 tons is ready for work at a gold mine about 300 miles east of Perth. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Egypt Hopes for Free Trade Pact With U.S. 

BYLINE:  By ABEER ALLAM 

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 5 

 BODY:
As President Hosni Mubarak visits Washington this week, high on his agenda is getting substantial talks started on a free trade agreement with the United States -- an idea that seemed far off before Sept. 11.
 Egypt's economy has taken a beating since last year's terror attacks, mainly from the sharp falloff in international tourism. Egypt says it needs help to build up trade with the United States beyond the fairly modest $4.2 billion in volume recorded last year, especially in clothing and textiles, which are sharply constrained by American import quotas. A sweeping elimination of trade barriers, like the agreements the United States has with Israel and Jordan, is called for, Egyptian officials say. 
 Egypt has wanted such an agreement with the United States for years, but before Sept. 11 Washington rebuffed its approaches, citing a long list of steps that Egypt would have to complete first. Issues like customs delays and red tape, weak protection for copyrights and trademarks, tax complications, the glacial pace of privatization and concerns about money laundering would have to be settled, Cairo was told. 
But when the Egyptian trade minister, Youssef Boutros Ghali, visited Washington last fall before the World Trade Organization's November conference in Qatar, he got a much warmer response. The State Department said after the visit that the United States "would boost efforts to help as Egypt struggles to cope with a decline in tourism due to terrorism fears," and that "one method of assistance is a United States-Egypt free trade agreement." 
After growing steadily through most of the 1990's, Egypt has suffered setbacks over the last three years. The Egyptian pound sank in value despite the government's expensive efforts to shore it up; it declined 20 percent last year, to 4.55 to the dollar. Some 55 state-owned companies were due to be privatized in 2001, but only a few were actually sold. Those factors contributed to a sharp fall in foreign investment, to $333 million in 2001 from $2 billion the year before; so did investors' persistent complaints of excessive bureaucracy and lack of transparency, despite efforts at reform.
Just as Egypt's economy was slowing, American financial aid began to contract, in tandem with aid to Israel, to free up money for Jordan and other new partners in the region. In 1997, Vice President Al Gore promised a concerted effort to redirect the Egyptian-American relationship "from aid to trade." 
Washington promoted a plan to extend the duty-free access granted under Israel's free trade agreement to include some products manufactured in designated industrial zones in Egypt, Jordan and territory administered by the Palestinian Authority. But when the peace process fell apart and Arab-Israeli tensions rose, Egypt said it could not make use of the special zones, known as Q.I.Z.'s.
"Given what Israel is doing now, I don't think Q.I.Z.'s are an option," Mr. Boutros Ghali said in an interview with the Oxford Business Group this month.
The United States is Egypt's biggest single trading partner, and, by value, America exports three times the amount to Egypt that it imports. American exporters stand to lose market share in Egypt without a free trade agreement, Cairo officials say, because of a new deal with the European Union to lower tariffs gradually over 12 years. 
"With a free trade agreement, both sides gain," said Ahmed Galal, managing director of the Egyptian Center for Economic Studies. "Without it, the United States will lose out, especially in information technology, telecommunications and e-commerce, while European investors will come to Egypt to export duty free to the E.U."
But the odds remain long, American officials say, and Egypt is not yet in shape to reap the full benefit of a trade deal. 
"The United States has very few free trade agreements, and getting in the queue to have one is a challenge," one United States official in Cairo said. "Countries who want to do this need the political stamina to make major changes, but the payoffs are enormous."
