HEADLINE: Angry Europeans to Challenge U.S. Steel Tariffs at W.T.O. 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 5 

 BODY:
Steel producers from around the world angrily denounced President Bush's decision today to impose protective tariffs on imported steel and vowed to fight the plan at the World Trade Organization.
 More ominously for the Bush administration, many trade experts said today that the United States was on shaky legal ground. Over the last two years, the United States has lost at least three smaller cases in which it tried to restrict imports on the same legal principle cited in the steel case today. 
 In Europe, steel executives and trade experts say the justification for import restrictions is particularly weak because American steel imports declined substantially last year. 
"At first sight, you would have to say the United States will have a very difficult time making the case," said Lode Van Den Hende, a trade lawyer in Brussels with the British law firm of Herbert Smith.
The European Union immediately announced plans to attack any new steel tariffs at the World Trade Organization, which has international authority as a court in such trade disputes.
"The U.S. decision to go down the route of protectionism is a major setback for the world trading system," said Pascal Lamy, the European Commission's top trade official. "Imports are not the cause of U.S. difficulties, and the measures announced today will not only not provide a solution but aggravate matters."
South Korean steel producers complained that the United States was arbitrarily discriminating against them, imposing tariffs on imports from Asia but exempting imports from Mexico and Canada.
In Russia, the foreign ministry summoned the American ambassador in Moscow to warn of the "serious impact on Russian-American relations."
Two weeks ago, Russia's agriculture ministry said it would ban imports of American poultry beginning next week as a result of what it said was salmonella contamination. Russia accounts for about half of all American poultry exports.
Western European steel makers are much less worried about exports to the United States, which are modest, than they are about being swamped with excess steel from Asian and South American producers that can no longer sell in the United States.
"Diminishing exports to the U.S. is one issue, but even more damaging is the fact that everybody else's steel will be coming to us," said Anthony Gooch, a spokesman for the European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union. "That's the real hammer blow for us."
The steel issue is certain to put new strain on relations among the United States and many of its closest allies. European leaders are already unhappy about President Bush's desire to expand the campaign against terrorism to countries like Iraq. 
But the steel issue has a particularly concrete effect on major corporations and jobs, so American tariffs are much more likely to lead to countermeasures than would disputes in other areas.
European leaders say the United States is merely trying to protect an industry that has not adjusted to changes in the world market. "The problem of the U.S. steel industry is not imports," said Guy Dolle, chief executive of Arcelor S.A., in Luxembourg, Europe's biggest steel producer. "The big problem in the United States is the legacy costs of the integrated steel companies," referring to their responsibility for pension and health benefits for retired steel workers.
Mr. Dolle noted that European steel makers had consolidated broadly through mergers the last 10 years. Arcelor itself is the result of the most recent merger of Usinor of France, Arbed of Luxembourg and Aceralia of Spain.
"Nothing like that has happened in the United States," Mr. Dolle said. "The United States has led the consolidation in almost every industry except steel."
In South Korea, industry executives were infuriated that the White House planned to impose stiff new tariffs on imports from Asia but not on producers in Canada and Mexico. "Why does the United States differentiate between nations?" asked Park Nei Hei, an economist on the board of Samsung. "As a Korean, I feel it's unfair."
Legal experts said the United States had to meet a difficult burden of proof if the tariffs were to survive challenge at the W.T.O.
The White House is justifying the new tariffs as a "safeguard" measure to protect its domestic steel industry from a surge in imports. Unlike a more typical antidumping case, the government is not arguing that foreign producers are competing unfairly. Rather, it is arguing that imports are causing serious damage to the industry.
Such actions are allowed under current international trade agreements. But they require showing that imports are the cause of the damage, and the W.T.O. has been very tough in demanding clear evidence.
Just two weeks ago, an appeals board of the organization, based in Geneva, rejected an American plan to impose safeguard tariffs on steel pipe from South Korea. Last year, it rejected two similar cases, one involving cotton yarn from Pakistan and another involving frozen lamb from New Zealand and Australia.
"The American case is pretty weak," said Romano Subiotto, a trade lawyer in Brussels with the law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. "I think the U.S. is going to find it difficult to prove that the imports they are targeting are the reason for the injury to the steel industry."
Mr. Van Den Hende, the lawyer in Brussels, said the case was clouded by the fact that America's big steel makers are groaning under a number of their own problems. The biggest is that they are burdened by huge pension obligations that push their costs far higher than those of the smaller and more nimble minimills.
"You cannot impose safeguards and restrict imports in order to remedy injuries caused by other factors," Mr. Van Den Hende said. "If there is a whole host of other things responsible, then you at least have to make a distinction between the harm that comes from imports and the harm caused by other reasons."
Regardless of whether the United States wins or loses, European steel makers are already pressing political leaders to impose their own "safeguard" measures to protect themselves against a surge of new imports.
European Commission officials estimate that the tariffs would affect about four million tons of European steel exported to the United States. But they predict the American tariffs would divert an additional 16 million tons a year to Europe from other countries.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; 
Grooming a Little Montmartre, Just North of the Bronx

BYLINE:  By EVE M. KAHN 

DATELINE: YONKERS 

 BODY:
JAGON ELDRIDGE, a saxophonist, was spending $550 a month for a 6-by-6-foot cubicle with paper-thin walls on the Upper West Side, his ears assaulted by unruly children next door. Kate Wattson, a painter, was negotiating the end of her marriage from a sun-deprived garden apartment in Brooklyn Heights. John Pavlou, a sculptor, was living over his parents' grocery store, feeling utterly isolated from Manhattan artistic life. 
 Now, lured by ads that promised cheap housing for artists and musicians with sunset views of the Hudson River, all three are neighbors in this city of about 196,000 just north of the Bronx, a place they would hardly have expected to call home. Their small apartments are in the downtown waterfront district, in Philipsburgh Hall, a once decrepit 1905 landmark that overlooks church steeples and the New Jersey Palisades. Its 28 studios run less than $875 per month. A ballroom near the lobby, lined in carved garlands and fluted pilasters, is being turned into a communal gallery and performance hall. 
 "I told a friend the other day, 'Wow! I'm living in a building with a marble temple front!' " Mr. Pavlou said. The building is five minutes from the train station; from there it's half an hour to Grand Central Terminal ($8.50 round trip, off peak). 
There's only one potential drawback: almost no one lives nearby. Blocks of industrial brick buildings from the early 1900's sit crumbling on the waterfront, near a recently rebuilt covered pier. Shops on the side streets with gingerbread trim have been renovated but not yet rented. Ground was broken downtown on Monday for a new bakery by the star designer Maya Lin. It is as if this place were somewhat groggily awakening from decades of post-industrial slumber. 
"It looks a little like a movie set waiting for the set dressers," Mr. Pavlou said. He moved to Philipsburgh, on Hudson Street, shortly after it opened in November. The sometimes desolate neighborhood doesn't faze him. In that, he's like the artist-adventurers who braved early SoHo, made TriBeCa and discovered Dumbo. Pioneering has its advantages, Mr. Pavlou said: lots of trash heaps of wood and glass scraps for furnishings and sculpture.
Philipsburgh is owned by a neighboring Episcopal church and the Greyston Foundation, a charity based in Yonkers that offers housing and job training, among other services. Greyston's next act of civic beautification, on Ashburton Avenue, will be that bakery by Maya Lin, her first industrial building. The bakery's workers had been chronically unemployed before Greyston taught them how to cook. 
The city can certainly use some lucky breaks. Since the 1960's it has suffered not only the usual doldrums of former factory towns but also Westchester County's worst poverty levels, battles over the desegregation of housing and schools, and political scandals. To jump-start the economy and to attract a colorful and creative class of people willing to live in less-than-perfect surroundings, Yonkers is encouraging artists to move downtown, a strategy that has worked in other communities along the Hudson. 
A decade ago, Peekskill declared a four-block area an artists' district. Some 80 of them now live there, and 28 new lofts are being readied (investors have spent millions of dollars in the district, refurbishing at least three dozen buildings, according to Bernard Molloy, head of the local chamber of commerce). Further upriver, a branch of the Dia Center for the Arts will open in Beacon next year, and Hudson has become home to artists as well as antiques dealers. 
"Artists' housing has gone from an esoteric term to a buzzword," said Robert Lane, the director of the design program at the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit urban planning group for the greater New York City area. First come the artists, and then ideally the galleries arrive, along with chic shops and restaurants. Part of its appeal, Mr. Lane added, is that "it generally doesn't bring children, with all the attendant issues of schools and services." But there's always a risk that, as in SoHo, the artists will gentrify an area too well. "They often price themselves out of their own good deeds," he said. 
It is likely that Yonkers will have to work hard not only to get artists, galleries and chic shops, but also to keep them. Leon Shilton, a finance professor at Fordham University who has analyzed the city's redevelopment plans, said he worries that newcomers to Yonkers could become disheartened by its fractious politics. 
Artists of various stripes have settled in Yonkers since the 19th century, mostly on its picturesque hilltops. The trompe-l'oeil muralist Richard Haas has lived for 22 years in an Arts and Crafts house perched on a riverfront cliff. His three murals near Philipsburgh Hall depict Yonkers's evolution from primeval shoreline to Victorian manufacturing hub. 
Downtown improvements since the late 1990's have been slow-paced, Mr. Haas acknowledged. "But there's enough commitment now that it should stick," he said. 
Philipsburgh, designed by the prolific local architect G. Howard Chamberlin, was originally an office building. The ballroom was used for performances and speeches by Clara Bow, Helen Hayes and Franklin D. Roosevelt. In 1978, in a previous attempt to revive downtown, the city built a colonnaded park around the corner. It was razed in 1988 partly because of complaints that it was attracting too many of what were considered unsavory characters.
"That they tore it down was mind-boggling to me," said Walter David Brown, a Manhattan architect who designed the site. He recently helped restore Philipsburgh, which had been condemned after a fire in 1997. The idea for making it an artists' colony came largely from the Rev. S. Burtner Ulrich, the rector of an Episcopal church across the street, St. John's (a Victorian pile undergoing its own $2.5 million overhaul). 
The colony, Father Ulrich said, is meant to enliven the neighborhood and turn the ballroom back into a cultural attraction. The city suggested that the church join with Greyston, which has already renovated 94 apartments in Yonkers for formerly homeless people. Rehabilitating Philipsburgh cost $7.5 million, with about a third of that money loaned by the city. 
All of the studios in Philipsburgh are occupied, and about 10 people are on a waiting list for units of 450 to 600 square feet including eat-in kitchens. Greyston has defined artist rather loosely: the occupants include interior and lighting designers, an urban planner and a gospel singer. Most are in their 20's and 30's. To qualify for a lease, they must earn less than $38,400 a year (for couples, $43,860). 
But the rents are not bargains, at least not in Yonkers, said Nortrud Wolf Spero, a real estate agent there. One-bedroom apartments larger than Philipsburgh's units are readily available for $750 a month, she said. What Philipsburgh offers is high-quality architecture, proximity to the stately train station and a budding artistic brotherhood. "It's a very positive, supportive environment," said Shanara Gabrielle, an actress who lives in the building with her high school sweetheart, Jeff Phillips, a composer and violinist.
Since 1982, Greyston has run a profitable baked-goods plant that supplies stores like Dean & DeLuca with cakes named Peanut Butter Explosion and Whiskey Pistachio Bundt, and Ben & Jerry's with its brownies. The $9 million Maya Lin building will replace the 7,000-square-foot bakery in downtown Yonkers. (The old facility will perhaps become a "small-business incubator for food-related manufacturing entrepreneurs," said Charles Lief, Greyston's president.)
On a polluted waterfront lot once occupied by a gas plant, the new bakery will have a roof garden and an atrium, giving workers river views and letting the public glimpse the baking process. 
"I wanted the building to be more spiritual than you'd expect," Ms. Lin said. On Yonkers's gritty streets, "it will glow like a beacon at night, telling people something unusual is going on here," she said. 
For now, the first landmark most New Yorkers notice in Yonkers is its copper-trimmed train station on Buena Vista Avenue, designed by Warren & Wetmore and Reed & Stem, the architects of Grand Central. Metro-North has announced it will renovate the station for $35 million. On Main Street, an old bar has been turned into the Coffee Break cafe, and there is talk up and down the street about other new restaurants in progress. A former trolley barn on the waterfront is slated to become upscale live-work lofts. And on a spit of riverbank just south of the station, the city is spending $7 million on a new park near a renovated pier that has jazz concerts in the summer and views of Manhattan. 
Philipsburgh's colonists are already leaping to their new home's defense. "The town's had its ups and downs like every place," said Mr. Phillips, the violinist. "It's gotten kind of a bad rap."
And attention, scoffers: just try finding a cut-rate loft in Williamsburg.

HEADLINE: China Is Increasing Its Budget For Military Spending by 17.6% 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 6 

 BODY:
China is increasing military spending this year by 17.6 percent, or $3 billion, bringing the publicly reported total to $20 billion, the finance minister announced today. 
 In a report to Parliament on the budget for 2002, the minister, Xiang Huaicheng, said continued large spending increases were needed for China's military "to utilize modern technology, especially high technology to raise our army's defense and combat capabilities," and to raise salaries for the country's 2.5 million officers and enlisted men. 
 The jump in spending follows many years of double-digit increases, reflecting China's effort to improve its mostly outdated forces and to attract better educated men into a military that has suffered from low morale. 
The publicly disclosed figures do not include major spending for weapons research and for the purchase of foreign weapons like two Russian-built destroyers China bought last year. Actual military spending may be three to five times the reported total of $20 billion, according to Western experts. 
China is believed to spend more on the military than any other country in Asia, but even the higher estimates are well below the spending levels of the United States, and the American technological advantage may, if anything, be growing, some experts say.
The Bush administration has proposed a $379 billion military budget for the next fiscal year, a 14.5 percent increase over the previous year's budget. 
Government spending over all will increase by 10 percent in the year ahead, expanding the deficit as officials try to prop up economic growth during the global slowdown, Mr. Xiang said. He promised a 28 percent increase in spending on living allowances for the unemployed, pensions and other social security measures "in order to protect social stability." 
Millions of farmers and workers in decrepit state industries are expected to lose their jobs in the years ahead as China further opens its markets to global competition within the rules of the World Trade Organization.

HEADLINE: TURF; 
On Sunday, A License To Snoop

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
BY 1:40 last Sunday afternoon, the crowd outside the prewar co-op on West 83rd Street was growing restive. Twenty-one people -- a blonde with hair down to her waist, guys in leather jackets and a father with his baby in a backpack -- were waiting for the doors to open. All but the baby were clutching folded classified ads, with this item circled: "Best 2BR Value, Elev., hi ceils, French doors, park block." And then the kicker: "$399,000."
 New Yorkers have always been curious about the value of real estate -- theirs and everyone else's. But cruising open houses has become a weekend ritual. 
 So forget movies and museums. Open houses are waiting. Last Sunday, the word went out: there were bargain two-bedrooms on the Upper West Side, a cheap loft in TriBeCa ($850,000) and a killer one-bedroom on West End Avenue ($259,000). This was a free show: no admission charge, no invitation required. 
It's "the perfect post-9/11 activity," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Associates, a real estate brokerage. "It combines the New York obsession with money and investment, and the post-September preoccupation with home and family." And although there is no citywide record of open-house attendance, Mr. Peters estimates that the number of shoppers has quadrupled since last year.
There have always been open houses, of course, but with low interest rates and hints of economic recovery, many more buyers and self-proclaimed real estate prognosticators are now beating paths to other people's doors.
In past years, open houses were businesslike affairs with a few serious buyers and a curious neighbor or two inspecting the cabinets and pacing out the bedrooms. But things have changed. On Sunday alone, there were 408 open houses in Manhattan, attended by thousands of inquisitive visitors. 
Over Sunday brunch, from E.A.T. on the Upper East Side to Bubby's in TriBeCa, house-hungry men and women map out the day's itinerary, circling promising ads with red pens. The scene shifts to acquaintances air-kissing in entrance halls of unfamiliar, unfurnished apartments.
Rather than dragging clients all over town, brokers now preside at the sign-in table. Last February, 25 people showed up at an open house for a five-room apartment on West 91st Street, according to Deanna Kory of the Corcoran Group. Last weekend, 77 signed in at a comparable apartment on West 79th Street. When inexpensive one- and two-bedrooms are advertised, the crowds are even larger.
Not everyone is just looking. In February 2001, 10 of their firm's deals resulted from open houses, reported Anita Perrone of the Corcoran Group; this February, the number reached 45. Paul Purcell, president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, estimated that his company's deals from open houses more than doubled from the same period a year ago.
On Sunday the clouds were sprinkling on West End Avenue, but the mood was festive as Joshua Zucker, a 26-year-old stock trader, recalled his recent adventures on the apartment circuit. "Last weekend, I met a woman at one open house, and we sort of went looking together," he said. "We went to one place; a FSBO," he said, showing off newly acquired real estate jargon. "You know, 'For Sale By Owner.' When we walked in together, the owner asked, 'Are you two married?' So we laughed, and I said, 'No, we're engaged,' and then we put on a show." 
He shrugged. "She gave me her number, but I never called. What are the chances? I ran into her in Macy's the next week -- when I was shopping for a birthday present for my real girlfriend." 
Like so many others these days, Mr. Zucker spends a lot of his time apartment-hopping. On Sunday he was joined by his twin brother, Jeremy, also a trader. 
When approached by a reporter, the Zuckers were in a one-bedroom at 675 West End Avenue. The broker, Clare Tomoney of Corcoran, said she already had an accepted offer for the $299,000 co-op but decided to hold the open house anyway.
Part of the fun of open house shopping is comparing notes with strangers and trying to uncover the seller's strategy. "I think they must not be sure of the offer," said Jesse Lunin-Pack, 29, an investment banker at Lehman Brothers. Mr. Lunin-Pack had heard that fewer than half the apartment owners lived in the building, making some banks reluctant to lend to new buyers there. If the accepted bidder could not find a mortgage easily, he or she might back off, clearing the way for another offer. Mr. Lunin-Pack left his name, just in case. 
A half-hour after the showing began, 10 or so people were milling around, even though the apartment was already taken. "I've seen cubbyholes for more money than this one," Joshua Zucker said.
The Zuckers then investigated 215 West 95th Street, a contemporary building ("Sun-splashed! Large 1BR, Walls of Wndws! Lux 24 HR Dm/Conc, Rf Deck, Gym, Grge"). Joshua Zucker's comments were equally abbreviated: "It's ugly. It's postwar. It has no character. And for the price -- no way." 
Real estate analysis is only part of the experience. During the open house, the brothers met JoAnn Hunter, a young actress in a black leather jacket who arrived on a bicycle. "I don't have to make a decision today," she said. "My time frame is like July-ish." She compared notes with the Zuckers in the elevator, then pedaled off to the next open house. 
To separate himself from the pack, Joshua Zucker is quick to tell brokers he is a serious buyer, and vows to find something by April 1. He is concentrating on the West Side, in the high 80's and 90's, and along with visiting open houses he scans the Internet. He has 10 favorite buildings and watches them like his favorite stocks, instructing several brokers to let him know the second anything opens up.
The Zuckers next checked out a "Terrace/Loft/Special" at 202 West 92nd Street priced at $415,000. The apartment, a big one-bedroom, is charming, with a working fireplace, a private roof deck and only one drawback: it's a fifth-floor walkup. The brothers climbed that high, continuing at a jogger's pace up the metal spiral staircase to the roof. After a cursory look at the view, they were ready to leave.
Brian Ronan, a Broadway sound consultant, and his friend Janet Dromgoole, a make-up artist, were more impressed. Mr. Ronan was touring open houses in order to decide if he should buy or sign another year's lease. While he declined to say how much rent he was paying, he emphasized that it was no bargain. For people like Mr. Ronan, open houses provide an easy way to gauge their options. 
The turnout was even bigger at 588 West End, where apartment 5D, a 650-square-foot one-bedroom ("Steal! Best brite 1BR in Prime Upper West Side Steps to Zabars and Riv Side Park"), was going for $259,000. The lobby was so chaotic by 2 p.m. that the doorman was acting as traffic cop, and the super had to start up the freight elevator. Upstairs, the broker, Chip Horne from Douglas Elliman, was ecstatic: after two hours, 85 people had come by, and he had a fistful of offers. (On Monday he said the owner had accepted an offer at the asking price.) 
When Mr. Lunin-Pack, the investment banker, walked in, the twins greeted him like an old friend. Another potential buyer, Olga Lifson, who is renting a studio and had perused three other apartments that day, joined the group.
"I just started last week," Ms. Lifson said. "I'm just trying to get a general idea of what's on the market." She is looking for an alcove studio or a one-bedroom, with space for a queen-size bed. 
The four left the open house together. Strolling along West End, they considered checking out the West 83rd Street two-bedroom advertised at $399,000. When they saw the line outside the front door, they went their separate ways with a chorus of farewells.
One of the people in line was Josh Galper, who stood on the third step with 14-month-old Jivan on his shoulders. "It's madness, what's going on," Mr. Galper said with a smile. "It's been like this ever since people lost faith in the stock market and have decided real estate is safer. And, from what we're told, there's not much available, and a lot of people looking for it." 
He glanced around. The agent was racing up to the entrance. "Hopefully, the market won't kill itself," Mr. Galper said, following her through the mahogany double doors.

HEADLINE: A Winning Strategy 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
In a world teeming with war and terror, you take your good news where you can get it. And some of that good news is here in New York.
 You'd have to go back to 1962, when Robert Wagner was mayor and you could rent a three-bedroom apartment with a terrace on West 72nd Street for $149 a month, to find a month that had as few homicides as New York City had last month. 
 The 32 murders recorded by the Police Department in February was the lowest number in any month since the city began tracking crime statistics on a monthly basis in 1962. 
To paraphrase a mid-60's Sinatra hit, 1962 was a very mild year. John F. Kennedy was president, "The Sound of Music" was on Broadway, and you could take a nearly weeklong cruise to Bermuda for $160. The idea that the murder rate now would be the same as it was then is astonishing. 
The plunge in crime in New York since the bloodletting of the late 80's and early 90's has been breathtaking. And there are many reasons. The first, as Police Commissioner Ray Kelly puts it, is that "size matters." The New York police force, compared with departments in other big cities, is enormous. There are nearly 40,000 cops in New York. That's a small army. (Los Angeles, for example, with a population about half that of New York, has 8,900 officers.)
Plans for a big buildup in the size of the department began in the Dinkins administration. The buildup got under way in January 1994, when Rudolph Giuliani took office. That coincided with important advances in police management techniques.
Nearly all experts agree that New York has been extraordinarily sophisticated in the use of computerized strategies for the effective deployment of police officers. The Compstat program developed during the Giuliani years has become a model for much of the country and in many other parts of the world.
And even as the police force was expanding and Compstat was being put in place, the terrible plague of crack cocaine that had brought insane levels of violence to the city's streets began to ease. Attitudes in the hardest-hit neighborhoods changed. People were sickened by the violence. Children traumatized by the murder of older siblings or cousins or parents or friends turned away from crack, and crackheads eventually became pariahs.
I think young New Yorkers have gotten too little credit for the changes in their behavior that have contributed to the curtailment of crime in the city.
Also important was the city's commitment to getting guns off the street, and the enactment of federal gun control measures. Richard Aborn, a longtime gun control advocate, said, "We finally understood how inextricably linked guns are to violent crime, and that's had a big impact." 
Other reasons that are frequently cited may not have played as large a role as some people believe. The improved economy in the second half of the 1990's may have contributed to the national drop in crime. But it's not likely it played a significant role in New York. The turnaround here trailed that of the national economy. And New York's precipitous decline in crime was well under way by the time the city's economy rebounded.
Similarly, the enormous numbers of criminals locked up over the past decade or so would seem to have been a big factor in any drop in crime. But the evidence shows that this phenomenon was a bigger deal in places like Texas and California than in New York, where there was never a huge spike in the number of city residents locked up in state prisons. 
The recipe for success in New York has been more cops, smarter policing, fewer guns, a drastic decline in the use of crack and better behavior by young people.
So what's ahead? The city is facing huge budget problems that make it difficult to maintain Police Department strength at its highest levels -- a little over 40,000. There are about 38,000 officers now, and that will increase to 39,200 after July 1. Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Kelly have both said they will attempt to hold the line there. 
As for deployment, Mr. Kelly said, "We still have to keep ourselves focused very much on the issue of crime suppression." But in the aftermath of Sept. 11 the department also has what he described as "this sort of overarching issue that can't be ignored -- counterterrorism."
He said he was confident the department could do both.

HEADLINE: The Urge to Converge 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
"Mere size is no sin against the law," President William Howard Taft told Congress in 1911, in defense of the legislation that had enabled his G.O.P. predecessor, Teddy Roosevelt, to bust the trusts stifling competition. (Taft weighed over 300 pounds at the time.)
 The principle that it was not a corporation's size itself, but only the purpose or effect of its size and power on competition, lay at the heart of antitrust law for the past century. It is the basis of the Ashcroft Justice Department's recent cave-in to the growing monopoly that is Microsoft. 
 In the legal world, the result of the seeming sinlessness of size has been the megamergers that have concentrated economic power in a few predatory oil companies, a handful of accountancy firms and an ever-dwindling number of banks. 
In the world of telecommunications, the urge to converge has led to the creation of worldwide media empires that promised the happy marriage of news and entertainment content with the computer, wireless telephone and video -- all supposedly lowering prices to consumers with no restraint of trade or news. 
Does anyone believe that is what has been happening?
In the real world, intimidating "mere size" has become, when not sin itself, the occasion of sin. Today's any-merger-goes regulators permit cross-ownership of content and distribution while encouraging corporate titans with swollen egos to gobble up competitors or suppliers. Where does this power grab leave the innovative entrepreneur, the small business, the individual talent and the consumer?
Hugeness is necessary to compete with foreign biggies, goes the monopolist mantra -- as if most multinationals were not rooted in the U.S. Only the monster conglomerate can afford to invest in new technologies, complaisant Washington regulators tell us -- as if innovation and invention were not also found in small laboratories and the brains of creative loners. 
The swallowed-up company's resulting loss of corporate identity and dilution of mission can be found in the case of the Disney empire's decision to ruin the reputation of one of its purchases, ABC News. Ted Koppel's "Nightline," a respected news program turning a profit and holding its own against the late-night entertainment competition, is to be replaced by the David Letterman show, if Disney can entice the comedian from CBS. 
The reason is not so much the size of the audience reached, but its makeup. Letterman's banter appeals to youthful acquisitors, whom advertisers lust after; Koppel's news interests older people, who do less buying and more dying. Disney decision: Scrap the news, go with the jokes. 
Koppel's reaction was dismayingly mild, holding on this page that "it is perfectly understandable that Disney would jump at the opportunity to increase earnings. . . ." 
Now, if The Times were to replace this column with a comic strip, I like to think you would hear a geshrei from me and a keening wail from even critical readers that would rattle corporate rafters. The Times would not sacrifice serious opinion-mongering for comic relief because this focused $3 billion outfit understands that its reason for being is primarily to inform. The Disney combine's mission, contrariwise, is to dispense profitable entertainment, and its misbegotten purchase of a news medium allows it to prostitute ABC News's journalistic mission to conform to the parent company's different goal.
With the roundheeled Michael Powell steering the Federal Communications Commission toward terminal fecklessness; with the redoubtable Joel Klein succeeded at Justice's antitrust division by an assortment of wimps; and with appeals courts approving the concentration of media power as if nothing had changed since President Taft's day, the checks and balances made possible by diverse competition are being eradicated.
The longtime anti-business coloration of liberals reduces their ability to take on the convergence con. It is for conservatives to ask ourselves: Since when is bigness goodness? 
The Constitution's brilliant system of checks and balances restrains each government branch's power. We oppose the concentration of authority in the federal government, urging its devolution to states and localities. We seek to empower productive individuals by cutting taxes. Our mothers' milk is market competition. 
Why, then, should we supinely go along with the seizure of economic power by today's triopolies and duopolies on their march to becoming tomorrow's monopolies?

HEADLINE: Bill to Raise The Insurance On Deposits Has 2 Big Foes 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
A Congressional proposal to increase the amount of bank deposits protected by government insurance is facing opposition from the Bush administration and the Federal Reserve.
 The level has remained unchanged, at $100,000 a depositor, for more than 20 years, and an increase would be reassuring to consumers, many of whom have been looking for havens as stock prices have declined and more companies have fallen into bankruptcy. 
 A bill in the House and a similar proposal in the Senate call for an increase in coverage by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to $130,000 a person. Deposit insurance covers losses if a bank or savings and loan fails. 
Both the Senate and the House bills recommend substantially more coverage for individual retirement accounts. The House proposal would increase coverage from $100,000 a person to $260,000 for I.R.A.'s, while the Senate is calling for an increase to $250,000.
The House bill will be marked up, or reviewed, today by the financial institutions subcommittee of the Financial Services Committee, according to Peggy Peterson, a spokeswoman for the committee. The increased coverage is part of a group of proposals being made to change the way the F.D.I.C., which insures depositors at 9,700 banks and savings and loans, administers insurance funds.
If the legislation passes, it would be the first increase in deposit insurance since the level was raised from $40,000 a depositor in 1980. The increase, particularly for retirement accounts, is being supported by community banks as a way to help them attract deposits. 
The provision, though, has attracted opposition from Federal Reserve and Treasury officials who say an increase in insurance would lead banks to make risky investments, because they know more of their customers' deposits have government backing.
Yesterday, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill sent a letter to members of the House Financial Services Committee discouraging an increase in deposit insurance.
"The administration continues to believe that the deposit insurance coverage level should remain unchanged," the letter said. "There is no evidence that an increase in the coverage level would promote competition or materially improve the ability of community banks to obtain funds. An increase in coverage would primarily benefit high net worth individuals and do little for the great majority of savers, who have deposit balances far below the current coverage limit."
In testimony before the House last August, Sheila C. Bair, assistant secretary for financial institutions, quoted Federal Reserve data suggesting that only 2 percent of households with deposit accounts had any uninsured deposits.
A spokesman for the Federal Reserve, David Skidmore, declined to comment, other than to say the agency's position had not changed since last summer, when a former Federal Reserve governor, Laurence H. Meyer, testified against the deposit insurance increase.
Spencer Bachus, a Republican from Alabama and chairman of the House subcommittee on financial institutions, said he was not worried about the opposition. Mr. Bachus, who introduced the bill in February, said he had already cut back the increase in insurance from $150,000, and conceded there might still be "some modification." But he insisted that the jump in deposit insurance was needed, because inflation had eroded 60 percent of the $100,000 insurance protection.
Given the declines in the stock market and the crisis in investor confidence caused by the bankruptcy of the Enron Corporation, he said, consumers need to be able to rely on their banks. "We learned from Enron that people don't need to be losing their retirement funds that they worked so hard to get," he said.
The provision on deposit insurance also faces opposition from Phil Gramm, the ranking Republican member of the Senate Banking Committee.
"To operate the banking system, you need a certain level of insurance," Senator Gramm said. "But you could lose some of the checks and balances." 
"People with over $100,000 in deposits will pay close attention to the condition of the bank itself, and have an incentive to be judicious" about where they deposit their savings, he added.
Mr. Gramm and others suggest that the last increase in deposit insurance may have contributed to the high number of savings and loan failures later that decade. At a Senate hearing last August, he said that during that period, "because of deposit insurance, deposits would come into a failing institution by the tens of millions of dollars and seize a higher rate of return with absolute certainty that the taxpayer was going to pick up the bill."
Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota and the bill's sponsor in the Senate, said the proposal was more relevant than ever despite some opposition. "The Fed and Treasury have not been enthusiastic about this," he said. "Given the volatility in the stock market now, it is important that people's financial strategies be broadened. People ought to be able to put a larger amount of money in their hometown bank if they want."

HEADLINE: GROUND ZERO: COMPENSATION; 
Charity Shifting Emphasis Away From Cash Payments

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
In six months, the Sept. 11 Fund has distributed $205 million, 85 percent of that in direct cash payments to victims. But in a major shift yesterday, the fund's leaders said that they now intended to sharply curtail direct grants to victims.
 Instead, they announced, most of their remaining donations, about $251 million, will be spent on mental health counseling, job training, small-business assistance and other programs aimed at addressing the region's long-term needs. 
 Joshua Gotbaum, chief executive of the fund, a joint project of the United Way of New York City and the New York Community Trust, said that yesterday's shift was prompted by a basic calculation. With so much money having already been distributed to victims from scores of charities and government programs, and with still more money yet to come from the federal Victims Compensation Fund, the time is right, he said, to focus on programs that will equip families and businesses to weather the years of hard times ahead. 
Mental health officials, for example, project that 30,000 people in New York alone will require counseling in the next year, he said at a news conference to report on the fund's first six months. Tens of thousands more will need job training. Hundreds of families will require financial advice and legal help as they sort out estates and custody issues.
After the bombing in Oklahoma City, Mr. Gotbaum noted, more victims sought counseling in the second year after the attack than in the first year. To bolster the point, he introduced Nancy B. Anthony, executive director of the Oklahoma City Community Foundation, who described herself as a "wounded veteran" of another time of national crisis.
"This process," she said, "is not about distributing money. This process is about helping people rebuild their lives."
In what amounted to a pointed critique of the charitable response to Sept. 11, Ms. Anthony explicitly warned against the favored approach of many funds: simply dividing up the money and sending out checks. In Oklahoma City, she said, families who received substantial cash payments often "wound up back on our doorsteps" after spending the money unwisely.
"It's not necessary to divide money up and hand it out," she said, urging charities to adopt a more traditional role of responding to demonstrated needs based on careful assessments of families.
But until now, that has not been the primary approach of the Sept. 11 Fund, the second largest fund set up in response to the attacks. According to the fund's six-month report, $175 million of the $205 million distributed thus far has been in direct cash assistance to victims and their families.
Most of the 3,200 families with relatives who were killed or severely injured received cash payments of $20,000. Of the 3,000 displaced families and 32,500 people who lost jobs, most received $4,000.
The other $30 million was distributed as loans or grants to community organizations, rescue and recovery groups and other services, like a telephone support line for victims. The Sept. 11 Fund's administrative costs, about $1.4 million a year, are being covered by separate donations from several foundations, officials said.
Franklin Thomas, chairman of the Sept. 11 Fund, said that although estimates are difficult, his instinct told him that no more than 25 percent of the fund's remaining $251.4 million would be paid out as cash grants to individual families and victims.
What this means, in effect, is that the tens of thousands of people thrown out of work by the attacks will now have to go elsewhere for any future cash aid, fund officials said. But they argued that donors never intended for the Sept. 11 Fund to become a substitute for government unemployment assistance. To continue giving money directly to the unemployed would leave little money for long-term needs, fund officials said.
Meanwhile, in another development yesterday, Eliot L. Spitzer, the state attorney general, announced that he would endorse the proposed transfer of nearly $100 million from the city's Twin Towers Fund to a private charity of the same name controlled by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor.
Many families had opposed the transfer, but Mr. Spitzer, who regulates charities in New York, said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani had agreed to meet several conditions to secure his approval of the transfer.
Mr. Giuliani will allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to name 20 percent of his charity's board members. He will also allow victims to name a board member, and he has agreed that his charity will be subject to audits by the city comptroller.
If the transfer is approved in court, as it must be, Mr. Giuliani has also agreed to distribute all $100 million within 60 days. The money is to be divided among the families of about 430 uniformed and civilian rescuers who died in the collapse of the World Trade Center, precisely the approach Ms. Anthony so passionately discouraged yesterday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Users of Steel Worry That Tariffs Will Be Costly 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Gary Hill, the president of National Metalwares, cannot yet quantify the effect steel tariffs will have on his business. But he assumes it will not be small, and it will not be good. 
 National Metalwares, at about $30 million in revenue, is small, but Mr. Hill said it had traditionally commanded a solid share of the market for tubular steel components used in school furniture and engine-powered lawn products like mowers or weed trimmers. But steel represents some 46 percent of the cost of making those products, and Mr. Hill fears that if tariffs cause his steel prices to shoot up then foreign competitors who use untaxed steel will eat away at his market share. 
 "We're going to be at a 20 to 25 percent cost disadvantage to offshore manufacturers who may now choose to target the U.S. market," Mr. Hill said. "And our customers may wind up under attack from offshore competitors now, too."
Across the country, users of steel -- be they small companies like National Metalwares, which is based in Aurora, Ill., or mega-users like General Motors -- are starting to assess the implications of the Bush administration's decision to impose tariffs of 8 percent to 30 percent on much imported steel. Few seem optimistic.
"Shipyards are busy now, but if steel prices go up, barge customers may postpone buying," worried Danny Irby, vice president for production at Jeffboat, a shipbuilding company in Jeffersonville, Ind.
Even companies whose customers cannot easily postpone purchases are concerned.
"Steel is a significant component of our products, and our industry information says we could be looking at upward pricing pressure in the range of 10 to 20 percent," said Christopher P. Feeney, a spokesman for Hillenbrand Industries, a company in Batesville, Ind., that makes coffins and health care equipment.
Still, no one is panicking -- yet. Since most companies buy steel on long-term contracts, few fear immediate price fluctuations.
"Steel prices are so low and the supply so flush that it looks like we'll be O.K. for the immediate future," said John F. Hessmer, vice president for construction at the Rockefeller Group Development Corporation, a New York City company that builds corporate and industrial sites across the country.
Joseph Hice, a spokesman for the Harley-Davidson Motor Company in Milwaukee, which uses primarily domestic steel, is equally sanguine. "We have good long-term relationships with our suppliers, so the tariffs shouldn't affect us," he said.
Some companies -- manufacturers of beverage cans, for example -- will probably pass added costs onto consumers, because few customers would pay to ship empty steel cans across oceans. The largest users, automakers, say, or big appliance makers, are such important customers for steel producers that competition may keep their prices low. 
Indeed, many applaud the tariffs for potentially maintaining healthy competition among domestic steel makers, even as they express concern that they will drive domestic prices up. "It's a double-bind situation," said Steven Gaut, a spokesman for Delphi Automotive Systems in Troy, Mich., which supplies many components for General Motors. 
Still, even the largest companies are not shrugging off the ramifications of the announcement on Tuesday. "It's too soon to assess the impact, but we certainly have a lot of people working on this," said Terrence C. Dunn Jr., a spokesman for GE Appliances, the General Electric unit in Louisville, Ky., that buys 210,000 tons of cold-rolled steel a year, all from American suppliers.
For many companies, pricing is less a concern than availability. Many worry that the hefty tariffs will drive away foreign suppliers, yet will not provide the economic support American companies need to stay solvent.
"The strength of the dollar, capacity usage -- there are plenty of issues affecting the long-term viability of the domestic steel industry," said Brian VanDommelen, who sets steel procurement strategies for Steelcase, the big furniture maker in Grand Rapids, Mich.
Others worry that American producers cannot provide superstrong or other specialty steels. Robert S. Miller, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in Bethlehem, Pa., and an officer of the American Iron and Steel Institute, insists that American companies can provide any type of steel. But users say that is not true. 
For example, Caterpillar, the heavy equipment manufacturer in Peoria, Ill., successfully lobbied to have some of the steel it imports from Britain and elsewhere exempted from the tariff rules. But Lewis E. Leibowitz, a lawyer for the Consuming Industries Trade Action Coalition, a polyglot group of medium-size steel users that has long lobbied against tariffs, readily lists numerous companies that he said had tried -- unsuccessfully -- to obtain superstrong or other specialty steels from domestic suppliers, and had simply given up.
"American steel companies can say that steel is fungible, but it's just not," he said.
In general, representatives of trade associations have been far less guarded in their comments than the companies they represent. For months, the Iron and Steel Institute, the primary steel industry trade group, and Mr. Leibowitz's group, have been trotting out dueling economists and other experts to prove mutually exclusive points.
The steel makers have "proved" that tariffs will save jobs without much effect on prices, and that American steel makers can provide any steel that any user needs. "The impact on customers will be nothing like the hysteria that we've been reading in the press," Mr. Miller of Bethlehem said.
The users' group insists that jobs will be lost, prices will skyrocket and companies will not have access to steel that they need. 
"This remedy will do more harm than good," Mr. Leibowitz countered.

PERSON: Marc V. Shaw 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
He Never Asked to Be the Mayor on Weekends

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
FROM the stink of things in his underdecorated but aggressively aromatic City Hall office, it is evident that Marc V. Shaw, New York City's deputy mayor for operations and, more famously, its mayoral surrogate when the boss sneaks those secret weekends out of town, has just parted company with a cigar. Maybe that's why he's being such a grouch: separation anxiety. 
 It turns out our favorite surrogate smokes economy, non-Cuban stogies, $2.50 a pop at a two-a-day pace, always behind closed doors: Mr. Shaw likes his privacy. And he is cost-conscious: main indulgence, season tickets to the Mets. But somewhere along the line he's sampled a top-shelf cigar. "Cubans get you high," he says, an off-the-cuff grin briefly replacing a standoffish scowl, his prevailing expression in an oft-interrupted hour of reluctant revelations. "What do we need, 5, 10 more minutes?" he asks every 5 or 10 minutes until he's saved by the bell, a summons from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose penchant for weekend privacy has cost Mr. Shaw his. 
 "I don't enjoy being in the public eye. I'm a staff person, not an elected official," he protests from behind a bedrock of gray stubble -- he doesn't enjoy shaving, either. "I'm just doing my job, and the part of this I find bizarre and sad is that the actual result of the media's dealing with the mayor's desire for privacy on weekends has been to impinge on mine." True enough.
So that's why he's acting like a grouch, slouched in a chair with his knees drawn up, feet planted on the coffee table, a hand shielding his mouth, as close to the fetal position as a balding adult in a rumpled white dress shirt and red tie can be while handling an inquiry he finds, well, impinging. Or is he just shy? Simply getting him to reveal his age, 47, and salary -- "$168,200 or something" -- feels like an exorcism. 
Mr. Shaw is out of sorts because suddenly, involuntarily, he is a pseudocelebrity, a butt of jokes, and the victim of an executive order stipulating that the deputy mayor for operations fills in when Mr. Bloomberg is away. He's no stranger to working weekends. "My kids used to say the difference between weekdays and weekends was that on weekends Daddy went to work in regular clothes instead of a suit." But an obligation that seemed innocuous has become an albatross.
First came the scruffy photo in The New York Post, snapped on a Saturday morning as he ventured outside to fetch his newspaper in Bayside, Queens, where he lives with his wife, Mary-Jane, a lawyer turned stay-at-home mom, and their three sons. Then came a week's worth of jokes on "Late Show With David Letterman," some ribald, all giddily portraying Mr. Shaw as a public official bursting with lowest-common-denominator male proclivities (i.e., a zest for wrestling, strip clubs, sloppiness).
"If they have a problem with the mayor's privacy issues, why are they picking on me?" grouses Mr. Shaw, echoing a lament already voiced by his spouse.
No, he doesn't appreciate last week's national exposure as star of a Letterman Top 10 list. No, he doesn't plan on framing it for posterity. "I'm not much on framing things," he says, indicating the bare office walls. "Hey, can we talk about something else? This is boring." 
Time to abandon a sore subject and move on, what with Mr. Shaw threatening to develop lockjaw and a steady stream of earnest underlings hammering away on his door like woodpeckers. 
Time to find out how this plum political post, for which he took a pay cut after resigning as executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (he's the forward-thinker who brought us E-ZPass and the MetroCard), fell into his lap like the string of other plums before it. Hint: he's a sharp fiscal manager in a crisis, not a cronyism hire. He didn't even get to know the new mayor until after the election. 
"I didn't think he was going to win," says Mr. Shaw, a bipartisan player who has toiled for the State Senate Finance Committee (1981-88), Peter F. Vallone (as his chief fiscal adviser and finance director for the City Council), Rudolph W. Giuliani (as his budget director and finance commissioner), and Gov. George E. Pataki (the M.T.A. job was secured with his say-so in 1996). 
Media intrusions aside, he considers this his pinnacle, even saddled with a $4.7 billion deficit he needs to shrink without endangering city services. "In a nutshell, it's like being the chief operating officer of the city, given the way this mayor operates and delegates." 
The deputy claims his "whole career is an accident," says he would rather run for his life than run for elected office and occasionally wishes he had stuck to academia. A Kenyan scholar, Simeon Chilungu, was his anthropology professor and mentor at SUNY-Buffalo. Mr. Shaw, an urban anthropologist from Plainview, in Nassau County, figured to end up in the professorial ranks, too. He moved from Buffalo to Hoboken, N.J., to compose his doctoral thesis on Hoboken's gentrification but hit a snag, ran low on funds, and when he got a paying offer to do econometrics research for the Wharton School instead of his own, he jumped. The subject was this city's 1980 fiscal crisis. 
What he learned continues to come in handy.

HEADLINE: The Recovery That Defied The Forecasts Of Economists 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
The economy's quick recovery from recession, evinced by the latest reports from the Commerce Department and the Federal Reserve, has taken many experienced forecasters by surprise.
 Their favorite explanation has been the unexpected resilience of consumers after the shock of Sept. 11. Yet at the end of last year, strong gains in productivity -- the amount of goods the average American worker produces in an hour -- also played an important and largely ignored role. 
 Yesterday, the Commerce Department released new figures showing a pickup of 1.6 percent in orders for manufactured goods in January, after an increase of 0.7 percent in December. Last week, the department revised its estimate of growth in gross domestic product for the final quarter of last year to 1.4 percent from 0.2 percent. 
The beige book of reports from the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, also released yesterday, described more signs of improvement in manufacturing, especially along the Eastern Seaboard and in auto-producing states like Michigan and Ohio. On the retail side, sales of home furnishings and appliances began to gain momentum in the Midwest. Though vacancies grew in commercial real estate across the country, home sales remained strong.
The Fed reported little change in labor markets, where employers cut bonuses and delayed raises in January and February. Contrary to the expectations of economists, however, the Fed's contacts hinted that the economy would soon start creating more jobs than it lost.
Even though the private sector has shed more than a million jobs, companies have still managed to turn out the goods and services consumers want, at prices they can afford, because of rising productivity.
Forecasters who doubted the economy's ability to grow at the end of last year may not have taken into account the effects of productivity because its growth was so unusual. 
"If productivity grows, the economy does well," said Edward C. Prescott, a professor at the University of Minnesota and senior adviser to the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Mr. Prescott contended that Wall Street's seers did not pay enough attention to productivity.
"I don't think they had a good basis for their forecasts," Professor Prescott said. "Sometimes pessimism or optimism gets popular, and it's contagious."
Rising productivity has enabled many companies to meet demand for their products even while reducing their work forces. "It's certainly been helpful in how we do our restructuring in ensuring that we be as cost effective as we can," said Martha Depenbrock, a spokeswoman for Procter & Gamble, which laid off 10,000 people last year.
Ms. Depenbrock said that Web-based management of payrolls, for example, had cut costs and freed time for other activities. The company has also achieved productivity gains -- and cost savings of $1 billion -- with a new method for developing manufacturing systems, she said. Procter & Gamble has already licensed the system to other businesses.
Rising productivity is by no means routine in a recession. "Productivity has stayed reasonably strong throughout, which is not your typical pattern," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution.
During the last 30 years, the average annual growth rate of productivity in all quarters was 1.7 percent. In quarters that included periods of recessions, as identified by the National Bureau of Economic Research, productivity shrank at an average annual rate of 0.35 percent. Yet in the three quarters since the most recent recession began in March 2001, productivity has clocked annual growth rates of 2.1 percent, 1.1 percent and 3.5 percent.
That last figure could be adjusted higher this morning, when the Labor Department releases its final estimates for the fourth quarter. Last week's upward revision of growth in gross domestic product for the fourth quarter suggests that workers were even more productive than initially thought.
"The productivity numbers have been holding up quite well," said Professor Prescott. "I suspect they'll be even higher with this revision in G.D.P. growth."
Productivity affects companies' ability to supply diverse goods and services at low prices. But in the last several months, most analysts concentrated on the demand side of the economy's grand equation, with a particular focus on the consumer. They still predicted that recovery would be slow to arrive.
Debating the economy's prospects after the terrorist attacks last September, the top forecasters at J. P. Morgan Chase decided that consumers were likely to retrench, said James E. Glassman, the bank's senior United States economist. In mid-December, J. P. Morgan Chase was predicting that the economy would contract by 2 percent in the fourth quarter. Other forecasts were more upbeat, but few predicted anything like the actual figure of 1.4 percent growth.
"It looks to me like that event just encouraged them to keep doing what they always do," Mr. Glassman said of consumers after Sept. 11. "There is a psychological dimension, and I think some clever companies figured out how to tap into this."
He called the "Keep America Rolling" slogan used by Chevrolet, a division of General Motors, particularly ingenious and perhaps a distraction from hard financial information. "I'm not sure the deals you got were that great when you walked away from the lot," he said.
Wall Street forecasters may also have overestimated consumers' reaction to the huge destruction of shareholder wealth in the stock markets last year. "Some, say on Wall Street, seemed to extrapolate their own portfolios to the rest of the population," said Dean M. Maki, an economist at Putnam Investments who studied the effects of changes in wealth while at the Federal Reserve. "The typical Wal-Mart shopper isn't affected very much one way or another by the way the stock market goes, whereas the typical Tiffany shopper probably is."
Improvements in productivity, even during a recession, can have lasting benefits. Businesses that try to do more with less can learn valuable lessons for helping productivity in the future, Mr. Litan of Brookings said. Companies do not forget how to make workers more efficient once a recession ends, he said.
The strong growth in productivity in the fourth quarter may not last, however.
"There's not strong empirical evidence that the productivity growth rate will stay up there," Professor Prescott said. "I expect it to stay on its trend, which is that nice 2 percent a year."
Productivity growth is hard to predict, he added. For example, a theory that was once popular stated that the gains from the technological discoveries of the 1970's, when productivity growth slinked along at less than 2 percent, did not show up until the technologies became part of business practices in the 1990's. But the theory worked only for some countries.
"Some people have argued that some new things come along and it takes a while before you can really exploit them," Professor Prescott said.
"If there's a slingshot, why didn't Japan do well when the United States and Europe were doing well?"

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SENATE HEARINGS; 
Some See Panic As Main Effect Of Dirty Bombs

BYLINE:  By JAMES GLANZ with ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6 

 BODY:
Radioactive materials in wide use in the United States could be turned into weapons of terror that would probably kill few people but would spread panic and produce severe economic damage, scientists told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today. 
 The materials would not produce nuclear explosions. Rather, they would be spread using conventional explosives in so-called dirty bombs. The scientists who testified at the committee's hearing today said such weapons were a potentially serious problem. 
 The most dangerous materials, they said, are bars of radioactive cobalt used to irradiate food, medical devices and other products to sterilize them. If turned into fine particles and dispersed under the right weather conditions, the cobalt could spread enough radiation to force the abandonment of an area the size of Manhattan, the scientists said. But federal and industry officials said such an action with radioactive cobalt was unlikely because of the intense radiation to which the person trying to use the weapon would be exposed and because the material is transported in secret and kept behind tons of lead and other shielding while on the road or in use. 
Other radioactive materials in tens of thousands of medical and industrial devices could be used to make weapons that would leave wide areas with radiation levels above Environmental Protection Agency limits, possibly leading to temporary evacuation and an extremely difficult cleanup. 
"Radiological terrorism is a very plausible threat," said Dr. Steven E. Koonin, a physicist and national security expert who is provost of the California Institute of Technology.
The necessary radioactive materials are relatively common, he said, and "the expertise for handling is widely known and readily acquired." 
Scientists at the hearing held to understand these threats and to devise ways of protecting Americans against them also said that they remained concerned that fissionable material -- the fuel for nuclear weapons -- and the expertise needed to use it could be spreading from the former Soviet Union to terrorist networks, but presented no new evidence of such leakage. 
Much of the testimony focused on commonplace industrial materials like radioactive cesium, widely used in devices that check the quality of welds, test the integrity of oil pipelines and even measure the thickness of asphalt on roadways. Medical probes and other devices also rely on materials of this kind. 
Dr. Richard A. Meserve, chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said that all such materials, as well as the much more powerful cobalt rods used in sterilizing food, are tightly controlled. He said that the weaker sources, if dispersed, would cause almost immeasurably small increases in cancer rates among people who were exposed. 
Ideally, he said, evacuations from contaminated areas could be orderly. "It would not be such a crisis that if it took people 20 minutes or an hour to get out, it would be a disaster," Dr. Meserve said. 
Nevertheless, that sort of attack could cause long-term problems because techniques for dealing with radioactive contamination rely largely on demolition and removal, Dr. Henry Kelly, president of the Federation of American Scientists, said. Because limits set by the Environmental Protection Agency for radiation exposure are so low, areas might have to be evacuated for the long term even when the health risks are relatively slight, he said. 
Dr. Kelly offered a case study of what might happen if a dirty bomb containing a cobalt food irradiation bar exploded at the southern tip of Manhattan on a day with a light wind blowing toward the northeast. He calculated that Manhattan as far north as Central Park would be contaminated at levels similar to those in the permanently closed zone around the Chernobyl power plant. Manhattan would have to be abandoned for decades, Dr. Kelly said. 
The scientists said that they believed anyone trying to transport and process the highly radioactive materials would be detected. 
"I am comfortable because of the heightened awareness and security at those plants," Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, said. But, he said, "I'd be even more comfortable" if technology to replace the radioactive bars could be developed. 
Thousands of cobalt-60 rods are used in more than 160 food sterilization centers, 40 in the United States, federal regulators said. 
Federal nuclear officials and executives in the sterilization industry said yesterday that it would be extraordinarily difficult for terrorists to steal and use the 18-inch-long rods, the most common radiation source in the industry.
"An individual physically handling an unshielded single source rod would receive a lethal (death within weeks) dose in about a minute, and an incapacitating dose (immediately deadly) in about 20 minutes," said an e-mail statement from Neil A. Sheehan, a spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which licenses businesses using the materials.

HEADLINE: A Struggling Town, A Hesitant Hope; 
Memories Tinge a Business's Plan

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY

DATELINE: MECHANICVILLE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
One day in January, a Canadian entrepreneur appeared out of the northern blue and said that of all the places in North America, he had chosen this proud but wobbling little city as the future site of a new company in the suddenly sexy business of emergency preparedness.
 "Mechanicville will be put on the map," the entrepreneur, Raymond Henry, explained over his cellphone. "They have to be prepared. It's a small city to receive 500 people a week. They will open restaurants; they will open hotels." 
 Talk like that tends to get attention in this city of less than a square mile, a city whose population is plummeting, a city with no hotels and whose best-known restaurant, Joyce's Log Cabin, is shuttered. Mechanicville is hardly the only upstate community pining for a savior to restore its luster, but Mr. Henry's proposal received particular attention. It could -- could -- mean the city's first economic boost since the dominant paper mill closed a generation ago. 
A memorandum of understanding was signed. A news conference was held. And the Web site for Mr. Henry's new company, the Cogesur Group, now includes references to the "First International Municipal and Emergency Management Center, Mechanicville, N.Y.," alongside an icon of an ever-fluttering flag.
But hesitation lingers in Mechanicville. People here have not forgotten the time, a quarter-century ago, when a man named Bob John Ray came through town. Or was it Billy Ray Bob? Anyway, this smooth talker with three first names was down at Joyce's Log Cabin for a few days, claiming to have pockets deep enough to pull out new cars for anyone who made him chuckle or weep.
The few people who did not smell a flimflammer jockeyed to become his new best buddy, which meant that he never had to pay his bill -- not as long as he kept sending folks to a local car dealership to choose the color of their new Mercury Cougars. He vanished, of course, without buying so much as a pine-scented car freshener. But he did give Mechanicville a metaphor to describe anything too good to be true, as in: 
Here comes another Bob John Ray. Or Billy Ray Bob. Or whatever.
This is not to say that Mr. Henry's integrity is in question. But Bob John Ray references are definitely back in vogue, and here is why. 
So far there is not much more to Cogesur's plan, beyond Mr. Henry's assurances of an imminent $20 million investment from people about whom nothing is known, except that they divined opportunity in the Bush administration's recent promise to spend more money on emergency preparedness. Plus, the whole plan hinges on voters' approving the sale of a soon-to-be-vacated elementary school to Mr. Henry at a better rate than you could find at the Family Dollar store in town. (That photograph on the company's Web site, the one with Cogesur's logo already adorning a sign outside the school building? It's just a composite.)
Then there was Mr. Henry's casual inquiry into whether the city would be willing to double the assessment of the five-acre property, to nearly $12 million. Mr. Henry said that a higher assessment would help in financing the project. Anthony Luciano, the city assessor, said that in his 12 years in office, "no one's ever asked me to raise an assessment." 
City officials want Cogesur so much that they are about ready to learn French, but first things first. For starters, Mr. Henry has to show them the money.
"You hate to blow him off," said William E. Connors, the city's administrator of community development. "I'm the guy that's the most cautious and most concerned about his ability. I'm the one who keeps bringing it up and people keep saying, 'Don't scare him off. Don't scare him off. We blow him off and he opens up in Troy, and we're kicking ourselves.' "
The last thing Mechanicville needs is another kick to its collective head.
It was once a microcosm of American industry, with paper rollers humming 24 hours a day at the Westvaco mill, freight trains rumbling through one of the country's largest railroad transfer stations, and streets bustling with immigrants and their children. The city may not have been as vital as Albany, 20 miles to the southwest, but it had a sense of place, and commemorated many of the local men who died in World War II with a plaque inside the elementary school. There are 44 names.
Now, the evidence of decline can be found in the census statistics kept in City Hall -- the population of 5,000 is less than half of what it was in the 1920's -- and in City Hall itself, where white paint peels from the facade. Even the tornado that tore through here in 1998, causing $50 million in damage, seemed almost gratuitously cruel. Did it really have to knock over one of the old mill's smokestacks?
Mechanicville survived that twister just as it has survived all the other setbacks. The school district began to build a new elementary school, scheduled to open in the fall of 2003. Local officials were still wondering what to do with the old school when there came an inquiry from Canada.
Within days, Mr. Henry was in Mechanicville, laying out his proposal. He would transform the school building into a center where police and municipal officials from around the country would come to learn Cogesur's computer-software program for emergency preparedness. Instead of youngsters learning long division, the school would have classrooms of adults learning to prepare for "floods, bioterrorism, earthquakes, bombs," Mr. Henry said.
Mr. Henry, 44, who said he was a former paramedic with a background in software, said that the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 had highlighted the need for "homeland security," and that governments would be spending billions to secure their communities. "Billions of dollars," he said. "Billions. B, as in boy."
The entrepreneur has six other partners, and his company's Web site (cogesur.com) sports the logos of other Canadian companies, including Novasys, which specializes in online learning and management. Mario Robert, the president of Novasys, said that he had met with people from Cogesur about a year ago -- "They have good people in the company" -- but had not heard from them since.
"What I told them was you get a contract, we will deliver the product," Mr. Robert said. But, he added, "We have no link with those people."
The biggest issue, of course, is money. Mr. Henry said that a "group of venture capitalists" planned to invest $20 million in the next month or so; he declined to identify the investors, other than to say that they were "mostly big banks" in the United States that were interested in getting in on a growth industry. 
He said he was working out of the office of a public relations firm, K2 Communications, that Cogesur would buy once the money came through. Philippe Dorget, a co-owner of K2 and the vice president for communications for Cogesur, confirmed this arrangement.
But why Mechanicville? "I always joke with the people of Mechanicville," Mr. Henry said. "It's the smallest city in the state of New York but if you draw a circle of a three-hour drive from it you have access to 100 million people."
The school board quickly approved a plan to sell the school and its five-acre riverfront property for $1, with the understanding that Cogesur would pay $350,000 to the school district over the next year -- and on the condition that the proposal pass a local referendum. City officials, meanwhile, are doing background checks and holding their breath; the issue is so fragile that Mayor Thomas J. Higgins declined to talk about it.
But Joseph Waldron, the police chief, said that he especially liked Mr. Henry's proposal that the small Police Department be moved out of City Hall's basement and into the training center, to be held up as a model of Cogesur efficiency. "We're cramped in a place where we have the boiler for all of City Hall," he said. "And when it rains, it all pours down the street and somehow makes its way to the police station."
More important, the whole city would benefit, he said.
But Chief Waldron is hedging his exuberance. "It's like any start-up company," he said. "It could be the greatest thing in the world, or it could be a flop. We've been burned before."
Paul J. Loatman Jr., the city's historian and a former school board member, is among the more skeptical people in town. He said that Mr. Henry had given the city no evidence that he had any financial backing at all, and yet Mechanicville is poised, basically, to give him five acres of riverfront property.
"I love this community, but I don't suspend my judgment," Mr. Loatman said. "This is a great place to raise a family, but your kids get educated, there's nothing here for them, so they leave. That's the way it's been for a generation.
"You don't want to rain on this guy's parade. But we don't need another Bob John Ray, Billy Bob Ray, whoever the heck that was."

Upstate
Articles in this series are exploring upstate New York in the gubernatorial election year. A previous article, about a proposal for video lottery terminals in Saratoga Springs, is available on the Web: nytimes.com/metro.
