HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Surge, Driven by Signs of a Strong U.S. Recovery

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks jumped yesterday as a rise in factory orders and a survey of business conditions gave fresh evidence that a strong economic rebound was in the making.
 "The market continues to get strength from economic numbers," said Michael Palazzi, co-head of equity trading for CIBC World Markets. 
 Wireless stocks were among the best performers after Sprint, the No. 3 long-distance telephone company, reaffirmed its 2002 financial outlook for its long-distance and Sprint PCS wireless divisions. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index hit its first four-day winning streak since early November. 
"People feared the worst but it seems the underlying fundamentals are intact," said Seth Tobias, who oversees $500 million in hedge funds for Circle T Partners.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 140.88 points, or 1.35 percent, to 10,574.29, pushed higher by J. P. Morgan Chase.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 16.63 points, or 1.45 percent, to 1,162.77, closing at its highest level since Jan. 7. The Nasdaq climbed 24.11 points, or 1.29 percent, to 1,890.39.
Market breadth was positive, especially on the New York Stock Exchange where 11 stocks rose for every 4 that declined. Nasdaq advancers beat losers 11 to 6.
Recent economic data have pointed to an uptick in economic activity.
A reading on United States orders for manufactured goods showed a rise of 1.6 percent in January, beating expectations.
The economy showed hints in the first two months of the year that it was recovering from recession, the Federal Reserve said yesterday in its beige book, an anecdotal report card on economic conditions across the country.
"People have responded to better economic data in hopes that will help corporate profits," said Kevin Logan, senior market economist for Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein.
J. P. Morgan Chase jumped $1.54, to $34.05, after Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown raised its rating to strong buy from buy.
Sprint rose $1.27, to $15.83, after saying its wireless business would add more subscribers in the first quarter than analysts were expecting. Its wireless unit, Sprint PCS, bolted $1.92 higher, to $11.47.
Nextel Communications rose 80 cents, to $6.28, after its chief financial officer said he was confident about meeting forecasts for full-year cash flow and subscriber growth.
AT&T Wireless Services was the most active issue on the Big Board and rose 74 cents, to $9.27.
Compaq Computer, the acquisition target of Hewlett-Packard, rose 40 cents, to $10.98. Hewlett lost 42 cents, to $20.18.
Hewlett won crucial backing on Tuesday for its $22 billion bid to acquire Compaq when a leading adviser to major investors urged shareholders to approve the contested deal. The vote is two weeks away. 
ImClone Systems, which agreed to new terms with Bristol-Myers Squibb for their drug development partnership, jumped $4.81, to $28.63. --------------------

Treasuries Fall
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasury bonds fell yesterday after factory orders rose in January, adding to concern the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates by midyear to temper inflation.
The manufacturing report is the latest sign the economy is rebounding from a yearlong recession, which helped push the benchmark 10-year Treasury rates to a three-year low in November. Investors have sold the securities in recent days, pushing yields to levels not seen since the end of January.
By late in the day, the 10-year note fell 9/32, to a price of 98 21/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 5.05 percent from 5.01 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond also fell, dropping 22/32, to a price of 97 19/32. Its yield rose to 5.54 percent from 5.49 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
F.T.C. Clears Acquisition Of Compaq by Hewlett
The Federal Trade Commission unanimously approved Hewlett-Packard's deal to acquire Compaq Computer. The move, while expected, paved the way for a tightly contested vote of Hewlett-Packard's shareholders on March 19.
 The F.T.C. said it "did not find reason to believe that the proposed transaction would impair competition in any relevant market," and did not ask for concessions. Page C4. 

US Airways Appoints a Chief
US Airways, which like many other airlines has had financial troubles since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said it had hired David N. Siegel, 40, left, a former executive at Continental Airlines and chairman of Avis, as president and chief executive. He succeeds Stephen M. Wolf, who reassumed the post after Rakesh Gangwal resigned in November. C4.

Swift Microsoft Settlement Urged
The Bush administration and nine states urged a federal judge to swiftly approve their settlement of the Microsoft antitrust case. C6.

Deficits Expected in Federal Budget
Officials said the rapidly recovering economy should improve the federal budget outlook a bit but probably not enough to avoid deficits for at least the next few years. A22.

Little Optimism From Steel Users
Across the country, users of steel are starting to assess the implications of the Bush administration's decision to impose tariffs of 8 percent to 30 percent on much imported steel. Few seem optimistic. C4.

A trade dispute between Russia and the United States escalated. World Business, Section W.

Brothers Vie for Global Crossing
A second Los Angeles investment firm confirmed that it was planning a bid for Global Crossing in a move that would pit one brother against another. C6.

Stock Gauges Rise More Than 1%
Stocks rose broadly. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 140.88 points, or 1.4 percent, to 10,574.29. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 16.63 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,162.77. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 24.11 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,890.39. C9.

Sabre Wants Rest of Travelocity
Sabre Holdings once owned all of Travelocity .com, an online system that sells airline tickets. Then it decided to acquire a rival online service, Preview Travel. That deal was structured as a merger of Preview into Travelocity, with Sabre owning 70 percent. Now Sabre wants to buy the remaining 30 percent at $23 a share. Market Place. C8.

9.8% Drop in Major Media Spending
Ad spending in major media fell 9.8 percent last year, to $94.3 billion, more than first feared. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

G.O.P. Senators Consider Fuel Plan
Senator John McCain and other Republicans appeared to be close to signing on to a modified proposal from Senate Democrats to raise federal fuel economy standards. An agreement would increase the measure's chances of survival as part of the Senate's energy bill. C8.

VW Tackles Ultra-Luxury Market
Volkswagen executives gave a glimpse of their secret project: an all-new two-door Bentley, which will go on sale later this year for about $150,000. Volkswagen is hardly alone in entering the rarefied world of ultra-luxury cars. World Business, Section W.

Cadillac acknowledged that it had encountered engine failures on a small number of its new CTS sedans, whose success is critical to the renaissance of the venerable brand. C8.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
NATIONAL STEEL SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The National Steel Corporation filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday because of low prices and a weak economy. 
The filing came a day after the Bush administration imposed tariffs on most steel imports. National Steel, majority owned by the NKK Corporation of Tokyo, said it received a $450 million loan to continue operating plants. The company, based in Mishawaka, Ind., makes about six million tons of steel a year and has 8,400 employees. National Steel, which had $2.49 billion in sales last year, listed $2.61 billion in debt and $2.3 billion in assets, according to papers filed in bankruptcy court in Chicago. National Steel has lost money in six consecutive quarters.

HEADLINE: U.S. Duties On Steel Anger Russia 

BYLINE:  BySABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 6 

 BODY:
A trade dispute between Russia and the United States escalated today, as punitive American duties on steel from Russia -- and elsewhere -- brought angry words from officials and fresh statements about a ban on American poultry.
 The tariffs announced Tuesday by President Bush angered all the nations affected, including Japan and Germany. But in Russia, the steel duties were also seen as yet another humiliation, after disqualifications in the Olympic Games and talk of American troops in Georgia, one of Russia's least friendly neighbors -- despite Russia's support of America in its war against terrorists. 
 The tariffs affect about a third of Russia's steel exports and will cost this country $1.2 billion in revenue over the next three years, officials said today. Russia is the world's fourth-largest steel producer, and steel makes up a tenth of its total exports to the United States. 
Russia's trade and economic development minister, German O. Gref, called the sanctions "inappropriate," and said Russia might introduce retaliatory measures. But at a briefing later today, Mr. Gref's deputy, Maxim Medvedkov, said Russia would first seek legal justification for the sanctions from the United States. Both officials said the new tariffs violated two bilateral treaties.
A question mark, meanwhile, hung over Russia's ban on American poultry, which is set to begin March 10. Both Mr. Gref and Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov hinted this morning that Russia might be willing to repeal the ban on American meat -- two-thirds of Russia's supply last year.
But at a news conference later today, Russia's agriculture minister, Alexei V. Gordeyev, reiterated concerns that American poultry was full of additives. He was joined by the health minister, Yuri L. Shevchenko, who complained on Russian television that American birds cause "excessive weight, high blood pressure and other health complaints."
The ban, he added, "has nothing to do with any trade wars.
"It is just a move to ensure the health of the nation," Mr. Shevchenko continued.
The trade tensions come ahead of a planned summit meeting in May between President Vladimir V. Putin and Mr. Bush.
Steel duties have been a sore point in relations in the past. Russian officials say the government stopped handing out subsidies to the steel industry years ago -- subsidies that the United States says have helped distort the steel market. Mr. Putin is seeking membership in the World Trade Organization in part to be able to fight trade sanctions, like these steel duties, in an international forum.
While the nation was fuming about steel tariffs and joking about chicken parts -- even Mr. Kasyanov smiled slightly as he stumbled over the words at a news conference tonight in Kaliningrad -- government policy makers were reviewing what was ultimately at stake.
The products are significant exports for each country. Russia will lose $400 million a year through the new steel duties, while American farmers export about $600 million worth of poultry products to Russia annually, about 20 percent of its total exports to this country.
The United States ambassador to Russia, Alexander Vershbow, said at a briefing that Russian officials had ignored American requests to discuss concerns about the poultry, leading to the conclusion that the ban was "based more on protectionism than on legitimate safety concerns." Earlier in the day, Mr. Vershbow was summoned to Russia's foreign ministry to discuss Russian concerns about steel tariffs.
Officials here were vexed by a remark Tuesday by the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, linking the poultry ban to the repeal of the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, a 1974 economic sanction intended to pressure Communist-bloc nations to allow free emigration, particularly for Russian Jews. The amendment is obstructing Russia's entry to the World Trade Organization.
"The amendment was drawn up over restrictions on Jewish immigration from the Soviet Union; the question is, what does poultry have to do with it?" said Mikhail Margelov, chairman of the foreign affairs committee of Russia's upper house of Parliament, as quoted by the Russian news agency Interfax.
Steel producers were particularly irked by the tariffs since Russian steel exports to the United States have already plummeted by about three-quarters since 1999, when Russia agreed to restrictions to avoid American antidumping duties. That five-year trade agreement is still in force, producers said today, and new duties would mean America's unilateral withdrawal.
"Again losses, again searches for new markets," said Andrei Petrosyan, deputy general director of Novolipetsk Steel, Russia's No. 3 producer. "This is very serious."
Nine large steel companies, most of which are privately owned, produce about 85 percent of this country's steel and all of its exports. Managers of the companies say they have not received state subsidies since the mid-1990's and that they cannot afford to produce metal below cost, something American lobbyists accuse them of doing.
There was a bright spot. Novolipetsk, which last year exported 17 percent of its output to the United States, said its most important product, steel slabs, semifinished rolled steel ingots, will be helped by yesterday's measures. Slabs make up about 80 percent of the factory's revenue, and are its single biggest export to the United States.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
As recovery builds, the less educated go to the end of the employment line.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
"EVEN if the economy is on the road to recovery," Alan Greenspan warned last week, "the unemployment rate, in typical cyclical fashion, may resume its increase for a time." Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who will appear before the Senate Banking Committee today, did not mention that the lingering effects of high unemployment early in a recovery tend to be concentrated among the unskilled and minorities. This is true even though recessions are becoming more egalitarian.
 Such a pattern was evident in the early 1990's. The recession officially ended in March 1991, with the unemployment rate at 6.8 percent. But unemployment continued to rise for 15 months and did not settle below 6.8 percent again until the end of 1993. Moreover, the rate rose from 12.3 to 13.5 percent for high school dropouts in the year after the recession ended, while for college graduates it stayed at 2.9 percent. The "jobless recovery" mainly involved the less skilled. 
 In part, unemployment remains high after growth resumes simply because more people actively look for work if they think their prospects are better. Having more active job seekers and fewer discouraged workers is not a sign of weakness. For this reason, economists often prefer to focus on the employment-to-population rate -- the fraction of the population that is working.
Even with this measure, however, jobs often keep sliding after a recession ends. The employment rate did not hit bottom until nine months after the 1991 recession, and the slide was greater and lasted longer for less-skilled workers. The fraction of high school dropouts who were employed fell for three full years after the recession ended.
Jobs are slow to recover at the end of a recession because employers are not sure if improved conditions will persist, so they expand work hours rather than hire new employees. Many employers also "hoard" skilled workers during a downturn because it would be costly to hire and train replacements when conditions improve. Neither reason, however, accounts for why job growth is particularly sluggish for the less skilled when the economy picks up.
The economist Melvin Reder suggested a reason in 1955: in a downturn, many employers raise skill requirements for a given job, rather than cut pay. The less skilled thus find their job options even more limited until demand picks up smartly, while skilled workers take positions further down the job ladder.
Lawrence Katz of Harvard suggests another reason. "Think of a recession as a time when firms reorganize," he said. Reorganization tends to increase demand for skilled workers, who are more flexible. Furthermore, when companies introduce new technology as part of a reorganization, they tend to hire skilled workers to operate the equipment and release unskilled workers whose jobs are made redundant.
To some extent, the lingering pattern of unemployment after growth resumes, especially among the less skilled, is inadvertently reinforced by the major policy tool used to lift the economy out of recession -- interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. With a lag, rate cuts stimulate demand for new capital and consumer durables. But this is a two-edged sword for workers. On the one hand, a rise in economic activity increases the demand for all factors of production, including workers. On the other hand, because machinery is cheaper, many companies replace some workers with machines, or hire fewer workers, because the machines can do the work at lower cost.
What's more, capital -- especially high-technology equipment -- and skilled labor are complementary factors of production, while capital and unskilled workers can be substituted for each other. In other words, highly skilled workers are hired to operate and service new machines, while less-skilled workers are let go because the machines can do their work.
The current recession -- which many forecasters think may have already ended -- is shaping up as if it consists of two distinct phases distinguished by how skilled and unskilled workers fared. In the first phase, which lasted from March to July 2001, the employment-to-population rate fell for those with at least some college training, from 74.9 to 73.9 percent, while it actually increased slightly, from 55.1 to 55.3 percent, for those with a high school education or lower.
In the second phase -- the six months after July 2001 -- the opposite happened: the employment rate stopped falling for those with at least some college education, and dropped 1.7 percentage points for those with a high school education or lower.
A similar picture holds by race and ethnicity. At the beginning of the recession, the employment rate fell more for whites than for blacks and about the same for whites and Hispanics. Since July, however, employment has fallen more for blacks and Hispanics. Likewise, unemployment rose for whites in the first phase and held steady for blacks and Hispanics, while in the second phase unemployment is growing around twice as fast for blacks and Hispanics.
The egalitarian nature of the first phase came as a surprise but is consistent with the egalitarian tilt of the early 1990's recession. This phenomenon probably resulted from the plunge in capital investment that apparently precipitated the downturn, the implosion of many dot-coms and the fact that the cyclically sensitive manufacturing sector is much more skill intensive than it was 20 years ago.
It appears, however, that the egalitarian phase is over. If recent trends hold, job opportunities will rise or remain steady for the better educated and continue to contract for some time for the less educated and minorities.
The message to policy makers should be clear: to avoid another jobless recovery, stimulate demand for less-skilled workers. This suggests that policies that spur investment, like an accelerated capital depreciation allowance, may prove to be counterproductive; lower capital costs would increase demand for skilled workers but reduce demand for less-skilled workers.
Senator Pete V. Domenici's proposal for a temporary cut in the payroll tax, which is borne disproportionately by low-paid workers and their employers, would do much more to increase job growth.
Although many have argued that the opportunity or desirability for fiscal stimulus has ended, if the immediate goal is to avoid another jobless recovery, a temporary cut in the payroll tax still has much to offer, especially versus initiatives that would subsidize capital investment.

HEADLINE: Possible Deal Seen on Fuel Economy Measure in Senate 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 6 

 BODY:
Senator John McCain and a handful of other Republicans appeared to be close tonight to signing on to a modified proposal from Senate Democrats to raise federal fuel economy standards. An agreement would increase the measure's chances of survival as part of the Senate's energy bill. 
 Fuel economy standards have not been raised significantly since the 1980's, and the auto industry has been lobbying heavily against an increase by Congress. 
 A fuel economy proposal in the energy bill was co-sponsored by Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts and Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, both Democrats, and called for a 50 percent increase in gas mileage for the average new automobile by the 2013 model year. In striking a compromise with Senator McCain, the proposal would require roughly the same mileage improvement by the 2015 model year as well as a trading system for greenhouse gas credits, according to people close to the negotiations. 
The credits could provide automakers with some leeway in reaching the goal. The compromise version would most likely also retain requirements for tougher safety standards for rollovers as well as requirements to design pickups and sport utility vehicles to be less of a threat to passenger cars during collisions. But it would still do away with the lower separate standards that now apply to pickups and sport utility vehicles.
Such legislation is unlikely to become law given the Republican House and White House, as well as opposition from some Midwestern Democrats. Even passage by the Senate is seen as a longshot, despite renewed concerns about dependence on foreign oil. 
Last week, General Motors held rallies at truck plants in Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin against the Kerry-Hollings proposal. Company officials, as well as officials from Ford and Chrysler, have said that such a measure would have a catastrophic effect on the industry, lead to more than 100,000 lost jobs and could even lead to the extinction of pickups and sport utilities.
"It will do little or nothing for the environment but will do a hell of a lot to destroy American jobs," Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said during a G.M. rally at a truck plant in Pontiac, Mich.
Democrats and environmental groups have said that the auto industry made a similar argument when fuel standards were first proposed in the 1970's. 
"This is a job creator," Senator Kerry said during a recent news conference, arguing that the standards could push the Big Three to be more competitive with foreign automakers. Toyota and Honda have been more aggressive in pushing innovations like hybrid electric-gasoline engines. 
Senator Levin, one of the industry's closest allies, plans to introduce a proposal that would take the issue out of the hands of Congress. Instead, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, a branch of the Transportation Department, would be given a timetable to make a decision. The auto industry has lobbied in the past against the agency's making the decision but would prefer that the agency handle it under the Bush administration. Andrew Card, a former top G.M. lobbyist, is President Bush's chief of staff. 
The auto industry thinks the compromises being made with Senator McCain will leave the bill little better than where it started. 
"A two-year extension does not solve the inherent problem that combining cars and trucks together, and then raising them by 50 percent, threatens the existence of S.U.V.'s, minivans and pickup trucks as we know them today," Stuart Schorr, a spokesman for DaimlerChrysler in Washington, said in an e-mail message.
In addition to Mr. McCain, Republican Senators who are said to be considering the proposal are Olympia Snowe and Susan Collins of Maine, Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island and Gordon Smith of Oregon.
The Bush administration has said that the Senate energy bill's fuel economy proposals are one of its flaws.
The proposal "would contribute to many thousands of additional passenger fatalities and injuries," according to a statement released by the Office of Management and Budget earlier this week. 
A study by the N.H.T.S.A. showed that reducing the weight of vehicles to increase fuel economy could also lead to hundreds of additional fatalities. But a more recent study, sponsored by Honda indicated that such reductions would not increase traffic fatalities and might even lower them.

PERSON: Hugh Morris Gloster 

HEADLINE: Hugh Gloster, 90, Ex-President of Morehouse 

 BODY:
Hugh Morris Gloster, who as president of the historically black Morehouse College greatly strengthened its endowment and faculty in the civil rights era, died on Feb. 16 in Decatur, Ga. He was 90.
 As Morehouse's seventh president and the first graduate to lead the school, he served from 1967 to 1986, as most predominantly black colleges faced new challenges as a result of the civil rights movement. Many previously all-white institutions began recruiting the best black students, forcing black colleges to compete while also facing the economic difficulties of the 70's. 
 Under Dr. Gloster's leadership at Morehouse, the campus doubled in size, as did the number of faculty members and their salaries. Faculty members holding Ph.D.'s increased to 65 percent of the total. Enrollment, meanwhile, doubled, and the endowment quadrupled to $29 million.
The fields of study were also increased, with the addition of an international studies program, a school of medicine and eight major fields in the department of business.
Dr. Gloster was also an author who often lectured on American literature and education. He wrote "Negro Voices in American Fiction," in print since 1948, and "My Life -- My Country -- My World" (1952) which became a standard anthology in college literature courses.
Hugh Morris Gloster was born May 11, 1911, in Brownsville, Tenn. He spent his early years in Memphis, where his father was a principal and teacher. After earning his bachelor's degree from Morehouse in 1931, he earned a master's degree from Atlanta University in 1933. He taught at LeMoyne-Owen College until 1941 and then at Morehouse until 1943, when he also earned a Ph.D. from New York University. He then worked for the United Service Organizations in Arizona and Atlanta.
At the Hampton Institute in Virginia, he rose to become the dean of faculty and helped the college raise $21 million. 
Dr. Gloster was a Fulbright professor of English at Hiroshima University in Japan and in the international educational exchange program at the University of Warsaw in Poland. He was also a member of several presidential commissions. 
Dr. Gloster was chosen by Benjamin Mays, the previous president of Morehouse, to succeed him, with the assent of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was on the board of trustees. 
Survivors include his wife of 45 years, Yvonne King Gloster; their daughters, Alice Burnette and Evelyn Dawkins; their son, Dr. Hugh M. Gloster Jr.; 4 stepchildren; 11 grandchildren; and 4 great-grandchildren.
"The tradition that Dr. Gloster helped create has benefited all black educational institutions," said Pat Swygert, president of Howard University, another top black college, who added that "the first two African-American presidents of Howard University, Mordecai Wyatt Johnson and James Nabrit Jr., were Morehouse men."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 12, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Thursday about Hugh Morris Gloster, former president of Morehouse College, omitted the names of his previous wives and misstated the length of his marriage to Yvonne Arnold King, who survives. Dr. Gloster's first marriage, to Louise Elisabeth Torrence, ended in divorce. In 1957 he married Beulah Victoria Harold, who died in 1985. Dr. Gloster and Ms. King were married in 1989, not 45 years ago.

HEADLINE: House Republicans Try Again for Bill on Tax Cut for Business 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- With evidence growing by the day that the recession is over, Republican leaders in the House made a last-ditch effort today to enact tax cuts for businesses this year by tying them to increased unemployment benefits.
 In their most serious effort yet to break a monthslong partisan deadlock, Republicans said they would bring to the House floor on Thursday a pared-down package of measures intended to help the economy, including tax breaks for companies that invest in new factories and equipment and a 13-week extension of unemployment benefits beyond the current 26-week limit. 
 The Democratic-controlled Senate has been pressing the House for weeks to give up on cutting taxes and pass an extension of unemployment benefits by itself. Democratic leaders said they were not sure whether the new House bill would lead to a bipartisan compromise. 
The maneuvering came as the Congressional Budget Office said today that the rapidly recovering economy should improve the federal budget outlook a bit but probably not enough to avoid deficits for at least the next few years.
The political calculus for both parties is changing along with the economic outlook.
Senator Kent Conrad, the North Dakota Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said today that he would try to come up with a balanced budget plan for the next fiscal year, reflecting his party's reluctance to give up its self-appointed role as guardian of fiscal discipline. But Mr. Conrad said reaching his goal would require him to use the Bush administration's economic and technical assumptions about the budget, which are more optimistic than those of the Congressional Budget Office. 
"It's a heavy lift," Mr. Conrad said.
Representative Jim Nussle, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said he had not ruled out a balanced budget for next year either. But he said his first priorities were to provide the money necessary to fight the war on terrorism, improve domestic security and put the economy on sound footing.
Nearly every economic indicator for the last few weeks has suggested that the economic downturn last year had given way to a robust recovery. Dan L. Crippen, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the Senate Budget Committee today that the economy was "rebounding in a remarkable fashion."
Mr. Crippen said the strong pace of recovery should add more than $100 billion to the budget office's surplus estimate over the next decade, bringing it to $2.38 trillion.
The budget office projected that if Congress and the Bush administration made no changes to current tax or spending policy, the $2 trillion federal budget would eke out a $5 billion surplus this year and $6 billion next year. A little more than a month ago the budget office projected a $21 billion deficit for this year and a $14 billion deficit for next year.
But because spending increases are a foregone conclusion, and further tax cuts remain a possibility, those surpluses are all but certain to disappear. 
President Bush is about to ask for more money for the war on terrorism. Both parties have long lists of spending requests for years to come. Extending unemployment benefits would cost $8.5 billion this year, and if the two parties agreed on the full package of economic measures to be taken up by the House on Thursday, it would cost $51 billion this year.
White House officials said the new budget projections were evidence that the tax cut pushed through Congress last year by President Bush was helping the economy and gradually restoring the budget surplus.
But House Republicans said the plan they would bring to the floor on Thursday would do much less for the economy than the three previous economic packages they had passed since last fall, all of which have been blocked in the Senate.
The decision by Republicans to drop some of the more contentious provisions of their package -- most notably an acceleration of planned income tax rate reductions -- reflected a growing consensus within the party that time may be running out for delivering on their promise of tax cuts for business.
Twice in recent months, the Senate has unanimously passed extensions of unemployment insurance, a step routinely agreed to by both parties in past recessions. Democrats have been putting increasing pressure on Republicans in the House to decouple their demand for tax cuts from the unemployment insurance extension, saying that hundreds of thousands of people a month are exhausting their unemployment benefits before they can find a new job.
Although the economy is growing again, unemployment tends to continue rising for at least the first several months of a recovery, and so far the historical pattern seems to be repeating itself in this business cycle.
The new House bill would allow businesses to write off an additional 30 percent of their investments in new factories and equipment for the next three years, a step intended to address one of the weakest aspects of the economy. 
The House bill would also create tax breaks for rebuilding lower Manhattan and extend a variety of longstanding deductions and credits that expired at the end of last year.
In addition to stripping out some of the tax cuts previously sought by Republicans, it would also drop a provision championed by Democrats, a one-time payment of up to $300 for low- and middle-income workers who did not get a rebate under the tax cut signed into law last year by President Bush.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Anew report says ad spending in major media fell 9.8 percent last year, more than first thought.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott and Allison Fass 

 BODY:
ADVERTISING activity in major media fell even more than had been feared last year, according to a report released yesterday by a company that tracks ad spending by marketers.
 Still, life goes on for Madison Avenue, particularly as signs begin to emerge of a nascent recovery in ad spending. Indeed, two large advertisers are making decisions on their accounts, with combined spending estimated at $160 million to $175 million. 
 The tracking company, CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres, reported that ad spending in major media fell 9.8 percent last year, to $94.3 billion, in contrast to a record $104.5 billion in 2000. Estimates of the decline in ad spending last year had previously ranged from 4 percent to 8 percent for media outlets like national television, newspapers, radio, magazines and outdoor. 
"Looking back, 2001 was an extraordinary year for the advertising industry," said David Peeler, president and chief executive at CMR in New York, because of the dot-com bust as well as "the downward turn in the economy, budget cuts, agency consolidations and the tremendous cuts in television advertising in the days following Sept. 11."
National newspapers suffered the largest decline in ad revenue last year among the major media, according to the report, down 23 percent. Of the 12 categories tracked by CMR, 2 had spending gains: cable television, up 1 percent, and nationally syndicated TV programs, up 0.1 percent.
General Motors remained the largest American advertiser in 2001, CMR reported, spending almost $2.2 billion. That was despite G.M.'s cutting of its ad budget by 25.4 percent, the largest percentage drop of any advertiser in the top 10. Other advertisers that significantly reduced their ad budgets included Philip Morris, at $1.38 billion, down 23.4 percent, and DaimlerChrysler, at $1.39 billion, down 17.3 percent.
Other estimates of ad spending for 2001 are scheduled to be released in the spring. That data will include spending in media not tracked by CMR, like direct marketing and Internet advertising.
Turning to the advertisers that made decisions on their accounts, one was the Wachovia Corporation and the other was the California State Lottery.
Wachovia, the nation's fourth-largest bank, will consolidate its account, with combined spending estimated at $60 million to $75 million, at Mullen/LHC, an office of Mullen in Winston-Salem, N.C.
Wachovia was acquired in 2001 by First Union, which for the last six years used Publicis & Hal Riney in San Francisco, part of the Publicis Groupe. Before then, Wachovia used, also for six years, Mullen/LHC, formerly known as Long Haymes Carr. The combined company operates under the Wachovia name.
The consolidation of accounts came after a six-week "shootout" between Riney and Mullen/LHC, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to determine which would be the agency of record for the combined company. With the decision, Riney has lost its second major account in five weeks, coming after the agency was dismissed by the Saturn division of General Motors.
Mullen/LHC "matched us as far as chemistry, cultural fit and creative ideas," said Shika Raynor, a spokeswoman for Wachovia in Charlotte, N.C. 
Erwin-Penland in Greenville, S.C., will continue handling secondary advertising assignments for Wachovia.
As for the California lottery, its account is being placed in review again, two months after lottery officials tentatively named a new agency. Spending was estimated at $100 million for a four-year contract.
The move came after the incumbent agency for five years, the Los Angeles office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, protested the decision to award the contract provisionally to the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, claiming that the review had been mishandled.
"During the course of the protest some facts came to light," said Jim Hasegawa, marketing director at the lottery in Sacramento, concerning the omission of required information from the agencies listing the names of executives at the sibling shops that would handle the media buying duties for the account. For DDB, that would be OMD, and for Grey, that would be MediaCom.
As a result, Mr. Hasegawa said, "it's in the lottery's best interest and the public's best interest" to review the account again.
David Park, chief executive at DDB Los Angeles, described the agency as frustrated and disappointed, but added, "We'll go along with whatever their rulings are -- we must -- with a smile on our face."
Another request for agencies to submit proposals will be sent within a month, Mr. Hasegawa said. The contract with Grey expires on June 30. Both Grey and DDB are expected to take part in the second review.

HEADLINE: MY MANHATTAN; 
Like Italy, Only Not Far Away

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LOURIE; Richard Lourie's latest book, "Sakharov: A Biography," is being published this month.

 BODY:
The Italians invented hanging out. The design of their towns and cities draws people together. Once, outside a train station in a small Italian town, I observed this scene: There was one customer in the outdoor cafe. A second arrived, scanned the dozen or so tables, then sat at a table next to the one already occupied. That probably would not have happened in the United States, except in places like Carmine Street in Greenwich Village, where the old traditions still live, even as they morph into more modern form.
 Carmine Street is in many ways exceptional, even eccentric. Unlike most streets in the Mondrianesque parallelogram of Manhattan, Carmine does not run east-west or north-south but cuts at an angle from Seventh Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas. It is only three blocks long. Both of those facts define its nature. 
 It is an obvious shortcut from one avenue to the next and yet, because it is so short, it never accumulated any of the piercing-and-bong-shop tackiness of Bleecker Street, which it intersects briefly and obliquely before emptying like a small tributary into the Avenue of the Americas. It's a village within the Village. 
It is best seen, and entered, from Seventh Avenue. From there it has the aspect of a pleasant street in a minor European city -- trees, awnings, sidewalk stands in all but the worst of weather, the copper oxidized green dome and cross of Our Lady of Pompei both anchoring and elevating the view. Perfect for a watercolor.
Its length makes it ideal for strolling and its one side street, Bedford, invites exploration with its minuscule cafes, unusual stores and a nearby chic restaurant, which is all alone on a residential block. Of course, like nearly everything else, Carmine Street is best enjoyed in lovely weather, but there is another aspect of the street that makes it appealing even on frigid days. Its smallness creates cozy intimacy, hominess. It is there in the easy ambience of the small shops cheek by jowl, some plain and utilitarian, some exotic like the East Corner Company, which has lovely treasures from the dynasties of China, and in the cuisine of its many restaurants, mostly a mix of traditional Italian and trendier Asian.
It is a real Greenwich Village street, not one tarted up for tourists. This is a difference that might be defined as that between a street with shoe stores and a street with only a cobbler. The cobbler of Carmine Street is Misha or Mike, depending on which nickname you prefer, who is from Odessa, Russia's Brooklyn. A stream of emigres from the former Soviet Union have passed through Magic Shoe Repair, shining shoes, working their way into America with a rag, polish and hungry energy. Like all Odessans, everything reminds Misha of a joke. But he transplants not only jokes from Russia, but tomatoes as well, and he becomes suddenly rapt and poetic as he describes their skin -- delicate, pale red -- the juicy plumpness within. 
But Misha's reverie is interrupted by a gleaming black Jaguar that pulls up in front of his store. A long-legged supermodel emerges. She's a regular customer and the banter begins at once, reaching a particularly sprightly pace when she is seated on the shoeshine chair and Misha is fitting her midcalf-high elegant boots, an experience certainly superior to selling a pair of shoelaces. And then she is gone like the kiss she blows at the door. A sudden windfall of beauty, grace, the excitement of celebrity and the great world. Carmine Street may be cozy and enclosed but this is still, after all, Manhattan. 
The heart of the little community of Carmine Street is the intersection with Bleecker, formed by Joe's Pizza and Father Demo Square, Our Lady of Pompei and Trattoria Spaghetto. Joe's is a no-nonsense joint if "nonsense" means tables. You can eat standing up or take your food to go. 
Either way, it's well worth it, pizza that is both genuine and tasty, the slices that New Yorkers transplanted to other states can only dream of. Most of the year, a good portion of the slices are consumed in Father Demo Square; though improvements are to be made, it is an undistinguished square of paving, benches and scraggly trees frequented by pensioners, pigeons and assorted urban jetsam. Though essentially wedged into the Avenue of the Americas, it still manages to provide a small miracle of tranquillity. 
The church was itself founded in 1927, replacing St. Benedict the Moor, which had served black residents until they were replaced by Italian immigrants in the late 19th century. But even before this, when the neighborhood residents were predominantly black, the street was at times integrated: Aaron Burr resided at property he owned there and the poet William Cullen Bryant lived there, as did Edgar Allan Poe (at a perfect address for him: 113 1/2).
The streets and the church are integrated again. That the church is a living institution I had occasion to witness while reading historical material that a woman in the rectory office had given me. Suddenly, the door opened and a handsome middle-aged woman in a fur coat entered, her eyes glistening with high emotion.
"I tried the church door and it was locked," she said.
By way of explanation, the woman in the rectory said, "They're working in there now." 
The first woman said: "But I really need to be in church! I really need it!" 
To which she was told, "Follow me."
In the window of Trattoria Spaghetto is a thank you note from the children of Our Lady of Pompei School for "helping us maintain high standards." That would seem to indicate that the school and the restaurant are knit together in the same community, but that impression would be illusory. The street has been largely de-Italianated. Nearly all the students in the parochial school are bused in. The families who made this an Italian street, even, said one resident, 90 percent Sicilian, are long gone to the suburbs.
There are very few left from the old days who can still remember when the Avenue of the Americas ended just a little south of Carmine, when the street was cobbled and rang with the wheels of peddlers' horse-drawn carts and the movies were all black-and-white. But there are a few last Mohicans and they preserve the honorable tradition of dolce far niente, sitting or standing around, talking; in a word, hanging out.
Where the old-timers congregate is determined by the precise position of the sun. In the blaze of summer they seek out the shade of a playground in a courtyard invisible from the street. In the more temperate weather they will move their metal folding chairs out onto the sidewalk, every day a parade if you know how to look. As the Earth tilts away from the sun in autumn, they move across the street on Carmine to enjoy the best of the scant rays on the church steps. 
But no matter where they are, the same rules apply: the talk must be fast, vigorous, jokey, argumentative, anything but boring. The group is exclusively male, with five to eight men, though sometimes a woman will drift over for a time and she is always treated with gallantry both while she is there and after she is gone. 
The subject of the conversations can range from an argument about what restaurant was there before the last two to the fine points of a boxer with the marvelous name Unknown Winston. Someone might recall the peddler who sold fruit off a wagon or their memories might be considerably more contemporary because some of them, having moved to the church step side on Sept. 11, had a clear vision of the Avenue of the Americas as a passenger jet roared over it low heading due south. 
Carmine Street may be something of a place apart, but it is still part of Lower Manhattan and its economic blood is only slowly rebuilding its strength. As the owner of the Magic Carpet restaurant said, "People are going to restaurants less and to Middle Eastern restaurants even less." 
A shame because the spinach pie there is especially subtle and the Saturday belly dancer is especially sinuous and is not of the overly fleshy sort perhaps because she is Norwegian by extraction. But that fits just right on Carmine Street, where the Chinese manager of the Village Laundry and Cleaner speaks with a Caribbean accent, pure smiling Calypso.
Though the old-timers still wield a certain proprietary authority, it is not their street anymore. As one of them, who has lived for almost seven decades on Carmine Street, says with an amazement that is both good-humored and tragic, "I'm a stranger on the block."
Now it belongs to the young people who have inundated the neighborhood. It is they who frequent the Unoppressive Nonimperialist Bargain Books store whose remainders lean to Kerouac and Eastern Zen masters. The store is not, however, antiexpansionist, having just taken over the shop next door to make a children's book annex.
It is the young who patronize Evergreen, one of the best video stores anywhere and the several vinyl-only stores; it is they who pack the Grey Dog's Coffee restaurant for its zesty stews and soups and the new restaurant, Deborah, which some days posts this notice: "Life is too short to eat bad food with unhappy people." They also favor the Asian restaurants like Yama because the food is exotic, low in calories, hip and healthful. Do Hwa, a Korean restaurant, has united two of the street's new aspects and has a D.J. sampling vinyl in the bar area, though not everyone will find kimchee and hip-hop the most auspicious combination. 
The youth culture of Carmine Street is bohemian in an easy, natural, even somehow wholesome way; few flaunt tattoos, whose bearers have no idea that in time those colors will run like Sunday comics left out in the rain. (Inks may have improved but flesh hasn't.) Though de Kooning lived here for a time, the street feels more like a musicians' than a painters' quarter. 
Music flows out of vinyl stores and people are usually on stools testing out some chords in Carmine Street Guitars, a building, one of three in a row, that dates from the 1820's, where stringed instruments by the dozen are suspended from the ceiling, angels in guitar heaven. 
The demographics are more mixed in the Italian restaurants like Trattoria Spaghetto, Cent'Anni, Marinella and Nostro Sapore. Some of the clientele are from other parts of Manhattan out for some Village Italian, the nice little place on a quiet side street. There are always out-of-towners seduced by guide-book prose. Some diners are from the old neighborhood, back in the city for one reason or another, who feel it a shame not to go back, walk around, have something to eat. Nostalgia and red sauce. 
Carmine Street is still changing. Twenty years from now one of today's vinyl-and-video neo-Beats may be deriding the SoHo-ization of Carmine Street, able to remember when it was still good little stores and interesting places to eat. One resident of the neighborhood, Karen Kramer, is making an epic effort to capture local history on film in a documentary, "The Ballad of Greenwich Village," which spans the whole history from 1811, when New York decided to adopt the grid system of streets and Greenwich Village declined to participate in anything so rectilinear -- that is, square -- to the present. She fights the classic battle of the documentarian, scratching for dollars even as people and places vanish, a cafe folds, a poet dies. 
For now it is the old-timers by the church steps who keep the past alive and the pace fast and furious: "No, that wasn't Unknown Winston; it was another guy. What's his name? What the hell is his name?"

HEADLINE: Notes From Fayetteville; 
North Carolina Under Friendly Fire

BYLINE:  By Catherine Lutz; Catherine Lutz, author of "Homefront: A Military City and the American 20th Century," is a professor of anthropology at the University of North Carolina.

DATELINE: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. 

 BODY:
At a quiet rural crossroads 25 miles northwest of the Army's Fort Bragg, a local lawman shot two soldiers on a Special Forces training exercise two weeks ago Saturday, killing one. The deputy feared for his life when the soldiers -- dressed in flannel shirts and jeans and failing to identify themselves -- grabbed for an automatic rifle in their bag. The soldiers wrongly assumed that the sheriff was in Pineland with them, Pineland being the imaginary country where these exercises have taken place over the last 50 years.
 By the Army's and most locals' accounting, the problem was a simple miscommunication. But the accident raises questions about the size and scale, invisibility, and day-to-day home-front impact of America's military -- the largest armed force the world has ever seen. 
 I first became aware of Pineland while researching Fayetteville, a city just to the east of Fort Bragg. Pineland has been imagined in great anthropological detail for use in these war games, its "country guide" describing a parallel universe to Fayetteville. Pineland has a small elite, a hospitable culture and struggling, honest poor folks with hearts and minds ready to be won. The report provides cultural advice for soldiers to avoid alienating the locals, as well as contact information for friendlies. In the war game's standard scenario, American forces assist a rebel David in overthrowing a tyrannous Goliath and liberating Pineland -- a kind of miniature American Revolution.
Beneath this imaginary plot lie very different stories of what United States forces have done in Guatemala, Vietnam or El Salvador, where the scenario has been different: propping up unpopular governments or assisting local militaries and paramilitaries in terrorizing civilians. And beneath Pineland's imaginary geography in North Carolina there are some complicated real places. They include Fayetteville, close to the vast fort's barracks side, and 10 rural counties, on the opposite boundary, where the games are mainly played.
Like many in military cities, Fayetteville's people mainly get by on low-paying retail jobs selling bath mats, tattoos or movie tickets to soldiers. Unemployment is high as residents tread water in a labor pool enlarged by military spouses and teenagers, and they cope with municipal budgets weakened by the fort's tax-free land and post-exchange shopping. The challenge to democracy comes not from the shadowy figures of Pineland but from low voter-registration rates -- most soldiers retain residency in their hometowns.
At the same time, soldiers are paid on a very egalitarian wage scale, which makes for a substantial middle class, and the city is more diverse than most in the South. That is the legacy of a century of war and an empire of American bases: French, German, Korean, Okinawan and Filipino floats all go by in the city's annual International Folk Festival. The pioneers in these groups probably came as spouses, but then relatives arrived and new communities grew.
The military mission here trumps all other public concerns and institutions. Political leaders around Fort Bragg have complained, to no avail, about jets that fly so low over some neighborhoods that children can see the pilots in their cockpits.
Playing the roles of Pineland's people does not pay a wage. Most in the area feel they are making a patriotic contribution when their land is used as a training ground and they become used to armed men with camo-painted faces appearing in their backyards. (The exercises are held four times a year, with about 100 soldiers participating each time.) When I visited recently, the men and women at the convenience store in Robbins talked about the accident and then switched to the recent shuttering of the town's furniture plant, hosiery mill and trailer factory. As jobs disappear, the Special Forces will have fewer hearts and minds to practice on in Pineland, and the student-soldiers may come across more bitter people like the man I met a few miles from Robbins. He was flying two large Confederate battle flags in front of his auto-repair yard and a sign that read, "This is not Mexico." His messages flew in the face of his Latino neighbors who work at the local Perdue plant, which has gone from three shifts to one.
War remains a hygienic fantasy for most Americans. The real costs of war and war preparations in lives and communities, at home or abroad, can remain distant from our everyday experience. The hollowing out of the real communities underneath Pineland reminds me of what Dwight Eisenhower said nearly 50 years ago, around the time when the Special Forces games first began under a cloud of apprehension about foreign attack. Watching the growing military budget and the effect of military industries on government, he feared the "great influence, almost an insidious penetration of our own minds that the only thing this country is engaged in is weaponry." As our current president proposes monumental increases in military expenditures and the numbers of the poor grow in Fort Bragg's shadow, Eisenhower's fears should be our own as well.

HEADLINE: More Graduates Mired in Debt, Survey Finds 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7 

 BODY:
Two out of 3 students must now borrow money to attend college, and 4 out of 10 face unmanageable debts as they finish college and enter the job market, according to a report released today.
 The report, by the lobbying arm of State Public Interest Research Groups, a nonprofit organization that studies social policy, found that debt among students doubled between 1992 and 2000, when the average graduate left college owing nearly $17,000 in educational loans. The figures are not adjusted for inflation, which remained low in that period. 
 Tracey King, an author of the report, said that higher education remained "a great investment," increasing a graduate's income over the course of a lifetime by more than $1 million. 
"At the same time," Ms. King said, "students are having a hard time when they're graduating with all this debt and the payments are a high percentage of their income."
The report, based on data from the Census Bureau and the Department of Education's National Center for Education Statistics, found that the share of students borrowing to finance their education rose substantially, to 59 percent in 1996 from 42 percent in 1992. During that period, federal financing through Pell grants shrank as tuition rose. 
Though Pell grants increased after 1996, the educational debt of graduating seniors jumped to $16,928 in 2000 from $9,188 in 1992.
A third of students graduate owing more than $20,000 in education loans, and nearly half of all student borrowers graduate with credit card debts that average $3,176. By 2000, 64 percent of students relied on loans to help finance their education.
The report defines an unmanageable educational debt as one draining more than 8 percent of a person's monthly income. The report said this was a standard definition used by the loan industry.
Alyssa Ferree, a student at the University of California at Davis, said she had hoped to become a teacher or a social worker after graduating in 2004 with a degree in community and regional development. In California, New York and elsewhere in the country, school systems face a severe shortage of teachers, and the recruitment of fresh talent has been a priority of policy makers.
But with her student loans set to reach $15,000 by graduation day, Ms. Ferree said she would have to aim for a better paying job after leaving college. 
"When I entered college I knew I'd have debt," Ms. Ferree said, "but I didn't expect it to be this much."

HEADLINE: If Jobs Are Gone for Good, What Good Are Benefits? 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: SOUTH BOSTON, Va., March 1 

 BODY:
For 13 years, Amy Altman worked at the JPS Apparel Fabrics plant here, and wound up earning $9.50 an hour. With production grinding toward a halt early last year, she began working one week on and one off, and on the off weeks she collected a $224 unemployment check. When the plant closed on Aug. 1, letting 346 workers go, the checks continued.
But in October, they stopped. Her eligibility, limited to six months, had expired. Creditors phoned. "When would I pay?" she recalls them asking. "Did I know I was late? I had nothing to pay nothing with." 
 Ms. Altman, 42, a divorced mother of two grown children, filed for bankruptcy. The judge let her keep her mobile home and her 1992 Chevrolet Cavalier, its blue paint rubbing off. Since moving in with her fiance, a 27-year veteran of JPS who has found work driving trucks, she has put the mobile home and its half-acre of land up for sale. She is asking $39,000. 
 The unemployment insurance program that ran out for Ms. Altman, just as it has run out for hundreds of thousands of other Americans since the onset of the recession that hit in early 2001, has been around for 67 years, as long as welfare. It was conceived as a lifeline to pull laid-off workers through recessions, granting them cash until their jobs came back or they found new ones, for a maximum of 26 weeks. In the last five recessions before this one, Congress routinely extended benefits, to 39 weeks. A bill passed by the House on Thursday would do so again. 
But even as Congress moves toward an extension this time around, a larger question about the program remains: whether for many beneficiaries, including hundreds here in this industrial string of towns in far southern Virginia, it still works as intended.
Previously, factories in this part of the country weathered recessions by reducing the work force and then bringing employees back when the economy revived. This time, however, the plants are shutting down, for good, leaving no jobs to bring workers back to.
Even as the national economy shows signs of rebounding, jobs here are leaving faster than they are coming, bloating welfare rolls as the tally of unemployed workers who have exhausted their benefits grows.
Unemployment in this area exceeds 10 percent, the level of a deep recession and almost twice the national rate. In Martinsville, it is 20 percent. In Danville, the area's biggest town, the number of laid-off workers jumped to 5,160 last December from 1,680 the December before.
What new jobs there are, in fields like warehousing and telemarketing, pay less than the old ones: $6 to $10 an hour (as against $9 to $15), or about what people laid off from the old jobs collect in unemployment benefits.
Small furniture companies have closed in all these towns. In Clarksville, the Russell Stover candy plant has also shut down this winter, eliminating 700 jobs. But it is the closing of textile and apparel factories that has done the most damage. 
In January, Burlington Industries said it would permanently shut four American plants, including one in Clarksville and another in nearby Halifax. Just over two years ago, the Tultex Corporation, then the biggest employer in Martinsville, filed for bankruptcy, shutting plants there and in South Boston, with the loss of 2,400 jobs. This year Vanity Fair Imagewear, which employs 2,300 people near Martinsville, is closing. 
In most cases, the reason is competition from foreign goods. With adoption of the North American Free Trade Agreement nine years ago acting as a spur, more and more shirts, dresses and cloth are being imported rather being churned out here. 
"More imports have meant more exhaustion of unemployment benefits," said Joyce Snead, manager of the Virginia Employment Commission's office in Martinsville. "It's a bad situation. It truly is. It is getting worse and more frightening."
Helping qualified workers apply for benefits and look for jobs is taxing Ms. Snead's office. She said she had asked the state to add five more counselors to her 32. 
"Unless the economic development people can turn things around, it's going to become even more difficult than it is now," she said. "We have gone from having 350 jobs posted on a weekly basis six months ago to less than 100." 
To get any of those 100, candidates must often ratchet down their standard of living. 
At the State Employment Commission office in South Boston, Linda Miles, 24, separated mother of three children, said she lost her Burlington job in January. It paid $9.35 an hour. She searched the office's computer for new jobs, and made a list of three: phlebotomist, $6 an hour; general warehouse worker, $6.90; cashier, $6. 
Ms. Miles's estranged husband pays her rent, but she has no unemployment benefits to fall back on: she had not worked long enough and earned enough to qualify. She is unwilling to leave the area, and without a job here, her last resort is welfare. 
She is not alone. In Danville's welfare office, Frederic Fraley, the manager, said the decline in caseloads after the overhaul of the nation's welfare system six years ago had reversed as the number of layoffs rose. In January, he had 601 cases, up from 531 a year earlier. 
Betty Wells, manager of the welfare office in Halifax, said her welfare cases grew by 22 percent in the latter half of 2001, and her food stamp cases 21 percent.
"That doesn't include all that's coming," said Mrs. Wells, who has been touched personally by the plant closings. After 30 years at the Burlington plant in Halifax, where he earned more than $15 an hour as a mechanical planner, her 53-year-old husband was let go in January.
There are government-paid job-training programs, but workers with 20 or 30 years' grounding in a single industrial skill tend to resist. Ollie Spencer, a counselor in Ms. Snead's office, said: "They will say to us, 'I was a good worker. Someone will want to hire me.' We tell them, 'Sure, go ahead, but if you're interested in training, we'll help.' "
People can also move. But many were born and raised here, and leaving would mean shedding the emotional and financial support of family and friends. Some are rooted to the land. 
James M. Parrish Sr., 56, was a mechanic for seven years at the JPS plant, where he earned $13.65 an hour. "I've got a double-wide on 25 acres of land half-owned with my ex-wife," he said. He also has 10 cows and 15 registered coon hounds for hunting. 
He is going to Southside Virginia Community College to learn to fix computers, but he is not going to move. 
"I've got animals I have to feed," he said.

HEADLINE: McCall Campaign Won't Pay for Israel Trip 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller running for governor, returned from a three-day trip to Israel yesterday, called a news conference to recount his impressions of Israel, and held out the possibility that his campaign would pick up part of the cost of the trip, a visit that could enhance his candidacy among Jewish voters in New York.
 But barely an hour after he finished telling reporters about his trip, Mr. McCall's office rolled back and announced that the costs would, in fact, be paid almost entirely by the New York State pension fund and by State of Israel Bonds, an organization that promotes economic development in Israel. The McCall campaign, an aide said, would cover only the cost of bumping up the comptroller from coach to first class on his El Al flight. 
 The back-and-forth occurred on a day when Mr. McCall returned from his trip at 7 a.m. and, within seven hours, called a news conference at his Manhattan office -- with a telephone link-up to reporters across the state -- to discuss his observations and to recount his meetings with Israeli leaders, among them Ariel Sharon, the prime minister, and Shimon Peres, the foreign minister.
The state comptroller, who is battling Andrew M. Cuomo for the Democratic nomination to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki, asserted that in visiting Israel, he was acting as the chief custodian of the state's pension fund. Mr. McCall said he wanted to personally inspect the projects that had benefited from his investment of $68 million from the fund into State of Israel Bonds.
"I go, whether it's Buffalo or Hong Kong or wherever we have invested money," Mr. McCall said. "I did this on behalf of my role as the sole trustee of the pension fund. And it is my responsibility, if we are investing money in any particular area or region or project, it is important to see the results of these investments."
But Mr. McCall's itinerary included a stop by the Western Wall in Jerusalem, public appearances with Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn, who represents one of the most heavily Jewish districts in New York, and a visit to a Jewish settlement on the West Bank. The settlement, while including a number of Jews from New York, has not benefited from any expenditures of New York State pension funds, Mr. McCall said.
And he acknowledged that the trip might afford some political benefit to a candidate running for office in New York, where Jewish voters make up a large segment of Democratic primary voters. (His aides aggressively pushed for coverage of the trip in New York newspapers.)
And in response to a question, he seemed receptive, at least momentarily, to the notion that his campaign might pay at least some of the costs of the trip, during which he was accompanied by three aides. "Maybe we will," Mr. McCall said, adding: "I don't know. We'll get all the bills and see what they are. And maybe we'll do that. I just haven't decided."
The decision was reached quickly. Reporters returning to their desks yesterday afternoon were greeted with phone calls from Mr. McCall's press secretary saying there was no reason for campaign funds to pay for this trip.
"There was no campaigning involved," said Steven Greenberg, the press secretary. "The comptroller was there in his role as the sole custodian of the fund."
Mr. Greenberg said the cost of the trip would be divided, almost evenly, between the Common Retirement Fund, which is financed by the pension contributions of New York State workers, and State of Israel Bonds. Mr. Greenberg was unable to provide a cost estimate. He also said he did not know how much the campaign would have to pay to cover upgrading Mr. McCall's ticket.
Mr. McCall is hardly alone in taking an international trip that might provide domestic political benefits. Mr. Pataki has gone to Israel, Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, all at taxpayers' expense. Mr. Cuomo has gone to the Dominican Republic -- the former housing secretary is, at least temporarily, not on a government payroll, so his campaign paid most of that expense.
Although Mr. McCall said such overseas inspection trips were usual for him, his aides were unable to note another time when he had returned and immediately called a news conference to draw attention to his voyage. And in truth, Mr. McCall devoted nearly five days in travel to inspecting what amounts to a minuscule portion of the pension portfolio that he controls: just $68 million out of $112 billion.
Mr. Cuomo's campaign manager, Josh Isay, denounced Mr. McCall for using state money to pay for the trip, describing it as evidence of what was wrong in Albany. "We need to end business as usual," he said.
Mr. McCall asserted that his visit to the West Bank settlement was critical to help him appreciate the struggles of the country. "These are controversial, and a lot of people advised me not to go to the settlements," he said "But I thought it was important for me to go because I needed to understand the movement. Who were the people who were there? Why were they there?"
"It was good to let them know of my concern, and my solidarity with them -- most of them former New Yorkers, particularly from Brooklyn," he said.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Increase 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7 

 BODY:
Mortgage rates around the country climbed this week as investors, looking at evidence that a recovery has begun, raised the odds that the Federal Reserve might increase short-term interest rates later this year. 
 Freddie Mac, the mortgage company, reported that the average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages increased to 6.87 percent, from 6.80 the previous week, according to the company's nationwide survey released today. Fifteen-year mortgages, which are a popular option for refinancing, rose to 6.37 percent, up from 6.28 percent the week before. 
 On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.07 percent, up from 4.94 percent the previous week.
